description: Amazon Web Services (AWS) is a collection of cloud-based services offered by Amazon.com, which provides access to hosted resources. The services range from hosted virtual servers and storage to DNS and Database hosting. AWS gives the chance for private companies to take advantage of the investment in infrastructure that Amazon has made including massive generators, their five different internet service providers and data centers. This series of videos is designed to introduce the viewer to some of the AWS products and demonstrate the basic skills required to deploy and maintain them.
name: Amazon Web Services
subtitle: Web Services

episodes.title: Intro To Amazon Web Services
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:23,434 --> 00:00:33,562
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:33,562 --> 00:00:36,607
All right, good morning,
good afternoon and good evening and

3
00:00:36,607 --> 00:00:38,800
welcome back to another
episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:38,800 --> 00:00:41,040
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

5
00:00:41,040 --> 00:00:44,580
Coming at you today with
Amazon Web Services.

6
00:00:44,580 --> 00:00:47,030
Now this is our first episode for
Amazon Web Services, and

7
00:00:47,030 --> 00:00:51,290
what I wanted to do is take a minute
to do an overview of the whole service.

8
00:00:51,290 --> 00:00:54,090
What the product is, and
kinda give you an idea of

9
00:00:54,090 --> 00:00:57,440
some of the things that we're gonna
be covering in the upcoming episodes.

10
00:00:57,440 --> 00:01:01,120
There are many,
many people out there that leverage AWS.

11
00:01:01,120 --> 00:01:03,330
And for the people who don't use it,

12
00:01:03,330 --> 00:01:06,690
you might be looking at it and
saying man, I'm missing out on something?

13
00:01:06,690 --> 00:01:10,150
And the short answer is yes, you're
actually missing out on something cool.

14
00:01:10,150 --> 00:01:13,515
But there are other offerings out there
that you might choose to go with too.

15
00:01:13,515 --> 00:01:15,490
But Amazon is one of
the more popular ones.

16
00:01:15,490 --> 00:01:20,080
So let's talk about what it is, and
why they're as popular as they are, right.

17
00:01:20,080 --> 00:01:23,090
Well, the story kind of starts with
a little bit of history, right.

18
00:01:23,090 --> 00:01:27,190
We need to go back, I don't know,
maybe about ten years or so.

19
00:01:27,190 --> 00:01:31,620
Amazon was one of the few
online e-retailers

20
00:01:31,620 --> 00:01:35,710
to survive the dot com bubble
burst in 1999 and 2000, right.

21
00:01:35,710 --> 00:01:39,920
So there were a lot of e-retailers out
there and not many of them made it.

22
00:01:39,920 --> 00:01:43,710
You have companies like eBay and
PayPal, right, you have Amazon.

23
00:01:43,710 --> 00:01:45,380
Companies like that survive the storm and

24
00:01:45,380 --> 00:01:49,448
have grown to become these online
retailing juggernauts, all right.

25
00:01:49,448 --> 00:01:53,080
The last time I saw some financials out
of Amazon, they were showing where their

26
00:01:53,080 --> 00:01:57,620
company dealt with revenues in excess
of one million dollars per hour.

27
00:01:57,620 --> 00:02:00,978
That means they're handling
transactions from hundreds,

28
00:02:00,978 --> 00:02:04,679
thousands of people per hour to
generate those kinds of revenues.

29
00:02:04,679 --> 00:02:08,594
It's more than any other storefront
that's out there, it's really impressive,

30
00:02:08,594 --> 00:02:10,091
the amount of commerce they do.

31
00:02:10,091 --> 00:02:12,590
All right, so how does that matter to us?

32
00:02:12,590 --> 00:02:15,350
Well in order to support
that infrastructure,

33
00:02:15,350 --> 00:02:19,010
Amazon needed some of the highest
level redundancy possible.

34
00:02:19,010 --> 00:02:22,480
They also needed servers
that could handle the load.

35
00:02:22,480 --> 00:02:26,180
The hundreds of thousands of people that
hit their site within an hour period,

36
00:02:26,180 --> 00:02:29,930
not just counting the tens of thousands
of people that actually place an order.

37
00:02:29,930 --> 00:02:31,770
It takes a lot of
infrastructure to support that.

38
00:02:31,770 --> 00:02:35,210
And if you've ever worked in
a commercial data center,

39
00:02:35,210 --> 00:02:37,620
you'll know there's a lot
of equipment involved.

40
00:02:37,620 --> 00:02:42,040
You've got proper heating and air for
all of those servers, the racks.

41
00:02:42,040 --> 00:02:45,920
Just the management piece of keeping
thousands of servers up to date and

42
00:02:45,920 --> 00:02:46,820
operational.

43
00:02:46,820 --> 00:02:48,900
It's a huge maintenance cost.

44
00:02:48,900 --> 00:02:52,824
You start factoring things in
like security guards and cameras,

45
00:02:52,824 --> 00:02:57,190
redundant diesel generators,
multiple internet service providers.

46
00:02:57,190 --> 00:03:02,116
There is a huge burden to providing
a online shop 24 hours a day,

47
00:03:02,116 --> 00:03:04,775
seven days a week, all right.

48
00:03:04,775 --> 00:03:07,465
But Amazon does it because they have to.

49
00:03:07,465 --> 00:03:13,445
If their site goes offline, they will
lose over a million dollars per hour.

50
00:03:13,445 --> 00:03:17,455
So to spend tens of millions or hundreds
of millions of dollars on a state of

51
00:03:17,455 --> 00:03:20,630
the art data center for
them, it makes sense, right?

52
00:03:20,630 --> 00:03:21,735
And they've done it, they did that.

53
00:03:21,735 --> 00:03:24,100
They'd invested in all of
that infrastructure so

54
00:03:24,100 --> 00:03:26,790
that their storefront
would always be available.

55
00:03:26,790 --> 00:03:29,500
And over the last ten years,

56
00:03:29,500 --> 00:03:34,230
you can count the outages that
Amazon has had on one hand.

57
00:03:34,230 --> 00:03:38,350
And during each of those outages
the website was still functional,

58
00:03:38,350 --> 00:03:39,710
you could still place orders.

59
00:03:39,710 --> 00:03:44,230
It was various little components of
the site that had issues, but the primary

60
00:03:44,230 --> 00:03:48,710
functionality has been up and running for
over ten years without interruption.

61
00:03:48,710 --> 00:03:49,620
That's impressive.

62
00:03:49,620 --> 00:03:53,100
There are not many companies that can lay
claim to something like that, all right.

63
00:03:53,100 --> 00:03:56,711
Well what they found was, after they
got this infrastructure in place,

64
00:03:56,711 --> 00:03:59,266
that most of the time they didn't need it,
right?

65
00:03:59,266 --> 00:04:03,110
When they're not having a failure do
you need your redundant equipment?

66
00:04:03,110 --> 00:04:05,560
Most of the time they found their
equipment was just sitting there

67
00:04:05,560 --> 00:04:06,920
not being used.

68
00:04:06,920 --> 00:04:09,709
And so someone,
I'm not sure exactly who, but

69
00:04:09,709 --> 00:04:13,640
someone within the Amazon
executive team had an idea.

70
00:04:13,640 --> 00:04:18,536
And the idea was, what if we rent out some
of this extra stuff to other companies,

71
00:04:18,536 --> 00:04:22,140
companies that can't afford to
do all of this crazy stuff?

72
00:04:22,140 --> 00:04:26,217
Companies that can't afford to have these
massive generators and five different

73
00:04:26,217 --> 00:04:30,010
internet service providers, and
data centers in more than one continent.

74
00:04:30,010 --> 00:04:32,660
Right, I mean this is expensive stuff.

75
00:04:32,660 --> 00:04:34,090
And they said, what if we took that and

76
00:04:34,090 --> 00:04:38,000
rented it out to these other companies,
and now they can take advantage of it too?

77
00:04:38,000 --> 00:04:39,250
And on one hand,

78
00:04:39,250 --> 00:04:42,770
we have our redundant infrastructure
that keeps Amazon up and running.

79
00:04:42,770 --> 00:04:43,450
And on the other hand,

80
00:04:43,450 --> 00:04:47,670
we defray part of the cost by
renting it out to other people.

81
00:04:47,670 --> 00:04:50,500
And that's how
Amazon Web Services was born.

82
00:04:50,500 --> 00:04:54,830
It was a chance for private companies
to take advantage of the investment in

83
00:04:54,830 --> 00:04:57,070
infrastructure that Amazon had made.

84
00:04:57,070 --> 00:04:59,570
Companies like Amazon are interesting,

85
00:04:59,570 --> 00:05:02,120
because they provide an online service,
right?

86
00:05:02,120 --> 00:05:04,130
There is no physical storefront for
Amazon.

87
00:05:04,130 --> 00:05:07,390
You can't walk into the local Amazon store
and buy a roll of toilet paper, right?

88
00:05:07,390 --> 00:05:08,920
You've gotta go to their website and
buy it,

89
00:05:08,920 --> 00:05:13,580
and they deliver it, so having their
website available is essential.

90
00:05:13,580 --> 00:05:16,200
When the website's not available,
the store is closed.

91
00:05:16,200 --> 00:05:18,360
All right, so that's one aspect.

92
00:05:18,360 --> 00:05:20,830
The other aspect is, they're very dynamic.

93
00:05:20,830 --> 00:05:23,510
They have peaks and valleys of access.

94
00:05:23,510 --> 00:05:26,940
So right now, it is, what time is it?

95
00:05:26,940 --> 00:05:28,480
It's 10 AM, US Eastern.

96
00:05:28,480 --> 00:05:32,800
And it might be kind of slow
on Amazon's website right now.

97
00:05:32,800 --> 00:05:35,280
Well, slow here in the United States.

98
00:05:35,280 --> 00:05:38,780
In France, Amazon's website
might be hopping right now,

99
00:05:38,780 --> 00:05:40,720
because it's later in the day, right?

100
00:05:40,720 --> 00:05:42,460
It's 3PM in France right now.

101
00:05:42,460 --> 00:05:45,320
And so
things might be hopping along over there.

102
00:05:45,320 --> 00:05:50,460
So their servers here in the US
are probably not churning along as fast,

103
00:05:50,460 --> 00:05:54,330
or not handling as much as a workload,
as the ones that are in Europe right now.

104
00:05:54,330 --> 00:05:58,320
And the ones that are servicing Asia,
they're probably really slow right now,

105
00:05:58,320 --> 00:05:59,800
cuz it's the middle of the night.

106
00:05:59,800 --> 00:06:05,110
And so they've got these servers with
unused resources just because of the time.

107
00:06:05,110 --> 00:06:08,470
But when the time of the day
rolls around to noon or

108
00:06:08,470 --> 00:06:11,730
5 PM or whatever their peak time is,
they really ratchet it up.

109
00:06:11,730 --> 00:06:15,660
So there are times during the day
where they need a ton of servers, and

110
00:06:15,660 --> 00:06:19,540
other times during the day where they
only need a fraction of that, all right?

111
00:06:19,540 --> 00:06:23,520
And that means that they have a lot
of extra resources sitting around.

112
00:06:23,520 --> 00:06:25,920
And if they can rent that out,

113
00:06:25,920 --> 00:06:28,560
now they can start to make money on these
things that they paid for, all right.

114
00:06:28,560 --> 00:06:30,980
If you take a company like us, ITProTV.

115
00:06:30,980 --> 00:06:31,950
We're the same way.

116
00:06:31,950 --> 00:06:33,940
We have video streaming servers.

117
00:06:33,940 --> 00:06:38,876
And there are times, we find especially
Sundays, on Sundays, people sit down and

118
00:06:38,876 --> 00:06:40,721
watch our shows a lot, right?

119
00:06:40,721 --> 00:06:43,970
They're hitting our servers, hitting
bandwidth, and doing a lot of consumption.

120
00:06:43,970 --> 00:06:47,610
But we find Monday mornings, actually
right now, is a Monday morning, Monday

121
00:06:47,610 --> 00:06:51,860
morning is kind of our slack time, and
we have a fraction of our users on there.

122
00:06:51,860 --> 00:06:56,100
So the servers that we've invested
in aren't working very hard, and

123
00:06:56,100 --> 00:06:58,728
so we've paid for
hardware that we're not leveraging.

124
00:06:58,728 --> 00:07:03,600
Wouldn't it be be nice instead,
if we could rent those servers from

125
00:07:03,600 --> 00:07:07,060
somebody else and
only pay for what we used?

126
00:07:07,060 --> 00:07:10,940
So if we weren't using all of our server
load, we don't have to pay for it.

127
00:07:10,940 --> 00:07:12,940
We just paid for the portion we used.

128
00:07:12,940 --> 00:07:15,280
Well you can't do that when
you buy your own server.

129
00:07:15,280 --> 00:07:18,312
When you buy a server,
you pay for 100% of it, right?

130
00:07:18,312 --> 00:07:21,368
And you have it, and
you have 100% of its hardware to use.

131
00:07:21,368 --> 00:07:24,250
If you're not using it,
it just gets wasted.

132
00:07:24,250 --> 00:07:28,810
But in a shared environment, a cloud
environment like Amazon Web Services,

133
00:07:28,810 --> 00:07:31,850
when you're not using
the resources someone else can.

134
00:07:31,850 --> 00:07:35,500
And so they take advantage of 100% of
the hardware, and you only pay for

135
00:07:35,500 --> 00:07:36,820
what you use.

136
00:07:36,820 --> 00:07:40,750
Now Amazon was the company that
really led this initiative.

137
00:07:40,750 --> 00:07:44,776
You might be watching this and saying,
hey that's great Don, but I like

138
00:07:44,776 --> 00:07:49,674
Microsoft Azure, or, I like HP's cloud, or
I like the Google web services they have.

139
00:07:49,674 --> 00:07:53,311
I forget what theirs is called,
Google Hosted Apps, something or another.

140
00:07:53,311 --> 00:07:57,801
There are many different vendors that
provide it, Rackspace is another big one.

141
00:07:57,801 --> 00:08:00,259
They're actually a great
company to work with.

142
00:08:00,259 --> 00:08:03,340
So companies like that,
provide a similar service.

143
00:08:03,340 --> 00:08:05,253
All right.
So why go with Amazon,

144
00:08:05,253 --> 00:08:07,370
versus these other guys?

145
00:08:07,370 --> 00:08:10,200
Well, really they all provide
basically the same thing, right?

146
00:08:10,200 --> 00:08:13,780
They all provide access
to hosted resources.

147
00:08:13,780 --> 00:08:16,660
Hardware, in their
state-of-the-art data centers, so

148
00:08:16,660 --> 00:08:18,640
that you don't have to create
a data center yourself.

149
00:08:18,640 --> 00:08:21,650
And then, you get access to the hardware,
and what you do with it is up to you.

150
00:08:22,790 --> 00:08:25,860
The difference, is Amazon's volume.

151
00:08:25,860 --> 00:08:30,000
They were the first big player in
this market, and they've cornered it.

152
00:08:30,000 --> 00:08:32,820
They have the lion's share of
cloud services that are out

153
00:08:32,820 --> 00:08:33,820
there on the Internet.

154
00:08:33,820 --> 00:08:36,900
And, when you look at their systems,
it shows.

155
00:08:36,900 --> 00:08:40,140
They've got many data centers
spread across the globe.

156
00:08:40,140 --> 00:08:43,172
A lot of the other providers,
have less data centers.

157
00:08:43,172 --> 00:08:45,672
All right.
Like Windows Azure, they're still growing,

158
00:08:45,672 --> 00:08:49,670
and so I think they're eight data centers
now, whereas, Amazon is far above that.

159
00:08:49,670 --> 00:08:51,020
Let me show you what I mean.

160
00:08:51,020 --> 00:08:53,990
Amazon has a nice little web page,
that you can go, and check out,

161
00:08:53,990 --> 00:08:56,179
that talks about their
global infrastructure.

162
00:08:56,179 --> 00:08:59,114
And you can get a chance to see
where all of there data centers are.

163
00:08:59,114 --> 00:09:03,420
And so they're showing right here in
the United States, which is part of

164
00:09:03,420 --> 00:09:08,380
North America, that data centers
are spread right here across the US.

165
00:09:08,380 --> 00:09:10,240
They don't currently have any in Canada.

166
00:09:10,240 --> 00:09:12,530
Canada just serves off of the US ones.

167
00:09:12,530 --> 00:09:13,920
Same thing with Mexico.

168
00:09:13,920 --> 00:09:17,640
So, although it is North America, all the
data centers are actually in the US, and

169
00:09:17,640 --> 00:09:19,530
they break it up into four regions.

170
00:09:19,530 --> 00:09:23,895
So we've got this US East,
which is the North Virginia region, U.S.

171
00:09:23,895 --> 00:09:27,480
West which is Northern California,
U.S. West Oregon.

172
00:09:27,480 --> 00:09:30,598
So you've got Southwest and
Northwest, and then you've got,

173
00:09:30,598 --> 00:09:34,770
the government cloud, that's one that's
special just for you U.S. government.

174
00:09:35,870 --> 00:09:40,110
Inside of these regions,
they have multiple data centers.

175
00:09:40,110 --> 00:09:41,290
So notice this one right here.

176
00:09:41,290 --> 00:09:42,760
US east, north Virginia.

177
00:09:42,760 --> 00:09:44,200
This is their main data center.

178
00:09:44,200 --> 00:09:47,970
The one in northern Virginia,
which is this yellow dot right here.

179
00:09:47,970 --> 00:09:51,540
That's the primary one for
Amazon web services.

180
00:09:51,540 --> 00:09:53,580
All of the other data
centers were added later.

181
00:09:53,580 --> 00:09:55,500
These were the ones that were added first.

182
00:09:55,500 --> 00:09:58,990
And when it started,
it started as one data center.

183
00:09:58,990 --> 00:10:02,550
But they recognized early on, that
what if that data center goes offline?

184
00:10:02,550 --> 00:10:04,080
Everything in it goes offline.

185
00:10:04,080 --> 00:10:05,850
So they built a second data center.

186
00:10:05,850 --> 00:10:07,170
And where did they build it?

187
00:10:07,170 --> 00:10:08,310
Right next door.

188
00:10:08,310 --> 00:10:11,415
So we actually have, two data centers,
sitting right side by side.

189
00:10:11,415 --> 00:10:14,340
Now you might say to yourself, well,
that's not very redundant, is it?

190
00:10:14,340 --> 00:10:16,610
Well, it's redundant from some things.

191
00:10:16,610 --> 00:10:22,060
So if you have two different data centers,
pulling power from multiple power sources,

192
00:10:22,060 --> 00:10:25,210
with internet connections
from multiple ISPs, but

193
00:10:25,210 --> 00:10:27,800
operated completely independently.

194
00:10:27,800 --> 00:10:31,410
Separate IT staffs, separate servers,
separate infrastructures,

195
00:10:31,410 --> 00:10:33,080
separate everything.

196
00:10:33,080 --> 00:10:36,028
They're redundant for everything,
except for a natural disaster.

197
00:10:36,028 --> 00:10:38,789
If a hurricane, or an earthquake
were to hit one of those buildings,

198
00:10:38,789 --> 00:10:40,610
it would probably take
the other one out too.

199
00:10:40,610 --> 00:10:41,800
All right.

200
00:10:41,800 --> 00:10:46,142
So when you see this yellow dot,
the blue dots around it,

201
00:10:46,142 --> 00:10:48,326
those are the data centers.

202
00:10:48,326 --> 00:10:49,160
Okay.

203
00:10:49,160 --> 00:10:53,200
And you'll see that this one has,
five availability zones.

204
00:10:53,200 --> 00:10:53,720
All right.

205
00:10:53,720 --> 00:10:58,210
The five zones, that means there's
actually five, completely separate,

206
00:10:58,210 --> 00:11:00,100
independent data centers.

207
00:11:00,100 --> 00:11:02,610
If one of those data centers
were to go off line,

208
00:11:02,610 --> 00:11:05,430
the other four would still be up,
and operational.

209
00:11:05,430 --> 00:11:08,090
And of the few outages
that Amazon has had,

210
00:11:08,090 --> 00:11:12,480
they've always been isolated to
single data centers like that.

211
00:11:12,480 --> 00:11:16,416
So that's kinda nice, that they've
got five different data centers,

212
00:11:16,416 --> 00:11:17,648
in the US East region.

213
00:11:17,648 --> 00:11:18,530
All right.

214
00:11:18,530 --> 00:11:19,920
Notice that it launched in 2006.

215
00:11:19,920 --> 00:11:23,060
This was the earliest one,
which was nine years ago.

216
00:11:23,060 --> 00:11:24,940
Actually, wait, that's bad math.

217
00:11:24,940 --> 00:11:27,630
So it was about, it was about
nine years ago, that it launched.

218
00:11:27,630 --> 00:11:31,230
You'll see the other ones
have launched since then.

219
00:11:31,230 --> 00:11:32,530
US West launched in 2009.

220
00:11:32,530 --> 00:11:36,462
Three years later, they built a data
center out here, in Northern California.

221
00:11:36,462 --> 00:11:37,440
All right.

222
00:11:37,440 --> 00:11:41,630
And so that was built, brought up, and an
online, so that if an East coast natural

223
00:11:41,630 --> 00:11:45,040
disaster happened, they have servers
on the West Coast, that can take over,

224
00:11:45,040 --> 00:11:47,460
and then they just
branched out from there.

225
00:11:47,460 --> 00:11:50,724
You've got three zones in northern
California, you've got three zones in

226
00:11:50,724 --> 00:11:54,196
Oregon now, which is up here, and there's

00:23:17,060 --> 00:23:20,210
when you guys download them,
you're clicking a link on our site that's

458
00:23:20,210 --> 00:23:25,130
actually linking to a storage bucket in
Amazon S3 and pulling the file from there.

459
00:23:25,130 --> 00:23:29,590
If all of our users start downloading
at once, S3 can handle it.

460
00:23:29,590 --> 00:23:33,450
But if it's just a user every here and
there downloading, it can handle that too.

461
00:23:33,450 --> 00:23:35,620
And we just pay for
the bandwidth that you guys consume.

462
00:23:35,620 --> 00:23:38,040
Every time you download a video from us,
it costs us some money,

463
00:23:38,040 --> 00:23:40,425
but that's part of the subscription fee.

464
00:23:40,425 --> 00:23:42,855
That's how we generate revenue.

465
00:23:44,265 --> 00:23:45,614
S3 makes that easy.

466
00:23:45,614 --> 00:23:49,036
The other cool part about S3 is when you
copy a file up to it, you can choose to

467
00:23:49,036 --> 00:23:52,730
have it replicated to data centers around
the world, so that when people download

468
00:23:52,730 --> 00:23:56,504
the file, they're downloading it from
somewhere geographically close to them.

469
00:23:56,504 --> 00:23:59,287
Which is usually gonna result
in faster download times.

470
00:23:59,287 --> 00:24:00,323
I say usually.

471
00:24:00,323 --> 00:24:02,067
S3 has some really good bandwidth, but

472
00:24:02,067 --> 00:24:04,683
if your end users have crummy bandwidth,
it doesn't matter

473
00:24:04,683 --> 00:24:08,110
where the file's coming from it's
gonna take a long time to download.

474
00:24:08,110 --> 00:24:10,090
So, you know, it can't work magic, but

475
00:24:10,090 --> 00:24:12,670
it can definitely give you the resources
to make those files available.

476
00:24:14,410 --> 00:24:17,060
All right, the next one is RDS.

477
00:24:17,060 --> 00:24:21,330
RDS is the Relational Database Service and
let me see if I can find that in here.

478
00:24:21,330 --> 00:24:22,600
It'll be down under databases.

479
00:24:22,600 --> 00:24:23,690
There it is, RDS.

480
00:24:25,450 --> 00:24:28,610
If you need a database,
which almost everybody does.

481
00:24:28,610 --> 00:24:31,270
Every website, if you have WordPress or
Drupal or Joomla.

482
00:24:31,270 --> 00:24:35,280
If you have, you know, SharePoint,
just about any website.

483
00:24:35,280 --> 00:24:38,890
But even non-websites, point of sales
systems, all sorts of stuff like that.

484
00:24:38,890 --> 00:24:41,110
You need a database to store your data.

485
00:24:41,110 --> 00:24:47,040
Well, you could go up to EC2, and spin up
a server, and load MySQL on it, right?

486
00:24:47,040 --> 00:24:47,730
Plenty of people do.

487
00:24:47,730 --> 00:24:49,930
You could manage your
own server right there.

488
00:24:49,930 --> 00:24:53,120
But you'd be doing exactly what I
just said, managing your own server.

489
00:24:53,120 --> 00:24:55,320
You'd have to apply updates
Updates to the underlying OS.

490
00:24:56,320 --> 00:25:00,390
You'd have to apply updates to MySQL,
you'd have to manage it's security.

491
00:25:00,390 --> 00:25:02,510
Any time an update came out
it might break something,

492
00:25:02,510 --> 00:25:04,720
you'd have to manage the backup
to be able to do restores.

493
00:25:04,720 --> 00:25:07,850
So there's a lot of
work involved with RDS.

494
00:25:07,850 --> 00:25:11,720
Well, you might not be a MySQL expert.

495
00:25:11,720 --> 00:25:14,970
Your company might not have
an SQL expert on staff.

496
00:25:14,970 --> 00:25:20,070
So instead, you can say, you know what,
let me leverage Amazon's staff.

497
00:25:20,070 --> 00:25:22,200
Amazon has some amazing
database engineers and

498
00:25:22,200 --> 00:25:25,500
some of the best database
engineers in the world, right?

499
00:25:25,500 --> 00:25:27,440
They've got them because their
database is massive, and

500
00:25:27,440 --> 00:25:30,620
they have tons of customers
querying it throughout the day.

501
00:25:30,620 --> 00:25:34,200
With RDS you choose to create a database,
but

502
00:25:34,200 --> 00:25:39,070
you don't manage the underlying server or
even the database engine itself.

503
00:25:39,070 --> 00:25:44,090
And you can pick from multiple engines,
they do MySQL, Microsoft SQL, Oracle.

504
00:25:44,090 --> 00:25:47,080
So you can actually pick from
these different database types and

505
00:25:47,080 --> 00:25:48,610
it will host on their servers.

506
00:25:48,610 --> 00:25:52,380
Servers that they manage,
they update, they backup.

507
00:25:52,380 --> 00:25:55,240
You just put your data in there,
and query your data, right?

508
00:25:55,240 --> 00:25:59,020
So it takes the back-end
side off of your plate, and

509
00:25:59,020 --> 00:26:03,220
lets you focus on the data side, which
is what you really need to work with.

510
00:26:03,220 --> 00:26:06,000
So RDS, really cool feature there.

511
00:26:06,000 --> 00:26:10,210
They do charge a bit extra for it than if
you just brought up your own server and

512
00:26:10,210 --> 00:26:14,280
that extra they charge, it's not much,
but that extra that they charge Is for

513
00:26:14,280 --> 00:26:15,360
the management piece.

514
00:26:15,360 --> 00:26:18,820
Their management of your databases and
believe me it's worth it.

515
00:26:18,820 --> 00:26:22,630
Even if you are a database expert it's
nice to have a second set of eyes watching

516
00:26:22,630 --> 00:26:23,530
your system.

517
00:26:23,530 --> 00:26:26,470
Just because it's in RDS doesn't mean
you can't get in there and tweak things.

518
00:26:26,470 --> 00:26:30,720
You can, but it's nice to have that
second team just taking care of it so

519
00:26:30,720 --> 00:26:31,670
you don't have to worry about it.

520
00:26:33,890 --> 00:26:37,140
All right, the fourth primary service
they have is called Cloud Front.

521
00:26:37,140 --> 00:26:40,090
And Cloud Front's kinda weird cuz
you'll see it here under storage and

522
00:26:40,090 --> 00:26:40,880
content delivery.

523
00:26:40,880 --> 00:26:43,560
And then you'll see other
pieces of it over here.

524
00:26:43,560 --> 00:26:46,680
Cloud Formation, Cloud Trail, Cloud Watch.

525
00:26:46,680 --> 00:26:48,090
What is Cloud Front?

526
00:26:48,090 --> 00:26:50,920
Well, if you're doing streaming video,
like we are.

527
00:26:50,920 --> 00:26:55,060
Streaming video is very
bandwidth intensive and latency.

528
00:26:55,060 --> 00:26:59,180
You don't want your end users to have
buffering video and stuttering and so on.

529
00:26:59,180 --> 00:27:03,980
So, with CloudFront, Amazon makes it
where you upload your video to one place.

530
00:27:03,980 --> 00:27:08,020
And when you upload CloudFront
will replicate it out to servers

531
00:27:08,020 --> 00:27:12,730
around the world so that your end users
can view it from a server close to them.

532
00:27:12,730 --> 00:27:15,230
So it's hosted video streaming.

533
00:27:15,230 --> 00:27:19,200
And it can do live as well as video
on demand, like recorded videos and

534
00:27:19,200 --> 00:27:20,230
provide that out there.

535
00:27:20,230 --> 00:27:24,370
Video streaming is the number one consumer
of bandwidth out there on the internet.

536
00:27:24,370 --> 00:27:28,290
Like Netflix and
Amazon Prime videos where they consume

537
00:27:28,290 --> 00:27:33,350
a huge portion of the internet's
traffic So doing it optimally is key.

538
00:27:33,350 --> 00:27:35,090
And it's really challenging to do that.

539
00:27:35,090 --> 00:27:36,840
With CloudFront,
they make it a lot easier.

540
00:27:36,840 --> 00:27:39,480
All right, so
those are the big four services.

541
00:27:39,480 --> 00:27:40,860
That was EC2, S3, RDS, and CloudFront.

542
00:27:40,860 --> 00:27:44,710
Those are what most people are gonna use,
right?

543
00:27:45,920 --> 00:27:49,970
But as you use those, you're gonna find
that you reach into some of the other

544
00:27:49,970 --> 00:27:51,902
services too to achieve various things.

545
00:27:51,902 --> 00:27:56,220
All right, so let me just kinda do a quick
run down on some of the other services

546
00:27:56,220 --> 00:27:58,790
you'll encounter as you start
to work today, all ight.

547
00:27:58,790 --> 00:28:00,540
Next one is VPC right.

548
00:28:00,540 --> 00:28:02,530
VPC is virtual private cloud.

549
00:28:02,530 --> 00:28:06,320
When you bring a server up in EC2
you might want it to be public for

550
00:28:06,320 --> 00:28:09,140
the whole world to see and
that's the default.

551
00:28:09,140 --> 00:28:13,420
But with VPC,
you can create isolated networks in EC2,

552
00:28:13,420 --> 00:28:17,420
so that your servers are not public but
private, right?

553
00:28:17,420 --> 00:28:20,980
If you're putting database server up there
for managing your timeclock or something,

554
00:28:20,980 --> 00:28:21,830
you don't want that to be public,

555
00:28:21,830 --> 00:28:24,460
you don't want the hold world to hit that,
you want that to be private.

556
00:28:24,460 --> 00:28:25,580
You're putting it in the cloud for

557
00:28:25,580 --> 00:28:28,780
redundancy, not to make it
available to the world.

558
00:28:28,780 --> 00:28:32,150
So you can use VPC to
create a private network.

559
00:28:32,150 --> 00:28:35,980
Once you've created that private network
you can combine that with Direct Connect.

560
00:28:35,980 --> 00:28:40,630
Direct Connect is basically a VPN service
where you can have your local site build

561
00:28:40,630 --> 00:28:44,980
a VPN tunnel to your VPC and
then you'll have access to those servers.

562
00:28:44,980 --> 00:28:48,480
All encrypted and
secured across the Internet, right?

563
00:28:48,480 --> 00:28:55,500
So that's another service that we'll bump
into Route 53 is our hosted DNS server.

564
00:28:55,500 --> 00:29:00,493
If you have a DNS zone, you can go out and
buy a name ITpro.tv or ITpro.net or

565
00:29:00,493 --> 00:29:01,750
whatever.

566
00:29:01,750 --> 00:29:03,790
You have to host that DNS name somewhere.

567
00:29:03,790 --> 00:29:05,420
Why not host it in route 53?

568
00:29:05,420 --> 00:29:08,370
When you host your DNS with Amazon,
you get their fully redundant

569
00:29:08,370 --> 00:29:12,180
DNS infrastructure but
you also get some special abilities.

570
00:29:12,180 --> 00:29:15,750
Your service might have dynamic
IP addresses that change.

571
00:29:15,750 --> 00:29:19,060
Route 53 will handle that or
your service might have static IPs.

572
00:29:19,060 --> 00:29:21,680
That's fine, route 53 won't need
to do anything special there.

573
00:29:21,680 --> 00:29:23,930
So you might choose to
use your own DNS servers.

574
00:29:23,930 --> 00:29:26,540
But if you're doing dynamic stuff,
like dynamic scaling,

575
00:29:26,540 --> 00:29:29,728
you'll almost always want to use
Route 53 to host your DNS name.

576
00:29:29,728 --> 00:29:32,190
All right, IAM.

577
00:29:32,190 --> 00:29:36,680
IAM, this guy right here is identity and
access management.

578
00:29:36,680 --> 00:29:40,290
If you're a one person shop,
if you're the only IT guy for

579
00:29:40,290 --> 00:29:42,120
your company you probably don't
care about IAM very much.

580
00:29:42,120 --> 00:29:45,270
You signed up for an account,
you got user account.

581
00:29:45,270 --> 00:29:46,960
You log in, you manage your servers.

582
00:29:46,960 --> 00:29:48,390
But if you have an IT department.

583
00:29:48,390 --> 00:29:51,580
If you have multiple members
of staff on your team or

584
00:29:51,580 --> 00:29:54,890
you have multiple applications
that you want to have different

585
00:29:54,890 --> 00:29:57,870
access to the data that you've stored
inside of AWS, you'll use IAM.

586
00:29:57,870 --> 00:30:01,030
This is where you create your
security credentials, and

587
00:30:01,030 --> 00:30:03,740
you dictate who is allowed to access what.

588
00:30:05,370 --> 00:30:08,140
There's a new service called workspaces.

589
00:30:08,140 --> 00:30:11,580
Workspaces is where you can
host a desktop in the cloud.

590
00:30:11,580 --> 00:30:14,770
If you're a traveling employee
that doesn't have a laptop or

591
00:30:14,770 --> 00:30:18,830
desktop that you carry with you, you might
want to have Of your desktop in the Cloud.

592
00:30:18,830 --> 00:30:21,750
So you can run a work station
system Linux or Windows.

593
00:30:21,750 --> 00:30:25,070
If it's Windows it can actually have
Microsoft Office pre-installed on it and

594
00:30:25,070 --> 00:30:26,170
it's right there in the Cloud.

595
00:30:26,170 --> 00:30:29,110
You can access it from anywhere in
the world by browsing to a website

596
00:30:29,110 --> 00:30:30,060
and logging in.

597
00:30:30,060 --> 00:30:31,450
It's a pretty neat one.

598
00:30:31,450 --> 00:30:35,530
I find that I'll usually work spaces
to create a management machine

599
00:30:35,530 --> 00:30:38,010
that I'll use to Amazon web services.

600
00:30:38,010 --> 00:30:42,110
That way I'm not logging into AWS right
here on my laptop which might get stolen.

601
00:30:42,110 --> 00:30:44,770
I'm logging into AWS from a laptop or
desktop or

602
00:30:44,770 --> 00:30:49,730
whatever that's in the cloud that
is separate from my own machine.

603
00:30:49,730 --> 00:30:51,620
And then lastly another
one that is kind of cool,

604
00:30:51,620 --> 00:30:54,070
let me see if I can find it in
here is the elastic transcoder.

605
00:30:54,070 --> 00:30:57,555
It is right here,
Elastic transcoder, this guy.

606
00:30:57,555 --> 00:31:00,010
I mentioned video streaming.

607
00:31:00,010 --> 00:31:02,140
When you upload a video and
stream it across the world,

608
00:31:02,140 --> 00:31:03,850
it sounds pretty easy, right?

609
00:31:03,850 --> 00:31:08,580
But unfortunately there's people
on Windows machines, Macs, Linux.

610
00:31:08,580 --> 00:31:11,390
There's people on iPhones and
Android phones and

611
00:31:11,390 --> 00:31:13,900
all sorts of different
devices that are out there.

612
00:31:13,900 --> 00:31:16,310
So people have different needs for
the video.

613
00:31:16,310 --> 00:31:20,620
There is no one video format that works
on everything believe me, we know.

614
00:31:20,620 --> 00:31:24,200
ITPro TV has been through a lot of
video growing pains over the years.

615
00:31:24,200 --> 00:31:26,280
So there is no one solution so
what do you do.

616
00:31:26,280 --> 00:31:28,650
Well, Elastic Transcoder
takes care of that.

617
00:31:28,650 --> 00:31:31,490
You can send up a video in one format and

618
00:31:31,490 --> 00:31:35,020
it will reincode it using
Amazon's processors.

619
00:31:35,020 --> 00:31:38,340
They've got millions of processors
available so they will,

620
00:31:38,340 --> 00:31:40,415
well may be not millions,
definitely hundreds of thousands though.

621
00:31:40,415 --> 00:31:42,780
[LAUGH] It will process and

622
00:31:42,780 --> 00:31:45,370
transfer that video way faster
than you could on your end.

623
00:31:45,370 --> 00:31:46,860
You're not tying up your machine.

624
00:31:46,860 --> 00:31:50,950
You send up a video in one format and then
they produce as many different formats as

625
00:31:50,950 --> 00:31:53,630
you need to meet the needs
of your customers.

626
00:31:53,630 --> 00:31:59,040
Again, less infrastructure on
your end using theirs on demand.

627
00:31:59,040 --> 00:32:03,960
I think that's a pretty good overview
right there of what Amazon web services

628
00:32:03,960 --> 00:32:06,600
is and what some of the things
are that it provides,

629
00:32:06,600 --> 00:32:08,780
the different ways that we can use them.

630
00:32:08,780 --> 00:32:10,730
So throughout the whole
rest of this series,

631
00:32:10,730 --> 00:32:13,560
what we're gonna be doing is
taking each of those components.

632
00:32:13,560 --> 00:32:18,140
And I'll show you how they work, how you
can use them, how we can create servers or

633
00:32:18,140 --> 00:32:22,480
put files up there, how we can work with
those different technologies to make them,

634
00:32:22,480 --> 00:32:23,970
well, to make them work for us.

635
00:32:23,970 --> 00:32:25,760
And hopefully to save you money.

636
00:32:25,760 --> 00:32:28,740
While giving you a better
infrastructure in the process, right?

637
00:32:28,740 --> 00:32:30,230
That's really what this is all about.

638
00:32:31,830 --> 00:32:34,510
All right, well that's a pretty
good spot for us to stop.

639
00:32:34,510 --> 00:32:38,350
Stay tuned because we've got more
Amazon web services coming up next.

episodes.title: Understanding AWS Pricing
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:08,421
[SOUND].

2
00:00:08,421 --> 00:00:11,897
In this segment we're gonna take a look
at the pricing structure built around

3
00:00:11,897 --> 00:00:13,600
Amazon Web Services.

4
00:00:13,600 --> 00:00:14,860
Before you get started with AWS,

5
00:00:14,860 --> 00:00:18,560
you're probably asking yourself [LAUGH]
how much is this going to cost?

6
00:00:18,560 --> 00:00:20,630
And it's a fair question.

7
00:00:20,630 --> 00:00:23,450
AWS pricing Is a little bit confusing.

8
00:00:23,450 --> 00:00:27,320
Confusing enough that I went ahead and
made a segment to address it.

9
00:00:27,320 --> 00:00:30,750
Having an understanding of how
much AWS is gonna cost is really

10
00:00:30,750 --> 00:00:34,590
difficult because it's
built upon what you use.

11
00:00:34,590 --> 00:00:38,960
One of the nice features of AWS
is that you pay for what you use,

12
00:00:38,960 --> 00:00:43,690
not what you thought you might use or
whatever, but what you actually use.

13
00:00:43,690 --> 00:00:47,210
So if you use the service a lot,
yeah, you'll get a big bill.

14
00:00:47,210 --> 00:00:51,480
But if you don't use the service at all,
then your bill will be very small, or

15
00:00:51,480 --> 00:00:53,040
maybe even zero.

16
00:00:53,040 --> 00:00:58,010
Amazon does have some free usage tiers,
which are designed for people like you,

17
00:00:58,010 --> 00:00:59,530
that are learning AWS.

18
00:00:59,530 --> 00:01:00,970
You can sign up for free.

19
00:01:00,970 --> 00:01:03,710
You can run a few servers,
put some storage up there, and

20
00:01:03,710 --> 00:01:05,780
they won't charge you a dime.

21
00:01:05,780 --> 00:01:07,920
And they usually give you
a year of that access,

22
00:01:07,920 --> 00:01:12,660
so plenty of time to learn and practice
and experiment with the technology.

23
00:01:12,660 --> 00:01:15,050
But if you're gonna be using this
in a production environment,

24
00:01:15,050 --> 00:01:17,730
you'll exceed those free
usage tiers pretty quickly.

25
00:01:17,730 --> 00:01:21,190
And you need to have an understanding
of what your costs are gonna be so

26
00:01:21,190 --> 00:01:22,860
you can plan your budget.

27
00:01:22,860 --> 00:01:25,203
You don't want to go into AWS blind and
just say,

28
00:01:25,203 --> 00:01:27,930
I'm gonna deploy a bunch of stuff, and
then all the sudden you start getting

29
00:01:27,930 --> 00:01:31,530
bills that are well beyond
what you expected them to be.

30
00:01:31,530 --> 00:01:34,810
So I just want to take a look at some of
the different ways that we incur cost.

31
00:01:34,810 --> 00:01:39,540
Now, there are a lot of different
services inside of AWS.

32
00:01:39,540 --> 00:01:42,180
And each one has their own pricing and

33
00:01:42,180 --> 00:01:44,410
billing structure that's
a little bit different.

34
00:01:44,410 --> 00:01:48,960
So I'm gonna look at some of the primary
ones and then we'll kind of go from there.

35
00:01:48,960 --> 00:01:52,140
But just understand that if you're using
some of the specialized services that

36
00:01:52,140 --> 00:01:54,360
there's additional costs there.

37
00:01:54,360 --> 00:01:57,220
All right, let's start with storage.

38
00:01:57,220 --> 00:02:01,820
Storage is one of the unavoidable things
inside of any kind of hosted web service.

39
00:02:01,820 --> 00:02:04,800
So it really doesn't matter
which pieces of AWS you use,

40
00:02:04,800 --> 00:02:08,690
they almost all require
storage of some sort.

41
00:02:08,690 --> 00:02:10,610
And the number one place
to store your storage,

42
00:02:10,610 --> 00:02:12,920
which is a pretty dumb sentence
now that I think about it.

43
00:02:12,920 --> 00:02:16,775
But anyhow [LAUGH] the number one place
to put your stuff is Amazon S3, right,

44
00:02:16,775 --> 00:02:18,600
the Simple Storage Service.

Looks like we got some kind of an error.

232
00:11:26,260 --> 00:11:27,390
But it's still letting me get through.

233
00:11:27,390 --> 00:11:28,880
So I'll try and push through.

234
00:11:28,880 --> 00:11:31,810
Says there was an error
processing my request but

235
00:11:31,810 --> 00:11:33,330
we'll see if that actually interferes.

236
00:11:33,330 --> 00:11:34,020
All right.
So I'll go in and

237
00:11:34,020 --> 00:11:35,360
start to punch in my name.

238
00:11:35,360 --> 00:11:37,180
You know, my company.

239
00:11:37,180 --> 00:11:38,780
I work for EdutainmentLIVE.

240
00:11:38,780 --> 00:11:41,000
My country is the United States.

241
00:11:41,000 --> 00:11:44,570
And we'll just fill all this,
nothing too special here.

242
00:11:44,570 --> 00:11:47,240
They need this information on you because
they are going to be billing, right?

243
00:11:47,240 --> 00:11:49,290
So they've got to be
able to track all that.

244
00:11:49,290 --> 00:11:54,300
And report it back, so
we'll just feed them the information.

245
00:11:54,300 --> 00:11:56,760
I'm using an incognito window here, and

246
00:11:56,760 --> 00:12:01,880
the main reason I'm doing that is because
I do have production amazon accounts in

247
00:12:01,880 --> 00:12:05,710
my main web browser, and I don't want
any of my credentials to pass over.

248
00:12:05,710 --> 00:12:10,340
Incognito mode is a great way to separate
out accounts to ensure that you don't get

249
00:12:10,340 --> 00:12:10,870
crossover.

250
00:12:10,870 --> 00:12:14,650
I would hate to accidentally do something
on my production Amazon account when I'm

251
00:12:14,650 --> 00:12:16,360
here in my demo account.

252
00:12:16,360 --> 00:12:18,730
In Google Chrome, it's called incognito.

253
00:12:18,730 --> 00:12:21,190
In Internet Explorer,
it's called InPrivate.

254
00:12:21,190 --> 00:12:25,940
In Firefox, it's called, oh shoot, I've
forgotten what it's called in Firefox.

255
00:12:25,940 --> 00:12:29,490
Well, anyhow, they all have this kind
of privacy mode you can go into, so.

256
00:12:31,950 --> 00:12:34,190
So we'll just punch this information in,
and

257
00:12:34,190 --> 00:12:36,750
I've got to give it my
office phone number here.

258
00:12:36,750 --> 00:12:39,190
And I've got to pass the CAPTCHA.

259
00:12:39,190 --> 00:12:40,290
So we'll do that.

260
00:12:40,290 --> 00:12:43,720
This is all the fun stuff you guys hate
when you sign up for webpages, but

261
00:12:43,720 --> 00:12:45,210
you understand why they do it, right?

262
00:12:45,210 --> 00:12:48,110
They've got to make sure
that bots aren't happening.

263
00:12:48,110 --> 00:12:50,770
If you could automate this process,
you could spend up millions of

264
00:12:50,770 --> 00:12:54,010
micro instances and
really get some processor power out of it.

265
00:12:54,010 --> 00:12:55,350
So that's what they're trying to prevent.

266
00:12:56,440 --> 00:12:58,770
All right, so I'll go ahead and
create that account.

267
00:12:58,770 --> 00:12:59,880
It shouldn't be too much.

268
00:12:59,880 --> 00:13:02,200
It might do some account verification,
and we'll see.

269
00:13:02,200 --> 00:13:05,870
But once we've got it, your free usage
tier starts right away, all right?

270
00:13:05,870 --> 00:13:08,960
So my free usage tier for
this account started right now.

271
00:13:08,960 --> 00:13:11,080
And I have got twelve months
to take advantage of that.

272
00:13:11,080 --> 00:13:13,710
And if I go above it,
I am going to get billed.

273
00:13:13,710 --> 00:13:15,970
So I do need to provide
some billing information,

274
00:13:15,970 --> 00:13:17,760
you will put a credit card on file.

275
00:13:17,760 --> 00:13:20,080
The credit card is the preferred
method of payment.

276
00:13:20,080 --> 00:13:23,260
They do have other ways, like they can
draft right out of your bank account and

277
00:13:23,260 --> 00:13:26,960
so on if you want to go that route,
but credit card is the most common.

278
00:13:28,270 --> 00:13:32,760
Once that's set up, you'll now be able
to go to the Amazon Web Services and

279
00:13:32,760 --> 00:13:35,750
get logged in and
you'll be able to start spinning stuff up.

280
00:13:35,750 --> 00:13:38,120
So you'll be ready to jump
to our other segments.

281
00:13:38,120 --> 00:13:42,284
We start showing how to configure
each of the different instances.

282
00:13:42,284 --> 00:13:45,708
For the free tier, there's nothing
else we need to do, it's activated and

283
00:13:45,708 --> 00:13:47,056
we start to spin up our stuff.

284
00:13:47,056 --> 00:13:50,591
But it's up to us to use restraint to make
sure we stay within our free tier and

285
00:13:50,591 --> 00:13:52,870
don't incur any extra billing.

286
00:13:52,870 --> 00:13:54,680
Alright, well I'm not going to wait for
this form to finish.

287
00:13:54,680 --> 00:13:56,100
We'll just stop here.

288
00:13:56,100 --> 00:13:59,870
Make sure you check back in though because
we're going to have more segments as we go

289
00:13:59,870 --> 00:14:03,830
into all of the individual AWS
services and get them configured.

290
00:14:03,830 --> 00:14:05,720
So, I hope you guys enjoyed the segment.

291
00:14:05,720 --> 00:14:06,410
I'll see you next time.

episodes.title: Getting Started With EC2
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,025 --> 00:00:05,056
[SOUND] In this segment we're gonna take

2
00:00:05,056 --> 00:00:10,544
a look at the EC2 administration panel and

3
00:00:10,544 --> 00:00:16,040
kind of our first overview of the service.

4
00:00:16,040 --> 00:00:20,137
The first time that you log into your
AWS console and you jump into EC2,

5
00:00:20,137 --> 00:00:22,450
it can be a little overwhelming.

6
00:00:22,450 --> 00:00:24,240
So we're gonna just kinda wade in and

7
00:00:24,240 --> 00:00:27,930
take a look at the user interface and
what's really being presented to us.

8
00:00:27,930 --> 00:00:29,880
So I've logged in with
my demo account here.

9
00:00:29,880 --> 00:00:31,510
I'm logged into AWS.

10
00:00:31,510 --> 00:00:34,730
And the first time you log in you'll
be presented with your AWS console,

11
00:00:34,730 --> 00:00:39,480
which is really just a list of
all the services from Amazon.

12
00:00:39,480 --> 00:00:43,820
And the one I want is EC2 so I'm gonna
choose EC2 right there out of my list.

13
00:00:43,820 --> 00:00:46,800
Now, if EC2 is the only thing you're
gonna be using and you're not gonna use

14
00:00:46,800 --> 00:00:50,410
any of these other services, one of
the things I like to do is way down here,

15
00:00:50,410 --> 00:00:53,000
at the bottom right,
you've got Set Start Page.

16
00:00:53,000 --> 00:00:57,380
And you can change that to default
to any one of the various services.

17
00:00:57,380 --> 00:00:59,200
So I can actually have
it default to EC2 so

18
00:00:59,200 --> 00:01:03,380
in the future when I log in,
it'll just go straight to the EC2 panel.

19
00:01:03,380 --> 00:01:06,190
You can still get back to this
console home if you want, but

20
00:01:06,190 --> 00:01:07,640
it'll take you right there.

21
00:01:07,640 --> 00:01:09,440
For me, that's what I normally want.

22
00:01:09,440 --> 00:01:12,690
EC2 is what I work with
the most inside of AWS.

23
00:01:12,690 --> 00:01:14,180
The other services are important too,

24
00:01:14,180 --> 00:01:17,120
but most of the other services we set and
forget.

25
00:01:17,120 --> 00:01:18,760
You just turn them on and that's it.

26
00:01:18,760 --> 00:01:20,630
But EC2 we're constantly interacting with.

27
00:01:20,630 --> 00:01:22,350
So you can change that behavior,
if you want.

28
00:01:23,430 --> 00:01:24,318
But I'm gonna go into EC2.

29
00:01:24,318 --> 00:01:28,265
And what we're looking at here
is the EC2 administrative panel.

30
00:01:28,265 --> 00:01:30,690
It's a little bit overwhelming, right?

31
00:01:30,690 --> 00:01:33,870
It's all text based,
the only image is the one button, and

32
00:01:33,870 --> 00:01:37,080
the rest of it is just a ton of
text that's being thrown at us.

33
00:01:37,080 --> 00:01:39,760
So let's talk a little bit about
what's here on the screen and

34
00:01:39,760 --> 00:01:41,560
what we're really dealing with.

35
00:01:41,560 --> 00:01:43,340
On the left side is our navigation tree,

36
00:01:43,340 --> 00:01:47,430
and this is what we're gonna use to
get to the specific areas we need.

37
00:01:47,430 --> 00:01:50,760
The reason this first screen is so
overwhelming is that it's an overview.

38
00:01:50,760 --> 00:01:53,370
It's trying to give us a little
bit of information from

39
00:01:53,370 --> 00:01:57,450
all of these areas over here,
and that can be a bit burdensome.

40
00:01:57,450 --> 00:01:59,060
It can be quite a bit.

41
00:01:59,060 --> 00:02:02,840
And every now and then, you'll get little
messages like this one which are informing

42
00:02:02,840 --> 00:02:05,920
you about some new service, and
you may or may not need that.

43
00:02:05,920 --> 00:02:09,270
This one here is saying I could easily
deploy my web applications with

44
00:02:09,270 --> 00:02:10,240
Elastic Beanstalk.

45
00:02:10,240 --> 00:02:11,900
I should learn about that.

46
00:02:11,900 --> 00:02:15,970
But if you just hide that it goes away, so
it's a little less clutter on the screen.

47
00:02:15,970 --> 00:02:18,420
You'll see things like that
pop up from time to time.

48
00:02:18,420 --> 00:02:22,900
But in the summary right here I can
see what services I'm using right now.

49
00:02:22,900 --> 00:02:26,800
If you just brought up a brand new
account, you'll see mostly zeroes.

50
00:02:26,800 --> 00:02:29,430
The only one that won't be
zeroed is a security group.

51
00:02:29,430 --> 00:02:33,290
The security group is how we control
who's allowed to access what resources.

52
00:02:33,290 --> 00:02:38,020
And when you sign up for an account,
Amazon creates one security group for you.

53
00:02:38,020 --> 00:02:41,670
Before it's all said and done, you'll
usually have quite a few security groups.

54
00:02:41,670 --> 00:02:42,920
They don't bill for those.

55
00:02:42,920 --> 00:02:45,580
They're like software firewalls we use for
controlling access.

56
00:02:45,580 --> 00:02:49,170
So it's just a part of the security
features inside of AWS.

57
00:02:49,170 --> 00:02:51,040
But the rest of this stuff
is pretty important.

58
00:02:51,040 --> 00:02:53,400
This very first one is really important.

59
00:02:53,400 --> 00:02:55,510
It's running instances.

60
00:02:55,510 --> 00:02:57,357
Those are the virtual machines,
the servers,

61
00:02:57,357 --> 00:03:00,080
that are running in your
environment right now.

62
00:03:00,080 --> 00:03:03,480
In other words, these are the servers
you're paying for right now.

63
00:03:03,480 --> 00:03:06,550
When you're running a server,
you pay for CPU and RAM, and

64
00:03:06,550 --> 00:03:10,100
when they're turned on and running,
you're paying for that CPU and RAM.

65
00:03:10,100 --> 00:03:12,690
When they're shut off,
you're just paying for storage.

66
00:03:12,690 --> 00:03:16,030
Now the storage, those are hard drives,
and those show up right here.

67
00:03:16,030 --> 00:03:17,330
Volumes, all right?

68
00:03:17,330 --> 00:03:20,600
So volumes, those are the hard drives that
are attached to your virtual machines and,

69
00:03:20,600 --> 00:03:21,460
again, you pay for those.

70
00:03:22,800 --> 00:03:24,600
We have key pairs.

71
00:03:24,600 --> 00:03:28,500
If you're bringing up Linux servers,
or servers that you're gonna SSH or

72
00:03:28,500 --> 00:03:31,990
connect into, you'll likely use
certificate-based authentication, and

73
00:03:31,990 --> 00:03:34,640
you'll create key pairs
to provide that access.

74
00:03:34,640 --> 00:03:36,640
And you may have zero, you may have 100.

75
00:03:36,640 --> 00:03:40,210
It depends on how many employees
you want working in those servers.

76
00:03:40,210 --> 00:03:46,310
Placement groups are a part of
the scalability inside of Amazon.

77
00:03:46,310 --> 00:03:50,895
When you dynamically bring up a server,
so if you tell the system hey, I've got

78
00:03:50,895 --> 00:03:54,000
a web server and when it gets busy, I want
you to spawn another one and when it gets

79
00:03:54,000 --> 00:03:58,220
busy, spawn a third one and a fourth one
or spawn 50 of them, however many, right?

80
00:03:58,220 --> 00:03:59,930
How does it know where to put those?

81
00:03:59,930 --> 00:04:04,870
You may want some to go in the Northern
Virginia Data Center number three, and

82
00:04:04,870 --> 00:04:08,860
others in the Data Center number one so
that you get multi-site redundancy.

83
00:04:08,860 --> 00:04:11,210
Well, you create placement
groups to define that.

84
00:04:11,210 --> 00:04:13,100
And so you'll just have a number
here indicating how many

85
00:04:13,100 --> 00:04:13,840
placement groups you have.

86
00:04:15,170 --> 00:04:16,560
Elastic IPs.

87
00:04:16,560 --> 00:04:19,040
Those are the static IPs for your servers.

88
00:04:19,040 --> 00:04:21,710
When you bring a server up in Amazon,
every time you

89
00:04:24,460 --> 00:04:27,960
shut it down and power it back on,
it'll get a new IP address.

90
00:04:27,960 --> 00:04:31,120
If you just do a reboot,
like a warm reboot, it won't get a new IP.

91
00:04:31,120 --> 00:04:32,650
But if you shut it down,

92
00:04:32,650 --> 00:04:35,560
the next time you turn it on
it'll get a different IP address.

93
00:04:35,560 --> 00:04:39,100
If you want it to have the same IP address
every time, you have to get an elastic IP,

94
00:04:39,100 --> 00:04:42,130
and so you've got your total right there.

95
00:04:42,130 --> 00:04:43,300
Our snapshots.

96
00:04:43,300 --> 00:04:47,520
If you want to take a quick backup of
a server, you can take a snapshot.

97
00:04:47,520 --> 00:04:50,170
And those snapshots you have to pay for
the storage, right, so

98
00:04:50,170 --> 00:04:52,370
where they're stored in S3.

99
00:04:52,370 --> 00:04:54,080
But otherwise they're just quick and

100
00:04:54,080 --> 00:04:56,620
easy you can do it while
the servers online or offline.

101
00:04:56,620 --> 00:04:57,660
You have the flexibility there.

102
00:04:58,960 --> 00:05:00,210
Load balancers.

103
00:05:00,210 --> 00:05:03,912
If I have more than one web server,
how do I balance my customers across it?

104
00:05:03,912 --> 00:05:05,189
I use load balancers.

105
00:05:05,189 --> 00:05:08,470
And so Amazon has built-in load balancing
systems that we can bring up, and

106
00:05:08,470 --> 00:05:10,730
you'll get your quantity right there.

107
00:05:10,730 --> 00:05:12,620
And then lastly,
the security groups that I mentioned.

108
00:05:12,620 --> 00:05:15,490
The firewalls, and
how many of those we've created too.

109
00:05:15,490 --> 00:05:17,460
Most of these are virtual resources.

110
00:05:17,460 --> 00:05:18,720
It's not like physical hardware.

111
00:05:18,720 --> 00:05:22,180
So we can spawn these, create them and
remove them whenever we want, right,

112
00:05:22,180 --> 00:05:23,160
so really, really flexible.

113
00:05:24,370 --> 00:05:27,300
After that, we see some general
information that's pretty useful.

114
00:05:27,300 --> 00:05:28,190
Create an instance.

115
00:05:28,190 --> 00:05:29,230
That's what most people want to do.

116
00:05:29,230 --> 00:05:31,320
They want to jump right in and
create a server.

117
00:05:31,320 --> 00:05:33,958
So we've got a button right here that
will take us right to that process.

118
00:05:33,958 --> 00:05:35,711
I'm gonna save that for another segment.

119
00:05:35,711 --> 00:05:38,200
Then we get our service health.

120
00:05:38,200 --> 00:05:43,350
If you're ever having problems with your
servers, they're collocated at Amazon.

121
00:05:43,350 --> 00:05:45,640
So maybe the problem's not your fault.

122
00:05:45,640 --> 00:05:47,130
Maybe it's Amazon's fault.

123
00:05:47,130 --> 00:05:50,050
And so they've got a nice little
health dashboard right here,

124
00:05:50,050 --> 00:05:53,740
where you can see each of the regions
that you're currently working in.

125
00:05:53,740 --> 00:05:56,310
And by default you'll see some
of the different ones here.

126
00:05:56,310 --> 00:05:58,350
I'm seeing the West Coast ones right now.

127
00:05:58,350 --> 00:06:02,540
And I can see that I'm up and healthy,
nothing crazy going on there.

128
00:06:02,540 --> 00:06:07,110
If I wanna the other reasons,
if I wanna see US East or

129
00:06:07,110 --> 00:06:11,670
one of the other guys,
right now I'm defaulting to US West.

130
00:06:11,670 --> 00:06:14,260
But I can go down here to
the Service Health Dashboard, and

131
00:06:14,260 --> 00:06:18,140
that'll take me into a screen where I'll
get to see all of the different locations

132
00:06:18,140 --> 00:06:20,770
in North America,
South America, Europe and Asia.

133
00:06:20,770 --> 00:06:22,970
And you can look and
see if there are issues.

134
00:06:22,970 --> 00:06:25,540
And don't be surprised if you see issues.

135
00:06:25,540 --> 00:06:27,030
Issues happen, right?

136
00:06:27,030 --> 00:06:30,248
But they've got multiple data centers
to be able to correct for that.

137
00:06:30,248 --> 00:06:34,590
And as I kind of skim down the list here,
I don't see any issues right now.

138
00:06:34,590 --> 00:06:37,986
But one of the nice things you can do is
over here you can subscribe to an RSS

139
00:06:37,986 --> 00:06:41,716
feed, so you can set up alerts so that you
get notified when there's a problem in

140
00:06:41,716 --> 00:06:44,018
a data center that you've
got systems in place.

141
00:06:46,957 --> 00:06:47,621
All right,

142
00:06:47,621 --> 00:06:52,330
the other stuff that we have over here on
the right are just frequently used things.

143
00:06:52,330 --> 00:06:54,900
You'll have links to go to
supported platforms and

144
00:06:54,900 --> 00:06:58,530
your default VPC,
which is a virtual private cloud.

145
00:06:58,530 --> 00:07:02,240
You technically have one
VPC created automatically,

146
00:07:02,240 --> 00:07:04,820
although it doesn't really show up,
and that's just where your servers go

147
00:07:04,820 --> 00:07:07,710
until you start dividing your
network up and you can create more.

148
00:07:07,710 --> 00:07:10,390
The rest of this is just help and
general information.

149
00:07:10,390 --> 00:07:14,530
So all the documentation for Amazon,
and their documentation's really good.

150
00:07:14,530 --> 00:07:18,390
They go in a lot of good detail, they
provide links to various resources, and

151
00:07:18,390 --> 00:07:21,670
they have a community forum where you
can post questions and get answers.

152
00:07:21,670 --> 00:07:25,730
Now if you're a paid account, you can
actually call Amazon up for support or

153
00:07:25,730 --> 00:07:27,060
do a live chat.

154
00:07:27,060 --> 00:07:30,440
But if you're in the free usage tier,
you can send them an email or

155
00:07:30,440 --> 00:07:31,400
you can use the community.

156
00:07:31,400 --> 00:07:32,890
It's up to you how you want to go.

157
00:07:32,890 --> 00:07:36,700
So you'll see forums right there,
pricing and contact.

158
00:07:36,700 --> 00:07:38,730
Then you've got the AWS Marketplace.

159
00:07:38,730 --> 00:07:42,573
The AWS Marketplace is really cool,
because if you're gonna bring up a new

160
00:07:42,573 --> 00:07:45,440
server and you wanna run
a certain set of applications,

161
00:07:45,440 --> 00:07:49,550
somebody else may have already built
a virtual machine that does that.

162
00:07:49,550 --> 00:07:51,211
And so you can go and
get it out of the Marketplace.

163
00:07:51,211 --> 00:07:52,579
Now I know it's called the Marketplace and

164
00:07:52,579 --> 00:07:54,067
it sounds like you have to pay for
everything.

165
00:07:54,067 --> 00:07:56,064
A lot of stuff in the Marketplace is free.

166
00:07:56,064 --> 00:07:59,847
If you wanna bring up a Drupal server
You could go on the marketplace and

167
00:07:59,847 --> 00:08:03,840
find where somebody's already made
a Drupal VM, and it may well be free.

168
00:08:03,840 --> 00:08:04,630
And you can spin it up,

00:09:59,990 --> 00:10:01,970

That is not part of the default free tier,

00:11:16,430 --> 00:11:18,360

00:11:18,360 --> 00:11:21,780

00:11:21,780 --> 00:11:24,850

00:11:24,850 --> 00:11:28,460
Well, one of the cool parts about

00:11:28,460 --> 00:11:32,050
If your server gets busy, it can spin
up a second server, or a third, or

242
00:11:32,050 --> 00:11:32,770
a fourth, or a fifth.

243
00:11:32,770 --> 00:11:35,050
It can spin up more servers
to react to your load.

244
00:11:35,050 --> 00:11:36,890
Well what if your website goes viral?

245
00:11:36,890 --> 00:11:39,420
And all of a sudden, people
are linking to it all over the world.

00:11:39,420 --> 00:11:41,190
A lot of us hope for that, right?

247
00:11:41,190 --> 00:11:42,920
Oh please, let me have my site go viral.

00:11:42,920 --> 00:11:46,690
But the negative side of that is you'll
get a huge amount of traffic, and

00:11:46,690 --> 00:11:49,980
Amazon will start spinning more and
more and more servers, and

00:11:49,980 --> 00:11:52,140
your bill is going up and up and up.

00:11:52,140 --> 00:11:54,330
And just because people
are watching your video on YouTube,

00:11:54,330 --> 00:11:55,740
doesn't mean they're buying your products.

00:11:55,740 --> 00:12:01,080
So there's not necessarily a level of

00:12:01,080 --> 00:12:03,470
So there's these arbitrary
limits that are set.

00:12:03,470 --> 00:12:06,780
That just say, hey, we can spin up this

00:12:07,800 --> 00:12:10,870
And it won't let anymore to spin up and

257
00:12:10,870 --> 00:12:13,820
To make sure that your bill
doesn't go through the roof.

00:12:13,820 --> 00:12:15,220
But these limits can be changed.

00:12:15,220 --> 00:12:18,280
You can go in and request a limit

00:12:18,280 --> 00:12:21,420

00:12:21,420 --> 00:12:24,340
Notice that most of the instances

00:12:24,340 --> 00:12:28,290
I can create two of the C3

00:12:31,560 --> 00:12:35,670
So you've got certain limits,
but other ones, like the 8X and

00:12:35,670 --> 00:12:38,110
4X, those are pretty expensive servers.

00:12:38,110 --> 00:12:40,220
They can rack up the bill really fast.

So the current limit is zero, and

if I want to spin any of those up,

00:12:45,890 --> 00:12:49,220
And you just click on that, and so

00:12:49,220 --> 00:12:50,610
request a limit increase.

00:12:50,610 --> 00:12:52,800
And when you do that,

00:12:52,800 --> 00:12:53,700
you just submit a ticket.

00:12:53,700 --> 00:12:55,590
And you say what region

00:12:55,590 --> 00:12:59,480
what you want that new limit to be,

00:12:59,480 --> 00:13:01,300
It usually happens pretty quickly.

00:13:01,300 --> 00:13:03,690
It usually only takes about an hour or

00:13:03,690 --> 00:13:08,120
I've never had them reject a request,

00:13:08,120 --> 00:13:11,190
But you just fill out that information and
they'll bump up that limit for you.

00:13:11,190 --> 00:13:12,618
It's just a protection mechanism for you.

00:13:15,800 --> 00:13:20,890

What we call virtual machines,

00:13:25,480 --> 00:13:29,890
So you bring up instances of a VM, and

00:13:29,890 --> 00:13:32,260
well, within the limits that we just saw.

running one you've got to pay for

00:14:11,890 --> 00:14:14,470

I say it's the Virginia link.

It's Virgina because

00:14:33,950 --> 00:14:38,270
Spot requests,
spot requests are special instances.

00:14:38,270 --> 00:14:40,300
They're instances that you're
not guaranteed to have.

00:14:40,300 --> 00:14:46,510
You basically bid or pay for leftover

00:14:46,510 --> 00:14:50,810
In a given hour, Amazon has a lot of
hardware that doesn't get used and so

00:14:50,810 --> 00:14:52,920
you can reserve it at a cheaper rate.

00:14:52,920 --> 00:14:56,170
But it's not really reserved, if
somebody's willing to pay the full rate,

00:14:56,170 --> 00:14:57,210
they get first access.

00:14:57,210 --> 00:14:59,930
And it's only if it's passed

00:14:59,930 --> 00:15:02,830
So if you have something where
time is not a factor but

00:15:02,830 --> 00:15:06,510
you just need the resources you can use

00:15:07,790 --> 00:15:12,870

00:15:12,870 --> 00:15:16,860

00:15:16,860 --> 00:15:18,135

00:15:18,135 --> 00:15:20,470

00:15:29,560 --> 00:15:31,590

00:15:31,590 --> 00:15:34,510
So when you shut them off

00:15:34,510 --> 00:15:36,250
you bring them up when you need them,

00:15:36,250 --> 00:15:37,740
They're billed at at a higher rate.

00:15:37,740 --> 00:15:38,910

00:15:38,910 --> 00:15:43,600
All right, now, when we create these

Well, they come from
virtual machine images, and

00:15:46,277 --> 00:15:48,277
Amazon makes a ton of them available.

00:15:48,277 --> 00:15:53,536
Amazon stores their images in a format
called an AMI, an Amazon Machine Image.

00:15:53,536 --> 00:15:57,437
And so looking right down here,
I've got Images and AMIs.

335
00:15:57,437 --> 00:16:01,721
AMIs, here it'll show any
AMIs that I've created.

00:16:01,721 --> 00:16:03,218
You can create your own, right?

00:16:03,218 --> 00:16:06,220
You may have your own specific
server configuration.

338
00:16:06,220 --> 00:16:08,680
You don't trust any of the other
guys that are out there, right?

339
00:16:08,680 --> 00:16:12,740
The Amazon Web Market, if you go in there,
you don't know who built that up, or

00:16:12,740 --> 00:16:16,710
maybe you know the company, but you just
wanna make sure you have total control.

341
00:16:16,710 --> 00:16:18,620
You can create your own AMI.

00:16:18,620 --> 00:16:22,160
You can build your own Linux or
Windows or even third party OSs.

00:16:22,160 --> 00:16:26,300
Not every OS works great in Amazon Web
Services, so you have to be careful with

00:16:26,300 --> 00:16:29,500

OpenBSD up there just fine.

00:16:29,500 --> 00:16:33,220
There's different systems that you may
choose to run for your needs, and so

00:16:33,220 --> 00:16:35,050
you can build your own AMIs.

347
00:16:35,050 --> 00:16:36,590
And they'll be stored right here, and

00:16:36,590 --> 00:16:39,880
you can use those to create
new virtual machines.

349
00:16:39,880 --> 00:16:44,300
Now, you can use the AMIs provided
by Amazon or the community, and so

00:16:44,300 --> 00:16:47,320
up here you'll see it
default to owned by me, but

we can change that to go to public images,

00:16:54,250 --> 00:16:58,470
to see, well,
33,666 different public images right now.

00:16:58,470 --> 00:16:59,980
When you log in it may be different.

00:16:59,980 --> 00:17:01,770
That's a ton of images.

00:17:01,770 --> 00:17:05,460
So you can filter that down based
on all sorts of different things,

00:17:05,460 --> 00:17:09,880
ones that are from Amazon, for

00:17:09,880 --> 00:17:13,550
Maybe I just want it running

00:17:13,550 --> 00:17:18,070
So you can start to filter based on

00:17:18,070 --> 00:17:21,030
Just be careful, and I'll do a separate
episode specifically on this,

00:17:21,030 --> 00:17:24,640
but be careful that you always
pay attention to the source.

00:17:24,640 --> 00:17:26,100
Who made it, all right?

00:17:26,100 --> 00:17:29,540
Because whoever made it can
choose to unmake it, right?

00:17:29,540 --> 00:17:32,760
So, if you rely on a particular AMI,

00:17:32,760 --> 00:17:37,370
if you're using it all the time,

00:17:37,370 --> 00:17:40,890

00:17:40,890 --> 00:17:43,620
So you might need to make a clone of

367
00:17:43,620 --> 00:17:47,170
might not be updating it, and so if
changes are happening in their system and

00:17:47,170 --> 00:17:49,340
they're making improvements,

00:17:49,340 --> 00:17:50,550
So always be careful with that.

00:17:50,550 --> 00:17:52,960
Pay attention to who the source is.

371
00:17:54,710 --> 00:17:57,990
All right, in addition to AMIs,

00:17:57,990 --> 00:17:59,220
Now what is that?

00:17:59,220 --> 00:18:03,745
Sometimes, we want to deploy an
application that's more than just one VM,

374
00:18:03,745 --> 00:18:04,810
all right?

375
00:18:04,810 --> 00:18:06,810
A great example would be web applications.

00:18:06,810 --> 00:18:10,450
With web applications, you've got web
servers that are the front end that your

00:18:10,450 --> 00:18:14,050
customers see, and then you've got
database servers that are the back end

00:18:14,050 --> 00:18:16,700
that you don't want your
customers to see that, right?

00:18:16,700 --> 00:18:19,780
But the web front end is useless
without the database, and

00:18:19,780 --> 00:18:21,870
the database is useless
without the web front end.

00:18:21,870 --> 00:18:24,690
So they're two separate servers but

00:18:24,690 --> 00:18:25,940
So that's a bundle.

00:18:25,940 --> 00:18:29,130
When we deploy that application,
we don't need just one VM.

00:18:29,130 --> 00:18:33,320
We need multiple VMs, and so we can create
bundled tasks to combine those things

00:18:33,320 --> 00:18:36,570
together, and they show using like
a Windows instance, for example.

00:18:36,570 --> 00:18:38,650
You can do all sorts of
different stuff here.

00:18:38,650 --> 00:18:40,954
You define what gets deployed
when that rolls out.

00:18:43,493 --> 00:18:46,040
Now each virtual machine requires storage.

00:18:46,040 --> 00:18:49,010
Most of them will include some
storage that's built into them, and

00:18:49,010 --> 00:18:51,370
then you can add more
storage if you need it.

00:18:51,370 --> 00:18:56,068
If you bring up a database server, for
example, it'll be a Linux box or a Windows

00:18:56,068 --> 00:19:00,130
box, and it'll have a volume or a hard
drive on it for the operating system, but

00:19:00,130 --> 00:19:03,485
you probably want a separate
hard drive for the database.
