00:19:03,485 --> 00:19:05,660
Now, there's a few different reasons
we might want to do that, but

395
00:19:05,660 --> 00:19:06,720
redundancy is the main one.

396
00:19:06,720 --> 00:19:09,730
We probably wanna replicate that
to another data center too, and so

397
00:19:09,730 --> 00:19:13,320
we do that by creating volumes
in the Elastic Block Store.

398
00:19:13,320 --> 00:19:15,130
EBS, the Elastic Block Store.

399
00:19:15,130 --> 00:19:17,970
It gets confused with
the Elastic Beanstalk.

400
00:19:17,970 --> 00:19:21,230
That's another program, or
another service from Amazon, but

401
00:19:21,230 --> 00:19:25,820
the Elastic Block Store, that's the one
where we create hard drives, and

402
00:19:25,820 --> 00:19:30,460
they can be cloned and replicated between
the different data centers at AWS.

403
00:19:30,460 --> 00:19:32,000
Really powerful stuff there.

404
00:19:32,000 --> 00:19:35,420
As you start to bring up instances,
you'll notice volumes appearing, and

405
00:19:35,420 --> 00:19:38,146
these will be the hard drives for
your existing servers, and

406
00:19:38,146 --> 00:19:41,049
you can start to add in more drives and
configure them as needed.

407
00:19:42,979 --> 00:19:44,588
Then we have snapshots.

408
00:19:44,588 --> 00:19:49,440
If you wanna take a quick back up of
a server, you can take a snapshot of it.

409
00:19:49,440 --> 00:19:51,180
You pick the server,
you take the snapshot.

410
00:19:51,180 --> 00:19:54,380
It'll give you the choice if you
want to do it online or offline.

411
00:19:54,380 --> 00:19:57,080
We usually do online cuz we
need the server to be up, but

412
00:19:57,080 --> 00:20:00,010
if the server's in the middle of writing
to a disk when you take the snapshot,

413
00:20:00,010 --> 00:20:01,360
that's now part of the snapshot.

414
00:20:01,360 --> 00:20:04,410
So you don't necessarily
get a consistent backup.

415
00:20:04,410 --> 00:20:06,510
It's always best to do it when
the server's offline, but

416
00:20:06,510 --> 00:20:08,380
that's not always an option.

417
00:20:08,380 --> 00:20:10,340
But when you take snapshots,
they show here.

418
00:20:10,340 --> 00:20:14,180
We need to see them so that we can
restore them if we need to, right?

419
00:20:14,180 --> 00:20:17,140
Quick and easy restores, but also just so

420
00:20:17,140 --> 00:20:20,550
that we can see that they exist
because we're paying for the storage.

421
00:20:20,550 --> 00:20:23,301
It costs money to
maintain those snapshots.

422
00:20:26,186 --> 00:20:28,260
Then we've got network and security.

423
00:20:28,260 --> 00:20:29,040
Network and security,

424
00:20:29,040 --> 00:20:33,290
these are areas where we'll come in and
set things a lot less frequently, right?

425
00:20:33,290 --> 00:20:36,130
We'll put things in here, and then
we'll kind of not get back to it again.

426
00:20:36,130 --> 00:20:41,090
Security groups are the first part, and
that's where we create software firewalls.

427
00:20:41,090 --> 00:20:44,640
You can create firewalls that
you put your servers behind, and

428
00:20:44,640 --> 00:20:48,590
once they're behind the firewall, you can
go down here and configure the inbound and

429
00:20:48,590 --> 00:20:52,770
outbound restrictions to define
who can access the system and how.

430
00:20:52,770 --> 00:20:57,180
So you'll see I've got one security
group created by default, and

431
00:20:57,180 --> 00:21:00,000
if I go to Inbound,
you'll see it's allowing all traffic,

432
00:21:00,000 --> 00:21:03,200
and if I go to Outbound,
it's allowing all traffic.

433
00:21:03,200 --> 00:21:05,560
So it's allowing everything.

434
00:21:05,560 --> 00:21:07,510
Well, I probably don't want that.

435
00:21:07,510 --> 00:21:09,020
If this is a public server, maybe.

436
00:21:09,020 --> 00:21:11,690
I don't know, but more than likely
we want to filter that out.

437
00:21:11,690 --> 00:21:15,680
So as we deploy our servers,
we'll create additional security groups so

438
00:21:15,680 --> 00:21:18,170
that we can restrict
the access people have.

439
00:21:18,170 --> 00:21:21,937
If it's a web server, we probably just
want people to get to it via port 80 and

440
00:21:21,937 --> 00:21:27,000
443, but if I want to be able to SSH into
the server to manage it, I might want to

441
00:21:27,000 --> 00:21:31,390
add SSH to the list and just put my
source IP address to limit it to just me.

442
00:21:31,390 --> 00:21:35,690
You can get really granular like that, so
it's basically just a firewall service.

443
00:21:35,690 --> 00:21:38,880
You may find that just one security
group is good enough for you.

444
00:21:38,880 --> 00:21:42,520
You create one and you define it for
everything, but I'll oftentimes create

445
00:21:42,520 --> 00:21:45,500
multiple ones because different
servers have different needs, and

446
00:21:45,500 --> 00:21:47,910
I want to kind of create
a bit of isolation there.

447
00:21:47,910 --> 00:21:49,401
It's up to you how you
want to go about that.

448
00:21:51,250 --> 00:21:53,500
All right, Elastic IPs.

449
00:21:53,500 --> 00:21:56,500
If you want your server to
have a static IP address,

450
00:21:56,500 --> 00:21:58,150
you've got to create an Elastic IP here.

451
00:21:58,150 --> 00:22:00,530
An Elastic IP is basically a reservation.

452
00:22:00,530 --> 00:22:04,020
You're reserving an IP address for
your server, and

453
00:22:04,020 --> 00:22:08,500
whether your server is on or off,
you have it, so it's a static IP.

454
00:22:08,500 --> 00:22:10,310
Here's the thing, though.

455
00:22:10,310 --> 00:22:14,910
When your server is online, it's gotta
have an IP address, and so Amazon, we

456
00:22:14,910 --> 00:22:19,870
usually use, it's sort of like DHCP, but
they do statically assign it in your VM.

457
00:22:19,870 --> 00:22:23,950
But they'll push an IP to your VM to use,
and when you shut your server down,

458
00:22:23,950 --> 00:22:27,120
that IP gets freed up for
anybody else to use,

459
00:22:27,120 --> 00:22:30,810
and when you bring the server back
up it'll just grab another IP.

460
00:22:30,810 --> 00:22:34,740
So every time you turn your server on,
it could potentially have a different IP.

461
00:22:34,740 --> 00:22:39,520
Well, when you reserve one, if your server
is off, you're still holding the IP.

462
00:22:39,520 --> 00:22:43,970
So what Amazon says is, hey, while your
server is online, it's gotta have an IP,

463
00:22:43,970 --> 00:22:45,670
so we're not gonna charge you for it.

464
00:22:45,670 --> 00:22:49,440
So you actually don't get charged for
static IPs or dynamic IPs while your

465
00:22:49,440 --> 00:22:54,880
server is on, but when you turn
your server off, now you're holding

466
00:22:54,880 --> 00:22:59,240
an IP that somebody else can't use, and
so for that, they do charge, all right?

467
00:22:59,240 --> 00:23:01,800
I don't remember exactly
what the charge is.

468
00:23:01,800 --> 00:23:03,400
I think it's $0.25 per day.

469
00:23:03,400 --> 00:23:05,580
So it's a real small amount, right?

470
00:23:05,580 --> 00:23:10,250
It's not a big deal to hold that IP, but
if your server's gonna be on all the time,

471
00:23:10,250 --> 00:23:11,910
you might as well get a static IP so

472
00:23:11,910 --> 00:23:14,190
you don't have to worry about
that changing, all right?

473
00:23:14,190 --> 00:23:16,140
So, Elastic IPs are how we do that.

474
00:23:18,020 --> 00:23:20,410
Now, you might ask yourself,
when wouldn't I want that?

475
00:23:20,410 --> 00:23:24,670
Well, if you're using a load balancer,
the end users are going to connect to

476
00:23:24,670 --> 00:23:28,480
the load balancer, not your servers, so at
that point you don't really care what IP

477
00:23:28,480 --> 00:23:31,920
address your servers have because the end
users connect to the load balancer.

478
00:23:31,920 --> 00:23:34,210
So in that scenario you
might not use Elastic IPs.

479
00:23:34,210 --> 00:23:36,514
You don't always have to
have static IPs on a server.

480
00:23:38,444 --> 00:23:40,380
All right,
placement groups I mentioned earlier.

481
00:23:40,380 --> 00:23:43,176
A placement group is how we define
where our servers are going to go,

482
00:23:43,176 --> 00:23:45,395
which data center,
which zone they're gonna go in.

483
00:23:45,395 --> 00:23:49,912
So, if they're going in
the North American East data center three

484
00:23:49,912 --> 00:23:53,070
versus the Sao Paulo data center two,
right?

485
00:23:53,070 --> 00:23:55,589
So I can pick between which ones and
set up these groups.

486
00:23:55,589 --> 00:23:58,273
When I create a new VM,
when I create a new instance,

487
00:23:58,273 --> 00:24:02,055
I just pick the placement group that
it goes to, and go in the right place.

488
00:24:02,055 --> 00:24:05,080
The nice part here is we can give
the placements groups names.

489
00:24:05,080 --> 00:24:10,200
So I can say like, production web servers,
or test web servers and so on.

490
00:24:10,200 --> 00:24:14,350
And I don't have to remember oh yeah, that
goes in Oregon data center two, right?

491
00:24:14,350 --> 00:24:16,000
I don't have to remember
that very specifically.

492
00:24:18,350 --> 00:24:22,190
Load balances are next and this is where I
can define those load balancing systems.

493
00:24:22,190 --> 00:24:25,460
These are basically an IP
that end users connect to and

494
00:24:25,460 --> 00:24:29,000
it will then distribute that traffic
across multiple servers on the back end.

495
00:24:29,000 --> 00:24:34,960
This is great for video streaming servers,
for web servers, especially web servers,

496
00:24:34,960 --> 00:24:39,230
file transfers, and so on that you can
have multiple servers on the back end, and

497
00:24:39,230 --> 00:24:43,080
if one of the back end servers goes down
the load balancer just stops sending to

498
00:24:43,080 --> 00:24:45,270
it and keeps sending to the other servers.

499
00:24:45,270 --> 00:24:48,930
So the load balancer will help you
mask failures on the back end.

500
00:24:48,930 --> 00:24:52,870
Now you don't see it here but the load
balancer is actually a virtual machine,

501
00:24:52,870 --> 00:24:54,730
it's an instance that's being brought up.

502
00:24:54,730 --> 00:24:57,850
But it is 100% managed by Amazon.

503
00:24:57,850 --> 00:25:01,270
You can't log into it,
you can't do a lot of crazy stuff on it,

504
00:25:01,270 --> 00:25:06,310
it's managed by them and they handle the
redundancy and the backup and all of that.

505
00:25:06,310 --> 00:25:08,520
So, you just define it here via the GUI.

506
00:25:08,520 --> 00:25:11,950
You create that load balance sheet,
you give it an IP address, and

507
00:25:11,950 --> 00:25:13,730
then Amazon takes care of the rest.

508
00:25:13,730 --> 00:25:17,370
So, that's really nice that that happens
but it is a software load balancer.

509
00:25:17,370 --> 00:25:19,100
So don't think they've
got a hardware load,

510
00:25:19,100 --> 00:25:21,980
like a F5 big IP or something like that.

511
00:25:21,980 --> 00:25:24,030
They don't have hardware
like that on the back end.

512
00:25:24,030 --> 00:25:26,465
This is just a Linux VM that's
being able to handle that.

513
00:25:28,322 --> 00:25:29,007
All right.

514
00:25:29,007 --> 00:25:30,270
Key pairs.

515
00:25:30,270 --> 00:25:33,810
When we want to do security, when we want
to do like SSH authentication against

516
00:25:33,810 --> 00:25:37,850
a server, we create key pairs to be able
to do that, to manage the connection.

517
00:25:37,850 --> 00:25:39,320
So we define them here.

518
00:25:39,320 --> 00:25:43,870
When you have multiple employees working
in your system, you wanna generate unique

519
00:25:43,870 --> 00:25:47,800
key pairs for each one because what
happens when an employee gets terminated?

520
00:25:47,800 --> 00:25:48,720
You wont have to go in and

521
00:25:48,720 --> 00:25:50,860
change everybody's key pair
if everybody's sharing one.

522
00:25:50,860 --> 00:25:52,410
You don't want to change it for everyone.

523
00:25:52,410 --> 00:25:54,140
You want to change it for just that user.

524
00:25:54,140 --> 00:25:57,749
So by isolating out like that it
gives us a more secure environment.

525
00:25:59,350 --> 00:26:01,660
And then lastly we have
network interfaces.

526
00:26:01,660 --> 00:26:04,620
This is another one that we don't mess
with a whole lot if you're just creating

527
00:26:04,620 --> 00:26:05,910
public servers.

528
00:26:05,910 --> 00:26:07,450
But if you're creating private servers.

529
00:26:07,450 --> 00:26:11,500
If you're creating multiple VPC's or
virtual private clouds.

530
00:26:11,500 --> 00:26:13,910
You might have a DMZ.

531
00:26:13,910 --> 00:26:15,640
Your cloud servers that
are exposed to the internet.

532
00:26:15,640 --> 00:26:19,550
And then you might have your back end
servers that are your database servers.

533
00:26:19,550 --> 00:26:22,720
And you don't want the internet to be
able to get to the database servers.

534
00:26:22,720 --> 00:26:25,320
So in that scenario you can set up

535
00:26:25,320 --> 00:26:29,170
a security group to allow access
between the two environments, right?

536
00:26:29,170 --> 00:26:30,270
So a firewall.

537
00:26:30,270 --> 00:26:34,080
But if you want even more control,
you can create a virtual machine

538
00:26:34,080 --> 00:26:38,030
with multiple network interfaces and
you can have it with interfaces and

539
00:26:38,030 --> 00:26:41,760
the two different VPCs or wherever you
need and you can start to get even more

540
00:26:41,760 --> 00:26:46,000
granular control there you can build
your own filtering system or a proxy.

541
00:26:46,000 --> 00:26:50,550
I see a lot of people do this with like
active directory federation services,

542
00:26:50,550 --> 00:26:53,590
where you might have a web application
proxy, so you can build that up

543
00:26:53,590 --> 00:26:57,590
you need a Windows server with network
interfaces in more than one VPC.

544
00:26:57,590 --> 00:27:01,270
All right,

545
00:27:01,270 --> 00:27:07,160
the last little section is the absolute
coolest thing in Amazon web services.

546
00:27:07,160 --> 00:27:09,540
If you're just bringing
up single servers in AWS,

547
00:27:09,540 --> 00:27:11,040
it's really no different
than a local appointment.

548
00:27:11,040 --> 00:27:13,570
You just bring up the local servers
you need, they run, and that's it.

549
00:27:13,570 --> 00:27:18,830
But the real power of AWS is being able
to spontaneously generate servers.

550
00:27:18,830 --> 00:27:22,560
If your site gets busy you
can spin up more servers.

551
00:27:22,560 --> 00:27:25,410
And if your site gets slow you can
reduce the amount of servers and

552
00:27:25,410 --> 00:27:26,490
it's all dynamic.

553
00:27:26,490 --> 00:27:29,330
You can't do that when you
own your own server farm.

554
00:27:29,330 --> 00:27:32,710
If I know that at peak time
I'm gonna need 50 web servers.

555
00:27:32,710 --> 00:27:34,640
But at my slow times I only need 20.

556
00:27:34,640 --> 00:27:39,530
Well, I would have to buy 50 servers
to handle the load of 50 servers, for

557
00:27:39,530 --> 00:27:40,990
the peak time.

558
00:27:40,990 --> 00:27:44,010
But when things get slow, 30 of my
servers are sitting there doing nothing.

559
00:27:44,010 --> 00:27:45,210
And that's just how it is, right?

560
00:27:45,210 --> 00:27:47,080
Because I bought my own servers.

561
00:27:47,080 --> 00:27:49,610
But with AWS,
I can spin up 20 instances and

562
00:27:49,610 --> 00:27:52,990
I can say always keep
20 instances on line.

563
00:27:52,990 --> 00:27:56,720
And then if things get busy,
spin up as many as you need, right?

564
00:27:56,720 --> 00:27:58,280
Not just 50, go beyond that.

565
00:27:58,280 --> 00:28:00,020
Spin up as many as you
need to handle the load.

566
00:28:00,020 --> 00:28:02,400
I don't want my engineers
to have a bad experience.

567
00:28:02,400 --> 00:28:06,240
And so from 5 PM to 6 PM maybe
I've got 50 servers, but

568
00:28:06,240 --> 00:28:08,600
the rest of day I'm down to just 20.

569
00:28:08,600 --> 00:28:13,600
And so now I'm only paying for what I
need that's where we really save money.

570
00:28:13,600 --> 00:28:16,790
I'm not having to buy a lot of hardware
that I don't need most of the time.

571
00:28:16,790 --> 00:28:21,990
But when I do need it, I've got it and
we set that up by creating auto scaling.

572
00:28:21,990 --> 00:28:25,660
With auto scaling,
you create auto scaling groups.

573
00:28:25,660 --> 00:28:28,360
So these are collections of servers
that are gonna be brought up

574
00:28:28,360 --> 00:28:29,710
to do auto scaling.

575
00:28:29,710 --> 00:28:33,650
So if I'm having web servers on
a web server auto scale group.

576
00:28:33,650 --> 00:28:37,120
And as that group gets busier because
it monitors the service as a whole.

577
00:28:37,120 --> 00:28:40,640
As it gets busier it'll start
to launch new web servers.

578
00:28:40,640 --> 00:28:44,480
Or I might have a database auto scaling
group and as the database servers get

579
00:28:44,480 --> 00:28:48,440
busier it can spawn up more read only
copies or whatever it is that I need.

580
00:28:48,440 --> 00:28:50,500
I can spawn more database
servers as needed.

581
00:28:51,620 --> 00:28:55,040
Well, when it goes to spawn them,
how does it know how to configure them?

582
00:28:55,040 --> 00:28:58,310
How does it know what OS to use and
what configuration to apply?

583
00:28:58,310 --> 00:29:00,810
Well, that's where launch
configurations come in.

584
00:29:00,810 --> 00:29:04,870
Launch configurations we define exactly
how to configure that web server.

585
00:29:04,870 --> 00:29:07,840
So when you bring up a new web server,
this is gonna say,

586
00:29:07,840 --> 00:29:10,460
all right,
attach it to this load balancer and

587
00:29:10,460 --> 00:29:14,040
attach it so that it has a role so it
can access the database on the back end.

588
00:29:14,040 --> 00:29:15,240
Now the web server comes up.

589
00:29:15,240 --> 00:29:17,150
It's already got the web pages on it.

590
00:29:17,150 --> 00:29:19,680
And the load balancer starts
balancing traffic to it.

591
00:29:19,680 --> 00:29:21,310
It hits the database on the back end.

592
00:29:21,310 --> 00:29:23,410
You've now got another web front end.

593
00:29:23,410 --> 00:29:26,480
And so they'll spawn up based
on your launch configuration.

594
00:29:26,480 --> 00:29:27,440
So those two pieces.

595
00:29:27,440 --> 00:29:31,500
Now, in the past this was one of
the hardest things to set up with Amazon,

596
00:29:31,500 --> 00:29:33,200
because they didn't have a GUI for it.

597
00:29:33,200 --> 00:29:34,560
So you had to go command line.

598
00:29:34,560 --> 00:29:38,360
There's a whole command line utility
suite that we can use to manage AWS.

599
00:29:38,360 --> 00:29:41,250
But now they've got it right here and
it's really useful.

600
00:29:41,250 --> 00:29:44,260
I used to use a third party
service called Elastic.

601
00:29:44,260 --> 00:29:49,900
Which they really specialize in taking
the newest features from Amazon S3 and

602
00:29:49,900 --> 00:29:51,780
making web GUI's for it.

603
00:29:51,780 --> 00:29:54,530
So Amazon will get around
to a GUI eventually.

604
00:29:54,530 --> 00:29:57,190
Elastic gets to it right away so
I used to use these guys.

605
00:29:57,190 --> 00:30:01,260
But once they brought in
the auto scaling right here,

606
00:30:01,260 --> 00:30:04,160
that was really the last piece that
I needed to be able to easily manage.

607
00:30:04,160 --> 00:30:06,350
And so I haven't used elastic in a while.

608
00:30:06,350 --> 00:30:07,980
But you can configure it right here.

609
00:30:07,980 --> 00:30:09,330
It's really slick stuff.

610
00:30:09,330 --> 00:30:11,500
We'll do a whole segment
dedicated just to that.

611
00:30:13,480 --> 00:30:17,690
All right, so that's kind of the high
level overview of our EC2 panel.

612
00:30:17,690 --> 00:30:18,840
What all this stuff is.

613
00:30:18,840 --> 00:30:20,460
What each function is.

614
00:30:20,460 --> 00:30:22,180
But we didn't actually
get to see it in use.

615
00:30:22,180 --> 00:30:25,680
And the reason we didn't, I'm saving
that for our following segments.

616
00:30:25,680 --> 00:30:26,470
So stay tuned here.

00:30:26,470 --> 00:30:30,720

segments that are coming up, and

618
00:30:30,720 --> 00:30:32,690
we'll take a look at each of these and
how to work with them,

619
00:30:32,690 --> 00:30:36,280
how to spin up those different systems and
get a chance to see what's what.

620
00:30:36,280 --> 00:30:38,010
So I hope you guys enjoyed this segment.

621
00:30:38,010 --> 00:30:39,820
Stay tuned, we've got more coming up next.

episodes.title: Creating An Instance
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,025 --> 00:00:03,285
[SOUND] In this segment,

2
00:00:03,285 --> 00:00:08,175
we're gonna take a look at creating

3
00:00:08,175 --> 00:00:13,065
an instance inside of Amazon EC2.

4
00:00:13,065 --> 00:00:16,309
So you'll find the process is
pretty straightforward, but

5
00:00:16,309 --> 00:00:18,220
we do have a lot of choices to make.

6
00:00:18,220 --> 00:00:20,380
And so
if you don't have a plan going into this,

7
00:00:20,380 --> 00:00:22,850
it can get really confusing really fast.

8
00:00:22,850 --> 00:00:25,440
And if this is your very first
time creating an EC2 instance,

9
00:00:25,440 --> 00:00:27,870
it's kinda nice to walk
through the process and

10
00:00:27,870 --> 00:00:30,350
get a chance to see what
each of those decisions are.

11
00:00:30,350 --> 00:00:32,930
After you've done it a few times though,
it'll be second nature to you and

12
00:00:32,930 --> 00:00:35,742
you'll be able to knock out these
VMs as fast as you need them.

13
00:00:35,742 --> 00:00:37,460
All right, so let's take a look at this.

14
00:00:37,460 --> 00:00:41,770
I've logged into my Amazon console here,
so I'm logged into AWS.

15
00:00:41,770 --> 00:00:46,560
I'm just gonna browse into EC2, and
inside of EC2 you'll get your summary, and

16
00:00:46,560 --> 00:00:49,180
there is a Launch Instance button
right here, which would create one,

17
00:00:49,180 --> 00:00:50,670
but I'm not gonna go that route.

18
00:00:50,670 --> 00:00:52,640
That just launches you
into a simple wizard.

19
00:00:52,640 --> 00:00:54,260
I'm gonna go into the Instances screen,

20
00:00:54,260 --> 00:00:56,740
cuz we get some more
options by going this way.

21
00:00:58,060 --> 00:01:02,100
Now when we go in here we're gonna see
any instance that we have right now.

22
00:01:02,100 --> 00:01:06,940
And when we go to create an instance,
we're going to basically create it and

23
00:01:06,940 --> 00:01:07,780
it'll show up in this list.

24
00:01:07,780 --> 00:01:09,960
And if you haven't created any
this is gonna be empty and

25
00:01:09,960 --> 00:01:11,820
you've got none, so that's where I'm at.

26
00:01:11,820 --> 00:01:13,580
And if I choose Launch an Instance,

27
00:01:13,580 --> 00:01:17,370
that's gonna walk through the process
of creating that first instance.

28
00:01:17,370 --> 00:01:23,000
Now before you create an instance, there's
a few things that you need to think about.

29
00:01:23,000 --> 00:01:26,160
The first thing that you need to
think about is what operating system

30
00:01:26,160 --> 00:01:27,980
image you're going to be using.

31
00:01:27,980 --> 00:01:29,500
Typically when we bring up service in AWS,

32
00:01:29,500 --> 00:01:32,830
they're normally gonna be
running either Linux or Windows.

33
00:01:32,830 --> 00:01:36,390
If you wanna run some other
OS you can do it, but

34
00:01:36,390 --> 00:01:38,900
there more than likely won't be images for
it.

35
00:01:38,900 --> 00:01:41,800
So you'll probably have to
create your own AMI to do that.

36
00:01:41,800 --> 00:01:47,670
Remember, AMI is an Amazon Machine Image,
and we can see those right down here.

37
00:01:47,670 --> 00:01:53,120
Under our Images and AMIs, we'll see
any AMIs that we've created and then

38
00:01:53,120 --> 00:01:58,420
we'll see other AMIs that we can load in
to create our new virtual machines from.

39
00:01:58,420 --> 00:02:02,490
So this is one of the first things I
think about before creating a new system.

40
00:02:02,490 --> 00:02:05,280
So we go in here and
we kind of pick what we want.

41
00:02:05,280 --> 00:02:09,960
I'm going to change this from
Owned by me to Public images.

42
00:02:09,960 --> 00:02:12,510
And inside of Public images
you'll see there's a lot.

43
00:02:12,510 --> 00:02:14,420
There's over 33,000 of them.

44
00:02:14,420 --> 00:02:16,620
So I'll need to filter that a little more.

45
00:02:16,620 --> 00:02:20,200
Under all images, we can restrict
this down to other systems,

46
00:02:20,200 --> 00:02:24,510
and for the most part what we're
gonna want are images made by Amazon.

47
00:02:24,510 --> 00:02:27,290
If we're bringing up servers in AWS,

48
00:02:27,290 --> 00:02:29,660
Amazon's really the only
person we can trust.

49
00:02:29,660 --> 00:02:32,150
There are other people that make images,
and

50
00:02:32,150 --> 00:02:34,140
if you trust those people
you can use their images.

51
00:02:34,140 --> 00:02:36,030
It's great, it's fine, it works great.

52
00:02:36,030 --> 00:02:38,930
But if you don't know them, if you're
just trying to create a Linux box and

53
00:02:38,930 --> 00:02:40,930
you don't know the other
people that are out there,

54
00:02:40,930 --> 00:02:43,650
at a minimum Amazon is
the one you can trust.

55
00:02:43,650 --> 00:02:46,840
I like to use Amazon images myself
because I know they'll support them.

56
00:02:46,840 --> 00:02:48,380
If I have problems they'll help me.

57
00:02:48,380 --> 00:02:51,800
If I start using third party AMIs,
I've got to rely on the third

58
00:02:51,800 --> 00:02:55,990
party to support it, so I may not get
all the help I need in one place.

59
00:02:55,990 --> 00:02:58,400
If you stick with Amazon AMIs,
you're gonna be safe.

60
00:02:58,400 --> 00:02:59,789
That doesn't mean don't
use the other ones.

61
00:02:59,789 --> 00:03:03,100
It's just understand the scenario
that you're deploying into to choose.

62
00:03:03,100 --> 00:03:06,000
So I'm going to filter this list
to just show me Amazon images,

63
00:03:06,000 --> 00:03:07,960
the AMIs that they built.

64
00:03:07,960 --> 00:03:11,150
And then under platforms
we can filter it even more.

65
00:03:11,150 --> 00:03:14,670
Now Amazon only produces
a certain amount of these images.

66
00:03:14,670 --> 00:03:17,080
Remember there were over 33,000 of them?

67
00:03:17,080 --> 00:03:19,870
And if I look, Amazon's producing 557,

68
00:03:19,870 --> 00:03:24,110
so a small percentage of the available
images are actually from Amazon.

69
00:03:24,110 --> 00:03:27,900
And when you look at the images
a lot of these are duplicates.

70
00:03:27,900 --> 00:03:31,550
I'm gonna sort them by name,
and convenient,

71
00:03:31,550 --> 00:03:34,700
some of them don't have names,
but if you look at some of them,

72
00:03:34,700 --> 00:03:38,160
if I sort by name, you'll notice
a lot of them have the same name.

73
00:03:38,160 --> 00:03:40,600
Like here's Amazon Elastic MapReduce.

74
00:03:40,600 --> 00:03:42,570
So if I'm going to deploy
MapReduce as a service,

75
00:03:42,570 --> 00:03:44,450
here are some of the different
ones that I can use.

76
00:03:44,450 --> 00:03:48,530
Well, there's different
dates attached to each one.

77
00:03:48,530 --> 00:03:51,290
Amazon updates their AMIs.

78
00:03:51,290 --> 00:03:55,950
If you're deploying it brand new,
you might as well take the newest one so

79
00:03:55,950 --> 00:03:57,770
it'll already have the updates.

80
00:03:57,770 --> 00:03:59,790
But if you deploy the old one,
that's fine too.

81
00:03:59,790 --> 00:04:02,780
You'll just have to do the updates
after it comes online.

82
00:04:02,780 --> 00:04:05,190
So why bother keeping the old ones?

83
00:04:05,190 --> 00:04:08,500
Well, if you're creating
an auto-scaling environment,

84
00:04:08,500 --> 00:04:11,400
you may want all of your
servers to be identical.

85
00:04:11,400 --> 00:04:16,340
So if I spawned a server earlier this
year and I used the March 25th image,

86
00:04:16,340 --> 00:04:20,390
this guy right here,
even though there's new ones.

87
00:04:20,390 --> 00:04:23,010
There's an April 4th image here.

88
00:04:23,010 --> 00:04:27,610
I could use that to spawn new machines,
but if I use the same one as my source

89
00:04:27,610 --> 00:04:30,780
machine, I know it'll be identical and
everything's consistent.

90
00:04:30,780 --> 00:04:34,230
So that's why Amazon keeps
the older AMIs in place.

91
00:04:34,230 --> 00:04:40,270
So while it says 557,
the number is probably closer to 57.

92
00:04:40,270 --> 00:04:44,195
There's a lot of duplication in here with
their AMIs just because they're giving you

93
00:04:44,195 --> 00:04:45,330
the older versions too.

94
00:04:46,460 --> 00:04:50,430
Now this screen is only displaying 50 AMIs
at a time, so it might take a while to

95
00:04:50,430 --> 00:04:53,910
browse around through here, so
it can be kinda challenging.

96
00:04:53,910 --> 00:04:57,400
But there's a few differences that
we're gonna see when we pick an AMI.

97
00:04:58,880 --> 00:05:03,590
In the naming convention that Amazon uses,
they'll designate a few different things.

98
00:05:03,590 --> 00:05:06,978
One of those things, unfortunately,
is not normally the OS.

99
00:05:06,978 --> 00:05:10,990
So when you look at these a lot of times
you don't necessarily know, is it Linux,

100
00:05:10,990 --> 00:05:13,709
is it Windows or whatever,
it may be denoted in there.

101
00:05:13,709 --> 00:05:17,499
But you can use the platforms
link to filter that down.

102
00:05:17,499 --> 00:05:21,245
So if I just want to see Windows AMIs I
can filter it and here they are.

103
00:05:21,245 --> 00:05:24,620
And so here's some Windows 2008,
Windows 2012.

104
00:05:24,620 --> 00:05:26,130
I can see each of those.

105
00:05:26,130 --> 00:05:28,510
And some of these are just
generic installs.

106
00:05:28,510 --> 00:05:31,050
Some of these have other
software installed on them.

107
00:05:31,050 --> 00:05:34,700
Some of them are English versus
Chinese versus whatever.

108
00:05:34,700 --> 00:05:37,048
So you can pick based on what you need.

109
00:05:37,048 --> 00:05:41,670
I've got 134 different
Windows images here.

110
00:05:41,670 --> 00:05:44,370
But at the end of the day,
they're either Windows Server 2008 or

111
00:05:44,370 --> 00:05:47,100
Windows Server 2012, so
it's really just two OSs.

112
00:05:47,100 --> 00:05:50,080
But 134 different variations of it.

113
00:05:50,080 --> 00:05:51,870
And so I'll need to go through and pick.

114
00:05:51,870 --> 00:05:55,380
Do I want it to have Microsoft SQL
deployed on it already or not?

115
00:05:55,380 --> 00:05:56,970
Do I just want a base install?

116
00:05:56,970 --> 00:05:59,240
So you go through and
pick the appropriate one.

117
00:05:59,240 --> 00:06:03,110
And you can use search criteria to hunt
and find various things this way, but

118
00:06:03,110 --> 00:06:03,850
you can go through.

119
00:06:03,850 --> 00:06:06,770
And again, there will be
multiple versions of each one

120
00:06:06,770 --> 00:06:09,230
based on updates that have
been applied and so forth.

121
00:06:10,310 --> 00:06:14,190
On the Linux side,
you'll notice if I choose CentOS, well,

122
00:06:14,190 --> 00:06:16,820
there's a couple that are in here but
not many.

123
00:06:16,820 --> 00:06:18,420
And that's because Amazon,

124
00:06:18,420 --> 00:06:22,880
on the Linux side, they actually
curate their own Linux distribution.

125
00:06:22,880 --> 00:06:26,570
If I change this from
CentOS to Amazon Linux.

126
00:06:26,570 --> 00:06:30,230
Amazon Linux is a special version of
Linux that Amazon themselves curates.

127
00:06:30,230 --> 00:06:33,800
They maintain their own updates servers,
their own repositories.

128
00:06:33,800 --> 00:06:37,070
It's built on top of CentOS,
so it is effectively CentOS.

129
00:06:37,070 --> 00:06:39,090
If you know how to use that,
you know how to use this.

130
00:06:39,090 --> 00:06:42,250
The difference is that Amazon
has a lot more support for

131
00:06:42,250 --> 00:06:44,350
it because they manage
what goes inside of it.

132
00:06:44,350 --> 00:06:46,550
So this is the one that I normally use.

133
00:06:46,550 --> 00:06:48,850
I usually use the Amazon Linux deployment.

134
00:06:48,850 --> 00:06:51,470
But you can pick and
choose based on what you want.

135
00:06:51,470 --> 00:06:53,790
If you wanna do Ubuntu,

136
00:06:53,790 --> 00:06:57,650
you'll notice Amazon doesn't
have any distributions for that.

137
00:06:57,650 --> 00:06:58,720
Doesn't mean you can't do it.

138
00:06:58,720 --> 00:07:00,940
You'll just have to find
it from another vendor.

139
00:07:00,940 --> 00:07:05,060
So if I go to all images in Ubuntu,
you'll see there's quite a few.

140
00:07:05,060 --> 00:07:09,140
There's actually 10,000 different
AMIs that are available.

141
00:07:09,140 --> 00:07:10,050
They're just not from Amazon.

142
00:07:11,260 --> 00:07:12,930
So this is a big decision for us.

143
00:07:12,930 --> 00:07:16,650
When we go to create a new instance,
we've gotta figure out what image to use.

144
00:07:16,650 --> 00:07:18,620
And there's a lot of images.

145
00:07:18,620 --> 00:07:22,530
Fortunately, when you use an image
you can choose to flag it so

146
00:07:22,530 --> 00:07:23,920
that it will be one of your favorites.

147
00:07:23,920 --> 00:07:27,740
You can use tags down here so
you can easily find it again.

148
00:07:27,740 --> 00:07:29,830
So you don't have to hunt and peck.

149
00:07:29,830 --> 00:07:32,030
Now if you use the Launch Instance Wizard,

150
00:07:32,030 --> 00:07:33,720
they actually make it
a little easier there.

151
00:07:33,720 --> 00:07:37,670
So if you have no clue where to start,
just use the Launch Instance Wizard and

152
00:07:37,670 --> 00:07:42,220
in there you'll get a default list
of the main AMIs to pick from.

153
00:07:42,220 --> 00:07:43,375
That makes it easy.

154
00:07:43,375 --> 00:07:45,477
But if you know exactly what you want,

155
00:07:45,477 --> 00:07:49,877
what you want to do is go down here to
AMI, find the AMI that you're looking for,

156
00:07:49,877 --> 00:07:54,250
so find whatever specific one it
is that you're trying to find.

157
00:07:54,250 --> 00:07:58,680
And then you'll choose it,
to create an instance from.

158
00:07:58,680 --> 00:08:02,320
Notice when I checked off this AMI,
I had a launch button right here.

159
00:08:02,320 --> 00:08:06,400
That will let me create an image
based on that AMI specifically.

160
00:08:06,400 --> 00:08:10,910
If I use the launch instance button right
here, I just get a smaller selection.

161
00:08:10,910 --> 00:08:14,140
Versus if I go down here to the AMIs,
I get the whole selection.

162
00:08:14,140 --> 00:08:18,460
So the process is the same, but the
selection is what's different, all right?

163
00:08:18,460 --> 00:08:20,700
Now, if you are gonna browse the AMIs,

164
00:08:20,700 --> 00:08:22,790
there's a few things you'll
notice in the naming convention.

165
00:08:22,790 --> 00:08:25,510
And let me just kind of
highlight that real quick, so

166
00:08:25,510 --> 00:08:29,160
we can get an idea,
get a good handle on this.

167
00:08:29,160 --> 00:08:33,060
When you look,
notice how some of them end in -ebs.

168
00:08:33,060 --> 00:08:38,980
Some of them end in -S3, and I don't see
any but some will end in dash gp2, also.

169
00:08:38,980 --> 00:08:40,250
There's one that ends in dash gp2.

170
00:08:40,250 --> 00:08:44,290
That is talking about what
type of storage they use.

171
00:08:44,290 --> 00:08:49,530
For most of us we want EBS,
EBS is the elastic block storage.

172
00:08:49,530 --> 00:08:52,940
Those are hard drives that we can
easily replicate between data centers.

173
00:08:52,940 --> 00:08:54,080
They're redundant.

174
00:08:54,080 --> 00:08:56,190
You get good performance out of them.

175
00:08:56,190 --> 00:08:56,830
EBS storage.

176
00:08:56,830 --> 00:08:58,370
That's what we normally use.

177
00:08:59,410 --> 00:09:03,580
If we have a server where we
want to pay a little less,

178
00:09:03,580 --> 00:09:05,740
performance isn't our problem but
storage is.

179
00:09:05,740 --> 00:09:08,150
We want a lot of storage and
we're not worried about speed.

180
00:09:08,150 --> 00:09:10,980
You can choose to store it in S3 instead.

181
00:09:10,980 --> 00:09:13,410
If you use the simple storage service,
S3, and

182
00:09:13,410 --> 00:09:16,340
put the drives there you're not going
to get as fast performance out of it.

183
00:09:16,340 --> 00:09:19,000
So for
database servers it's out of the question.

184
00:09:19,000 --> 00:09:21,700
But if you've got a major download server
where you're gonna be storing a lot of

185
00:09:21,700 --> 00:09:24,440
download files, you can store
the hard drives for it in S3.

186
00:09:24,440 --> 00:09:27,870
It'll be a little less expensive
on the storage side and

187
00:09:27,870 --> 00:09:30,430
it will work perfectly fine for
serving up those files.

188
00:09:31,630 --> 00:09:36,000
The third option is GP2 and GP2,
that stands for General Purpose 2.

189
00:09:36,000 --> 00:09:38,550
The EBS, those used to be
our general purpose drives.

190
00:09:38,550 --> 00:09:40,248
You'd use them for pretty much everything.

191
00:09:40,248 --> 00:09:44,410
General purpose two is the new
generation of those EBS drives, and

192
00:09:44,410 --> 00:09:48,660
they're on SSD, solid state drives,
or solid state digital drives.

193
00:09:48,660 --> 00:09:54,310
So solid state drives are a lot more
expensive and they run a lot faster.

194
00:09:54,310 --> 00:09:56,040
So, we usually want those.

195
00:09:56,040 --> 00:09:59,080
You do pay a little bit more,it's not too
terrible much more to store on there.

196
00:09:59,080 --> 00:10:01,550
So if you've got a server that
performance is your key and

197
00:10:01,550 --> 00:10:04,150
you want SSD's you'll want
to choose the GP2 image.

198
00:10:05,420 --> 00:10:08,490
But if it's just a normal server,
you're not necessarily with the SSDs,

199
00:10:08,490 --> 00:10:10,660
you can do EBS and
it'll be on magnetic drives.

200
00:10:10,660 --> 00:10:12,280
Your traditional spinning disks.

201
00:10:12,280 --> 00:10:16,500
They're fast, they're scuzzy, most of
them are either 10,000 or 15,000 RPMs, so

202
00:10:16,500 --> 00:10:17,700
they're fast.

203
00:10:17,700 --> 00:10:19,660
Not as fast as SSDs.

204
00:10:19,660 --> 00:10:21,950
So that's one of the decisions we have.

205
00:10:21,950 --> 00:10:27,490
Right here I've got three different
of these Amazon AMIs right here.

206
00:10:27,490 --> 00:10:29,440
One is EBS, one is GB2, one is S3.

207
00:10:29,440 --> 00:10:31,150
They're identical.

208
00:10:31,150 --> 00:10:35,980
They are identical installations of Amazon
Linux, but different types of storage.

209
00:10:35,980 --> 00:10:37,640
So I pick and choose based on the storage.

210
00:10:38,650 --> 00:10:42,520
The other things we'll see here in the
naming convention, I've got the platform.

211
00:10:42,520 --> 00:10:45,153
Notice how all of these are x86_64.

212
00:10:45,153 --> 00:10:49,280
That means these are the 64
bit versions of Linux.

213
00:10:49,280 --> 00:10:51,210
You'll find other ones
that just say x86 and

214
00:10:51,210 --> 00:10:53,520
those would be the 32
bit versions of Linux.

215
00:10:53,520 --> 00:10:58,860
When you deploy a Windows or a Linux AMI,
you need to pick between 32 and 64 bit.

216
00:10:58,860 --> 00:11:03,770
If you're doing a micro instance,
it's only got 600 some odd megs of memory,

217
00:11:03,770 --> 00:11:05,630
it doesn't have a lot of power to it.

218
00:11:05,630 --> 00:11:08,810
A 32 instance is fine, but
if you start scaling up,

219
00:11:08,810 --> 00:11:12,820
once you get to a medium instance
that has 3.75 gigs of memory or

220
00:11:12,820 --> 00:11:16,850
more, you really benefit
from having a 64 bit OS.

221
00:11:16,850 --> 00:11:19,710
Four gigs is kinda the limit with 32 bit,
and

222
00:11:19,710 --> 00:11:23,350
once you cross four gigs you
