682
00:32:22,370 --> 00:32:25,540
So I know that first one, is my LINUX box,
and I can go, and give it a name.

683
00:32:25,540 --> 00:32:28,703
So I'll call that my LINUX VM, and

684
00:32:28,703 --> 00:32:34,170
then I'll name this other one,
this one's my Windows VM.

685
00:32:35,940 --> 00:32:38,290
Those names have absolutely
zero effect on the VM.

686
00:32:38,290 --> 00:32:40,110
The VM itself,
doesn't even know that changed.

687
00:32:40,110 --> 00:32:40,870
It's just for us.

688
00:32:40,870 --> 00:32:42,060
It's for administrative purposes.

689
00:32:42,060 --> 00:32:44,350
We can tell those apart, and
recognize what they are.

690
00:32:46,140 --> 00:32:47,000
All right.

691
00:32:47,000 --> 00:32:49,500
Now my Linux VM is up,
and running, and happy.

692
00:32:49,500 --> 00:32:52,240
You'll see my status checks,
running two out of two checks, are happy.

693
00:32:52,240 --> 00:32:53,810
It's up, and it's perfect.

694
00:32:53,810 --> 00:32:56,170
My Windows machine still
says initializing.

695
00:32:56,170 --> 00:32:56,900
When it boots up,

696
00:32:56,900 --> 00:33:00,840
it has to start some services that let it
check in with Amazon to monitor health.

697
00:33:00,840 --> 00:33:03,620
And so it's not really ready for
production use,

698
00:33:03,620 --> 00:33:06,360
until I see those status checks go green.

699
00:33:06,360 --> 00:33:07,830
So I don't wanna mess with that one.

700
00:33:07,830 --> 00:33:10,770
This screen will update periodically,
and I'll see that change, but

701
00:33:10,770 --> 00:33:11,850
my Linux one is done.

702
00:33:11,850 --> 00:33:15,140
So I'll take that Linux one, and
I'm gonna go ahead, and stop it for now.

703
00:33:15,140 --> 00:33:16,470
I'll just choose stop.

704
00:33:16,470 --> 00:33:18,890
It's warning me that it's gonna go ahead,
and shut it down.

705
00:33:18,890 --> 00:33:22,120
If I had any ephemeral storage,
which we'll talk about later.

706
00:33:22,120 --> 00:33:24,430
The ephemeral storage gets
deleted when you shut down.

707
00:33:24,430 --> 00:33:25,210
So it's just warning me.

708
00:33:25,210 --> 00:33:27,040
I don't have any, so I'll say yes to stop.

709
00:33:28,310 --> 00:33:29,790
And it's gonna go ahead,
and shut that one down.

710
00:33:29,790 --> 00:33:34,123
And as soon as this other one checks in,
and gets healthy, I'll shut it down too.

711
00:33:34,123 --> 00:33:35,356
All right.
So in this segment,

712
00:33:35,356 --> 00:33:37,804
we gotta a chance to see,
creating those virtual machines,

713
00:33:37,804 --> 00:33:39,130
getting them put in place.

714
00:33:39,130 --> 00:33:41,240
We saw the hard way,
where we get all the options.

715
00:33:41,240 --> 00:33:44,630
We saw the easy way, with the little
wizard, we can quickly get them deployed.

716
00:33:44,630 --> 00:33:46,873
Really need to be able to
build up that environment.

717
00:33:46,873 --> 00:33:47,415
All right.

718
00:33:47,415 --> 00:33:49,250
Well I hope you guys enjoyed this segment.

719
00:33:49,250 --> 00:33:51,980
Stay tuned, we've got more
Amazon web services, coming up.

episodes.title: Resizing An Instance
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,008 --> 00:00:08,958
[SOUND]
In this segment,

2
00:00:08,958 --> 00:00:13,560
we're gonna take a look at resizing our
Amazon Web Services, or EC2 instance.

3
00:00:13,560 --> 00:00:18,420
It's no secret here at the ITProTV
studios that I'm a bit of a tightwad.

4
00:00:18,420 --> 00:00:19,830
I don't like to spend money.

5
00:00:19,830 --> 00:00:24,360
And so when I bring up new servers and
Amazon Web Services, I try and

6
00:00:24,360 --> 00:00:29,350
keep them at the lowest level of hardware
required so that my bill is smaller.

7
00:00:29,350 --> 00:00:32,320
We don't want to waste money
on resources we're not using.

8
00:00:32,320 --> 00:00:36,520
So when I'm building up a new environment,
when I'm bringing up web servers, and

9
00:00:36,520 --> 00:00:41,510
database servers, file servers, whatever
it is that I'm bringing up inside of EC2,

10
00:00:41,510 --> 00:00:43,430
I'll typically use micro-instances.

11
00:00:43,430 --> 00:00:45,970
I'll use the smallest instance possible.

12
00:00:45,970 --> 00:00:48,798
Because when I'm building the environment,
I'm the only one in there.

13
00:00:48,798 --> 00:00:53,470
And a micro-instance is perfectly good
enough to handle almost everything.

14
00:00:53,470 --> 00:00:54,940
Databases get a little bit iffy.

15
00:00:54,940 --> 00:00:57,390
But pretty much everything else
works really well in them.

16
00:00:57,390 --> 00:00:59,700
And so
you can build the environment that way.

17
00:00:59,700 --> 00:01:01,890
And then when you're ready to
move it into production, or

18
00:01:01,890 --> 00:01:05,925
ready to put it under load testing,
then you bump up the hardware.

19
00:01:05,925 --> 00:01:07,590
Cuz it might take me days or weeks,

20
00:01:07,590 --> 00:01:11,990
it might even take me months to build
up a really complex environment.

21
00:01:11,990 --> 00:01:16,710
I don't want to pay for extra large
instances that are costing me $2 an hour

22
00:01:16,710 --> 00:01:21,660
or something like that, when I could be
doing micro instances at $0.02 an hour.

23
00:01:21,660 --> 00:01:24,310
Fortunately inside of
Amazon they make it really

24
00:01:24,310 --> 00:01:27,420
easy to increase the hardware
level of your instances.

25
00:01:27,420 --> 00:01:28,610
It's really pretty simple.

26
00:01:30,030 --> 00:01:32,650
I give the scenario of me
purposely starting off lower.

27
00:01:32,650 --> 00:01:33,420
Maybe you don't.

28
00:01:33,420 --> 00:01:36,430
Maybe you have a web server and
you're running on medium instances, or

29
00:01:36,430 --> 00:01:39,730
whatever it is that you need, and
all of a sudden you have a video go viral.

30
00:01:39,730 --> 00:01:41,310
And it really just spirals out there and

31
00:01:41,310 --> 00:01:45,760
tons of people are starting to hit that
video, and your server's getting crushed.

32
00:01:45,760 --> 00:01:46,330
All right.

33
00:01:46,330 --> 00:01:50,280
Well, you can quickly bump up
the resources to met your need.

34
00:01:50,280 --> 00:01:54,980
Now, in Amazon web services there's
two different ideas of handling load.

35
00:01:54,980 --> 00:01:58,840
You've got scaling up versus scaling out.

36
00:01:58,840 --> 00:02:01,970
Scaling out means we add more instances.

37
00:02:01,970 --> 00:02:05,560
So I might have one web server, I add
a second, and a third, and a fourth, and

38
00:02:05,560 --> 00:02:07,570
I put a load balancer in front of them.

39
00:02:07,570 --> 00:02:10,330
Scaling out requires development effort.

40
00:02:10,330 --> 00:02:12,920
You've gotta have a website that's
designed to run on more that one server.

41
00:02:12,920 --> 00:02:15,360
You've gotta have a database server
that's separate that they can all access.

42
00:02:15,360 --> 00:02:18,920
You've got security concerns,
load balancers, auto scale groups,

43
00:02:18,920 --> 00:02:20,670
all that complexity.

44
00:02:20,670 --> 00:02:23,390
So scaling out gives you the most power.

45
00:02:23,390 --> 00:02:25,470
You can scale out to huge environments.

46
00:02:25,470 --> 00:02:27,440
But it requires a lot of planning.

47
00:02:27,440 --> 00:02:28,730
Scaling up,

48
00:02:28,730 --> 00:02:33,710
on the other hand, is where you just take
your existing VM and bump up its hardware.

49
00:02:33,710 --> 00:02:36,730
Give it more memory, give it more CPU,
give it more storage.

50
00:02:36,730 --> 00:02:39,450
You resize that instance.

51
00:02:39,450 --> 00:02:42,350
And that doesn't require
much planning at all, right?

52
00:02:42,350 --> 00:02:43,760
We're not changing our software.

53
00:02:43,760 --> 00:02:44,690
We're not changing our IPs.

54
00:02:44,690 --> 00:02:46,230
We're not using load balancers.

55
00:02:46,230 --> 00:02:48,460
We're just taking
an individual instance and

56
00:02:48,460 --> 00:02:51,080
increasing the hardware
services available for it.

57
00:02:51,080 --> 00:02:53,320
And you can increase or decrease.

58
00:02:53,320 --> 00:02:57,380
So, maybe you work for a school.

59
00:02:57,380 --> 00:03:00,537
And so, during the school year
when the student are there,

60
00:03:00,537 --> 00:03:02,360
your servers are slammed.

61
00:03:02,360 --> 00:03:05,620
And so you're bumped up to
really high hardware resources.

62
00:03:05,620 --> 00:03:09,190
But during the summertime
the students all go home.

63
00:03:09,190 --> 00:03:10,920
The servers are kind
of sitting there idle.

64
00:03:10,920 --> 00:03:14,290
You can actually lower them
to lower resources and

65
00:03:14,290 --> 00:03:15,560
save some money over the summer.

66
00:03:15,560 --> 00:03:19,000
So there's all sorts of different
reasons for resizing the instances.

67
00:03:19,000 --> 00:03:19,890
Let's take a look at how it's done.

68
00:03:20,930 --> 00:03:22,370
The process is actually the same.

69
00:03:22,370 --> 00:03:23,920
Whether you're using Linux or Windows,

70
00:03:23,920 --> 00:03:28,490
it's kind of operating system independent
because it's a hardware change.

71
00:03:28,490 --> 00:03:31,330
We go into our EC2 console.

72
00:03:32,590 --> 00:03:35,340
And once we get in there,
we go into our instances list,

73
00:03:35,340 --> 00:03:36,990
and we'll see the instances
that we've got.

74
00:03:36,990 --> 00:03:40,640
I've got a Linux instance and a Windows
instance both just kinda sitting there.

75
00:03:40,640 --> 00:03:44,740
They're idling, running,
not doing anything too fancy.

76
00:03:44,740 --> 00:03:47,720
For both of these,
I brought them up as micros.

77
00:03:47,720 --> 00:03:49,710
So they're very, very small.

78
00:03:49,710 --> 00:03:52,257
They'll have a little
over 600 megs of memory.

79
00:03:52,257 --> 00:03:53,970
They'll have one virtual CPU.

80
00:03:53,970 --> 00:03:57,570
They'll have six CPU
burst credits an hour, so

81
00:03:57,570 --> 00:04:01,300
that they're really, that one CPU they
have is really being held to 20%.

82
00:04:01,300 --> 00:04:05,520
So, these are really low on the resources.

83
00:04:05,520 --> 00:04:06,700
Well, I can bump that up.

84
00:04:07,950 --> 00:04:10,910
You can pick any of your virtual machines,
and you can increase them.

85
00:04:10,910 --> 00:04:13,340
And the way that we do that
is through our action menu.

86
00:04:13,340 --> 00:04:16,150
But before I go to resize it,

87
00:04:16,150 --> 00:04:19,870
I need to be aware that I'm changing
the hardware of this instance.

88
00:04:19,870 --> 00:04:23,410
And most operating systems
really don't like that.

89
00:04:23,410 --> 00:04:29,060
And so the official procedure for doing
this is to shut the instance down first.

90
00:04:29,060 --> 00:04:32,340
So resizing an instance like
this involves some downtime.

91
00:04:32,340 --> 00:04:35,169
We're gonna take the server offline,
so you wanna schedule this for

92
00:04:35,169 --> 00:04:36,700
after hours or whatever.

93
00:04:36,700 --> 00:04:38,150
Now you might be saying to yourself,
well Don,

94
00:04:38,150 --> 00:04:41,000
I wanna be able to react to
heavy load on my server, and

95
00:04:41,000 --> 00:04:44,670
taking the server offline is not exactly
how we react to heavy load, is it?

96
00:04:44,670 --> 00:04:46,810
Well, there's two arguments here.

97
00:04:46,810 --> 00:04:48,980
Argument number one is that if
your server's under a heavy enough

98
00:04:48,980 --> 00:04:51,740
load that it's getting crushed,
it might as well be off.

99
00:04:51,740 --> 00:04:54,440
Because most users are not being
able to get to your system.

100
00:04:54,440 --> 00:04:57,420
So you can shut it down,
bump up the resources, bring it back up.

101
00:04:57,420 --> 00:05:01,290
And after a small outage,
now you've got heavier resources.

102
00:05:01,290 --> 00:05:06,250
Argument number two is, if you wanna
really handle load without downtime,

103
00:05:06,250 --> 00:05:08,480
you need to be using a load balancer.

104
00:05:08,480 --> 00:05:12,010
If you have more than one server behind
a load balancer, or even if you have

105
00:05:12,010 --> 00:05:15,980
one server behind a load balancer, that
sounds like it doesn't make any sense.

106
00:05:15,980 --> 00:05:18,410
Why would I put one server
behind a load balancer?

107
00:05:18,410 --> 00:05:21,810
But it's because I'm planning for
adding more later.

108
00:05:21,810 --> 00:05:24,840
And so as that one server gets busy,
I can leave it online, and

109
00:05:24,840 --> 00:05:29,260
I can bring up more servers behind
the load balancer to pick up the slack.

110
00:05:29,260 --> 00:05:32,040
That works without taking
the server offline.

111
00:05:32,040 --> 00:05:35,200
So scaling out, no service interruption.

112
00:05:35,200 --> 00:05:37,250
Scaling up, there is.

113
00:05:37,250 --> 00:05:39,960
So I'm gonna take my Linux VM and
I'm gonna shut it down first.

114
00:05:39,960 --> 00:05:42,660
I'm gonna go under my Actions menu, and

115
00:05:42,660 --> 00:05:45,130
we'll see down here where I can go and
stop it.

116
00:05:45,130 --> 00:05:46,430
So I'm gonna go ahead and stop it.

117
00:05:47,960 --> 00:05:48,680
So it's just warning me.

118
00:05:48,680 --> 00:05:49,480
It's gonna shut it down.

119
00:05:49,480 --> 00:05:52,670
If I have any temporary storage, or
femoral storage, it's gonna get erased.

120
00:05:52,670 --> 00:05:53,230
I'm okay with that.

121
00:05:54,600 --> 00:05:56,630
I know I've said this in other segments,
but

122
00:05:56,630 --> 00:06:01,040
always be careful to make sure you
choose stop and not terminate.

123
00:06:01,040 --> 00:06:02,650
Terminate means shut it down and
delete it,

124
00:06:02,650 --> 00:06:05,020
and that's not exactly what we want here.

125
00:06:05,020 --> 00:06:07,500
That'll create an all new kind of
outage you'll have to deal with.

126
00:06:07,500 --> 00:06:08,780
So we want to make sure we choose stop.

127
00:06:08,780 --> 00:06:11,470
That's gonna gracefully shut
down that operating system.

128
00:06:11,470 --> 00:06:15,030
And, depending on the OS,
this can take seconds, minutes.

129
00:06:15,030 --> 00:06:18,550
If you have a really, really poorly
configured one, it might take even longer.

130
00:06:18,550 --> 00:06:21,510
But it shouldn't take too
terribly long to stop.

131
00:06:21,510 --> 00:06:26,740
Once it's stopped, under the Action menu,
will have this Change Instance Type.

132
00:06:26,740 --> 00:06:31,040
It was grayed out when I first went to
it because the instance was running.

133
00:06:31,040 --> 00:06:35,300
Now that the instance has stopped,
the Change Instance Type lights up.

134
00:06:35,300 --> 00:06:39,830
And now I can choose that, and it shows
that it's currently at T2 micro, and

135
00:06:39,830 --> 00:06:43,640
I can drop that down and
pick from my different instances.

136
00:06:43,640 --> 00:06:48,130
So if I want to bump it up to a small or
medium, or whatever, I can do that.

137
00:06:48,130 --> 00:06:50,390
I can even go between
the different generations and

138
00:06:50,390 --> 00:06:55,230
the different types there, so you'll see
some of the gen two, gen three, and so

139
00:06:55,230 --> 00:06:57,810
on, as they're all kind
of laid out right here.

140
00:06:57,810 --> 00:07:00,430
So we just pick which one we
want based on our resources.

141
00:07:00,430 --> 00:07:04,090
Now it doesn't tell us the resources of
each of these, so you do need to go and

142
00:07:04,090 --> 00:07:05,030
do your research.

143
00:07:05,030 --> 00:07:08,030
Pull up the instance list that's
published on Amazon's web site and

144
00:07:08,030 --> 00:07:09,810
figure out the resources you need.

145
00:07:09,810 --> 00:07:12,110
So I'm gonna bump up to an M3 medium.

146
00:07:12,110 --> 00:07:13,580
All right, so I'll choose M3 medium.

147
00:07:13,580 --> 00:07:17,360
And it's also offering
to upgrade my storage.

148
00:07:17,360 --> 00:07:21,850
We have EBS, so I'm already using
the Elastic Block Store from my storage on

149
00:07:21,850 --> 00:07:24,480
this system, but
it's offering to do EBS Optimized.

150
00:07:24,480 --> 00:07:27,620
That's where they move it to
the really fast drives for us and

151
00:07:27,620 --> 00:07:29,000
give us better performance.

152
00:07:29,000 --> 00:07:30,730
Additional charges apply.

153
00:07:30,730 --> 00:07:33,580
Well, additional charges apply
to the instance type too.

154
00:07:33,580 --> 00:07:37,530
When I bump up,
I'm moving into a new pricing tier.

155
00:07:37,530 --> 00:07:41,940
One word of caution,
if you've done a reserved instance,

156
00:07:41,940 --> 00:07:46,220
let's say you reserved
a small instance for a year.

157
00:07:46,220 --> 00:07:48,890
So I've got a one year
contract on a small instance.

158
00:07:48,890 --> 00:07:53,910
When you bump the VM up to a medium,
it's no longer in your reserved instance.

159
00:07:53,910 --> 00:07:58,090
So when you bump it up to a medium,
it's now an on-demand medium, so

160
00:07:58,090 --> 00:08:01,380
you're pricing model is going
to be higher there too.

161
00:08:01,380 --> 00:08:04,510
What about that small instance
you reserved for a year?

162
00:08:04,510 --> 00:08:05,580
It's still sitting there.

163
00:08:05,580 --> 00:08:09,810
You can bring up a new server and stick
it that one year reserve instance, but

164
00:08:09,810 --> 00:08:13,170
otherwise it's sitting there empty.

165
00:08:13,170 --> 00:08:16,070
And you don't pay for
a server that's not running, but

166
00:08:16,070 --> 00:08:18,260
you're taking advantage of
that price break either.

167
00:08:18,260 --> 00:08:20,860
So just be aware that with
the reserved instances, when you

168
00:08:20,860 --> 00:08:24,110
change the instance type, you might not
be under the same pricing tier anymore.

169
00:08:24,110 --> 00:08:27,810
All right, so I'm going to move to medium,
and I'll apply that.

170
00:08:27,810 --> 00:08:30,390
It only takes a few seconds to apply.

171
00:08:30,390 --> 00:08:34,450
Amazon is taking this server that's
offline and it's attaching different CPUs.

172
00:08:34,450 --> 00:08:36,860
I only had one CPU on that Linux VM.

173
00:08:36,860 --> 00:08:40,850
When I go to medium, I'll have two,
and it's removing the 20% governor.

174
00:08:40,850 --> 00:08:44,040
It's removing the burst credits,
because on a medium,

175
00:08:44,040 --> 00:08:46,440
you actually get full
access to those CPUs.

176
00:08:46,440 --> 00:08:47,620
It's bumping up my memory.

177
00:08:47,620 --> 00:08:49,490
I'm trying to do this from memory myself.

178
00:08:49,490 --> 00:08:52,580
I think on a medium instance
you get 7.5 GB of memory, so

179
00:08:52,580 --> 00:08:56,500
it's bumping that up, and
now I've got a medium instance.

180
00:08:56,500 --> 00:09:00,255
And I can fire that up and
my system will now show the new resources.

181
00:09:00,255 --> 00:09:04,737
It'll show that I've got that additional
memory or processor or whatever.

182
00:09:04,737 --> 00:09:08,220
Now when you boot your operating system
up, it's gonna recognize that change,

183
00:09:08,220 --> 00:09:09,960
and it starts to take advantage of it.

184
00:09:09,960 --> 00:09:14,890
So your down time is really however
long it takes to shut the VM down, and

185
00:09:14,890 --> 00:09:16,490
then start it back up again.

186
00:09:16,490 --> 00:09:20,010
So you should be able to do this in one or
two minutes.

187
00:09:20,010 --> 00:09:21,540
So if you're under heavy load,

188
00:09:21,540 --> 00:09:25,990
yes you're creating an outage, but
you've already got that outage in a way.

189
00:09:25,990 --> 00:09:28,860
A lot of your customers are not
getting the access, you bump it up and

190
00:09:28,860 --> 00:09:29,660
now you're in business.

191
00:09:29,660 --> 00:09:32,040
But if you can do this after
hours that's even better.

192
00:09:32,040 --> 00:09:35,670
So here we've bumped up that resource,
and there we go.

193
00:09:35,670 --> 00:09:38,080
Now, one other little
caveat I want to throw out.

194
00:09:38,080 --> 00:09:43,050
If you've got a really old instance that's
been running in Amazon for a long time.

195
00:09:45,110 --> 00:09:48,310
Before EBS, before Elastic Block Store,
there was a different type of

196
00:09:48,310 --> 00:09:51,810
storage called an Instance Store,
and you may still see that.

197
00:09:51,810 --> 00:09:54,730
Now Amazon doesn't recommend people use it
anymore, so when you bring up new VM's, or

198
00:09:54,730 --> 00:09:56,880
new instances,
they're not gonna have that.

199
00:09:56,880 --> 00:09:58,250
But if you have ones
that have been around for

200
00:09:58,250 --> 00:10:01,340
a while they might still
have Instant Store storage.

201
00:10:01,340 --> 00:10:05,190
And if they do,
you can't change their instance type.

202
00:10:05,190 --> 00:10:08,550
With those instances they're locked
into the type that you made.

203
00:10:08,550 --> 00:10:11,910
So if you ever have an instance
that you shut down and

204
00:10:11,910 --> 00:10:15,260
that option doesn't show up under your
Action menu, you just can't change

205
00:10:15,260 --> 00:10:18,820
the instance type, it might be
that has Instant Store storage.

206
00:10:18,820 --> 00:10:19,950
And if that's the case,

207
00:10:19,950 --> 00:10:23,470
the only way to scale it up is
to create an all new instance.

208
00:10:23,470 --> 00:10:26,890
You create a new instance, you backup
your operating system day on one,

209
00:10:26,890 --> 00:10:29,220
you restore it through the other,
and there you go.

210
00:10:29,220 --> 00:10:30,470
Much more involved, right?

211
00:10:30,470 --> 00:10:33,420
Much longer downtime on that one,
cuz you've got to rebuild the system.

212
00:10:33,420 --> 00:10:35,500
So, not very convenient.

213
00:10:35,500 --> 00:10:38,380
Fortunately, the EBS volume ones,
they're not affected by that.

214
00:10:38,380 --> 00:10:42,170
And so any VMs that create over
the last few years will be fine.

215
00:10:42,170 --> 00:10:44,100
And it really is the few years.

216
00:10:44,100 --> 00:10:46,460
So, you'd have to have
an old virtual machine.

217
00:10:46,460 --> 00:10:48,060
One that's been kicking around for
five years or

218
00:10:48,060 --> 00:10:52,830
so that would have
an Instant Store storage on it.

219
00:10:52,830 --> 00:10:57,010
Windows VMs are the same way, cuz this is
hardware, it doesn't care what the OS is.

220
00:10:57,010 --> 00:10:58,600
We would just check off
our Windows machine and

221
00:10:58,600 --> 00:11:01,050
we would go to Change Instance Type.

222
00:11:01,050 --> 00:11:05,010
We can boot it up and run, and
now we're running on these new resources.

223
00:11:05,010 --> 00:11:09,671
And at the end of the day,
maybe this was just a one time thing,

224
00:11:09,671 --> 00:11:13,090
maybe you work for
somebody like H&R Block.

225
00:11:13,090 --> 00:11:13,610
Right?

226
00:11:13,610 --> 00:11:14,695
They're a tax company.

227
00:11:14,695 --> 00:11:17,540
And so, here in the US,
H&R Block is a tax company.

228
00:11:17,540 --> 00:11:19,390
They help you file your tax returns.

229
00:11:19,390 --> 00:11:22,920
And in the months of March and
April, or really,

230
00:11:22,920 --> 00:11:27,530
I guess January through April,
they are insanely busy.

231
00:11:27,530 --> 00:11:31,810
And so they'll bump all their servers
up cuz everybody is filing their taxes.

232
00:11:31,810 --> 00:11:35,890
But then after April,
that's when taxes are due, April 15th.

233
00:11:35,890 --> 00:11:39,050
And so after that, their usage drops.

234
00:11:39,050 --> 00:11:40,780
They actually have a lot
of seasonal employees.

235
00:11:40,780 --> 00:11:44,140
They actually cut employees
during the non active months.

236
00:11:44,140 --> 00:11:49,190
And so, they'll want to bump
up from January to April.

237
00:11:49,190 --> 00:11:53,740
But then, from May through December,
they'll want to step back down.

238
00:11:53,740 --> 00:11:56,480
And you can easily do that just
by choosing the instance, and

239
00:11:56,480 --> 00:11:59,690
going back here to Change Instance Type,
and

240
00:11:59,690 --> 00:12:03,100
switching right back to whatever
instance type it is that you need.

241
00:12:03,100 --> 00:12:04,570
So you can pick and choose.

242
00:12:04,570 --> 00:12:06,040
You can go up, and you can go down.

243
00:12:06,040 --> 00:12:10,170
And when you reboot,
your operating system will recognize that.

244
00:12:10,170 --> 00:12:13,600
All right, so
that is resizing an instance.

245
00:12:13,600 --> 00:12:18,930
Be aware that if you move up to a higher
instance that includes more storage,

246
00:12:18,930 --> 00:12:22,030
your operating system probably
won't recognize it right away.

247
00:12:22,030 --> 00:12:25,120
And that's because the storage is
talking about the hard drive itself.

248
00:12:25,120 --> 00:12:28,880
Your operating system creates
partitions inside of the storage.

249
00:12:28,880 --> 00:12:33,050
So if I bump up to a medium instance,
I get more storage.

250
00:12:33,050 --> 00:12:37,260
I'll need to go into my software,
into my OS, and in Linux or in Windows,

251
00:12:37,260 --> 00:12:41,090
I'll need to go and resize my partitions
to take advantage of that extra storage.

252
00:12:41,090 --> 00:12:45,690
If you do that,
when you step down to a smaller instance,

253
00:12:45,690 --> 00:12:48,000
you've got these bigger
drives that you're using now.

254
00:12:48,000 --> 00:12:50,070
And it's gonna cause some problems right,
and

255
00:12:50,070 --> 00:12:52,050
it's gonna change your billing structure.

256
00:12:52,050 --> 00:12:56,180
Because you're using more storage than
what that instance type normally contains.

257
00:12:56,180 --> 00:12:57,308
So be aware of that too.

258
00:12:57,308 --> 00:13:01,750
You might wanna step up to a higher
instance and not adjust your storage.

259
00:13:01,750 --> 00:13:03,950
Just because that when you step
back down it's all the same.

260
00:13:03,950 --> 00:13:08,470
And so that's oftentimes what I'll do,
is not mess with the storage piece.

261
00:13:08,470 --> 00:13:09,610
All right.

262
00:13:09,610 --> 00:13:13,030
So in this segment we got a chance
to see how to resize the instances.

263
00:13:13,030 --> 00:13:14,390
Really pretty easy, right?

264
00:13:14,390 --> 00:13:16,190
It does require some downtime though,

265
00:13:16,190 --> 00:13:18,600
so be aware of that and
always keep it in mind.

266
00:13:18,600 --> 00:13:20,080
All right,
well I hope you guys enjoyed the segment.

267
00:13:20,080 --> 00:13:24,670
Stay tuned, we've got more Amazon
web services coming up next.

episodes.title: Assigning A Static IP
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:06,725
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:07,887 --> 00:00:12,480
In this segment we're gonna take a look
at assigning a static IP to our servers.

3
00:00:12,480 --> 00:00:15,800
When you bring up an instance
inside of EC2 it's going

4
00:00:15,800 --> 00:00:18,220
to be assigned an IP address.

5
00:00:18,220 --> 00:00:21,330
Amazon will set up each of
your instances to use DHCP and

6
00:00:21,330 --> 00:00:26,220
they'll pull an address from the available
public pool of IPs that Amazon has.

7
00:00:26,220 --> 00:00:28,590
No actually, usually you get two IPs.

8
00:00:28,590 --> 00:00:32,580
An internal private IP that'll
be 172 dot something and

9
00:00:32,580 --> 00:00:35,260
then a public internet accessible IP.

10
00:00:35,260 --> 00:00:38,190
Now it's dynamically generated
when that instance starts and

11
00:00:38,190 --> 00:00:41,810
so you'll have that IP the entire
time that instance is on.

12
00:00:41,810 --> 00:00:46,000
But if you ever stop the instance,
if you shut it down, while it's off,

13
00:00:46,000 --> 00:00:50,150
that IP returns to the pool,
and Amazon is very busy, so

14
00:00:50,150 --> 00:00:53,150
the odds are that it's going to
be given out to another customer.

15
00:00:53,150 --> 00:00:56,870
So it's a rare day that
you're able to stop a VM and

16
00:00:56,870 --> 00:00:59,800
start it and
have it get the same IP address.

17
00:00:59,800 --> 00:01:03,610
Now, that may be fine if your server's
behind a load balancer you really don't

18
00:01:03,610 --> 00:01:05,220
care what IP address it has.

19
00:01:05,220 --> 00:01:07,860
And so you don't have to
mess around with static IPs.

20
00:01:07,860 --> 00:01:10,910
But if you want to know that your
server always has the same IP and

21
00:01:10,910 --> 00:01:15,940
you wanna update a DNS record to
reflect that you need a static IP.

22
00:01:15,940 --> 00:01:19,270
Now Amazon does not charge for static IPs.

23
00:01:19,270 --> 00:01:22,430
They're free as long as the server is on.

24
00:01:22,430 --> 00:01:24,840
If you shut the instance off though,

25
00:01:24,840 --> 00:01:27,300
that's when the IP is supposed
to go back into the pool.

26
00:01:27,300 --> 00:01:30,800
And so
Amazon starts to charge from that point.

27
00:01:30,800 --> 00:01:34,900
So static IPs do cost money if your
server is off, but most of us aren't

28
00:01:34,900 --> 00:01:38,190
in the business of bringing servers up
that are gonna be turned off, right?

29
00:01:38,190 --> 00:01:41,100
So most of us have our servers on,
and so we never have to pay for

30
00:01:41,100 --> 00:01:43,500
the static IPs, they're just a part of it.

31
00:01:43,500 --> 00:01:47,240
Amazon figures your server
has to have an IP anyway, so

32
00:01:47,240 --> 00:01:49,230
what do we care if it's
the same IP every time?

33
00:01:49,230 --> 00:01:51,030
So why charge extra for it, right?

34
00:01:51,030 --> 00:01:52,010
They only charge you extra for

35
00:01:52,010 --> 00:01:55,100
the scenario where you're not
returning it back to the pool.

36
00:01:55,100 --> 00:01:58,200
So, when I brought these two instances up,
I've got a Linux VM and

37
00:01:58,200 --> 00:02:03,270
a Windows VM, they came up, and
Amazon assigned them a dynamic IP.

38
00:02:03,270 --> 00:02:07,290
Now, the IP, it's not listed on this,
well, actually, it is, it's right there.

39
00:02:07,290 --> 00:02:08,480
We get it listed right here.

40
00:02:08,480 --> 00:02:11,550
It's not listed on the screen when I first
looked at it because my resolution is too

41
00:02:11,550 --> 00:02:13,450
low, but when I scroll over, there it is.

42
00:02:13,450 --> 00:02:16,412
I can see the two public
IPs it gave to my servers.

43
00:02:16,412 --> 00:02:19,280
Now there's a pretty big
gap between the IPs.

44
00:02:19,280 --> 00:02:21,620
It's not normally gonna issue
them in order or anything.

45
00:02:21,620 --> 00:02:24,920
It's just pulling them from
this available pool of IPs.

46
00:02:26,110 --> 00:02:30,210
It also gives them a public DNS name and
this DNS name,

47
00:02:30,210 --> 00:02:32,460
it's not really intended for
you to give your customers.

48
00:02:32,460 --> 00:02:33,746
If you look at it, it's pretty long.

49
00:02:33,746 --> 00:02:41,880
It's ec2-the IP
address.compute-1.amazonaws.com.

50
00:02:41,880 --> 00:02:45,590
This DNS name is used simply to
make life a little easier on us

51
00:02:45,590 --> 00:02:48,050
when we're tying it to load balancers and
things of that nature.

52
00:02:48,050 --> 00:02:52,470
But we're typically not going to use
this public DNS name right here.

53
00:02:52,470 --> 00:02:53,900
All right, but I've got these public IPs.

54
00:02:53,900 --> 00:02:57,750
My problem is, if I turn the VM off,
I might lose that IP.

55
00:02:57,750 --> 00:03:00,050
So if I go and
I update a bunch of my DNS records,

56
00:03:00,050 --> 00:03:02,540
if I say,
maybe I'm setting up a new FTP server.

57
00:03:02,540 --> 00:03:04,580
So I create ftp.itpro.tv.

58
00:03:04,580 --> 00:03:07,900
And I point it to this IP right here.

59
00:03:07,900 --> 00:03:10,650
And then one day, I shut this VM
down to do a little maintenance.

60
00:03:10,650 --> 00:03:13,710
Maybe I'm resizing my instance,
bumping it up or whatever.

61
00:03:13,710 --> 00:03:16,520
When I boot it back up,
it can get a different IP.

62
00:03:16,520 --> 00:03:19,450
Now that DNS record I made is wrong and
I gotta go and update that or

63
00:03:19,450 --> 00:03:23,170
my customers are getting unable to connect
to server errors, things of that nature.

64
00:03:23,170 --> 00:03:25,050
You don't want that to happen.

65
00:03:25,050 --> 00:03:27,000
So we wanna assign a static IP.

66
00:03:27,000 --> 00:03:32,310
Well, step one for
assigning an IP is to allocate the IP.

67
00:03:32,310 --> 00:03:36,710
We need to reach into Amazon's pool and
say, allocate an IP address for me.

68
00:03:36,710 --> 00:03:38,700
Give me this IP so I've got it available.

69
00:03:38,700 --> 00:03:41,960
All right, so
you can go down here to your network and

70
00:03:41,960 --> 00:03:45,420
security section, and go into elastic IPs.

71
00:03:46,940 --> 00:03:48,760
All right.
This is all inside of EC2.

72
00:03:48,760 --> 00:03:52,740
If I start from scratch, right, if I go
back to my console home I'm going into EC2

73
00:03:52,740 --> 00:03:57,490
where my instances are, and
then I'm going down to my elastic IPs.

74
00:03:57,490 --> 00:03:58,760
All right.

75
00:03:58,760 --> 00:04:02,010
They're called elastic
IPs because you can move

76
00:04:02,010 --> 00:04:04,000
these from server to server to server.

77
00:04:04,000 --> 00:04:06,980
It's really easy for you to bounce these
around and do various things with them, so

78
00:04:06,980 --> 00:04:08,340
that they're really flexible, and

79
00:04:08,340 --> 00:04:10,710
that's kind of where the elastic
terminology comes in.

80
00:04:10,710 --> 00:04:13,580
They can also be failed over
between data centers too.

81
00:04:13,580 --> 00:04:16,510
There's some extra things you have
to do to get that working, but

82
00:04:16,510 --> 00:04:18,560
it really does give you
a little bit of flexibility.

83
00:04:18,560 --> 00:04:23,100
All right, you can see I don't have
any addresses allocated right now.

84
00:04:23,100 --> 00:04:26,900
Doesn't mean I'm not using IPs,
I just don't have any static IPs.

85
00:04:26,900 --> 00:04:30,710
So I'll hit allocate new address and
it's gonna say are you sure?

86
00:04:30,710 --> 00:04:31,570
Yes, I am sure.

87
00:04:31,570 --> 00:04:32,880
Go ahead and do it.

88
00:04:32,880 --> 00:04:33,860
And there it is.

89
00:04:33,860 --> 00:04:34,940
I just got a static IP.

90
00:04:34,940 --> 00:04:35,920
All right.

91
00:04:35,920 --> 00:04:37,520
So it's right there and it's in my chart.

92
00:04:37,520 --> 00:04:40,120
Notice it didn't let
me pick an IP address.

93
00:04:40,120 --> 00:04:41,750
There's a reason for that.

94
00:04:41,750 --> 00:04:45,670
You might know an IP address that
someone else's site was using.

95
00:04:45,670 --> 00:04:49,560
And if they've changed IPs you could
potentially bring your server up with

96
00:04:49,560 --> 00:04:51,320
an IP they were using.

97
00:04:51,320 --> 00:04:55,760
I am probably not the first person
to get this elastic IP right here.

98
00:04:55,760 --> 00:04:57,980
Other people may have used it for
other things.

99
00:04:57,980 --> 00:05:01,910
This can be a real problem with
things like email servers.

100
00:05:01,910 --> 00:05:04,570
Someone else may have brought up
a spam server with this IP and

101
00:05:04,570 --> 00:05:05,890
got it blacklisted.

102
00:05:05,890 --> 00:05:09,580
And now I bring up a server with
this IP and I'm blacklisted,

103
00:05:09,580 --> 00:05:10,780
even though I haven't sent a single email.

104
00:05:10,780 --> 00:05:14,000
All right, so
understand that there can be some history

105
00:05:14,000 --> 00:05:16,680
with an IP address that
you get from Amazon.

106
00:05:16,680 --> 00:05:18,820
So, here, I've got that IP, and

107
00:05:18,820 --> 00:05:23,640
if I do find that it's blacklisted,
I could go and get it cleared and so

108
00:05:23,640 --> 00:05:27,380
on, or you could just remove it and
allocate a new one, right?

109
00:05:27,380 --> 00:05:31,310
So you can release the address
to put it back in Amazon's pool.

110
00:05:31,310 --> 00:05:33,530
And allocate a new one.

111
00:05:33,530 --> 00:05:34,110
But this one's fine.

112
00:05:34,110 --> 00:05:36,180
I actually have two servers though,
so I"m going to go ahead and

113
00:05:36,180 --> 00:05:38,520
allocate a second address.

114
00:05:38,520 --> 00:05:40,920
So I'll just hit that and
there we go I've got another one.

115
00:05:40,920 --> 00:05:45,070
So now I've got two IP addresses that are
available for me to use for my servers.

116
00:05:45,070 --> 00:05:48,490
Now, neither of them
are attached to an instance.

117
00:05:48,490 --> 00:05:50,680
So, right now I'm paying money.

118
00:05:52,040 --> 00:05:56,770
I'm paying, I really should have looked
this up, I believe it's $0.25 per day.

119
00:05:56,770 --> 00:06:00,420
Let me pull up the elastic IP pricing.

120
00:06:01,920 --> 00:06:03,040
And we'll find out for sure.

121
00:06:05,100 --> 00:06:06,510
So the elastic IP, here we go.

122
00:06:08,420 --> 00:06:11,190
Whoops, my little search
didn't work out so well.

123
00:06:11,190 --> 00:06:12,460
There I did it, there we go.

124
00:06:12,460 --> 00:06:15,690
The elastic IPs, they don't cost you
a dime while the server's running.

125
00:06:15,690 --> 00:06:16,760
So zero dollars.

126
00:06:16,760 --> 00:06:19,990
But when the server is off,
so if we look down here and

127
00:06:19,990 --> 00:06:25,860
find IP is not associated with a running
instance, on a per hour is 0.005, so

128
00:06:25,860 --> 00:06:32,040
it's half a penny per hour, which

129
00:06:32,040 --> 00:06:37,780
works out to about $0.12 or $0.13 a day,
so it's actually lower than what I said.

130
00:06:37,780 --> 00:06:39,760
So it's not an outrageous amount.

131
00:06:39,760 --> 00:06:41,190
But they do have a fee.

132
00:06:41,190 --> 00:06:42,470
So be aware of that.

133
00:06:42,470 --> 00:06:46,250
The other thing to be aware of is if
you have more than one IP on a server.

134
00:06:46,250 --> 00:06:49,140
So if you want to attach
multiple IPs to the same server.

135
00:06:49,140 --> 00:06:53,440
Maybe you have one web server but
you've got multiple websites on it and

136
00:06:53,440 --> 00:06:57,870
you don't wanna do just the name masking,
cuz that doesn't always work.

137
00:06:57,870 --> 00:07:01,550
So instead, you want to do separate
IP addresses for each site.

138
00:07:01,550 --> 00:07:05,750
Well, the additional IPs on that
one server will cost you money, and

139
00:07:05,750 --> 00:07:08,210
it's not much, half a cent per hour.

140
00:07:09,660 --> 00:07:13,150
All right, so not a big deal there,
we go ahead and create these IPs.

141
00:07:13,150 --> 00:07:16,780
I'm now paying half a cent per
hour while these aren't attached.

142
00:07:16,780 --> 00:07:20,250
I need to attach them to an instance,
and that's the second part.

143
00:07:20,250 --> 00:07:24,940
So, allocate is the first part,
associate is the second part.

144
00:07:24,940 --> 00:07:28,440
Associate is when we
tie the IP to a server.

145
00:07:28,440 --> 00:07:31,560
Now when I go to my instances I've
already got a window server, right here.

146
00:07:31,560 --> 00:07:32,990
So here's my Windows server.

147
00:07:32,990 --> 00:07:36,330
And its IP address, if I scroll
over is 54.172.48.110, right, so,

148
00:07:36,330 --> 00:07:39,260
it's got an IP that ends in 110.

149
00:07:39,260 --> 00:07:43,570
And I'm actually logged
into that server over here.

150
00:07:43,570 --> 00:07:49,320
So if I drop into its command prompt,
I can see it right there.

151
00:07:49,320 --> 00:07:54,100
Well actually, when you look here, you're
gonna see this internal, private IP.

152
00:07:54,100 --> 00:07:58,110
See, I've got 172.31.3.59,
that's that internal IP.

153
00:07:58,110 --> 00:08:01,840
But here on my wallpaper they're
showing that public IP of 110.

154
00:08:01,840 --> 00:08:07,470
And if I fire up a web browser,
and I go to a site like.

155
00:08:07,470 --> 00:08:09,350
Oops, if I minimize it.

156
00:08:09,350 --> 00:08:12,159
If I go to a site like, we'll do.

157
00:08:12,159 --> 00:08:15,950
[LAUGH] Apparently Internet Explorer
is going to be beyond my technical

158
00:08:15,950 --> 00:08:16,482
skills today.

159
00:08:16,482 --> 00:08:17,210
All right.

160
00:08:17,210 --> 00:08:19,380
So I'm going to go to ipchicken.com.

161
00:08:19,380 --> 00:08:22,620
If you can't trust the IP
chicken who can you trust?

162
00:08:22,620 --> 00:08:24,130
Let me just add them to my trusted zone.

163
00:08:24,130 --> 00:08:27,080
And tell that to stop popping.

164
00:08:27,080 --> 00:08:27,850
There we go.

165
00:08:27,850 --> 00:08:33,083
So I can see that when I went out to the
internet, that was my IP, 54.172.48.110.

166
00:08:33,083 --> 00:08:33,970
All right.

167
00:08:33,970 --> 00:08:36,890
So I've got that IP,
that's what I'm using.

168
00:08:36,890 --> 00:08:39,660
I have this private IP internally, and

169
00:08:39,660 --> 00:08:43,280
Amazon does a one to one map mapping so
that it's tied to me.

170
00:08:43,280 --> 00:08:46,420
All the traffic makes it to me, and
it doesn't mess with any of the software.

171
00:08:46,420 --> 00:08:49,090
But it makes it where I
can change the IP address

172
00:08:49,090 --> 00:08:52,490
while the server's online without
having to mess with the server.

173
00:08:52,490 --> 00:08:53,040
All right.

174
00:08:53,040 --> 00:08:55,500
So the server I can leave
its configuration alone.

175
00:08:55,500 --> 00:08:59,240
I can change the public IP and
Amazon's changing that NAT mapping.

176
00:08:59,240 --> 00:09:00,570
So let's see that in action.

177
00:09:00,570 --> 00:09:03,900
I'm gonna take one of these elastic IPs.

178
00:09:03,900 --> 00:09:05,630
I'll take the one that ends in 120.

179
00:09:05,630 --> 00:09:08,280
My current IP address ends in 110.

180
00:09:08,280 --> 00:09:09,600
This one ends in 120.

181
00:09:09,600 --> 00:09:13,550
So I'll take that, and
I'll choose to associate the address.

182
00:09:13,550 --> 00:09:17,120
And I'm gonna pick the instance
that I want to associate it to.

183
00:09:17,120 --> 00:09:21,070
And you can choose by the instance name
where you've got that right there.

184
00:09:21,070 --> 00:09:23,900
You can choose by a network
interface if you have more than one

185
00:09:23,900 --> 00:09:25,840
interface on the same server.

186
00:09:25,840 --> 00:09:29,370
Or you can choose by the private
IP if you know the private IP.

187
00:09:29,370 --> 00:09:32,710
If you're using VPCs,
you can designate those.

188
00:09:32,710 --> 00:09:36,080
I'm not using any VPCs yet,
so I'll go by instance name.

189
00:09:36,080 --> 00:09:38,550
And I'm gonna pick my Windows server.

190
00:09:38,550 --> 00:09:39,150
Okay?

191
00:09:39,150 --> 00:09:43,040
Now notice that I called it Windows VM,
cuz it's human-readable, but

192
00:09:43,040 --> 00:09:45,280
it'll actually go to the instance ID.

193
00:09:45,280 --> 00:09:49,990
So it's i-f- whatever,
I never remember those.

194
00:09:49,990 --> 00:09:52,270
So it's kinda nice that they
give us the name to pick from.

195
00:09:52,270 --> 00:09:54,920
But if you wanna see that ID,
you can go to the instances screen and

196
00:09:54,920 --> 00:09:56,230
it's right there in one of the columns.

197
00:09:57,300 --> 00:10:00,340
So I'm gonna choose to associate that and

198
00:10:00,340 --> 00:10:05,610
now that new IP is tied to
the private IP of my Windows VM.

199
00:10:05,610 --> 00:10:10,330
And when I go back up to my instances,
here's my Windows VM.

200
00:10:10,330 --> 00:10:13,570
And notice that that DNS name has changed.

201
00:10:13,570 --> 00:10:19,670
Now the DNS name is the new IP ending in
120 and the IP address is changed too.

202
00:10:19,670 --> 00:10:24,020
And it's a hyperlink which is your hint
to know that it's actually a static IP.

203
00:10:24,020 --> 00:10:26,655
You click on that it'll take
you to the elastic IP page.

204
00:10:26,655 --> 00:10:28,410
Versus these ones that aren't hyperlinked,

205
00:10:28,410 --> 00:10:29,740
those are the ones that
are dynamically generated.

206
00:10:29,740 --> 00:10:31,070
That's a quick easy way to tell.

207
00:10:33,452 --> 00:10:37,230
All right, and if I just over to my
Windows server, over here if I go into my

208
00:10:37,230 --> 00:10:43,580
command prompt my IP address before,
I think I might have gotten disconnected.

209
00:10:44,690 --> 00:10:47,900
My RDP client doesn't like
being put in the background.

210
00:10:47,900 --> 00:10:52,120
But my IP address before on
the private side was 172.31.3.59.

211
00:10:52,120 --> 00:10:55,310
It's still going to
have that same address.

212
00:10:55,310 --> 00:10:56,440
That hasn't changed.

213
00:10:56,440 --> 00:10:59,660
All right, but
what has changed is the public IP.

214
00:10:59,660 --> 00:11:03,420
And now that I say that,
I think I got disconnected.

215
00:11:03,420 --> 00:11:05,600
How could I have possibly
gotten disconnected?

216
00:11:05,600 --> 00:11:08,800
Well, probably the fact that I'm remote
desktopped into that public IP, and

217
00:11:08,800 --> 00:11:10,700
I just lost the public IP, right?

218
00:11:10,700 --> 00:11:13,060
The address changed on my system, so

219
00:11:13,060 --> 00:11:15,280
I'm trying to remote into a system
that I can't connect to anymore.

220
00:11:15,280 --> 00:11:18,065
So that's why it's upset,
so let me disconnect.

221
00:11:18,065 --> 00:11:20,510
[LAUGH]
Yeah,

222
00:11:20,510 --> 00:11:22,230
you'd think I would have noticed that.

223
00:11:22,230 --> 00:11:25,320
So let me go back to my dashboard and
get that IP address.

224
00:11:25,320 --> 00:11:29,270
So I'll take the new IP
address of my window's server.

225
00:11:29,270 --> 00:11:31,740
That is one hint that
it is already working.

226
00:11:31,740 --> 00:11:35,460
[LAUGH]
So let me find my Windows VM here,

227
00:11:35,460 --> 00:11:39,250
I'm gonna edit that one, and
I'll just change it to the new IP address.

228
00:11:40,860 --> 00:11:42,570
And I'll get connected back.

229
00:11:42,570 --> 00:11:46,930
All right, so here I'm connecting, I'm
gonna get connected to that Windows box.

230
00:11:46,930 --> 00:11:48,440
So when I log in,

231
00:11:48,440 --> 00:11:52,300
notice the wallpaper right here
still says that my IP ends in 110.

232
00:11:52,300 --> 00:11:56,290
And that's because that wallpaper was
generated when this virtual machine

233
00:11:56,290 --> 00:11:57,490
was created.

234
00:11:57,490 --> 00:12:00,370
And now I'm making
changes to it afterwards.

235
00:12:00,370 --> 00:12:03,070
So this information can get
out of date pretty quick.

236
00:12:03,070 --> 00:12:05,670
Don't trust what's on the wallpaper.

237
00:12:05,670 --> 00:12:08,200
You might have changed your instance size,
and so on.

238
00:12:08,200 --> 00:12:11,800
Amazon will refresh that when you shut the
server down and start it back up again.

239
00:12:11,800 --> 00:12:14,540
But if you don't shut your server down,
it might not update that.

240
00:12:14,540 --> 00:12:16,100
You won't see it.

241
00:12:16,100 --> 00:12:18,410
So be aware that that data
might be out of date.

242
00:12:18,410 --> 00:12:20,330
But if I go to my IP chicken here and

243
00:12:20,330 --> 00:12:23,880
refresh that page,
I can see now I've got 54.172.214.120.

244
00:12:23,880 --> 00:12:31,640
I've got that new address because, well,
I changed it, I mapped it to this server.

245
00:12:31,640 --> 00:12:33,860
So now it's a static IP.

246
00:12:33,860 --> 00:12:38,100
If I shut this server down, if I leave
it on, whatever, that IP is assigned.

247
00:12:38,100 --> 00:12:42,310
It's tied to this machine, and when I
bring it back up, it'll have the same IP.

248
00:12:42,310 --> 00:12:44,860
So I don't have to go and
change my DNS records or

249
00:12:44,860 --> 00:12:48,770
anything like that, it's already in
there and it's already in place.

250
00:12:48,770 --> 00:12:53,220
If I go back to my Instances,
and I shut them down, right.

251
00:12:53,220 --> 00:12:55,090
So let me go and take my Instances here.

252
00:12:55,090 --> 00:12:57,710
I'll take my Linux VM and my Windows VM
and I'm just gonna go ahead and

253
00:12:57,710 --> 00:12:58,625
stop those guys.

254
00:12:58,625 --> 00:12:59,619
All right.

255
00:12:59,619 --> 00:13:01,760
So they're gonna shut down.

256
00:13:01,760 --> 00:13:05,330
And it's gracefully shutting
down the operating systems.

257
00:13:05,330 --> 00:13:08,960
When they shut down what's gonna
happen is on the Windows one

258
00:13:08,960 --> 00:13:11,380
I'll still see the IP associated with it.

259
00:13:11,380 --> 00:13:14,480
But on the Linux one I'm
just using a dynamic IP.

260
00:13:14,480 --> 00:13:17,060
And so it's not going to be associated,
it's going to disappear.

261
00:13:17,060 --> 00:13:18,980
So it will show us the IP being gone.

262
00:13:18,980 --> 00:13:19,480
So.

263
00:13:19,480 --> 00:13:23,280
If we're patient people and we sit here
and wait we can see that disappear.

264
00:13:23,280 --> 00:13:25,080
If we get impatient like
me we might not wait.

265
00:13:25,080 --> 00:13:27,660
But that is basically what's gonna happen.

266
00:13:30,010 --> 00:13:32,970
I'm trying to think of something
stalling to talk about while we wait.

267
00:13:32,970 --> 00:13:33,852
Oop there we go.

268
00:13:33,852 --> 00:13:37,490
[LAUGH] Notice my Windows VM,
it's shut down but

269
00:13:37,490 --> 00:13:40,570
it still has a DNS name and
it still has an IP.

270
00:13:40,570 --> 00:13:42,870
It's static, we've associated it.

271
00:13:42,870 --> 00:13:47,620
But my Linux box, it's got a no DNS name
and no other public IP because they've

272
00:13:47,620 --> 00:13:51,990
been returned to Amazon's pool and
somebody else probably has that now right?

273
00:13:51,990 --> 00:13:54,320
Amazon, really busy,
they're constantly spinning up and

274
00:13:54,320 --> 00:13:57,605
taking down servers so
IPs get used pretty quickly.

275
00:13:57,605 --> 00:13:59,275
They'll get re-used real fast.

276
00:13:59,275 --> 00:13:59,945
All right.

277
00:13:59,945 --> 00:14:02,955
Now I assigned an IP to that
server while it was on.

278
00:14:02,955 --> 00:14:04,585
You can assign the IP while it's off too.

279
00:14:04,585 --> 00:14:05,895
If I go to elastic IPs and

280
00:14:05,895 --> 00:14:10,495
take this other address, I can associate
it with my Linux box even though it's off.

281
00:14:10,495 --> 00:14:11,645
And that's fine.

282
00:14:11,645 --> 00:14:14,725
You just wont actually really
see it until it boots up.

283
00:14:14,725 --> 00:14:17,450
So now it's associated and
I've got a static IP there.

284
00:14:17,450 --> 00:14:22,260
If I go back to my instances,
now they both have their DNS names, and

285
00:14:22,260 --> 00:14:22,860
they've got their IPs.

286
00:14:24,620 --> 00:14:28,320
All right, so in this segment we got
a chance to see how to create a static

287
00:14:28,320 --> 00:14:32,630
IP by allocating it, and then attaching it
to a virtual machine by associating it.

288
00:14:32,630 --> 00:14:37,120
So allocate, then associate, those are our
steps right there, pretty straightforward.

289
00:14:37,120 --> 00:14:38,720
Not the hardest thing we're
gonna do in a given day.

290
00:14:38,720 --> 00:14:41,240
All right well,
I hope you guys enjoyed this segment,

291
00:14:41,240 --> 00:14:43,870
stay tuned we got more
Amazon Web Services coming up.

episodes.title: RDP To A Windows Instance
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:08,292
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:08,292 --> 00:00:12,962
In this segment, we're gonna take a look
at how to use the remote desktop protocol

3
00:00:12,962 --> 00:00:15,750
to connect to a Windows
instance in Amazon EC2.

4
00:00:15,750 --> 00:00:19,409
If you've just brought up your
nice new shiny Windows instance,

5
00:00:19,409 --> 00:00:23,037
you're probably thinking great,
how do I get connected to it?

6
00:00:23,037 --> 00:00:25,830
[LAUGH] I need to log in so
I can start to work with it.

7
00:00:25,830 --> 00:00:27,700
Well, Amazon's got you covered.

8
00:00:27,700 --> 00:00:32,600
When they build up a Windows instance,
they create an administrative user account

9
00:00:32,600 --> 00:00:35,390
that's on the system that's ready for
you to be able to connect to it.

10
00:00:35,390 --> 00:00:40,010
And they even create security group
rules that allow that connectivity.

11
00:00:40,010 --> 00:00:44,230
Now, it is a little bit looser than what
you may want, and that can be problematic,

12
00:00:44,230 --> 00:00:48,190
so let's take a look at what's involving
getting connected the first time and

13
00:00:48,190 --> 00:00:54,360
how we can help secure that to ensure that
the bad guys don't get in to the system.

14
00:00:54,360 --> 00:00:55,420
All right?
Cuz RDP,

15
00:00:55,420 --> 00:00:56,910
it has security built in to it but

16
00:00:56,910 --> 00:01:01,580
it's not the greatest protocol
in the world for handing that.

17
00:01:01,580 --> 00:01:04,820
Basically if we want to remote in to our
server once the instance is fired up,

18
00:01:04,820 --> 00:01:08,510
as you can see I've got
a Windows VM right here.

19
00:01:08,510 --> 00:01:12,590
Once the instances is fired up, we can use
remote desktop protocol to connect to it.

20
00:01:12,590 --> 00:01:13,500
It's already enabled.

21
00:01:13,500 --> 00:01:14,670
It's turned on.

22
00:01:14,670 --> 00:01:16,650
We just need to do it, right?

23
00:01:16,650 --> 00:01:18,930
And getting connected to
a Windows one is pretty easy.

24
00:01:18,930 --> 00:01:21,610
You just select the VM that
you want to connect to.

25
00:01:21,610 --> 00:01:24,370
Up top, you'll see a connect button.

26
00:01:24,370 --> 00:01:25,830
I'm in the EC2 panel.

27
00:01:25,830 --> 00:01:31,122
If you're not familiar with that,
I basically went into the AWS console and

28
00:01:31,122 --> 00:01:35,530
went in to EC2 and from there,
I went into my instances.

29
00:01:35,530 --> 00:01:37,440
Here's where I saw my instances.

30
00:01:37,440 --> 00:01:38,460
I've chosen a Windows VM.

31
00:01:38,460 --> 00:01:41,580
You'll see that connect button
on Lennox VMs also, but

32
00:01:41,580 --> 00:01:43,930
Lennox VMs don't use
remote desktop protocol,

33
00:01:43,930 --> 00:01:47,940
they use something else, so
this is really just on the Windows side.

34
00:01:47,940 --> 00:01:49,690
So, when we choose that Windows VM,
we can hit connect and

35
00:01:49,690 --> 00:01:52,210
we're going to get an interesting box.

36
00:01:52,210 --> 00:01:55,520
It's not actually connecting
us to the system.

37
00:01:55,520 --> 00:02:00,120
It's giving us the tools to connect and
then we have to connect ourselves.

38
00:02:00,120 --> 00:02:02,500
Microsoft Remote Desktop Protocol
is proprietary.

39
00:02:02,500 --> 00:02:03,760
It's just Microsoft.

40
00:02:03,760 --> 00:02:05,370
It's their own solution.

41
00:02:05,370 --> 00:02:06,970
And so,
if you want to remote into a server,

42
00:02:06,970 --> 00:02:10,470
you're gonna have to use
a Remote Desktop Protocol client.

43
00:02:10,470 --> 00:02:13,850
If you're running a Windows machine,
it's already built in, right?

44
00:02:13,850 --> 00:02:18,360
Windows, I think they started including it
in Windows XP, maybe even in Windows 2000,

45
00:02:18,360 --> 00:02:21,210
but Windows Vista, Windows 7,
Windows 8, Windows 10,

46
00:02:21,210 --> 00:02:25,655
they've all got the RDP client built in so
there's nothing to install there.

47
00:02:25,655 --> 00:02:28,975
You can just fire up that remote
desktop protocol client and

48
00:02:28,975 --> 00:02:31,755
load the configuration file that
they're about to let us download.

49
00:02:31,755 --> 00:02:36,065
If you're running a Linux box, well,
there's a number of third party RDP

50
00:02:36,065 --> 00:02:40,315
clients that are out there, like Open RDP,
that you can use to be able to fire up and

51
00:02:40,315 --> 00:02:45,295
connect in, and on the Mac side, Microsoft
actually has an official RDP client for

52
00:02:45,295 --> 00:02:48,445
the Mac, so
you can go into the Apple store,

53
00:02:48,445 --> 00:02:52,010
the Mac OS Store whatever it's called.

54
00:02:52,010 --> 00:02:54,570
You can download the RDP
client from there.

55
00:02:54,570 --> 00:02:56,670
Then you just need our configuration.

56
00:02:56,670 --> 00:03:00,440
Now, they provide the RDP file
right here that we can download.

57
00:03:00,440 --> 00:03:02,660
You don't technically need it, but

58
00:03:02,660 --> 00:03:05,560
it's nice because it's gonna
fill in the IP address for us.

59
00:03:05,560 --> 00:03:09,160
If you're using dynamic IPs, the IP
address of your server might change from

60
00:03:09,160 --> 00:03:12,840
time to time, so you can just quickly
come in here and download the new file.

61
00:03:12,840 --> 00:03:16,210
If you've assigned a static IP like
I have, the IP will never change.

62
00:03:16,210 --> 00:03:18,880
So you just download the file once and
you'll be good to go.

63
00:03:18,880 --> 00:03:22,490
But even if I don't download the file,
it's got the IP right there and

64
00:03:22,490 --> 00:03:23,420
the user name.

65
00:03:23,420 --> 00:03:27,810
So I can just fire up an RDP client and
point it to that IP address and

66
00:03:27,810 --> 00:03:30,760
log in with the administrator account and
I'll have access.

67
00:03:30,760 --> 00:03:33,210
You don't actually have to use this file.

68
00:03:33,210 --> 00:03:36,100
But it is nice cuz it
helps you to avoid typos.

69
00:03:36,100 --> 00:03:38,620
Now if I download that file,
it's just going to come in here and

70
00:03:38,620 --> 00:03:41,640
save that as an RDP file,
so I'll save that,

71
00:03:41,640 --> 00:03:47,043
and then I'll fire up my
Microsoft Remote Desktop Client and

72
00:03:47,043 --> 00:03:52,100
I'm gonna import that in here
I'll go to file, and import.

73
00:03:52,100 --> 00:03:55,280
Now you could just double click on
the RDP file that would open it up.

74
00:03:55,280 --> 00:03:57,810
On windows that's what I normally do,
I just double click on it.

75
00:03:57,810 --> 00:03:58,820
But here I'm going to import it.

76
00:03:58,820 --> 00:04:01,520
And the reason why I want to import it
is I want to change some things on it.

77
00:04:02,530 --> 00:04:05,350
When I open that up it's
gonna add it here on my list.

78
00:04:05,350 --> 00:04:08,410
It is stuck all the way
to the bottom of course.

79
00:04:08,410 --> 00:04:10,090
So I've got it right here.

80
00:04:10,090 --> 00:04:12,620
I'm going to rename that, so
I can remember what it is.

81
00:04:12,620 --> 00:04:14,470
So I'm just gonna right click and
edit this one.

82
00:04:14,470 --> 00:04:16,150
And change its name, so
I can remember what it is.

83
00:04:16,150 --> 00:04:17,520
So this is my Windows VM.

84
00:04:17,520 --> 00:04:18,070
All right?

85
00:04:18,070 --> 00:04:21,620
It's already filled in the IP address for
me, and it's already set some of the other

86
00:04:21,620 --> 00:04:24,620
values as far as what security
is supported, and so on.

87
00:04:24,620 --> 00:04:26,740
So, the configuration is really done for
me.

88
00:04:26,740 --> 00:04:29,510
But you'll notice that it leaves
out things like the password.

89
00:04:29,510 --> 00:04:30,080
All right?

90
00:04:30,080 --> 00:04:33,100
Well, when you go to log in, you're
gonna have to provide a password and

91
00:04:33,100 --> 00:04:34,570
you may want to put it in here.

92
00:04:34,570 --> 00:04:36,110
We need to get that password.

93
00:04:36,110 --> 00:04:38,400
The other thing is,
if we don't put it here, when we log in,

94
00:04:38,400 --> 00:04:42,890
it's gonna ask us for the password and
Amazon generates a complex password for

95
00:04:42,890 --> 00:04:44,850
your default administrator account.

96
00:04:44,850 --> 00:04:47,540
Every Windows server has
an administrator account.

97
00:04:47,540 --> 00:04:49,310
You might have disabled it, but it exists.

98
00:04:49,310 --> 00:04:50,130
It's there.

99
00:04:50,130 --> 00:04:51,670
And so Amazon knows that.

100
00:04:51,670 --> 00:04:53,650
If an attacker is trying to hit
your server, they're gonna try and

101
00:04:53,650 --> 00:04:55,240
exploit that administrator account.

102
00:04:55,240 --> 00:04:57,020
So they give it a complex password.

103
00:04:57,020 --> 00:05:00,330
And once you get in you'll probably
wanna start creating your own accounts.

104
00:05:00,330 --> 00:05:02,520
And then eventually disable
this administrator account so

105
00:05:02,520 --> 00:05:04,160
it's not available anymore.

106
00:05:04,160 --> 00:05:06,720
But the first time you connect,
we need it, right?

107
00:05:06,720 --> 00:05:12,160
So if I go back to my EC2 screen here,
I can choose to get the password.

108
00:05:12,160 --> 00:05:16,160
Now they don't just display the password
on the screen, and the reason is

109
00:05:16,160 --> 00:05:19,950
your user name and password for Amazon
web services might have been compromised.

110
00:05:19,950 --> 00:05:21,460
And so they don't want
somebody to be able to log in,

111
00:05:21,460 --> 00:05:25,510
and just all the sudden begin pulling all
of these credentials off of your servers.

112
00:05:25,510 --> 00:05:26,810
That would be really bad.

113
00:05:26,810 --> 00:05:31,180
So, we already had to login once,
just to get to the EC2 panel.

114
00:05:31,180 --> 00:05:31,900
All right?

115
00:05:31,900 --> 00:05:35,390
But when we go to get this password,
it's going to ask us for

116
00:05:35,390 --> 00:05:40,000
the key pair, the certificate that was
generated when we built the server.

117
00:05:40,000 --> 00:05:44,870
When you built the server out it asked if
you wanted to use an existing key pair, or

118
00:05:44,870 --> 00:05:46,480
to use an all new one.

119
00:05:46,480 --> 00:05:47,918
Well it's gonna list it right here.

120
00:05:47,918 --> 00:05:50,340
And it's gonna say if you
want to get this password,

121
00:05:50,340 --> 00:05:52,370
you've got to give me your certificate.

122
00:05:52,370 --> 00:05:55,450
So this is the second
factor of authentication.

123
00:05:55,450 --> 00:05:58,840
I have my certificate saved right here
on my drive somewhere, let me find it.

124
00:05:58,840 --> 00:06:02,290
I should probably take a little
more care to know where I put that.

125
00:06:02,290 --> 00:06:04,010
So I'll go ahead and load it up and

126
00:06:04,010 --> 00:06:07,950
once your certificate is loaded in you can
hit decrypt password, and there it is.

127
00:06:07,950 --> 00:06:12,626
There is the password and you can
see that that is a complex password.

128
00:06:12,626 --> 00:06:17,536
Now, for me, I could go and remote desktop
into this IP and this username but

129
00:06:17,536 --> 00:06:22,218
one of the problems that I always have
is you can't paste into the Windows

130
00:06:22,218 --> 00:06:23,700
password field.

131
00:06:23,700 --> 00:06:25,880
So I can't just copy and
paste this password over.

132
00:06:25,880 --> 00:06:26,990
It won't let me.

133
00:06:26,990 --> 00:06:29,740
So I probably want to go some other route.

134
00:06:29,740 --> 00:06:32,690
And that's why I like to edit
the password of my RDP client.

135
00:06:32,690 --> 00:06:36,100
So in here I can go into my password,
and I can just paste that in.

136
00:06:36,100 --> 00:06:39,280
It's not a great idea to save your
password but you'll likely want to go and

137
00:06:39,280 --> 00:06:41,060
change this one right away anyway.

138
00:06:41,060 --> 00:06:42,350
So no big deal there.

139
00:06:42,350 --> 00:06:44,210
So I'll go ahead and save that and

140
00:06:44,210 --> 00:06:48,180
now that it's in place I can double click
on it and I'm going to remote desktop in.

141
00:06:48,180 --> 00:06:50,170
This is the first time I've
seen the certificate so

142
00:06:50,170 --> 00:06:52,600
it's asking me to confirm it,
I'll go ahead and continue.

143
00:06:53,760 --> 00:06:57,440
And now I'm remote desk-topped
into that server that I built up.

144
00:06:57,440 --> 00:06:57,990
Okay?

145
00:06:57,990 --> 00:06:58,780
So here I am.

146
00:06:58,780 --> 00:06:59,710
I'm looking at my server.

147
00:06:59,710 --> 00:07:01,210
So, it's very, very exciting.

148
00:07:01,210 --> 00:07:05,230
So now our remote desktop in,
now it's just a Windows server.

149
00:07:05,230 --> 00:07:08,240
I work with it like I would any other
Windows server, I install the software I

150
00:07:08,240 --> 00:07:12,710
need, I do my Windows updates, I do my
configurations, join it to a domain if it

151
00:07:12,710 --> 00:07:17,220
needs that or whatever it is that I need
to do, now I'm working with my system.

152
00:07:17,220 --> 00:07:21,420
And in the future if I want to connect to
this box I don't have to log in to AWS

153
00:07:21,420 --> 00:07:28,060
first, I can come in and just fire up
my remote desktop client, and here.

154
00:07:28,060 --> 00:07:31,760
So, I can fire up my remote desktop client
I don't have to be logged into AWS at all

155
00:07:31,760 --> 00:07:35,030
I can just come right in here and as long
as I have messed with that password I'll

156
00:07:35,030 --> 00:07:38,730
be able to click on that, and it'll take
me right into the server, no AWS involved.

157
00:07:40,460 --> 00:07:41,910
So really makes things easy.

158
00:07:43,280 --> 00:07:48,080
One word of caution tho, this server,
it's got a public IP address.

159
00:07:48,080 --> 00:07:52,900
And RDP is turned on by default, and
the firewall rule that's put in place on

160
00:07:52,900 --> 00:07:57,730
the security group for this server
allows anyone in the world to connect.

161
00:07:57,730 --> 00:08:01,400
So if you're watching this live and
you've got that password fast enough,

162
00:08:01,400 --> 00:08:02,970
you could actually RDP
into the server right now.

163
00:08:02,970 --> 00:08:04,420
It's open to the world.

164
00:08:04,420 --> 00:08:06,450
It's a really bad idea
to leave it that way.

165
00:08:06,450 --> 00:08:11,410
So what you wanna do is, usually even
before you generate that password, go and

166
00:08:11,410 --> 00:08:12,910
change the firewall rules.

167
00:08:12,910 --> 00:08:16,060
And so back in my EC2 screen.

168
00:08:16,060 --> 00:08:16,900
I'm gonna close this.

169
00:08:16,900 --> 00:08:20,430
And I'm gonna look at that Windows VM and
figure out which security group it's in.

170
00:08:20,430 --> 00:08:22,750
Way over here I can see
it's in Launch Wizard One.

171
00:08:22,750 --> 00:08:24,560
Now, I wasn't very creative with the name.

172
00:08:24,560 --> 00:08:27,690
So, I'll go into
the Launch Wizard One security group.

173
00:08:27,690 --> 00:08:31,625
And you'll see that it's got
some inbound and outbound rules.

174
00:08:31,625 --> 00:08:33,417
The outbound is all traffic out.

175
00:08:33,417 --> 00:08:35,083
That server can get to wherever it wants.

176
00:08:35,083 --> 00:08:41,260
But on an inbound RDP TCP port
3389 is allowed from every source.

177
00:08:41,260 --> 00:08:42,570
All zeros means everybody.

178
00:08:42,570 --> 00:08:44,800
So everyone in the world
can RDP into this server.

179
00:08:44,800 --> 00:08:47,320
If they have the user name and
password, they can get into it.

180
00:08:47,320 --> 00:08:49,090
That's not good, all right?

181
00:08:49,090 --> 00:08:50,740
So I'm gonna edit that.

182
00:08:50,740 --> 00:08:59,167
And at a minimum, what you wanna do is
change this from anywhere to my IP, okay?

183
00:08:59,167 --> 00:09:04,007
My IP, the web browser will actually
look at the IP address of your current

184
00:09:04,007 --> 00:09:08,625
machine and it'll put that in and
now I'm the only one that can get in.

185
00:09:08,625 --> 00:09:14,792
Let me move that over a little bit and
you'll see it's 209.251.159.179/32.

186
00:09:14,792 --> 00:09:17,350
Slash 32 means this one IP address.

187
00:09:17,350 --> 00:09:22,010
So the IP I'm at right now is the only
one allowed to RDP into that system.

188
00:09:22,010 --> 00:09:23,160
Okay.

189
00:09:23,160 --> 00:09:26,180
That might not be exactly what you want.

190
00:09:26,180 --> 00:09:28,470
So that's the IP that I'm at right now,

191
00:09:28,470 --> 00:09:30,760
but what about the other
people in my office?

192
00:09:30,760 --> 00:09:31,640
They might wanna get in.

193
00:09:31,640 --> 00:09:35,170
Or what if I go home and
I'm on my home machine and I wanna get in?

194
00:09:35,170 --> 00:09:38,890
Well, what I can do is I can go home,
I can find out my public IP

195
00:09:38,890 --> 00:09:43,270
at home cuz I've got a dynamic IP
at home I can then edit this and

196
00:09:43,270 --> 00:09:46,980
add a second entry,
permitting my IP at home.

197
00:09:46,980 --> 00:09:49,260
And then I can access the system and
work with it, and

198
00:09:49,260 --> 00:09:52,190
when I'm done I can come back to
the firewall rule and remove it.

199
00:09:52,190 --> 00:09:55,400
It's important to remove it
because my IP at home is dynamic.

200
00:09:55,400 --> 00:09:59,410
One day I could lose that IP and it goes
to some other cable internet customer and

201
00:09:59,410 --> 00:10:00,880
now they've got access to my server.

202
00:10:00,880 --> 00:10:02,510
They probably won't know it, right?

203
00:10:02,510 --> 00:10:03,330
But they do.
And so

204
00:10:03,330 --> 00:10:05,450
that's something you want to be aware of.

205
00:10:05,450 --> 00:10:09,230
So, you'll want to approve
that RDP access just for

206
00:10:09,230 --> 00:10:12,510
the systems that you want to be
allowed to connect and use, all right?

207
00:10:12,510 --> 00:10:17,790
So, we can go in and continue to modify
this list to add in other things.

208
00:10:17,790 --> 00:10:22,120
I've got custom IP chosen right now which
lets you do these subnet mask ranges.

209
00:10:22,120 --> 00:10:23,280
And so I could change that.

210
00:10:23,280 --> 00:10:26,630
My range, I'm trying to remember
where it actually starts,

211
00:10:26,630 --> 00:10:31,160
I think it starts like 177,
is that right 177?

212
00:10:31,160 --> 00:10:38,018
Yeah, 177, so it starts at 177 and
it is a /28, I believe.

213
00:10:38,018 --> 00:10:41,190
So a /28 means that my range actually

214
00:10:41,190 --> 00:10:45,270
goes from .177 all the way up
through 189 or something like that.

215
00:10:45,270 --> 00:10:48,640
So there's a whole range of IPs here
at the office that we could be using.

216
00:10:48,640 --> 00:10:52,550
And this one entry can account for
all of those IPs.

217
00:10:52,550 --> 00:10:54,130
So I can punch that in and hit save.

218
00:10:54,130 --> 00:10:56,869
And now my whole office is approved.

219
00:10:56,869 --> 00:10:59,607
And I can continue to add more rules.

220
00:10:59,607 --> 00:11:06,583
And I could add another RDP rule,
TCP 3389 custom IP.

221
00:11:06,583 --> 00:11:09,792
And then here I could put my home IP,
or whatever.

222
00:11:09,792 --> 00:11:13,699
I don't know my home IP, but
I'll put in a fake one just to do it.

223
00:11:15,410 --> 00:11:16,830
There.
So maybe that's my home IP, so

224
00:11:16,830 --> 00:11:17,950
I can punch that in.

225
00:11:17,950 --> 00:11:20,070
And so now I've got two RDP rules.

226
00:11:20,070 --> 00:11:21,340
They both apply.

227
00:11:21,340 --> 00:11:25,770
If I'm here at the office, the first rule
is gonna hit and I'll be allowed access.

228
00:11:25,770 --> 00:11:29,120
But if I'm at home, the second rule will
hit and I'll be allowed access also.

229
00:11:29,120 --> 00:11:30,490
But if I'm out at a hotel or

230
00:11:30,490 --> 00:11:34,170
if there's an attacker on the internet,
they're not gonna be allowed access.

231
00:11:34,170 --> 00:11:36,640
It's really important to change that.

232
00:11:36,640 --> 00:11:38,400
This might be a public web server.

233
00:11:38,400 --> 00:11:41,650
I want the whole world to be
able to get to my website.

234
00:11:41,650 --> 00:11:43,610
I don't want the whole world to RDP and

235
00:11:43,610 --> 00:11:48,480
so be aware that customize your rules, so
you know if it is a web server we might

236
00:11:48,480 --> 00:11:52,380
have another entry here that says
HTTP is allowed from anywhere.

237
00:11:52,380 --> 00:11:55,010
I want HTTP from anywhere.

238
00:11:55,010 --> 00:11:55,780
That's cool.

239
00:11:55,780 --> 00:11:57,370
I'm fine with that.

240
00:11:57,370 --> 00:11:59,710
I just don't want RDP from anywhere.

241
00:11:59,710 --> 00:12:02,060
So make sure you're very restrictive.

242
00:12:02,060 --> 00:12:04,940
And that's where it's kind of handy
if you have one security group.

243
00:12:04,940 --> 00:12:07,660
You can define this one time, but
you might have different needs for

244
00:12:07,660 --> 00:12:08,610
different servers.

245
00:12:08,610 --> 00:12:11,220
So you may have many
different security groups.

246
00:12:11,220 --> 00:12:12,700
Every time you spin up a new server,

247
00:12:12,700 --> 00:12:16,430
make sure you double check this
because the default is everywhere.

248
00:12:16,430 --> 00:12:17,040
All right.

249
00:12:17,040 --> 00:12:19,860
So getting connected,
it's pretty straight forward.

250
00:12:19,860 --> 00:12:22,750
Once you have that administrative
password, you can log in, change it,

251
00:12:22,750 --> 00:12:25,350
do whatever you need, and
you don't need to use the console anymore.

252
00:12:25,350 --> 00:12:27,828
You can just use your RDP client,
you've got a user name and

253
00:12:27,828 --> 00:12:31,345
password on the on a system,
you connect in and you work with it.

254
00:12:31,345 --> 00:12:32,667
Really, really straight forward.

255
00:12:32,667 --> 00:12:34,250
I connected by IP address.

256
00:12:34,250 --> 00:12:36,515
You can connect by DNS name
if you've assigned one.

257
00:12:36,515 --> 00:12:38,725
Either the DNS name that Amazon assigns.

258
00:12:38,725 --> 00:12:40,815
This really long annoying one, right here.

259
00:12:40,815 --> 00:12:42,335
You can connect with that or

260
00:12:42,335 --> 00:12:44,515
you can connect with a DNS
name that you've assigned.

261
00:12:44,515 --> 00:12:45,655
If you've mapped it to that IP.

262
00:12:46,815 --> 00:12:49,290
Useful is you have a IP.

263
00:12:49,290 --> 00:12:52,480
All right, so in this segment,
we got a chance to see how to

264
00:12:52,480 --> 00:12:56,690
basically fire up RDP and
get connected to our Windows Instance, so

265
00:12:56,690 --> 00:13:00,480
we can get to the work, so we can start to
use this server for the forces of good.

266
00:13:00,480 --> 00:13:03,380
So, kind of an important step if
you're gonna be customizing it

267
00:13:03,380 --> 00:13:04,720
for your environment.

268
00:13:04,720 --> 00:13:06,040
Well I hope you guys enjoyed the segment.

269
00:13:06,040 --> 00:13:06,620
Stay tuned.

270
00:13:06,620 --> 00:13:08,830
We've got more Amazon Web Services
coming up next.

episodes.title: SSH Into A Linux Instance
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,178 --> 00:00:08,019
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:08,019 --> 00:00:13,007
In this segment we're gonna take
a look at SSH in into a Linux instance

3
00:00:13,007 --> 00:00:14,819
in Amazon Web Services.

4
00:00:14,819 --> 00:00:18,851
When you bring up a new Linux instance,
in EC2, they basically,

5
00:00:18,851 --> 00:00:21,200
they have to create a root account.

6
00:00:21,200 --> 00:00:25,000
As part of building that system up, and
once the servers online, it's up and

7
00:00:25,000 --> 00:00:28,530
it's running, we need a way to
connect to it, and work with it.

8
00:00:28,530 --> 00:00:32,530
So, we know there's a root account,
but boy that's a security risk.

9
00:00:32,530 --> 00:00:35,867
You don't wanna have a root account
that people can HSS in, and so

10
00:00:35,867 --> 00:00:39,770
it's standard best practices to
disable HSS for the root account.

11
00:00:39,770 --> 00:00:41,960
And Amazon knows this,
and they've done it.

12
00:00:41,960 --> 00:00:43,780
So, even though there's
a root account in place,

13
00:00:43,780 --> 00:00:46,480
we can't use it to connect
[LAUGH] to our Linux server.

14
00:00:46,480 --> 00:00:50,200
So, how the heck do we get connected to
our Linux instance when we bring it up

15
00:00:50,200 --> 00:00:51,960
inside of Amazon Web Services?

16
00:00:51,960 --> 00:00:55,980
Well, fortunately what Amazon does is
really the best example of security

17
00:00:55,980 --> 00:00:57,280
practices for Linux.

18
00:00:57,280 --> 00:01:01,710
They disable SSH for root, and
then they create a standard user for

19
00:01:01,710 --> 00:01:05,870
you that has an SSL
certificate attached to them.

20
00:01:05,870 --> 00:01:09,900
Or not just SSL, just a certificate
itself attached to you that can use for

21
00:01:09,900 --> 00:01:13,340
all sorts of different things,
including SSH.

22
00:01:13,340 --> 00:01:16,280
And so they use certificate based
authentication to establish

23
00:01:16,280 --> 00:01:17,610
an SSH connection.

24
00:01:17,610 --> 00:01:21,350
And that means that user account that they
make for you, it's got a password, but

25
00:01:21,350 --> 00:01:22,420
you don't know what it is.

26
00:01:22,420 --> 00:01:24,100
It doesn't matter because you
never need that password,

27
00:01:24,100 --> 00:01:26,430
you use the certificate
to authenticate and

28
00:01:26,430 --> 00:01:29,960
once you connect you can create whatever
other user accounts you want, and

29
00:01:29,960 --> 00:01:33,780
they can do password authentication or
you can use certificate authentication.

30
00:01:33,780 --> 00:01:37,590
Depending on your needs, but it does make
getting connected the first time a little

31
00:01:37,590 --> 00:01:40,360
bit tricky, so
let me walk you through the process.

32
00:01:40,360 --> 00:01:45,010
When you go into EC2, let's start
all the way back at the console.

33
00:01:45,010 --> 00:01:48,500
So, we get a logged into our AWS console,
if I can say it,

34
00:01:48,500 --> 00:01:53,685
and we go into EC2 and
we pull our instances.

35
00:01:53,685 --> 00:01:57,405
You'll see all of your instances that are
fired up, if you have Windows instances,

36
00:01:57,405 --> 00:01:59,265
you'll connect to them using RDP.

37
00:01:59,265 --> 00:02:05,135
Windows doesn't support SSH, so that's
not an option, but your Linux instances,

38
00:02:05,135 --> 00:02:10,295
they're set up for SSH, so when we choose
that Linux instance, you'll have a button

39
00:02:10,295 --> 00:02:13,812
that lights up that says, connect, and
that's gonna help us get connected.

40
00:02:13,812 --> 00:02:18,180
It's gonna help us by
using some form of SSH.

41
00:02:18,180 --> 00:02:19,620
Now, what do I mean by that?

42
00:02:19,620 --> 00:02:25,210
Well, SSH, the secure shell, it's an open
standard, anybody can support it.

43
00:02:25,210 --> 00:02:30,179
Pretty much every Unix system developed in
the last ten years is going to have SSH

00:14:59,885 --> 00:15:00,395
getting approved.

257
00:15:01,415 --> 00:15:05,915
Make sure you limit that because
there are numerous systems out there.

258
00:15:05,915 --> 00:15:09,425
Attack bot networks,
these zombie networks that are out there,

259
00:15:09,425 --> 00:15:14,705
they are scanning the Internet, and port
22, everybody knows that's SSH, and so

260
00:15:14,705 --> 00:15:18,315
they can see it and they can start trying
to brute force usernames and passwords.

261
00:15:18,315 --> 00:15:21,925
We're already helping with that by
having certificate based authentication,

262
00:15:21,925 --> 00:15:23,810
but better safe than sorry.

263
00:15:23,810 --> 00:15:25,470
Limit who's allowed to connect to the SSH.

264
00:15:26,500 --> 00:15:31,040
There is one other thing that I want to
mention, I did all of this from my Mac,
