265
00:15:31,040 --> 00:15:32,820
which is the same as on Linux.

266
00:15:32,820 --> 00:15:36,820
So, when you go to connect, you just fire
up a terminal, and you use the built-in

267
00:15:36,820 --> 00:15:40,660
SSH client, you connect in, and
you work everything's fine.

268
00:15:40,660 --> 00:15:47,689
That PAM file format of the certificate
is the standard for SSH.

269
00:15:47,689 --> 00:15:51,632
On the Windows side Amazon recommends
PuTTY, but for whatever reason, and

270
00:15:51,632 --> 00:15:56,068
I don't know why, but for whatever reason,
PuTTY does not support the PAM format for

271
00:15:56,068 --> 00:15:57,440
certificates.

272
00:15:57,440 --> 00:15:59,910
So, if you try and
build a SSH session with PuTTY,

273
00:15:59,910 --> 00:16:02,590
it's not going to work
with that certificate.

274
00:16:02,590 --> 00:16:05,850
So, that's one of the other reasons why on
this connect screen it's got the connect

275
00:16:05,850 --> 00:16:10,410
using PuTTY link, to take you to an
article to explain how to connect, and one

276
00:16:10,410 --> 00:16:14,490
of the things they'll mention in here is
that you need to convert the certificate.

277
00:16:14,490 --> 00:16:19,260
So, they're telling us,
you need to install it and so on.

278
00:16:19,260 --> 00:16:21,870
And then they mention firing
up a utility called PuTTYgen.

279
00:16:22,930 --> 00:16:28,110
If you install PuTTY on your system,
it'll install a utility called PuTTYgen.

280
00:16:28,110 --> 00:16:30,672
When you download PuTTY,
let me go here to the download page,

281
00:16:30,672 --> 00:16:33,300
you'll see there's several
ways you can download it.

282
00:16:33,300 --> 00:16:37,270
If you just download the executable,
you won't have PuTTYgen, but you'll see

283
00:16:37,270 --> 00:16:41,280
PuTTYgen here as a separate download, or
you get the installer that has all of it.

284
00:16:41,280 --> 00:16:47,900
PuTTYgen can convert a PAM file to a PPK
file, and that's what PuTTY likes to use.

285
00:16:47,900 --> 00:16:49,760
PuTTY likes these PPK files.

286
00:16:49,760 --> 00:16:52,960
So, they have the instructions
that posted right here,

287
00:16:52,960 --> 00:16:54,830
which I got to from that connect screen.

288
00:16:54,830 --> 00:16:59,210
They show how to go in and load the PAM
file, and convert that to a PPK,

289
00:16:59,210 --> 00:17:01,300
that's what they're doing right there.

290
00:17:01,300 --> 00:17:06,270
And once it's converted as a PPK, then
you'll be able to use PuTTY to connect up,

291
00:17:06,270 --> 00:17:07,750
and get into that system.

292
00:17:07,750 --> 00:17:08,810
I'm not a big fan of that,

293
00:17:08,810 --> 00:17:12,360
I don't know why PuTTY doesn't support
PAM file formats, but they don't.

294
00:17:12,360 --> 00:17:13,670
So, it's kind of a headache.

295
00:17:13,670 --> 00:17:16,230
I usually use a [LAUGH] Linux or
Unix system to connect, and

296
00:17:16,230 --> 00:17:17,730
don't worry about it.

297
00:17:17,730 --> 00:17:20,900
And there are other SSH
clients that are out there.

298
00:17:20,900 --> 00:17:23,860
There's plenty of really
big ones like SecureCRT,

299
00:17:23,860 --> 00:17:26,810
that do support PAM file formats,
so that you can use those.

300
00:17:26,810 --> 00:17:28,230
It's up to you what you want to use.

301
00:17:29,340 --> 00:17:33,010
The big difference being that PuTTY is
free, versus SecureCRT that starts at,

302
00:17:33,010 --> 00:17:36,279
I think it starts at like $100,
so not the least expensive.

303
00:17:37,325 --> 00:17:41,700
So, in this segment we got
a chance to see connecting up for

304
00:17:41,700 --> 00:17:44,770
the first time to our
Amazon EC2 Linux instance.

305
00:17:44,770 --> 00:17:48,460
We saw how to use SSH, how to deal
with that certificate file, and for

306
00:17:48,460 --> 00:17:50,550
the most part it was
pretty straight forward.

307
00:17:50,550 --> 00:17:54,630
On the Linux side, we needed to change the
permissions on the file before we could

308
00:17:54,630 --> 00:17:56,210
connect, it checks for that.

309
00:17:56,210 --> 00:17:59,860
On the Windows side, if you're using
PuTTY, you've got to convert it to a PPK.

310
00:17:59,860 --> 00:18:03,471
The file permissions don't really apply
on the Windows side, that's a Linux and

311
00:18:03,471 --> 00:18:04,740
a Mac OS thing.

312
00:18:04,740 --> 00:18:08,843
So, little bits of difference there,
little caveats of getting connected, but

313
00:18:08,843 --> 00:18:09,919
the process itself?

314
00:18:09,919 --> 00:18:10,450
It's pretty straightforward.

315
00:18:11,560 --> 00:18:13,290
I hope you guys enjoyed this segment.

316
00:18:13,290 --> 00:18:16,890
Stay tuned, we've got more Amazon AWS,
it's kinda redundant, I guess,

317
00:18:16,890 --> 00:18:18,740
more AWS stuff coming up.

episodes.title: Removing An Instance
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,025 --> 00:00:08,189
[SOUND].

2
00:00:08,189 --> 00:00:08,994
In this segment,

3
00:00:08,994 --> 00:00:13,020
we're going to take a look at
removing an instance from Amazon EC2.

4
00:00:13,020 --> 00:00:16,120
When you build up a server, you may only
need it for a certain period of time.

5
00:00:16,120 --> 00:00:19,600
Maybe you're doing testing or development,
or maybe it's a purpose-built server and

6
00:00:19,600 --> 00:00:21,500
that purpose is just done, right?

7
00:00:21,500 --> 00:00:23,510
Well when that happens,
we need to remove the instance.

8
00:00:23,510 --> 00:00:26,080
We need to get it out of there
because we're gonna pay for

9
00:00:26,080 --> 00:00:27,420
it as long as it's there.

10
00:00:27,420 --> 00:00:29,040
Even if you shut the instance down, right,

11
00:00:29,040 --> 00:00:32,440
if you stop the instance,
you're still paying for storage.

12
00:00:32,440 --> 00:00:34,280
You're not paying for
processor and memory anymore,

13
00:00:34,280 --> 00:00:36,800
which is nice, but you're paying for
storage of that data.

14
00:00:36,800 --> 00:00:39,892
So when we're done with an instance,
we need to get it out of the system,

15
00:00:39,892 --> 00:00:40,780
all right.

16
00:00:40,780 --> 00:00:43,526
We do that through a process
called terminating.

17
00:00:43,526 --> 00:00:47,903
In Amazon EC2, that word, terminate,
when you terminate an instance,

18
00:00:47,903 --> 00:00:51,589
that means, shut it off if it's
still on ,and then delete it.

19
00:00:51,589 --> 00:00:55,200
And this will actually wipe it
out with no means of recovery.

20
00:00:55,200 --> 00:00:56,960
If you have a backup of it,
that's great, but

21
00:00:56,960 --> 00:01:00,870
if you don't have a backup of it,
it's gone and that's it, all right?

22
00:01:00,870 --> 00:01:02,340
So let's take a look at it.

23
00:01:02,340 --> 00:01:03,950
The process is pretty easy, but

24
00:01:03,950 --> 00:01:07,890
there are a few little quirks we can
bump into that we need to be aware of.

25
00:01:07,890 --> 00:01:13,150
When we go into our console, so
I'm logged into the AWS console here.

26
00:01:13,150 --> 00:01:17,530
I'll just go to EC2 and
I'll go take a look at my instances.

27
00:01:17,530 --> 00:01:19,210
And I can see some of
the instances that I've got.

28
00:01:19,210 --> 00:01:22,530
And I've got this server right here
that I was using for something, and

29
00:01:22,530 --> 00:01:23,910
I'm done with it.

30
00:01:23,910 --> 00:01:27,850
It's a medium instance, and so
I'm having to pay for that extra CPU and

31
00:01:27,850 --> 00:01:29,290
memory that I chose.

32
00:01:29,290 --> 00:01:31,690
So it's costing me money right now.

33
00:01:31,690 --> 00:01:34,330
I probably need to get that out
of there if I'm done with it.

34
00:01:34,330 --> 00:01:36,970
The other thing is, on the storage
side there's hard drives, or

35
00:01:36,970 --> 00:01:41,600
volumes attached to this instance,
and those are costing me money too.

36
00:01:41,600 --> 00:01:45,349
This particular instance, if I go down
here to my volumes, I can look and

37
00:01:45,349 --> 00:01:47,500
see, oh, I didn't name my instance, so

38
00:01:47,500 --> 00:01:50,089
it's gonna be a little hard for
me to spot it here.

39
00:01:50,089 --> 00:01:53,860
But we can look in here and
find out who we're attached to.

40
00:01:53,860 --> 00:01:57,240
And so
we'll see some of these different systems.

41
00:01:57,240 --> 00:01:59,090
There's my Windows VM, my Linux VM.

42
00:01:59,090 --> 00:02:00,559
So I didn't name it, but
it's this guy right here.

43
00:02:00,559 --> 00:02:04,867
So I've got three hard drives attached to
that server and they're sitting there,

44
00:02:04,867 --> 00:02:06,600
and that's gonna cost me money.

45
00:02:06,600 --> 00:02:10,180
I've got a snapshot of one of them, so
the snapshot is costing me money too.

46
00:02:10,180 --> 00:02:14,390
So as long as I leave this server here,
I am kind of wasting money.

47
00:02:14,390 --> 00:02:15,299
So let's get rid of it.

48
00:02:15,299 --> 00:02:19,645
Well, to get rid of it,
you just go to your Instances, you select

49
00:02:19,645 --> 00:02:25,330
the instance you want to get rid of,
and you go to Actions and Terminate.

50
00:02:25,330 --> 00:02:29,940
When you choose Terminate, it's gonna
shut the VM down if it's still running.

51
00:02:29,940 --> 00:02:31,719
If it's already off,
it doesn't have to do that, obviously.

52
00:02:31,719 --> 00:02:33,970
And then it's gonna remove it.

53
00:02:33,970 --> 00:02:36,490
Now, removing doesn't happen instantly.

54
00:02:36,490 --> 00:02:38,260
It takes a little bit of time.

55
00:02:38,260 --> 00:02:40,960
It sits there and
it thinks about it, and over time,

56
00:02:40,960 --> 00:02:42,580
it gets to where it'll remove it.

57
00:02:42,580 --> 00:02:44,870
Let me take like this Windows one here.

58
00:02:44,870 --> 00:02:46,350
I'll toast this guy.

59
00:02:46,350 --> 00:02:49,110
So I'm gonna take the Windows one and
I'll go down here to Terminate.

60
00:02:49,110 --> 00:02:51,640
It's running right now, so it's warning
me that it's gonna shut it down and

61
00:02:51,640 --> 00:02:52,910
it's gonna wipe it out.

62
00:02:52,910 --> 00:02:56,030
It's telling me here on
an EBS-backed instance

63
00:02:56,030 --> 00:02:59,720
the default function is
to delete the drives.

64
00:02:59,720 --> 00:03:00,860
So when I terminate it,

65
00:03:00,860 --> 00:03:04,980
not only am I removing the VM,
the drives are gonna get deleted too.

66
00:03:04,980 --> 00:03:07,590
If I want to preserve those drives,
I need to go and

67
00:03:07,590 --> 00:03:10,300
back them up or
detach them from the VM first.

68
00:03:10,300 --> 00:03:13,060
If you detach them,
then you can remove the instance, and

69
00:03:13,060 --> 00:03:14,430
the drives will stay behind.

70
00:03:14,430 --> 00:03:16,560
You might need that data somewhere else.

71
00:03:16,560 --> 00:03:17,140
All right.

72
00:03:17,140 --> 00:03:20,940
You've also got the option to
release the Elastic IP, right.

73
00:03:20,940 --> 00:03:23,760
You may not want that,
you may want to keep the Elastic IP so

74
00:03:23,760 --> 00:03:25,210
you can assign it to another server.

75
00:03:25,210 --> 00:03:28,330
It's an IP you've been using for a while,
you might not want to give that back.

76
00:03:28,330 --> 00:03:31,030
I don't like to release
the IPs because I know another

77
00:03:31,030 --> 00:03:33,300
Amazon AWS customer is gonna get it.

78
00:03:33,300 --> 00:03:36,540
And so, somebody might be going to a
website that I had been running on one IP,

79
00:03:36,540 --> 00:03:40,080
and now that IP is showing something else,
something I don't control.

80
00:03:40,080 --> 00:03:43,280
So I usually hold on to the Elastic IP for
a little while,

81
00:03:43,280 --> 00:03:47,750
just to make sure everybody's caches have
updated and nobody's hitting that old IP.

82
00:03:47,750 --> 00:03:49,230
So just keep that in mind too.

83
00:03:49,230 --> 00:03:53,870
The default is to keep the Elastic IP,
you can choose to release it here.

84
00:03:53,870 --> 00:03:57,920
When we say Yes to Terminate,
it's gonna go and terminate that system.

85
00:03:57,920 --> 00:03:59,810
You'll see it's shutting it down.

86
00:03:59,810 --> 00:04:02,600
And when it's done,
it's going to remove it.

87
00:04:02,600 --> 00:04:04,760
Now, the removal doesn't
happen right away.

88
00:04:04,760 --> 00:04:07,880
Once it shuts down,
you're no longer being billed for it.

89
00:04:07,880 --> 00:04:09,230
I am being billed right now.

90
00:04:09,230 --> 00:04:12,560
But as soon as it finishes shutting down,
my billing stops.

91
00:04:12,560 --> 00:04:16,610
It will still show up in your console for
up to 48 hours.

92
00:04:16,610 --> 00:04:19,760
So for up to 48 hours, it may still
be sitting there in your console and

93
00:04:19,760 --> 00:04:21,870
show with a terminated status.

94
00:04:21,870 --> 00:04:26,060
And just at some point, Amazon runs
a clean up service and removes it.

95
00:04:26,060 --> 00:04:27,910
It's a low priority task for them.

96
00:04:27,910 --> 00:04:29,430
They're not billing you for it.

97
00:04:29,430 --> 00:04:32,120
So it's not hurting
anything to leave it there.

98
00:04:32,120 --> 00:04:35,028
So they wait for times when their
servers are idle or slow and

99
00:04:35,028 --> 00:04:37,877
disk access isn't a big deal,
and that's when they go and

100
00:04:37,877 --> 00:04:40,600
they wipe your machine and
actually remove it.

101
00:04:40,600 --> 00:04:43,160
So the termination may
not happen right away.

102
00:04:43,160 --> 00:04:45,690
See how mine says Terminated but
it's still here.

103
00:04:45,690 --> 00:04:49,630
And if I hit Refresh,
I'll refresh and it's still there.

104
00:04:49,630 --> 00:04:53,710
And it'll sit there, it'll sit for
hours before it finally disappears.

105
00:04:53,710 --> 00:04:56,657
If you catch it at the right time,
it might delete right away, but

106
00:04:56,657 --> 00:04:59,024
I find that it normally takes
at least the few hours.

107
00:04:59,024 --> 00:05:02,165
All right, so that one is terminated,
the Windows VM is detached.

108
00:05:02,165 --> 00:05:07,635
If I go down to my Volumes and I look
at my volumes down here, I'll see that

109
00:05:07,635 --> 00:05:11,195
the one that was flagged as Windows VM
that was here at the bottom is now gone.

110
00:05:11,195 --> 00:05:15,940
So the volume was deleted, I no longer
have its drive, and that's it, all right.

111
00:05:15,940 --> 00:05:20,760
So that's a normal,
run of the mill deletion, or termination.

112
00:05:20,760 --> 00:05:22,520
That's what most of you will see.

113
00:05:22,520 --> 00:05:24,840
But there's a few caveats, all right.

114
00:05:24,840 --> 00:05:29,560
When you create a VM, when you're
initially building up that instance,

115
00:05:29,560 --> 00:05:33,540
there's a few choices you make that
can effect termination, all right.

116
00:05:33,540 --> 00:05:36,750
And if you're not the one
that built up that instance,

117
00:05:36,750 --> 00:05:38,750
you might not know which
options were chosen.

118
00:05:38,750 --> 00:05:43,940
So we may bump into a few instances where
it won't allow us to terminate, all right.

119
00:05:43,940 --> 00:05:44,590
Let me show you what I mean.

120
00:05:44,590 --> 00:05:46,670
I'm gonna go and create a new instance.

121
00:05:46,670 --> 00:05:49,319
So I'll go back to my Instance page
here and I'll do Launch an Instance.

122
00:05:50,350 --> 00:05:55,015
And if I just do the simple wizard here,
I take the Amazon Linux, or Red Hat or,

123
00:05:55,015 --> 00:05:56,592
let's do SUSE this time.

124
00:05:56,592 --> 00:05:58,630
I'll pick that one, all right.

125
00:05:58,630 --> 00:06:00,341
When we go to launch it,
we pick some stuff.

126
00:06:00,341 --> 00:06:03,026
If you just hit Review and Launch,
it'll create a normal machine and

127
00:06:03,026 --> 00:06:05,060
it'll terminate just fine.

128
00:06:05,060 --> 00:06:08,052
But if we go into our advanced settings,

129
00:06:08,052 --> 00:06:12,018
if we start going into our
details down here, right?

130
00:06:12,018 --> 00:06:15,022
When we start going into the details we
get options that we can change that start

131
00:06:15,022 --> 00:06:16,290
to manipulate things.

132
00:06:16,290 --> 00:06:21,370
When you look down, you see
Enable Termination Protection, all right?

133
00:06:22,432 --> 00:06:27,130
There is nothing worse than getting
that sinking feeling when you

134
00:06:27,130 --> 00:06:30,340
accidentally terminate a machine and
you didn't mean it.

135
00:06:30,340 --> 00:06:33,340
You were going to use Stop
just to shut it down, and

136
00:06:33,340 --> 00:06:35,560
you accidentally clicked Terminate, right?

137
00:06:35,560 --> 00:06:38,390
Or maybe you hired a new employee,
and they're like, hey,

138
00:06:38,390 --> 00:06:39,850
I want to shut this machine down.

139
00:06:39,850 --> 00:06:41,440
Terminate?
That sounds like it'll shut it down.

140
00:06:41,440 --> 00:06:42,710
Let's do it.

141
00:06:42,710 --> 00:06:46,180
So somebody accidentally chooses that and
deletes the server.

142
00:06:46,180 --> 00:06:48,690
Now, that's not the kind of person you
should have working in the system,

143
00:06:48,690 --> 00:06:49,630
but it can happen.

144
00:06:49,630 --> 00:06:51,030
It can happen accidentally.

145
00:06:51,030 --> 00:06:52,520
You get a confirmation screen, so

146
00:06:52,520 --> 00:06:55,840
you'd really have to screw up pretty
bad to make it happen, but it could.

147
00:06:55,840 --> 00:07:00,390
So we have the option to turn on
Accidental Termination Protection.

148
00:07:00,390 --> 00:07:04,260
This will not allow you to terminate
the instance while it's turned on.

149
00:07:04,260 --> 00:07:08,490
So someone, if they want to terminate it,
they would have to actively turn off

150
00:07:08,490 --> 00:07:11,260
the protection, and
then terminate the instance.

151
00:07:11,260 --> 00:07:13,490
It's a nice little safety net to have,
all right?

152
00:07:13,490 --> 00:07:16,950
You definitely don't want that on an auto
scaling environment, where you're

153
00:07:16,950 --> 00:07:21,330
having machines spawn up and terminate
automatically, you don't want that.

154
00:07:21,330 --> 00:07:24,630
But on systems that you want 24/7,
365 days a year,

155
00:07:24,630 --> 00:07:26,808
there's no reason not to turn that on.

156
00:07:26,808 --> 00:07:30,240
We can turn on that protection, all right?

157
00:07:30,240 --> 00:07:33,870
The other place that we can bump into
problems is on the storage side.

158
00:07:33,870 --> 00:07:37,470
On the storage side, when we create
a drive, there's gonna be a root drive,

159
00:07:37,470 --> 00:07:39,230
right, there's always a root drive.

160
00:07:39,230 --> 00:07:44,108
And you'll see Delete on Termination
is checked by default, okay.

161
00:07:44,108 --> 00:07:47,910
That means that if I delete this instance,
this volume is gonna get deleted also.

162
00:07:47,910 --> 00:07:49,736
Makes sense, it's the root,
the instance doesn't exist so

163
00:07:49,736 --> 00:07:51,630
we don't need the root anymore.

164
00:07:51,630 --> 00:07:54,150
But if you've added more drives,
watch the default.

165
00:07:54,150 --> 00:07:56,750
I'm gonna go and add a few more drives.

166
00:07:56,750 --> 00:08:00,480
The default is not to
delete on termination.

167
00:08:00,480 --> 00:08:03,980
So if somebody went in here and they just
whipped up a couple of 64 gig drives like

168
00:08:03,980 --> 00:08:09,190
this, when it was all said and done, if
they didn't pay attention to this column,

169
00:08:09,190 --> 00:08:11,460
some of your volumes might
not be set to delete.

170
00:08:11,460 --> 00:08:13,750
So when you go and
delete this instance, when you go and

171
00:08:13,750 --> 00:08:16,190
terminate the instance,
some of the volumes get left behind.

172
00:08:16,190 --> 00:08:18,370
And you’re getting billed for that.

173
00:08:18,370 --> 00:08:21,030
You’re getting billed for
the storage of those volumes.

174
00:08:21,030 --> 00:08:24,950
If you delete the instance, the name
attached to the volume disappears.

175
00:08:24,950 --> 00:08:28,030
And so now when you go into the volumes
list, you see this list of volumes.

176
00:08:28,030 --> 00:08:30,904
And you can see you've got volumes
that aren't attached to anybody, but

177
00:08:30,904 --> 00:08:32,398
you don't know where they came from.

178
00:08:32,398 --> 00:08:34,570
You're like,
where the heck did that volume come from?

179
00:08:34,570 --> 00:08:36,220
Is it safe to delete?

180
00:08:36,220 --> 00:08:37,260
I don't know.

181
00:08:37,260 --> 00:08:38,850
That's the challenge.

182
00:08:38,850 --> 00:08:41,000
So, oftentimes we do want this.

183
00:08:41,000 --> 00:08:43,980
We do want to delete on termination,
so we check those off.

184
00:08:43,980 --> 00:08:46,120
But you might not,
you might want to save that data.

185
00:08:46,120 --> 00:08:49,929
And if you do that, it's really
important that you label your volumes so

186
00:08:49,929 --> 00:08:52,870
that you can remember
where they came from.

187
00:08:52,870 --> 00:08:56,770
Because the names that Amazon attaches
to them are not terribly useful,

188
00:08:56,770 --> 00:08:58,270
because they're just GUIDs.

189
00:08:58,270 --> 00:09:00,220
Amazon doesn't know what
you're gonna use these for.

190
00:09:00,220 --> 00:09:03,690
So you need to go back and either name
them, or tag them, or do something so

191
00:09:03,690 --> 00:09:04,900
you can identify where it came from.

192
00:09:06,320 --> 00:09:10,950
All right, so those are the two
big caveats that we can bump into.

193
00:09:10,950 --> 00:09:12,320
And let me show you those in action.

194
00:09:12,320 --> 00:09:16,780
I'm not actually gonna spin this VM up,
but let me go back to my EC2 screen.

195
00:09:16,780 --> 00:09:20,478
And before the show, I created
an instance, this guy right here.

196
00:09:20,478 --> 00:09:25,277
And I have termination
protection turned on, and

197
00:09:25,277 --> 00:09:32,390
one of my volumes doesn't have
a Delete on Terminate option set.

198
00:09:32,390 --> 00:09:35,069
Well first off, if I take this instance,
so I've got it right here.

199
00:09:35,069 --> 00:09:38,209
It doesn't have a name so I probably
need to give it some kind of a name.

200
00:09:38,209 --> 00:09:40,700
And so I'll call this my Temp VM.

201
00:09:40,700 --> 00:09:43,200
Maybe I'm just experimenting with
something so I create a Temp VM.

202
00:09:44,330 --> 00:09:44,840
It's got a name.

203
00:09:44,840 --> 00:09:49,307
And that's pretty nice because when I go
down to my volumes, I see these volumes,

204
00:09:49,307 --> 00:09:53,539
and none of the volumes have names,
they just have these volume IDs, right?

205
00:09:53,539 --> 00:09:55,260
I don't know what heck they are.

206
00:09:55,260 --> 00:09:58,370
But if I scroll over here I can
see who they're attached to.

207
00:09:58,370 --> 00:10:02,550
And I see Linux VM and Temp VM,
so I can tell right there.

208
00:10:02,550 --> 00:10:05,310
But this is where we probably
want to give them a name.

209
00:10:05,310 --> 00:10:08,175
Because if I remove that instance,
this will go blank, and

210
00:10:08,175 --> 00:10:10,220
I'll have no idea where it came from.

211
00:10:10,220 --> 00:10:13,400
So I can go to these volumes and
I can say what they are.

212
00:10:13,400 --> 00:10:15,883
The small one, the 10 gig one,

213
00:10:15,883 --> 00:10:21,049
that's the first one that was created,
so that's the Temp VM Root.

214
00:10:21,049 --> 00:10:23,810
So I'll go ahead and give it that name so
I can remember that's what it was.

215
00:10:23,810 --> 00:10:26,380
But the other ones,
I don't know what they are yet.

216
00:10:26,380 --> 00:10:30,340
So when I create those drives and add
them, I'll probably assign them somewhere.

217
00:10:30,340 --> 00:10:34,110
So maybe this one is Temp VM/var folder.

218
00:10:36,060 --> 00:10:41,522
And then maybe this one
down here is Temp VMs/usr,

219
00:10:41,522 --> 00:10:44,709
or we'll do /home, right?

220
00:10:44,709 --> 00:10:47,689
So that's the /home folder on that drive,
all right?

221
00:10:47,689 --> 00:10:50,917
So now, not only do I know
what VM they were attached to,

222
00:10:50,917 --> 00:10:54,790
I know what that drive is,
what mount point was tied to that drive.

223
00:10:54,790 --> 00:10:58,520
So that I can identify it,
even after the VM is deleted, all right.

224
00:10:58,520 --> 00:10:59,570
And I'm doing it here by naming it.

225
00:10:59,570 --> 00:11:01,390
You don't have to do it with a name,
you can go down here and

226
00:11:01,390 --> 00:11:03,000
do it with a tag too, right.

227
00:11:03,000 --> 00:11:06,370
Remember, you can create custom tags and
you can add one in.

228
00:11:06,370 --> 00:11:09,099
That name, it's just a tag,
you see it right there, right.

229
00:11:09,099 --> 00:11:11,917
So you could create your own tags,
and then you can filter on them and

230
00:11:11,917 --> 00:11:13,760
do all sorts of crazy stuff, right.

231
00:11:13,760 --> 00:11:16,960
So here I've got the name and
the path in one value.

232
00:11:16,960 --> 00:11:19,600
I might want to do multiple ones,
a name and a path separately.

233
00:11:19,600 --> 00:11:24,850
So I can say, show me all the volumes tied
to Temp VM, and then I'll see each one.

234
00:11:24,850 --> 00:11:29,371
Or I can say, show me all the /vars for
all of my VMs, you can query on it if you

235
00:11:29,371 --> 00:11:33,219
got separate keys, so
that gives you a little more power there.

236
00:11:33,219 --> 00:11:36,780
All right, so now,
when I go up to my instances, If I try and

237
00:11:36,780 --> 00:11:41,510
delete Temp VM, I'll take that guy and
I'll go to Terminate.

238
00:11:41,510 --> 00:11:43,420
Terminate is lit up, and

239
00:11:43,420 --> 00:11:47,680
if you look, most of us don't really pay
attention to a lot of the options in here.

240
00:11:49,320 --> 00:11:53,741
We've got an option about the termination
protect, did I not turn on?

241
00:11:53,741 --> 00:11:55,535
Oh, sorry, here it is.

242
00:11:55,535 --> 00:11:57,100
[LAUGH] I couldn't find it in the list.

243
00:11:57,100 --> 00:12:00,590
You've got Change Termination Protection
right there, and if you choose

244
00:12:00,590 --> 00:12:03,880
Change Termination Protection you'll see,
it's currently enabled.

245
00:12:03,880 --> 00:12:05,100
And I can disable it.

246
00:12:05,100 --> 00:12:08,600
You can turn this on or
off whether the VM's on or off.

247
00:12:08,600 --> 00:12:10,130
It doesn't matter if the VM's running.

248
00:12:10,130 --> 00:12:11,520
So I could take this Linux VM and

249
00:12:11,520 --> 00:12:15,320
I could go and Change Termination
Protection, and enable it.

250
00:12:15,320 --> 00:12:18,960
I can turn it on, and
now I won't be able to terminate that.

251
00:12:18,960 --> 00:12:22,210
But notice when I choose the Temp VM,
I can go to Actions and

252
00:12:22,210 --> 00:12:23,670
Terminate is still lit up.

253
00:12:23,670 --> 00:12:25,450
Even though it's disabled,
it is still lit up.

254
00:12:25,450 --> 00:12:26,845
I can choose that.

255
00:12:26,845 --> 00:12:29,675
And it's just gonna say,
all right, go ahead.

256
00:12:29,675 --> 00:12:32,515
But when it goes to terminate,
it's not gonna do it.

257
00:12:32,515 --> 00:12:36,785
It says, This instance has Termination
Protection and will not be terminated.

258
00:12:36,785 --> 00:12:40,819
The button is there, it's clickable, but
it's kind of grayed out a little bit and

259
00:12:40,819 --> 00:12:41,753
it doesn't work.

260
00:12:41,753 --> 00:12:43,125
[LAUGH] It doesn't do anything.

261
00:12:43,125 --> 00:12:46,115
So as long as you've got
Termination Protection, you're safe.

262
00:12:46,115 --> 00:12:50,730
And you can go to Actions and
Change Termination Protection, and

263
00:12:50,730 --> 00:12:52,770
you can disable it.

264
00:12:52,770 --> 00:12:58,348
Once it's disabled, now, you can go and
terminate that instance.

265
00:12:58,348 --> 00:13:00,857
And now it's not giving me
that warning anymore, and

266
00:13:00,857 --> 00:13:03,260
it's asking what I wanna
do about the volumes.

267
00:13:03,260 --> 00:13:06,040
The default is to delete them,
so I get a nice little warning.

268
00:13:06,040 --> 00:13:08,190
And this one is giving
me a warning right here,

269
00:13:08,190 --> 00:13:12,020
The following volume is not
set to delete on termination.

270
00:13:12,020 --> 00:13:13,700
And see how it gives you the volume ID?

271
00:13:13,700 --> 00:13:16,200
That's because it doesn't
know if you gave it a name.

272
00:13:16,200 --> 00:13:18,160
And so, if you didn't give it a name,
how do you identify it?

273
00:13:18,160 --> 00:13:19,270
Here's the volume ID.

274
00:13:19,270 --> 00:13:24,000
So I know this volume ID is gonna be
orphaned when I delete this instance.

275
00:13:24,000 --> 00:13:26,820
I wouldn't have seen that if I
didn't click that down arrow, right.

276
00:13:26,820 --> 00:13:28,580
The default is not to even show you that.

277
00:13:28,580 --> 00:13:30,750
So you don't know that you're
about to leave a volume behind.

278
00:13:30,750 --> 00:13:33,450
I'll go ahead and say, Yes to Terminate.

279
00:13:33,450 --> 00:13:35,550
And it's gonna terminate that VM.

280
00:13:35,550 --> 00:13:37,780
I'll give it a second while
it flips to terminate.

281
00:13:37,780 --> 00:13:41,834
Now, even if I didn't get that volume ID,
because I named my volumes,

282
00:13:41,834 --> 00:13:44,680
it'll be easy for
me to spot what was left behind.

283
00:13:44,680 --> 00:13:48,160
If you didn't name it, that's where
things become challenging, right.

284
00:13:48,160 --> 00:13:51,040
In my little demo environment here,
I've only got a couple of volumes.

285
00:13:51,040 --> 00:13:53,710
But imagine if you had 1,000
volumes in there, right?

286
00:13:53,710 --> 00:13:55,430
How many orphans could you generate?

287
00:13:55,430 --> 00:13:58,157
And then how do you tell one orphan apart
from another to figure out which one you

288
00:13:58,157 --> 00:13:59,170
wanna actually remove?

289
00:13:59,170 --> 00:14:01,540
It gets really confusing really fast.

290
00:14:01,540 --> 00:14:05,900
And that's because the AWS console doesn't
really track a history of an object.

291
00:14:05,900 --> 00:14:09,530
You don't have an audit log for that
object to see what VM it was attached to.

292
00:14:09,530 --> 00:14:12,927
There are ways to pull that
from the Amazon API, but

293
00:14:12,927 --> 00:14:15,069
in the GUI, we don't see that.

294
00:14:15,069 --> 00:14:17,330
All right, so it's shutting that VM down.

295
00:14:18,560 --> 00:14:21,400
I'm trying to remember what
operating system I did on that,

296
00:14:21,400 --> 00:14:22,530
I think it was a Red Hat VM.

297
00:14:22,530 --> 00:14:25,420
So it shouldn't take too
terribly long to shut down.

298
00:14:25,420 --> 00:14:28,590
But it's gonna shut down and
once it's done, it'll go to Terminate.

299
00:14:28,590 --> 00:14:31,220
Now as long as it's shutting down,
all the drives are still gonna be there.

300
00:14:31,220 --> 00:14:32,619
It won't get rid of them
until they're gone.

301
00:14:32,619 --> 00:14:35,560
So I'm trying to stall here for
a second while it terminates.

302
00:14:35,560 --> 00:14:37,280
There we go.
All right, so

303
00:14:37,280 --> 00:14:39,470
it shows it's terminated, it's gone.

304
00:14:39,470 --> 00:14:44,470
And if I go down to my volumes,
I'll see the other volumes are gone.

305
00:14:44,470 --> 00:14:48,520
So the Temp VM Root,
Temp VM/home, they're gone.

306
00:14:48,520 --> 00:14:51,670
But Temp VM/var was left behind.

307
00:14:51,670 --> 00:14:54,590
So there it is right there, still sitting,
and I know who it came from.

308
00:14:54,590 --> 00:14:58,749
If I scroll over here,
the attached information is empty.

309
00:14:58,749 --> 00:15:02,180
And that's where we get lost, that's where
we don't remember where it came from.

310
00:15:02,180 --> 00:15:06,190
So having a name or having tags to be able
to identify it is really important, and

311
00:15:06,190 --> 00:15:08,230
it's up to you to set those.

312
00:15:08,230 --> 00:15:12,150
But now I can come in and I can
choose that disk and I can remove it.

313
00:15:12,150 --> 00:15:15,660
So if I wanna get rid of that I can
delete the volume right there and

314
00:15:15,660 --> 00:15:16,610
bump that one out.

315
00:15:16,610 --> 00:15:19,630
I don't need it anymore, so
I'll delete it, and there it goes.

316
00:15:20,820 --> 00:15:25,070
So if you set up the VM,
you may have checked off all those boxes

317
00:15:25,070 --> 00:15:27,220
to delete the volumes
when they get removed.

318
00:15:27,220 --> 00:15:30,760
If you didn't set up the VM,
you don't know if they were set or not.

319
00:15:30,760 --> 00:15:33,390
So whenever you terminate an instance,
it's a good idea to go back and

320
00:15:33,390 --> 00:15:35,330
check to make sure the volumes are gone.

321
00:15:35,330 --> 00:15:36,670
Same thing with the Elastic IPs.

322
00:15:36,670 --> 00:15:39,630
If there was a static IP
assigned to that instance and

323
00:15:39,630 --> 00:15:44,130
you've terminated the machine, if you
didn't choose that option to release it,

324
00:15:44,130 --> 00:15:45,130
you're still being billed for it.

325
00:15:45,130 --> 00:15:50,080
So you need to go down to Elastic IPs,
and find that unattached IP address, and

326
00:15:50,080 --> 00:15:52,240
attach it back to your instance,
all right.

327
00:15:52,240 --> 00:15:54,160
So that's another little caveat,

328
00:15:54,160 --> 00:15:57,178
a thing that we need to be aware
of when we set all this up.

329
00:15:57,178 --> 00:16:00,892
All right, so in this segment we got to
see a chance to terminate the instance,

330
00:16:00,892 --> 00:16:03,820
get it out of there,
[LAUGH] get us to stop being billed.

331
00:16:03,820 --> 00:16:05,350
It's a pretty straight forward process.

332
00:16:05,350 --> 00:16:08,569
But you guys see where there's a couple
little hang ups that we can bump into.

333
00:16:08,569 --> 00:16:10,280
I hope you guys enjoyed the segment.

334
00:16:10,280 --> 00:16:12,980
Stay tuned, we've got more AWS coming up.

episodes.title: Third Party S3 Software
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:08,209
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:08,209 --> 00:00:11,326
In this segment, we're going to take
a look at some third-party software that's

3
00:00:11,326 --> 00:00:13,560
available to work with Amazon S3.

4
00:00:13,560 --> 00:00:17,110
The web-based GUI for
Amazon S3 is pretty powerful.

5
00:00:17,110 --> 00:00:18,100
You can upload your data.

6
00:00:18,100 --> 00:00:20,270
You can start to work with it,
set your permissions and

7
00:00:20,270 --> 00:00:21,330
make that available to people.

8
00:00:21,330 --> 00:00:24,880
And for most of us that's
probably good enough, all right?

9
00:00:24,880 --> 00:00:29,410
But one area that the web based
GUI suffers is bulk uploads.

10
00:00:29,410 --> 00:00:32,880
If you're loading large amounts of data or
swapping out data, right?

11
00:00:32,880 --> 00:00:34,510
Replacing your old file with a new file,

12
00:00:34,510 --> 00:00:38,540
the web-based GUI gets to be pretty
cumbersome, pretty fast, all right?

13
00:00:38,540 --> 00:00:41,320
So there are a number third-party
companies out there that have made

14
00:00:41,320 --> 00:00:42,000
software to do this.

15
00:00:42,000 --> 00:00:46,490
I guess it's worth mentioning also,
you can use the S3 API to do it.

16
00:00:46,490 --> 00:00:48,950
So the application programming interface,

17
00:00:48,950 --> 00:00:52,630
you can have a software that
reaches right out into Amazon S3.

18
00:00:52,630 --> 00:00:56,150
If your company is developing a product,
then you'll probably want to do that.

19
00:00:56,150 --> 00:01:00,850
But if you're just a company that isn't
focused on providing web services, but

20
00:01:00,850 --> 00:01:03,960
is just trying to put your data somewhere
to make it available to your customers,

21
00:01:03,960 --> 00:01:06,138
you don't wanna have to go in and
invent a program for this.

22
00:01:06,138 --> 00:01:10,450
So there's third-party providers out
there that have taken the Amazon API, and

23
00:01:10,450 --> 00:01:13,530
developed really nice
graphical user interfaces and

24
00:01:13,530 --> 00:01:17,150
simple clients that you can run on your
machine, that make it a lot easier to

25
00:01:17,150 --> 00:01:21,760
bulk upload files, manipulate permissions,
remove files, and so on, all right.

26
00:01:21,760 --> 00:01:25,375
So let's take a look at some
of the more popular ones.

27
00:01:25,375 --> 00:01:27,414
I actually use one myself
that's not as popular and

28
00:01:27,414 --> 00:01:29,980
some of the guys in the studio
were making fun of me.

29
00:01:29,980 --> 00:01:34,250
Probably the most popular S3 client you'll
hear about is one called Cyberduck.

30
00:01:34,250 --> 00:01:35,840
Now Cyberduck is just for the Mac.

31
00:01:35,840 --> 00:01:36,740
So not on the Windows side.

32
00:01:36,740 --> 00:01:38,500
I'll do a Windows one here in a moment.

33
00:01:38,500 --> 00:01:40,870
But Cyberduck is a third party utility.

34
00:01:40,870 --> 00:01:45,730
You can get it at Cyberduck.io or
it's in the MacOS app store, amazingly.

35
00:01:45,730 --> 00:01:50,350
If you go to their website, it's free and
they just ask for donations.

36
00:01:50,350 --> 00:01:52,080
You go in the app store and it's $23.99.

37
00:01:52,080 --> 00:01:55,740
So they do charge there, but
here it's free, but they want donations.

38
00:01:55,740 --> 00:02:00,650
Now, the neat thing about Cyberduck
is it connects to FTP, SFTP, WebDev,

39
00:02:00,650 --> 00:02:05,900
S3, OpenStack Swift, which means
it connects to Google Drive, also.

40
00:02:05,900 --> 00:02:10,220
It connects to a number of different
storage areas so that you can access it.

41
00:02:10,220 --> 00:02:12,580
And it basically works like an FTP client.

42
00:02:12,580 --> 00:02:14,530
You'll see,
if you've ever used an FTP client,

43
00:02:14,530 --> 00:02:16,700
you know when you connect up to a server.

44
00:02:16,700 --> 00:02:17,660
You see something like this.

45
00:02:17,660 --> 00:02:20,770
Here is one of the buckets for
this particular user.

46
00:02:20,770 --> 00:02:25,550
And you'll see where they've uploaded
image files and nightly files, updates,

47
00:02:25,550 --> 00:02:26,990
source codes and so on.

48
00:02:26,990 --> 00:02:29,200
They're uploading it and there it is.

49
00:02:29,200 --> 00:02:33,040
Right, a graphical client, we can just
drag and drop the files that we want.

50
00:02:33,040 --> 00:02:36,480
You can pull up the properties and
permissions on each of these files and

51
00:02:36,480 --> 00:02:40,050
work with them in a very simple,
easy to use, GUI, all right.

52
00:02:40,050 --> 00:02:41,730
You know, I said it was Mac only,

53
00:02:41,730 --> 00:02:44,420
they do have a Windows downloader here,
look at that.

54
00:02:44,420 --> 00:02:46,180
You learn something new everyday.

55
00:02:46,180 --> 00:02:48,430
So it looks like this one is a Windows and
Mac only,

56
00:02:48,430 --> 00:02:51,380
I'll have to backtrack on my
statement from a minute ago.

57
00:02:51,380 --> 00:02:54,630
But Cyberduck, very popular,
a lot of people make use of this.

58
00:02:54,630 --> 00:02:57,070
So definitely one you should check out.

59
00:02:57,070 --> 00:03:00,220
If Cyberducks not to your liking there is
another couple of offerings that are out

60
00:03:00,220 --> 00:03:02,142
there that are pretty popular.

61
00:03:02,142 --> 00:03:05,800
Cloudberry, Cloudberry explorer
is the one that I used to use.

62
00:03:05,800 --> 00:03:07,900
CloudBerry Explorer actually
has two different additions.

63
00:03:07,900 --> 00:03:10,140
They have a freeware Windows client and

64
00:03:10,140 --> 00:03:13,040
they have a paid one that had
some more advanced functionality.

65
00:03:13,040 --> 00:03:15,050
Now CloudBerry is Windows only.

66
00:03:15,050 --> 00:03:19,870
So notice they mention that Windows
download and that's about it right, so

67
00:03:19,870 --> 00:03:21,110
we don't see that.

68
00:03:21,110 --> 00:03:22,740
The free one is absolutely free.

69
00:03:22,740 --> 00:03:26,680
The advanced one is just $40, right,
so it's not terribly expensive.

70
00:03:26,680 --> 00:03:29,850
But it works very similar to Cyber Duck,
except, its UI,

71
00:03:29,850 --> 00:03:33,130
its user interface,
looks a lot more like an FTP client.

72
00:03:33,130 --> 00:03:36,260
So you've got multiple panes,
the left side being your computer,

73
00:03:36,260 --> 00:03:39,420
the right side being your S3 bucket,
and you can copy stuff.

74
00:03:39,420 --> 00:03:41,070
It does some things that I really like.

75
00:03:41,070 --> 00:03:45,840
It makes it really easy to adjust
the mime, or the metadata, for files.

76
00:03:45,840 --> 00:03:47,110
So you can change their mime type,

77
00:03:47,110 --> 00:03:49,860
you can change the metadata, and
include all sorts of neat stuff, and

78
00:03:49,860 --> 00:03:52,900
you can do it on the fly, without
having to download the files to do it.

79
00:03:52,900 --> 00:03:56,730
You could easily rename and
move files and change their permissions.

80
00:03:56,730 --> 00:04:00,800
So, neat stuff, all done right
here through a simple GUI client.

81
00:04:00,800 --> 00:04:04,290
And that's just CloudBerryLab.com
if you want to check that one out.

82
00:04:05,640 --> 00:04:07,460
The third one is the one that I use,
all right?

83
00:04:07,460 --> 00:04:08,950
And you might've noticed
this in a lot of my shows,

84
00:04:08,950 --> 00:04:12,070
I have this little accordion icon
here at the top of my screen.

85
00:04:12,070 --> 00:04:14,660
And that's because I use
a program called ExpanDrive.

86
00:04:14,660 --> 00:04:16,490
And I have it for Mac and Windows.

87
00:04:16,490 --> 00:04:18,930
I always like to have software
that works in both environments.

88
00:04:18,930 --> 00:04:20,510
And so this is the one that I use.

89
00:04:20,510 --> 00:04:25,230
What ExpanDrive does, is it allows you
to mount network storage locations

90
00:04:25,230 --> 00:04:27,920
as if they were local folders or
if they were network folders.

91
00:04:27,920 --> 00:04:32,610
So, this kind of takes the whole foreign
storage thing out of the picture.

92
00:04:32,610 --> 00:04:35,570
It just makes it look like
map drives on your system.

93
00:04:35,570 --> 00:04:37,540
So on Windows you can map
them to drive letters.

94
00:04:37,540 --> 00:04:40,130
You can map your S3
bucket to your S drive.

95
00:04:40,130 --> 00:04:43,530
And when you browse to S:,
you're actually in your S3 bucket and

96
00:04:43,530 --> 00:04:44,980
then working with your data.

97
00:04:44,980 --> 00:04:47,520
and if you're on your Mac you just mount
them to folders right there on your

98
00:04:47,520 --> 00:04:50,950
desktop and you can browse right
into them and gain access to it.

99
00:04:50,950 --> 00:04:55,650
Much like Cyberduck it supports SFTP,
Google Drive and

100
00:04:55,650 --> 00:04:57,454
so on, if I can go into their
site I can get the whole list,

101
00:04:59,195 --> 00:05:01,905
probably in a crazy video that I
don't want to watch, but here you go.

102
00:05:01,905 --> 00:05:05,096
So Dropbox, Box, Google Drive,
and all these guys, but

103
00:05:05,096 --> 00:05:08,175
Amazon S3 is right there in the list,
and so I use this.

104
00:05:08,175 --> 00:05:13,185
If I hit my little expand drive button up
here, you'll see I've got my ITProTV site

105
00:05:13,185 --> 00:05:18,435
and Amazon S3 right there, to be able
to go in and gain access to my buckets.

106
00:05:18,435 --> 00:05:22,710
When you click on that, it's just going to
connect up and it'll mount it as a drive.

107
00:05:22,710 --> 00:05:23,840
And there it comes.

108
00:05:23,840 --> 00:05:27,160
So right there I can see this new hard
drive on my system called Amazon S3.

109
00:05:27,160 --> 00:05:29,730
And here's all the various buckets for
our system.

110
00:05:29,730 --> 00:05:30,700
So when you guys go and

111
00:05:30,700 --> 00:05:35,410
pull images out of our site, it's actually
coming from this ITProTV image bucket and.

112
00:05:35,410 --> 00:05:38,580
There's all the images,
the thumbnails, the other images.

113
00:05:38,580 --> 00:05:41,140
This is the stuff that you guys see
when you are browsing our site or

114
00:05:41,140 --> 00:05:42,320
using our Roku channel.

115
00:05:42,320 --> 00:05:43,712
All coming out of S3.

116
00:05:43,712 --> 00:05:46,510
All right, and if you're downloading
videos from our site, well,

117
00:05:46,510 --> 00:05:50,835
that's actually coming from our IT Pro
TV Video Bucket, which is right here.

118
00:05:50,835 --> 00:05:53,595
And this is the one, it's probably
a bit of a mess in here, let's see.

119
00:05:53,595 --> 00:05:55,205
But this is where the downloads come from.

120
00:05:55,205 --> 00:05:57,635
Now if you're streaming our video,
the streams don't come from here.

121
00:05:57,635 --> 00:06:02,675
Amazon S3 does not support streaming,
it supports downloading, right?

122
00:06:02,675 --> 00:06:04,885
So, for downloading videos it's great.

123
00:06:04,885 --> 00:06:06,075
For streaming videos,

124
00:06:06,075 --> 00:06:11,050
you'll really need to use Amazon Cloud
Front, or some other product like we do.

125
00:06:11,050 --> 00:06:14,400
But basically, I can browse in here
until when a new episode is recorded,

126
00:06:14,400 --> 00:06:17,850
when we add a new show, so
you'll see Amazon web services right here,

127
00:06:17,850 --> 00:06:20,820
they've already uploaded some
of the shows that we've filmed.

128
00:06:20,820 --> 00:06:21,950
We can see them right in here, so

129
00:06:21,950 --> 00:06:24,400
here's some of the STV stuff
that we filmed before.

130
00:06:24,400 --> 00:06:27,200
And these are new episodes now
that are gonna be tacked on and

131
00:06:27,200 --> 00:06:28,940
they'll just copy them right over there.

132
00:06:28,940 --> 00:06:31,990
And I can see that and
work with it like I'm browsing my drive.

133
00:06:31,990 --> 00:06:36,220
So, really neat stuff,
takes the difficulty out of S3.

134
00:06:36,220 --> 00:06:41,180
Even if you like the GUI in the web
based environment for AWS, even

135
00:06:41,180 --> 00:06:45,570
if you like that, you'll find that bulk
uploads are a lot easier with a client.

136
00:06:45,570 --> 00:06:47,940
The web based uploader
is not the greatest.

137
00:06:47,940 --> 00:06:50,550
And I've had some problems with
it with dealing with large files.

138
00:06:50,550 --> 00:06:55,890
So you're using something like Cloudberry
or CyberDuck or ExpanDrive or whatever.

139
00:06:55,890 --> 00:06:59,330
They're good solutions, and so
they can kind of take care of that.

140
00:06:59,330 --> 00:07:02,720
Also remember, if you're a developer,
there is the whole API open to you.

141
00:07:02,720 --> 00:07:06,140
These guys aren't doing any magic; there
is no secret here to what they are doing.

142
00:07:06,140 --> 00:07:08,330
They are just leveraging the published.

143
00:07:08,330 --> 00:07:10,960
As three APIs so
that you don't have to, right?

144
00:07:10,960 --> 00:07:14,350
So that's what you're paying for, and
is that worth 40 bucks or 25 bucks?

145
00:07:14,350 --> 00:07:17,040
Or is that worth free in
the case of CyberGuy?

146
00:07:17,040 --> 00:07:17,850
I think it is, right?

147
00:07:17,850 --> 00:07:21,080
So take advantage of those,
they're there for you.

148
00:07:21,080 --> 00:07:23,500
All right, so in this segment we got
a chance to see some of the third party

149
00:07:23,500 --> 00:07:26,375
software that's available I'm really just
hitting the tip of the iceberg, right?

150
00:07:26,375 --> 00:07:29,666
There is a ton of different vendors
out there that make software

151
00:07:29,666 --> 00:07:31,040
that interacts with S3.

152
00:07:31,040 --> 00:07:33,950
So, just be aware of that and
browse around.

153
00:07:33,950 --> 00:07:34,920
Try a few different ones.

154
00:07:34,920 --> 00:07:35,700
Find the one you like.

155
00:07:35,700 --> 00:07:37,950
All right,
I hope you guys enjoyed the segment.

156
00:07:37,950 --> 00:07:38,450
Stay tuned.

157
00:07:38,450 --> 00:07:40,780
We've got more Amazon
web services coming up.

episodes.title: Modifying Object Properties
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:08,167
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:08,167 --> 00:00:11,479
In this segment, we're gonna take a look
at modifying the properties of any of

3
00:00:11,479 --> 00:00:13,550
the files that we've
uploaded into Amazon S3.

4
00:00:14,610 --> 00:00:15,788
During the upload wizard,

5
00:00:15,788 --> 00:00:20,280
if you used the upload wizard, it's got
a couple of questions that it asks.

6
00:00:20,280 --> 00:00:24,060
And those questions are gonna determine
the default properties of an object

7
00:00:24,060 --> 00:00:27,970
once it goes up into S3, but
those questions are not permanent.

8
00:00:27,970 --> 00:00:29,380
They're not set in stone.

9
00:00:29,380 --> 00:00:33,850
You can actually change pretty much every
single thing that it asks in the wizard

10
00:00:33,850 --> 00:00:35,242
after the fact.

11
00:00:35,242 --> 00:00:38,330
So oftentimes when I'm doing
a bulk upload, if I'm uploading

12
00:00:38,330 --> 00:00:41,830
thousands of files, I won't even bother
setting the properties during the upload.

13
00:00:41,830 --> 00:00:45,400
I'll just go ahead and upload them, and
once they're in S3 I'll go back and

14
00:00:45,400 --> 00:00:46,830
start to modify from there.

15
00:00:47,850 --> 00:00:50,990
It's up to you how you want to go about
it, but the process is pretty simple.

16
00:00:50,990 --> 00:00:52,770
Let's see how to do it.

17
00:00:52,770 --> 00:00:56,070
Here I am in my AWS console and
I'm just going to go down to S3 to

18
00:00:56,070 --> 00:00:59,600
get to my S3 admin screen, and
I'll pick one of my buckets.

19
00:00:59,600 --> 00:01:02,760
So I'll go to this demo
bucket I created earlier.

20
00:01:02,760 --> 00:01:04,630
Inside of the bucket I've
got a couple of files.

21
00:01:04,630 --> 00:01:09,520
Now I uploaded these files earlier and
I chose various things in the wizard.

22
00:01:09,520 --> 00:01:11,820
Now if I remember that, it's great.

23
00:01:11,820 --> 00:01:14,410
But if you're like me,
it was more than five minutes ago so

24
00:01:14,410 --> 00:01:16,590
I've already forgotten
the options that I chose.

25
00:01:16,590 --> 00:01:18,990
I don't really remember if some
of these are set to public or

26
00:01:18,990 --> 00:01:20,300
not public or whatever.

27
00:01:20,300 --> 00:01:22,560
So I probably need to go back and
verify that and

28
00:01:22,560 --> 00:01:26,000
maybe even modify some of
the settings to meet my new needs.

29
00:01:26,000 --> 00:01:26,880
So we can go through and

30
00:01:26,880 --> 00:01:31,150
start to modify that using our
properties view up there on the right.

31
00:01:31,150 --> 00:01:33,190
To work with it,
you just check off a file, so

32
00:01:33,190 --> 00:01:38,120
I'll do this Apple-Remote-Desktop-Demo
video, and I can choose properties,

33
00:01:38,120 --> 00:01:41,800
and now I'll start to see information
about the properties that were set.

34
00:01:41,800 --> 00:01:44,340
This kind of reads like
the wizard when you upload it.

35
00:01:44,340 --> 00:01:47,518
You'll see a lot of the same options.

36
00:01:47,518 --> 00:01:50,990
Now for some of these options you can go
into the property screen and modify it.

37
00:01:50,990 --> 00:01:53,490
For some of them, though,
there's even easier ways.

38
00:01:53,490 --> 00:01:55,990
There's little shortcuts
in your right-click menu.

39
00:01:55,990 --> 00:01:59,940
If you right-click on a file
you'll see Make Public,

40
00:01:59,940 --> 00:02:04,100
Rename, and Properties, which really just
takes you to this screen right here.

41
00:02:04,100 --> 00:02:07,830
But Rename and Make Public,
those are the two that are easiest.

42
00:02:07,830 --> 00:02:10,770
We can quickly do these without even
going to the properties screen.

43
00:02:10,770 --> 00:02:13,225
Renaming files is nice because
you don't have to download it or

44
00:02:13,225 --> 00:02:14,300
re-upload it with a new name.

45
00:02:14,300 --> 00:02:17,870
You can just rename the file right there
is S3 without transferring the file.

46
00:02:17,870 --> 00:02:22,620
And making it public, that was a question
during the initial upload wizard.

47
00:02:22,620 --> 00:02:26,250
And maybe at that time we didn't want to
make it public, but now we are ready.

48
00:02:26,250 --> 00:02:28,150
So we can go in and
choose to make it public here, and

49
00:02:28,150 --> 00:02:30,660
that will give everyone permissions to it.

50
00:02:30,660 --> 00:02:33,898
So those are nice little shortcuts that
we can use to assign some things, but

51
00:02:33,898 --> 00:02:37,210
there's other things that aren't in
here that we really need to go to our

52
00:02:37,210 --> 00:02:38,960
properties screen for.

53
00:02:38,960 --> 00:02:41,760
So in our property screen, if we start to
look at some of the different things here.

54
00:02:41,760 --> 00:02:43,570
Let me move my browser so
my head's not on it.

55
00:02:43,570 --> 00:02:47,740
When we start to look at the property
screen here, it starts with details and

56
00:02:47,740 --> 00:02:49,050
there's not a whole lot in here.

57
00:02:49,050 --> 00:02:52,870
You've got the option to switch
between standard redundant storage and

58
00:02:52,870 --> 00:02:54,740
reduced redundancy storage.

59
00:02:54,740 --> 00:02:58,080
Reduced redundancy storage means put it
on hard drives that are not redundant.

60
00:02:58,080 --> 00:02:59,880
If a hard drive fails,
you'll lose your data.

61
00:03:00,930 --> 00:03:04,040
If you're replicating your data to more
than one data center, that may be okay and

62
00:03:04,040 --> 00:03:08,080
you can save money by using that
lower-cost non-redundant storage.

63
00:03:08,080 --> 00:03:11,380
But if you're putting all of it in one
data center and you don't want that to go

64
00:03:11,380 --> 00:03:15,010
offline, if you don't want to mess around
with load balancers and all that mess,

65
00:03:15,010 --> 00:03:17,930
then you can just stick with standard
storage and you'll get redundancy.

66
00:03:17,930 --> 00:03:21,490
A physical hard drive failure
will not take your data offline.

67
00:03:21,490 --> 00:03:23,490
The other thing is server side encryption.

68
00:03:23,490 --> 00:03:25,760
You can turn it on, they do AES 256,

69
00:03:25,760 --> 00:03:29,960
which is pretty strong, and
that'll encrypt your data on the server.

70
00:03:29,960 --> 00:03:32,360
Now Amazon manages the keys for that, so

71
00:03:32,360 --> 00:03:34,920
you are kind of trusting them
to provide the encryption.

72
00:03:34,920 --> 00:03:37,520
If you're using your own encryption,
you just leave that at none.

73
00:03:37,520 --> 00:03:39,480
And notice that you can go back and
forth on these.

74
00:03:39,480 --> 00:03:43,910
You can choose to move from standard
to reduced redundancy and back again.

75
00:03:43,910 --> 00:03:47,210
So these are things that we can
change our mind about later.

76
00:03:47,210 --> 00:03:50,780
Just understand that if you go between
one type of storage and another, or

77
00:03:50,780 --> 00:03:53,440
if you encrypt and then decrypt,
it does take time.

78
00:03:53,440 --> 00:03:55,630
It's not an immediate
change that that happens,

79
00:03:55,630 --> 00:03:57,200
cuz it's gotta go through and
process your data.

80
00:03:59,260 --> 00:04:01,220
The next part are permissions.

81
00:04:01,220 --> 00:04:06,070
The permissions screen is identical
to what we saw in the upload wizard.

82
00:04:06,070 --> 00:04:07,650
Right, here it's just very basic.

83
00:04:07,650 --> 00:04:09,690
You can specify who's a grantee,

84
00:04:09,690 --> 00:04:12,448
who we're granting permissions to,
and what they get.

85
00:04:12,448 --> 00:04:15,340
You'll see Open/Download,
Edit Permissions, and

86
00:04:15,340 --> 00:04:18,910
View Permissions and
my screen is rendering it a little weird.

87
00:04:18,910 --> 00:04:23,530
Let me see, well, yeah, Amazon didn't do
the greatest job of styling that one.

88
00:04:23,530 --> 00:04:25,730
But [LAUGH] you'll see here open and
download,

89
00:04:25,730 --> 00:04:30,330
that's what we normally want regular users
to be able do to get access to the file.

90
00:04:30,330 --> 00:04:31,280
View Permissions.

91
00:04:31,280 --> 00:04:33,950
They can look at the permissions on
the file to see who should have access.

92
00:04:33,950 --> 00:04:37,610
And then Edit Permissions, they can
actually change those permissions.

93
00:04:37,610 --> 00:04:39,500
So you can pick and choose.

94
00:04:39,500 --> 00:04:42,720
One of the options in the wizard
was to make a file public, or

95
00:04:42,720 --> 00:04:44,620
if I right-click I can make it public.

96
00:04:44,620 --> 00:04:47,330
You can do the same thing right
here in the permission screen.

97
00:04:47,330 --> 00:04:49,375
I can choose add more permissions.

98
00:04:49,375 --> 00:04:52,833
And for the grantee I can put everyone.

99
00:04:52,833 --> 00:04:56,500
Everyone, if I grant everyone
Open/Download, now anyone on

100
00:04:56,500 --> 00:05:01,190
the Internet will be able to access
this file, this video, and download it.

101
00:05:01,190 --> 00:05:02,610
Play it, whatever they want to do.

102
00:05:02,610 --> 00:05:03,610
They'll have that option.

103
00:05:05,460 --> 00:05:07,700
If I want them to be able to view and
edit permissions, I can do that to.

104
00:05:07,700 --> 00:05:10,790
That's a phenomenally bad idea
when you're doing it to everyone.

105
00:05:10,790 --> 00:05:12,910
But you might be granting
this to your own company.

106
00:05:12,910 --> 00:05:16,440
Maybe you've got 20 different AWS admins,
right?

107
00:05:16,440 --> 00:05:19,520
And so they all need the ability
to come in and manage these files.

108
00:05:19,520 --> 00:05:22,980
So I might choose to add more permissions,
so I'll add another set.

109
00:05:22,980 --> 00:05:25,940
And for the Grantee I might
pick Authenticated users.

110
00:05:25,940 --> 00:05:31,260
That would be anybody who has
an account inside of my AWS account.

111
00:05:31,260 --> 00:05:33,840
So I could pick that and
I can grant them full access.

112
00:05:33,840 --> 00:05:39,370
Or I can do just me or
the AWS demo account, which is my account.

113
00:05:39,370 --> 00:05:41,560
If I've created other accounts
I'll see them in the list.

114
00:05:41,560 --> 00:05:45,030
And you can even go into IAM and
create groups and issue it that way too.

115
00:05:45,030 --> 00:05:48,181
So you've got a lot of flexibility there
as far as issuing out that kind of

116
00:05:48,181 --> 00:05:48,810
permission.

117
00:05:50,200 --> 00:05:51,340
I'm gonna just delete that one out.

118
00:05:51,340 --> 00:05:53,310
So I'm basically making this one public.

119
00:05:53,310 --> 00:05:56,500
This is no different than right-clicking
on it and choosing Make Public or

120
00:05:56,500 --> 00:05:58,020
hitting that checkmark
when you do the upload.

121
00:06:00,280 --> 00:06:04,300
Notice that I've got a Save button here
inside of the Permissions section.

122
00:06:04,300 --> 00:06:07,160
Each section has its
own little Save button.

123
00:06:07,160 --> 00:06:10,310
But if you switch from one section
to another it doesn't erase it.

124
00:06:10,310 --> 00:06:11,680
So they're really all the same.

125
00:06:11,680 --> 00:06:14,360
So don't feel like you have
to hit Save on each one.

126
00:06:14,360 --> 00:06:15,730
You can just hit it one time for
all of them.

127
00:06:16,980 --> 00:06:19,360
Now the last section is the one that
I end up spending the most time with,

128
00:06:19,360 --> 00:06:20,760
which is Metadata.

129
00:06:20,760 --> 00:06:24,410
Inside of Metadata you can attach
information about this file so

130
00:06:24,410 --> 00:06:27,690
that other systems that are downloading
it will know how to handle it.

131
00:06:27,690 --> 00:06:30,430
You can specify all sorts of things.

132
00:06:30,430 --> 00:06:32,670
You'll see it's actually created one for
me.

133
00:06:32,670 --> 00:06:35,300
When I uploaded this, it was a video.

134
00:06:35,300 --> 00:06:38,360
And so Amazon looked at that,
recognized it and

135
00:06:38,360 --> 00:06:43,380
set it with a content type
of application/octet-stream.

136
00:06:43,380 --> 00:06:46,250
Octet-stream means don't play this.

137
00:06:46,250 --> 00:06:48,770
If you click on it, just download it.

138
00:06:48,770 --> 00:06:50,260
This is gonna be a downloadable video.

139
00:06:50,260 --> 00:06:53,160
If somebody clicks on it, it will
download to their system as a file.

140
00:06:53,160 --> 00:06:55,400
And then they can go and
play it however they want.

141
00:06:55,400 --> 00:06:57,010
That might be what we want.

142
00:06:57,010 --> 00:07:00,400
But maybe I want when they click
on this for it to actually play.

143
00:07:00,400 --> 00:07:03,820
I want this video to play in the browser,
not to download.

144
00:07:03,820 --> 00:07:07,170
So if I want that,
I need to change this content type.

145
00:07:07,170 --> 00:07:09,810
And you can use the drop-down box,
and you'll see some different ones.

146
00:07:09,810 --> 00:07:13,160
It's not complete, though, so if there's
one that you want to type that isn't

147
00:07:13,160 --> 00:07:15,570
there, you can just go in and
actually type it in.

148
00:07:15,570 --> 00:07:18,066
So I'm gonna put in video/mp4.

149
00:07:18,066 --> 00:07:22,920
When you do video/mp4,
now the systems that click on it will

150
00:07:22,920 --> 00:07:27,600
know that that's actually a mp4 file
that they can play and it'll play it.

151
00:07:27,600 --> 00:07:30,150
Now before I save that,
let me show you this in action.

152
00:07:30,150 --> 00:07:35,970
I'm gonna copy that URL and I'll just go
to another tab here in the background.

153
00:07:35,970 --> 00:07:39,140
If I browse to that URL,
right, so there it is.

154
00:07:39,140 --> 00:07:42,550
When I browse to it I'm getting
that it's an octet-stream and

155
00:07:42,550 --> 00:07:43,970
it's asking me to download it.

156
00:07:43,970 --> 00:07:46,050
So here it is I can choose
to save that file and

157
00:07:46,050 --> 00:07:47,290
I'll save it to my drive wherever.

158
00:07:48,550 --> 00:07:49,930
I'll cancel that.

159
00:07:49,930 --> 00:07:53,133
But if I go back here to
my Properties screen and

160
00:07:53,133 --> 00:07:57,580
I set this to video/mp4 and
I hit Save, it's gonna save that.

161
00:07:57,580 --> 00:07:59,690
That's gonna change that content type.

162
00:07:59,690 --> 00:08:04,760
And when somebody accesses this file,
the metadata will be presented to tell it,

163
00:08:04,760 --> 00:08:08,410
hey, this isn't just a octet-stream.

164
00:08:08,410 --> 00:08:10,140
This is actually an mp4.

165
00:08:10,140 --> 00:08:11,930
Now notice how long it's taking.

166
00:08:11,930 --> 00:08:14,180
This isn't something that's
simply written to the database.

167
00:08:14,180 --> 00:08:17,520
It's actually embedded in the file itself,
in the header, and

168
00:08:17,520 --> 00:08:19,580
so Amazon is having to
restructure that file.

169
00:08:19,580 --> 00:08:23,120
So when you change metadata,
it can take a while, so

170
00:08:23,120 --> 00:08:25,030
you do have to be patient with it.

171
00:08:25,030 --> 00:08:27,450
Content type is the one that
I work with the most, but

172
00:08:27,450 --> 00:08:30,560
there are tons of different file
metadata things that can be set.

173
00:08:30,560 --> 00:08:32,200
And you can even create
your own custom ones,

174
00:08:32,200 --> 00:08:35,700
which can be useful if you're tapping into
it with some kind of programming language.

175
00:08:35,700 --> 00:08:40,370
So you'll see Add more metadata and we
can start to add other records here that

176
00:08:40,370 --> 00:08:44,110
each perform different things,
for example, Content-Language.

177
00:08:44,110 --> 00:08:47,650
If you want to designate what language
this file is in, you can do it there.

178
00:08:47,650 --> 00:08:50,640
Or Expires, that's a nice one,
to be able to know, hey,

179
00:08:50,640 --> 00:08:51,983
you shouldn't be using this file.

180
00:08:51,983 --> 00:08:52,860
It's expired.

181
00:08:52,860 --> 00:08:54,820
There may be a replacement for it.

182
00:08:54,820 --> 00:08:56,860
You can do other things
like Cache Control.

183
00:08:56,860 --> 00:08:59,510
This is useful if you're worried
about people caching a web page that

184
00:08:59,510 --> 00:09:00,750
changes frequently.

185
00:09:00,750 --> 00:09:03,420
You can turn on Cache Control and
set it not to cache, and

186
00:09:03,420 --> 00:09:06,290
that way every time they
go they'll get a new copy.

187
00:09:06,290 --> 00:09:08,290
And again, this list is not even complete.

188
00:09:08,290 --> 00:09:10,580
There are a ton of other
ones that are out there.

189
00:09:10,580 --> 00:09:13,490
So if you've gotta a different key that
you wanna use, you can just type it in

190
00:09:13,490 --> 00:09:19,560
right here, for whatever it is that
you need, and then specify a value.

191
00:09:19,560 --> 00:09:23,350
Just keep in mind that if it's a custom
key, Amazon doesn't know what that is, and

192
00:09:23,350 --> 00:09:26,360
so this next drop-down box for
the values will always be blank.

193
00:09:26,360 --> 00:09:28,960
But on the one's that they know what
it is, a lot of times you'll find where

194
00:09:28,960 --> 00:09:31,895
the drop-down box will
actually show you options.

195
00:09:31,895 --> 00:09:37,150
And I'm not picking one that does it, but
basically you can pop that information in.

196
00:09:37,150 --> 00:09:39,290
But if it's a custom key,
they don't know what to display.

197
00:09:40,640 --> 00:09:42,600
So it saved that change for me.

198
00:09:42,600 --> 00:09:44,250
And I’m gonna take this URL again.

199
00:09:45,250 --> 00:09:45,880
It hasn’t changed.

200
00:09:45,880 --> 00:09:47,530
I guess I don’t need to copy it again.

201
00:09:47,530 --> 00:09:50,660
But I’ll go in here,
I’m gonna provide that URL a second time.

202
00:09:50,660 --> 00:09:54,930
And this time, when I go to it,
[LAUGH] it’s gonna download, great.

203
00:09:54,930 --> 00:09:57,820
I’ve more than likely cached
it with Cache Control, right?

204
00:09:57,820 --> 00:10:00,430
But when my browser goes to hit it,
it’ll see that new content type and

205
00:10:00,430 --> 00:10:02,930
it’ll say, hey, this is a video, an mp4.

206
00:10:02,930 --> 00:10:04,310
I should go ahead and play it.

207
00:10:04,310 --> 00:10:05,700
And it'll play it in browser.

208
00:10:05,700 --> 00:10:08,170
I don't know if that was a Google Chrome
thing there that did it or

209
00:10:08,170 --> 00:10:09,440
if I just have it cached.

210
00:10:09,440 --> 00:10:11,670
I've been having some issues with
Google Chrome's cache lately, so

211
00:10:11,670 --> 00:10:12,770
that's probably it.

212
00:10:12,770 --> 00:10:15,270
But it'll hit that and
it'll play the video.

213
00:10:15,270 --> 00:10:16,430
Content types are pretty important.

214
00:10:17,570 --> 00:10:22,020
So what we just saw were
the different properties

215
00:10:22,020 --> 00:10:25,280
that are right here on the object,
and this is what we'll normally do.

216
00:10:25,280 --> 00:10:28,240
The only negative about these is that
the properties really are just for

217
00:10:28,240 --> 00:10:29,790
a single object.

218
00:10:29,790 --> 00:10:31,820
I'm just modifying
the Apple remote desktop.

219
00:10:31,820 --> 00:10:35,540
But what if I have a bunch of videos
in here, what if I have a lot?

220
00:10:35,540 --> 00:10:40,370
Well, this property screen can work for
multiple files.

221
00:10:40,370 --> 00:10:43,890
If I click off more than one file and
I hit properties, it'll work.

222
00:10:43,890 --> 00:10:46,870
But notice how my options
just got really reduced.

223
00:10:48,100 --> 00:10:51,290
Now it's only showing me options
that are common across the files and

224
00:10:51,290 --> 00:10:56,510
even things like metadata disappear, and
now I can only specify these changes.

225
00:10:56,510 --> 00:11:00,130
So there are some changes we can
do in bulk, others we can't.

226
00:11:00,130 --> 00:11:01,550
If you want to do changes in bulk for

227
00:11:01,550 --> 00:11:05,480
something like metadata,
Amazon recommends you use their API.

228
00:11:05,480 --> 00:11:08,230
But another route is you can
use third-party clients.

229
00:11:08,230 --> 00:11:11,270
If you haven't checked it out, we recorded
a segment on third-party software that

230
00:11:11,270 --> 00:11:15,830
integrates with S3, and you can use
things like CloudBerry Explorer.

231
00:11:15,830 --> 00:11:18,400
It'll actually go and bulk set MIME types.

232
00:11:18,400 --> 00:11:21,330
The various things like that that it
can do that make it really handy for

233
00:11:21,330 --> 00:11:23,680
bulk changes of properties.

234
00:11:23,680 --> 00:11:26,040
But in the GUI,
these are the ones that we have.

235
00:11:26,040 --> 00:11:29,160
And we can go through and
modify those and get them set.

236
00:11:29,160 --> 00:11:33,130
Also keep in mind that the bucket
itself has properties.

237
00:11:33,130 --> 00:11:36,160
If I go back to my All Buckets screen and

238
00:11:36,160 --> 00:11:38,475
I go into Properties,
I'll see the properties for

239
00:11:38,475 --> 00:11:43,425
my bucket that was created, and you can
set permissions up at the bucket level.

240
00:11:43,425 --> 00:11:47,405
When you upload files they can actually
inherit the permissions of the bucket,

241
00:11:47,405 --> 00:11:50,065
if you want to go that route, and it makes
it where you don't have to go through and

242
00:11:50,065 --> 00:11:51,552
set a bunch of permissions.

243
00:11:51,552 --> 00:11:56,152
You can set the whole bucket as public,
and that saves you a lot of time.

244
00:11:56,152 --> 00:12:00,852
You'll also see other things in here for
manipulating things like the logging,

245
00:12:00,852 --> 00:12:04,192
lifecycle, how long the data's valid for,
tags and so on.

246
00:12:04,192 --> 00:12:06,862
There's a lot more advanced
stuff on the bucket itself.

247
00:12:06,862 --> 00:12:08,809
And we'll see some of these
features in another segment.

248
00:12:09,870 --> 00:12:12,950
All right, so in this segment we got a
chance to see modifying the properties on

249
00:12:12,950 --> 00:12:16,180
an object is pretty straightforward and
pretty useful stuff.

250
00:12:16,180 --> 00:12:17,560
Hope you guys enjoyed the segment.

251
00:12:17,560 --> 00:12:18,640
Stay tuned.
We've got more

252
00:12:18,640 --> 00:12:19,900
Amazon Web Services coming up.

episodes.title: Advanced Permissions In S3
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:08,125
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:08,125 --> 00:00:12,130
In this segment, we're going to take a
look at advanced permissions in Amazon S3.

3
00:00:12,130 --> 00:00:15,170
When you upload an object,
a file, a video, whatever, into

4
00:00:15,170 --> 00:00:19,540
Amazon S3 into one of your buckets, the
wizard will offer to set some permissions.

5
00:00:19,540 --> 00:00:22,430
And even after the fact, once something
is up into S3, you can go and

6
00:00:22,430 --> 00:00:23,730
modify the permissions.

7
00:00:23,730 --> 00:00:25,440
But as I’ve said in some
of my other segments,

8
00:00:25,440 --> 00:00:28,260
the permissions are really basic,
they’re fairly limited.

9
00:00:28,260 --> 00:00:32,530
You can designate everybody
has access to a file, or

10
00:00:32,530 --> 00:00:36,370
only particular users have access
to a file, but that’s about it.

11
00:00:36,370 --> 00:00:37,930
What if we wanna go more advanced?

12
00:00:37,930 --> 00:00:43,340
What if you want to say only this
IP address has access to a file or

13
00:00:43,340 --> 00:00:46,350
only people who have been
referred by my website,

14
00:00:46,350 --> 00:00:49,150
coming from a link on my domain,
are allowed to access that.

15
00:00:49,150 --> 00:00:51,075
So you are basically
disabling direct linking.

16
00:00:51,075 --> 00:00:52,570
You've got to come from this site.

17
00:00:52,570 --> 00:00:55,040
Well, we didn't see that in the wizard,
did we?

18
00:00:55,040 --> 00:00:56,980
And that's because it's not supported.

19
00:00:56,980 --> 00:00:59,980
It's not there in the permissions setting.

20
00:00:59,980 --> 00:01:03,590
But, in Amazon S3,
we can create what's called a policy.

21
00:01:03,590 --> 00:01:07,810
On our S3 bucket, you can create
a bucket policy that defines

22
00:01:07,810 --> 00:01:10,810
very advanced configuration examples.

23
00:01:10,810 --> 00:01:12,410
Examples like I said just a moment ago.

24
00:01:12,410 --> 00:01:15,330
Restricting access to particular IPs or
domains.

25
00:01:15,330 --> 00:01:19,780
Doing all sorts of really interesting
things and it's very powerful, but

26
00:01:19,780 --> 00:01:23,662
like any type of system that's very
powerful, it's pretty complex.

27
00:01:23,662 --> 00:01:24,650
All right.

28
00:01:24,650 --> 00:01:25,870
Let me show you what I mean.

29
00:01:25,870 --> 00:01:31,986
So here I am in my AWS console and if I go
down to S3, and I take a bucket, right.

30
00:01:31,986 --> 00:01:35,370
Like my ITProTV AWS demo bucket here.

31
00:01:35,370 --> 00:01:37,420
When I look at its properties,

32
00:01:38,810 --> 00:01:42,340
I'll see some basic information about
it and you'll see permissions, right?

33
00:01:42,340 --> 00:01:45,550
So here are some permissions that are set
on it, I've got my static logging,

34
00:01:45,550 --> 00:01:47,970
notifications, versioning, and so on.

35
00:01:47,970 --> 00:01:50,980
I don't really see any
mention about a policy and

36
00:01:50,980 --> 00:01:53,360
that's because it's hidden,
right here under permissions.

37
00:01:53,360 --> 00:01:55,860
I guess it's not really hidden,
it's just really small.

38
00:01:55,860 --> 00:01:59,842
You've got add more permissions,
and you've got add bucket policy.

39
00:01:59,842 --> 00:02:03,190
All right,
a bucket policy is that little script

40
00:02:03,190 --> 00:02:05,490
that we can write that
defines advanced permissions.

41
00:02:05,490 --> 00:02:07,940
Now when you hit add bucket policy,
what does it do?

42
00:02:07,940 --> 00:02:12,680
It gives you this, a text entry window and
you're ready to write.

43
00:02:12,680 --> 00:02:18,260
Well, the S3 bucket
policies use a proprietary,

44
00:02:18,260 --> 00:02:21,880
it's kind of like XML,
layout to designate permissions.

45
00:02:21,880 --> 00:02:24,710
And if you don't know that layout,
if you don't know that language for

46
00:02:24,710 --> 00:02:26,910
writing it,
this screen's absolutely useless to you.

47
00:02:26,910 --> 00:02:27,650
It's not gonna help.

48
00:02:28,780 --> 00:02:31,070
But there is something nice
at the bottom of the screen.

49
00:02:31,070 --> 00:02:36,580
You'll see the AWS policy generator and
the sample bucket policies.

50
00:02:36,580 --> 00:02:39,510
For years,
Amazon just had sample bucket policies, so

51
00:02:39,510 --> 00:02:42,640
you could look at some samples and
then customize them to meet your needs.

52
00:02:42,640 --> 00:02:45,220
But now they've got this nice little
policy generator that helps out.

53
00:02:45,220 --> 00:02:46,210
All right.

54
00:02:46,210 --> 00:02:49,260
Before we go to the generator though
let's take a look at those samples and

55
00:02:49,260 --> 00:02:52,030
get an idea of how they work, all right.

56
00:02:52,030 --> 00:02:56,560
So here's the samples page, and
they lay out some examples and

57
00:02:56,560 --> 00:02:59,930
you can see in here,
let me zoom in on this a little bit.

58
00:02:59,930 --> 00:03:00,760
It's kind of tiny.

59
00:03:02,630 --> 00:03:04,330
We'll make it insanely large.

60
00:03:04,330 --> 00:03:04,870
There we go.
So

61
00:03:04,870 --> 00:03:07,040
you can see an example of
a very simple policy here and

62
00:03:07,040 --> 00:03:08,240
this one's pretty straight forward.

63
00:03:08,240 --> 00:03:13,090
This is granting permissions to multiple
accounts with added conditions.

64
00:03:13,090 --> 00:03:16,490
We know we can add permissions to
an account, but to set conditions.

65
00:03:16,490 --> 00:03:17,890
That's a different story.

66
00:03:17,890 --> 00:03:22,860
Here you'll see where we're adding in
a statement that's allowing access

67
00:03:22,860 --> 00:03:24,490
to a principle.

68
00:03:24,490 --> 00:03:28,610
If you look at the principle
it's referencing an IAM,

69
00:03:28,610 --> 00:03:31,450
that's a user account inside of S3.

70
00:03:31,450 --> 00:03:33,040
So it's pointing to a user account and

71
00:03:33,040 --> 00:03:35,750
it's saying that user is
going to be allowed access.

72
00:03:35,750 --> 00:03:38,020
And then as I scroll over,
I'll see another user.

73
00:03:38,020 --> 00:03:40,990
So I've got two different users
that are being allowed access.

74
00:03:40,990 --> 00:03:45,180
And then on the action,
that is the additional principle,

75
00:03:45,180 --> 00:03:47,080
the additional setting.

76
00:03:47,080 --> 00:03:49,810
When we give somebody permission
to a bucket in the GUI,

77
00:03:49,810 --> 00:03:53,990
you can give them open or download, that's
one permission, it's not one or the other.

78
00:03:53,990 --> 00:03:55,530
It's open slash download.

79
00:03:55,530 --> 00:03:58,750
Then there's view permissions and
edit permissions, that's it.

80
00:03:58,750 --> 00:03:59,810
Those are the options in the GUI.

81
00:03:59,810 --> 00:04:05,790
But here they're giving them
put object and put object ACL.

82
00:04:05,790 --> 00:04:09,780
That means they can upload a file and
they can add an ACL.

83
00:04:09,780 --> 00:04:11,930
They can change permissions on that file.

84
00:04:11,930 --> 00:04:15,010
But they can't delete a file,
they can't rename a file.

85
00:04:15,010 --> 00:04:16,640
This is very specific,

86
00:04:16,640 --> 00:04:20,760
we're giving them just particular
actions that they can take.

87
00:04:20,760 --> 00:04:23,070
Then we're specifying the resource.

88
00:04:23,070 --> 00:04:27,580
Notice here they're saying
the example bucket/star.

89
00:04:27,580 --> 00:04:30,180
That star,
that means everything in the bucket.

90
00:04:30,180 --> 00:04:32,470
So they're giving them
access to the bucket itself.

91
00:04:32,470 --> 00:04:34,720
But you could even specify subfolders.

92
00:04:34,720 --> 00:04:38,230
Maybe I'm just giving them access to
a particular folder in that bucket and

93
00:04:38,230 --> 00:04:40,650
that's something that you really
can't do usually in the GUI.

94
00:04:40,650 --> 00:04:43,210
Then there's some additional
strings down here.

95
00:04:43,210 --> 00:04:46,020
They're mentioning that when
they upload something and

96
00:04:46,020 --> 00:04:49,640
they want to upload it,
it needs to be flagged as public read.

97
00:04:49,640 --> 00:04:52,650
If it's not flagged as public read,
it won't let them upload it.

98
00:04:52,650 --> 00:04:56,210
So they're not allowed to upload
private files, just public files, so

99
00:04:56,210 --> 00:04:58,990
we can get really,
really specific with this stuff.

100
00:04:58,990 --> 00:05:02,130
But, how do you know what
to put in all this stuff?

101
00:05:02,130 --> 00:05:06,520
Well, some of this, like here, these ARNs,
these are Amazon's resource names.

102
00:05:06,520 --> 00:05:11,160
These are the detailed name that
