identify some kind of object in AWS.

103
00:05:11,160 --> 00:05:14,910
We could go find that user account in AIM,
pull up their properties, and

104
00:05:14,910 --> 00:05:16,040
get their ID from there.

105
00:05:16,040 --> 00:05:17,460
That's where that came from.

106
00:05:17,460 --> 00:05:18,817
Same thing with the bucket.

107
00:05:18,817 --> 00:05:21,193
The bucket is a little easier, right,

108
00:05:21,193 --> 00:05:26,247
because the bucket is always ARN:AWS:S3:::
and then the name of the bucket.

109
00:05:26,247 --> 00:05:28,670
That one you probably don't
even have to look up.

110
00:05:28,670 --> 00:05:30,150
But the rest of this stuff,

111
00:05:30,150 --> 00:05:34,640
how do you know the format to put that in,
to make that my bucket policy?

112
00:05:34,640 --> 00:05:36,400
Well you could memorize it, I suppose.

113
00:05:36,400 --> 00:05:37,760
Which is crazy talk.

114
00:05:37,760 --> 00:05:41,530
So instead we can use
the AWS policy generator and

115
00:05:41,530 --> 00:05:43,430
it can help us to generate that policy.

116
00:05:44,590 --> 00:05:47,030
Before I do that though, let's take
a look at just a couple other examples.

117
00:05:47,030 --> 00:05:49,330
I specifically mention
one that I use a lot.

118
00:05:49,330 --> 00:05:51,230
Which is limiting by IP.

119
00:05:51,230 --> 00:05:54,060
Here's an example where they're
coming through and they're allowing.

120
00:05:54,060 --> 00:05:55,710
And for
the principle they've got it set to star.

121
00:05:55,710 --> 00:06:00,770
So they're allowing anyone to access
this bucket, the example bucket.

122
00:06:00,770 --> 00:06:04,270
But then they set that condition
to say only if their IP address

123
00:06:04,270 --> 00:06:07,550
meets this range or this IP specifically.

124
00:06:07,550 --> 00:06:11,620
That way, if you need one of your
servers to access the data but

125
00:06:11,620 --> 00:06:13,750
you don't want the general
public to do it,

126
00:06:13,750 --> 00:06:17,820
now you can limit it to these
particular IPs, really advanced.

127
00:06:17,820 --> 00:06:20,220
And then the refer one was
the other one that I mentioned.

128
00:06:20,220 --> 00:06:21,130
And it's right here.

129
00:06:21,130 --> 00:06:24,170
And you'll see under the condition,
they look for the referer,

130
00:06:24,170 --> 00:06:27,560
and they're specifying their site,
example .com.

131
00:06:27,560 --> 00:06:29,930
And each of the different
formats that URL might take.

132
00:06:29,930 --> 00:06:32,980
So, if they're coming from that site,
let them access the file.

133
00:06:32,980 --> 00:06:36,010
If they're not coming from that site,
then they can't access the file,

134
00:06:36,010 --> 00:06:37,450
really neat way to protect that content.

135
00:06:39,370 --> 00:06:42,160
It stops link sharing and
all that other good stuff.

136
00:06:42,160 --> 00:06:47,230
So, really advanced things here
inside of the policy system.

137
00:06:47,230 --> 00:06:50,580
If you use the policy generator,
right so back here under my bucket,

138
00:06:50,580 --> 00:06:54,020
when it's asking me for that policy,
I can hit the AWS policy generator,

139
00:06:54,020 --> 00:06:55,640
and it will take you here.

140
00:06:55,640 --> 00:06:57,730
It normally defaults to SNS.

141
00:06:57,730 --> 00:06:59,690
I've been in here before,
so mine was different.

142
00:06:59,690 --> 00:07:02,570
So it defaults to an SNS policy,
which is not what we want.

143
00:07:02,570 --> 00:07:05,350
But you drop that down and
choose S3 Bucket Policy.

144
00:07:05,350 --> 00:07:08,560
And it's gonna update to reflect S3.

145
00:07:08,560 --> 00:07:11,190
And now,
in a much easier to use interface,

146
00:07:11,190 --> 00:07:13,110
we can specify what we're doing.

147
00:07:13,110 --> 00:07:16,750
We can allow or deny access,
and we can specify a principal.

148
00:07:16,750 --> 00:07:19,800
The principal would be a particular
person we were granting access to, so

149
00:07:19,800 --> 00:07:24,290
we would do the ARM for that person, or
if we want this to apply to everyone,

150
00:07:24,290 --> 00:07:26,600
you would just throw a star in there.

151
00:07:26,600 --> 00:07:30,800
And you can do more than one person at
a time, you just separate them by commas,

152
00:07:30,800 --> 00:07:34,780
and that will go ahead and
designate that you've got multiple people.

153
00:07:34,780 --> 00:07:38,410
The policy is an S3 policy cuz
that's what I chose up above, right.

154
00:07:38,410 --> 00:07:39,640
That's where that came from.

155
00:07:39,640 --> 00:07:41,160
But you can choose to apply it to all.

156
00:07:41,160 --> 00:07:43,660
You could use this policy other places.

157
00:07:43,660 --> 00:07:46,500
I've never had a scenario where my
policy was generic enough to do that.

158
00:07:46,500 --> 00:07:48,340
But you do have the option.

159
00:07:48,340 --> 00:07:50,470
Then what actions we want to give them.

160
00:07:50,470 --> 00:07:52,950
If you want them to have full control,
you can hit All Actions.

161
00:07:52,950 --> 00:07:57,890
But if you drop it down,
you'll see the full list of permissions.

162
00:07:57,890 --> 00:07:59,710
Create bucket, delete bucket.

163
00:07:59,710 --> 00:08:01,810
You'll see create object, delete object.

164
00:08:01,810 --> 00:08:02,990
There's delete object.

165
00:08:02,990 --> 00:08:04,910
You'll see get bucket information.

166
00:08:04,910 --> 00:08:07,450
So there's gets, lists, puts, right?

167
00:08:07,450 --> 00:08:09,430
Put objects,
that's how we actually create them.

168
00:08:09,430 --> 00:08:11,810
So each of these are in here and
you can pick and choose.

169
00:08:11,810 --> 00:08:14,530
You can choose one, you can choose ten,
however many you need

170
00:08:14,530 --> 00:08:18,900
to determine exactly what access this
particular person would have, all right?

171
00:08:18,900 --> 00:08:22,180
So maybe I want these people
to be able to get objects.

172
00:08:22,180 --> 00:08:23,060
And so I'll come in here and

173
00:08:23,060 --> 00:08:27,380
do Getobject so they'll be able
to download some kind of content.

174
00:08:27,380 --> 00:08:28,500
All right.

175
00:08:28,500 --> 00:08:31,030
Then what resource am I protecting?

176
00:08:31,030 --> 00:08:34,650
I need to specify the ARN for
that resource, and

177
00:08:34,650 --> 00:08:39,190
normally we're going to be putting in
the ARN like I showed here, right?

178
00:08:39,190 --> 00:08:42,590
So ARN:AWS:S3.

179
00:08:42,590 --> 00:08:44,000
Followed by the bucket.

180
00:08:44,000 --> 00:08:48,700
But you can go more detailed and
do sub folders or even specific objects.

181
00:08:48,700 --> 00:08:53,590
So, I could say ARN:AWS:S3:::.

182
00:08:53,590 --> 00:08:56,818
And then mine was called, I don't
even remember what mine was called.

183
00:08:56,818 --> 00:09:00,010
[LAUGH] AWS Demo Bucket One or
something like that.

184
00:09:00,010 --> 00:09:01,290
Oh, I think it was ITPROTV dash.

185
00:09:04,030 --> 00:09:05,550
There we go,
I should probably go ahead and look.

186
00:09:05,550 --> 00:09:08,200
But there's my bucket and
then I can say, slash star, and

187
00:09:08,200 --> 00:09:09,950
this would apply to the whole bucket.

188
00:09:09,950 --> 00:09:14,220
Or I could say, slash, and
specify a particular object.

189
00:09:14,220 --> 00:09:21,460
So I could do
the Apple Remote Desktop Demo.mp4,

190
00:09:21,460 --> 00:09:27,260
so I'm being really detailed that very
specific mp4 file that I want to do,

191
00:09:27,260 --> 00:09:30,950
or we just use the star and
the hold button all right.

192
00:09:30,950 --> 00:09:34,300
Then we can add conditions and the
conditions are optional but when you hit

193
00:09:34,300 --> 00:09:38,970
add conditions here's where we can start
to specify other things to filter on.

194
00:09:38,970 --> 00:09:40,850
Things like the refer and so on.

195
00:09:40,850 --> 00:09:43,620
If you look through here you'll just
see a ton of different options.

196
00:09:43,620 --> 00:09:45,640
The refer is actually
a part of the string.

197
00:09:45,640 --> 00:09:49,730
So we could say string equals and
that's where you see user agents,

198
00:09:49,730 --> 00:09:52,460
source IP and other ones.

199
00:09:52,460 --> 00:09:57,020
The one I want is the refer which I
could have swore was under here but

200
00:09:57,020 --> 00:09:58,410
I'm not seeing it.

201
00:09:58,410 --> 00:10:01,960
Let's go, it is not on your
string let's do StringLike.

202
00:10:03,560 --> 00:10:06,360
Sometimes you have to poke around before
you find the exact one that you want.

203
00:10:06,360 --> 00:10:09,150
Where is refer let me go
back to my examples here.

204
00:10:09,150 --> 00:10:12,778
So here we've the the refer
is under StringLike hm.

205
00:10:12,778 --> 00:10:17,450
I must have over looked it,
so StringLike, AWS:refer.

206
00:10:18,820 --> 00:10:20,180
I do not see it in the list.

207
00:10:20,180 --> 00:10:21,490
Well anyhow,
I'll pick one of these other ones.

208
00:10:21,490 --> 00:10:22,760
I'll do like source IP.

209
00:10:22,760 --> 00:10:25,550
And so
I can then specify that IP range, so

210
00:10:25,550 --> 00:10:31,730
if I want to approve our office I
can come in and specify our office.

211
00:10:31,730 --> 00:10:32,540
And so I can add that.

212
00:10:32,540 --> 00:10:36,450
And now anybody in my office will be able
to access that file and download it.

213
00:10:36,450 --> 00:10:39,150
And if you're out of my office,
you'll have an IP out of that range,

214
00:10:39,150 --> 00:10:42,550
it won't apply, and
you won't be able to do it, right?

215
00:10:42,550 --> 00:10:43,670
You go through and you fill this out.

216
00:10:43,670 --> 00:10:46,770
Now, you're probably going to
add more than one statement.

217
00:10:46,770 --> 00:10:48,790
Each statement is a set of
permissions that you're assigning.

218
00:10:48,790 --> 00:10:50,620
And so you'll define all of those.

219
00:10:50,620 --> 00:10:54,560
If I want the general public to be able to
access, I'll need to add that one in too.

220
00:10:54,560 --> 00:10:57,400
And when you're done,
right down here at the bottom,

221
00:10:57,400 --> 00:10:59,340
we'll be able to generate that policy.

222
00:10:59,340 --> 00:11:02,190
So I need to hit add to save a statement,
there it is.

223
00:11:02,190 --> 00:11:04,710
I can go and
add more statements if I need to.

224
00:11:04,710 --> 00:11:08,190
But otherwise, I can generate the policy
as it's written, and here it is.

225
00:11:08,190 --> 00:11:12,210
So I don't have to know the in's and
out's of the policy language.

226
00:11:12,210 --> 00:11:17,200
I can just do that and now when I go
back to my properties of my bucket,

227
00:11:17,200 --> 00:11:20,960
I can paste that in and
now I've got some advanced permissions.

228
00:11:20,960 --> 00:11:24,110
The GUI permissions on the bucket
itself still apply and

229
00:11:24,110 --> 00:11:27,450
the permissions on the object still apply,
but this overrides it.

230
00:11:27,450 --> 00:11:29,430
The bucket policy's gonna override and

231
00:11:29,430 --> 00:11:33,040
the nice thing is the bucket policy will
apply to new files that we upload too.

232
00:11:33,040 --> 00:11:35,810
So even if we forget to set
permissions on the new files,

233
00:11:35,810 --> 00:11:37,390
the policy will take care of that.

234
00:11:37,390 --> 00:11:39,010
And people will get their access.

235
00:11:39,010 --> 00:11:44,150
So now only this IP range is going
to be allowed to access the bucket.

236
00:11:44,150 --> 00:11:49,840
All right, and once we have that all in
there we can save that on our system.

237
00:11:49,840 --> 00:11:53,470
And we're in business so
I must have a typo somewhere,

238
00:11:53,470 --> 00:11:55,520
it doesn't seem to be
lighting up my save button.

239
00:11:55,520 --> 00:11:59,110
Hm, that's interesting.

240
00:11:59,110 --> 00:12:00,440
Let me try that one more time.

241
00:12:00,440 --> 00:12:05,660
I'm gonna add my bucket policy, case that
in, and for some reason, there we go.

242
00:12:05,660 --> 00:12:08,620
I just hit space on my keyboard to
type something to make that save

243
00:12:08,620 --> 00:12:09,170
button light up.

244
00:12:09,170 --> 00:12:11,950
Whatever JavaScript you're using
isn't detecting the paste.

245
00:12:11,950 --> 00:12:14,340
So that did it and I'll just save that.

246
00:12:14,340 --> 00:12:16,280
Now that policy is in place.

247
00:12:16,280 --> 00:12:18,830
And we can come back and
edit that policy whenever you want.

248
00:12:18,830 --> 00:12:20,610
Notice you can only have one policy.

249
00:12:20,610 --> 00:12:24,530
The add bucket policy is gone so if you
need multiple statements they all need to

250
00:12:24,530 --> 00:12:28,380
be in the same policy so when you edit it,
you'll add in the additional ones.

251
00:12:28,380 --> 00:12:32,500
That's why I said, I've never had a policy
so generic I could reuse it other places.

252
00:12:32,500 --> 00:12:35,190
And that's because you've gotta have all
these different statements in there.

253
00:12:35,190 --> 00:12:37,010
It becomes pretty specialized, all right?

254
00:12:37,010 --> 00:12:39,670
So usually,
each bucket will have its own policy.

255
00:12:39,670 --> 00:12:44,080
But AWS bucket policies,
that's the secret to advanced permissions.

256
00:12:44,080 --> 00:12:46,890
If you wanna learn more, definitely
take a look at that examples page.

257
00:12:46,890 --> 00:12:50,200
It lays out some great samples of
how to do these bucket policies,

258
00:12:50,200 --> 00:12:52,500
some of the ones that are very common.

259
00:12:52,500 --> 00:12:56,550
And you can just manipulate those to
match your needs, what your company uses.

260
00:12:56,550 --> 00:13:00,480
And then you can go into the AWS Policy
Generator and actually make them.

261
00:13:00,480 --> 00:13:03,380
And boy, does that save some time.

262
00:13:03,380 --> 00:13:05,480
We use to not have that tool and
you had to write them by hand.

263
00:13:05,480 --> 00:13:07,500
And typos were your number one nemesis.

264
00:13:07,500 --> 00:13:10,130
So you have to do a couple of dry
runs before you got it right.

265
00:13:10,130 --> 00:13:11,490
But now it's pretty easy.

266
00:13:12,672 --> 00:13:16,620
All right, so that's an example of AWS or
S3 bucket policies.

267
00:13:16,620 --> 00:13:19,150
I hope you guys enjoyed the segment,
stay tuned,

268
00:13:19,150 --> 00:13:21,052
we've got more Amazon
web services coming up.

episodes.title: Load Balancing in EC2
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,001 --> 00:00:08,378
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:08,378 --> 00:00:09,270
In this segment,

3
00:00:09,270 --> 00:00:12,961
we're gonna take a look at load
balancing inside of Amazon Web Services.

4
00:00:12,961 --> 00:00:16,213
One of the really valuable
features of using AWS and

5
00:00:16,213 --> 00:00:21,353
EC2 is that you get to take advantage of
Amazon's state of the art data centers,

6
00:00:21,353 --> 00:00:27,280
and not just one, it's plural, there are
many, many data centers that they have.

7
00:00:27,280 --> 00:00:31,740
When you deploy a server, an EC2,
if you're just throwing a single server up

8
00:00:31,740 --> 00:00:35,878
there to do a job, you're not really
getting all the benefits, right?

9
00:00:35,878 --> 00:00:38,969
Sure you get the benefits of things
like not having to maintain warranty

10
00:00:38,969 --> 00:00:42,430
on hardware, not having to worry
about your operating system licenses.

11
00:00:42,430 --> 00:00:44,336
That kind of stuff is alleviated.

12
00:00:44,336 --> 00:00:46,580
You don't have to worry about
power generators and all.

13
00:00:46,580 --> 00:00:48,500
But, you can go even further.

14
00:00:48,500 --> 00:00:52,580
You can set up load balancing, so
that when your customers go to access your

15
00:00:52,580 --> 00:00:57,270
server, that your customers are spread
across multiple servers, and

16
00:00:57,270 --> 00:01:00,220
that's gonna make it where each
server doesn't get overloaded.

17
00:01:00,220 --> 00:01:03,837
And as your systems get busier,
you can just add more in behind that load

18
00:01:03,837 --> 00:01:07,295
balancer, and the traffic is evenly
balanced across the servers.

19
00:01:07,295 --> 00:01:08,545
It's really cool to do.

20
00:01:08,545 --> 00:01:09,963
In a physical environment,

21
00:01:09,963 --> 00:01:14,045
it's tough to do load balancing cuz you've
got to buy physical servers, right?

22
00:01:14,045 --> 00:01:16,988
But with AWS, or with EC2 specifically,

23
00:01:16,988 --> 00:01:21,100
we can spin up new
instances whenever we want.

24
00:01:21,100 --> 00:01:25,000
So when our servers start to get really
busy, we can spawn new instances.

25
00:01:25,000 --> 00:01:28,640
So, maybe I've got three servers normally,
and the servers start getting busy.

26
00:01:28,640 --> 00:01:30,040
So, I add another three.

27
00:01:30,040 --> 00:01:31,460
So I go up to six.

28
00:01:31,460 --> 00:01:34,780
But then the servers start getting slow
and I just remove some of those and

29
00:01:34,780 --> 00:01:37,461
I go back down to three again,
or two or whatever, right?

30
00:01:37,461 --> 00:01:43,670
That possibility, that action,
is made possible by load balancing.

31
00:01:43,670 --> 00:01:46,510
We're gonna see in another segment
something called auto scaling.

32
00:01:46,510 --> 00:01:49,260
Auto scaling is where it automatically
detects the servers are busy and

33
00:01:49,260 --> 00:01:52,010
adds servers on demand and
scales them back.

34
00:01:52,010 --> 00:01:55,700
That's super cool, but
that doesn't work without a load balancer.

35
00:01:55,700 --> 00:01:58,254
Your customers don't know that
you've got multiple servers,

36
00:01:58,254 --> 00:01:59,920
they don't know which one to connect to.

37
00:01:59,920 --> 00:02:02,080
So you need something to
tell them where to connect,

38
00:02:02,080 --> 00:02:03,711
and that's what a load balancer does.

39
00:02:03,711 --> 00:02:04,378
In the past,

40
00:02:04,378 --> 00:02:08,685
there were a number of companies out
there that make hardware load balancers.

41
00:02:08,685 --> 00:02:10,377
And so if you want a new load balancer,
you had to go out and

42
00:02:10,377 --> 00:02:11,128
buy one of these things.

43
00:02:11,128 --> 00:02:12,836
And they were expensive.

44
00:02:12,836 --> 00:02:17,775
I've worked with a lot of the F5 Networks,
is a great networking company.

45
00:02:17,775 --> 00:02:21,340
They make these appliances called BIG-IP
boxes, and they do load balancing.

46
00:02:21,340 --> 00:02:24,890
They're great, but they are expensive.

47
00:02:24,890 --> 00:02:27,630
I think the base model is
something like $14,000.

48
00:02:27,630 --> 00:02:29,430
They're a lot of money.

49
00:02:29,430 --> 00:02:35,120
In AWS, because this is all virtualized
inside of Amazon's data centers, they can

50
00:02:35,120 --> 00:02:39,670
actually perform the load balancing for
us, and it costs a fraction back, right?

51
00:02:39,670 --> 00:02:43,360
Let's take a look at that pricing

00:14:58,810 --> 00:14:59,370

But just remember that negative, the

balancer and

00:15:14,440 --> 00:15:17,719

00:16:01,802 --> 00:16:06,371

00:16:06,371 --> 00:16:07,945

00:16:07,945 --> 00:16:12,800

00:16:12,800 --> 00:16:16,319

00:16:16,319 --> 00:16:19,581

326
00:16:19,581 --> 00:16:21,262

00:16:21,262 --> 00:16:23,960
The Load Balancer will just
stop sending traffic to it.

328
00:16:23,960 --> 00:16:26,600
So if I have three servers and

329
00:16:26,600 --> 00:16:30,495
then the Load Balancer will stop sending
traffic to the one and all of my

330
00:16:30,495 --> 00:16:34,474
traffic will then be redistributed
across the two remaining servers.

331
00:16:34,474 --> 00:16:35,531
Really cool.

332
00:16:35,531 --> 00:16:37,920
Failures can happen,
your end users won't even notice.

333
00:16:39,130 --> 00:16:43,129
Also if you want to do upgrades and

00:16:43,129 --> 00:16:46,575

00:16:46,575 --> 00:16:49,330

00:16:49,330 --> 00:16:52,225

00:16:52,225 --> 00:16:55,901

00:16:55,901 --> 00:17:00,198

00:17:02,200 --> 00:17:06,290
If you can load a web page
from the server, it'll work.

00:17:06,290 --> 00:17:08,391
It's up it's valid,

00:17:08,391 --> 00:17:13,197
So you punch in a file name, so

343
00:17:13,197 --> 00:17:14,970
which most of us have.

344
00:17:14,970 --> 00:17:17,750
But you might have index.php or
something different, so

345
00:17:17,750 --> 00:17:19,514
you can change to specify that here.

346
00:17:19,514 --> 00:17:24,185
And as long as it can get a copy of that
page, it assumes that the note is up.

347
00:17:24,185 --> 00:17:27,760
But HTTP is not the only one,
you can do HTTPS or

348
00:17:27,760 --> 00:17:30,900
straight SSL, you can do TCP anything.

349
00:17:30,900 --> 00:17:32,873
I can do TCP 22.

350
00:17:32,873 --> 00:17:34,498
Well, that's SSH.

351
00:17:34,498 --> 00:17:37,930
So it's gonna reach out on port 22 and
say, can I get a connection?

352
00:17:37,930 --> 00:17:42,150
And if it gets a response,
then that port is open and active.

353
00:17:42,150 --> 00:17:44,397
It doesn't actually know
if it's truly working,

354
00:17:44,397 --> 00:17:46,184
it just sees if that port is responding.

355
00:17:46,184 --> 00:17:48,663
For MySQL, you might do 30306.

00:17:48,663 --> 00:17:50,680
It can check to see if that's responding.

00:17:50,680 --> 00:17:53,767
It's not the most accurate at this point,

00:17:53,767 --> 00:17:57,218

359
00:17:57,218 --> 00:17:58,835
So it might still be
answering on that port,

360
00:17:58,835 --> 00:18:00,960
even though the databases
are inaccessible.

361
00:18:00,960 --> 00:18:02,273
It won't know that.

362
00:18:02,273 --> 00:18:03,857
So instead, that's where CloudWatch and

363
00:18:03,857 --> 00:18:06,150
some of the other services come

364
00:18:07,530 --> 00:18:11,007
But for me, I'm doing HTTP and
I do have an index.html.

00:18:11,007 --> 00:18:15,190
So I'm gonna leave that to the default,
then we need to set our thresholds.

00:18:15,190 --> 00:18:19,306
These thresholds determine how
quickly we detect a failure and

367
00:18:19,306 --> 00:18:22,264
how quickly we react and
then correct for it.

368
00:18:22,264 --> 00:18:25,710
The detection is made up of these
first two, response timeout.

369
00:18:26,760 --> 00:18:30,018
How long do we wait to get a copy

370
00:18:30,018 --> 00:18:31,670
The default is five seconds.

371
00:18:31,670 --> 00:18:33,230
If I request index.html and

372
00:18:33,230 --> 00:18:37,390
I don't get it within 5 seconds,
Im gonna decide that that's a failure and

373
00:18:37,390 --> 00:18:41,360
then my health check interval is I'm
gonna check it every 30 seconds.

374
00:18:41,360 --> 00:18:44,530
So every 30 seconds,
I'm gonna request that page.

375
00:18:44,530 --> 00:18:48,708
If I don't get the page in five seconds,
I'll view it as a fail.

376
00:18:48,708 --> 00:18:52,530
Well, when there's a failure, how long do
we wait before we take it out of the pool?

377
00:18:52,530 --> 00:18:54,679
That's this next one,
the Unhealthy Threshold.

378
00:18:54,679 --> 00:18:56,120
The default is 2.

379
00:18:56,120 --> 00:19:00,146
If I fail two checks, if two times I
request that page and I don't get it,

380
00:19:00,146 --> 00:19:02,533
then I'll take the server out of the pool.

381
00:19:02,533 --> 00:19:03,780
I'll flag it as out of service.

382
00:19:04,970 --> 00:19:08,155
If it starts to become healthy again,
I'll bring it back online.

383
00:19:08,155 --> 00:19:09,800
That's that last entry here
is the Healthy Threshold.

384
00:19:09,800 --> 00:19:11,933
The Healthy Threshold is much larger,
it's 10.

385
00:19:11,933 --> 00:19:14,384
It says, if the server comes back online,

386
00:19:14,384 --> 00:19:18,620
wait until it passes ten checks before
we actually put it back in service.

387
00:19:19,900 --> 00:19:22,864
Now those numbers right there are good for
a lot of people, but

388
00:19:22,864 --> 00:19:24,410
let's qualify this into time.

389
00:19:25,420 --> 00:19:27,915
If I'm checking every 30 seconds and

390
00:19:27,915 --> 00:19:32,225
I require 2 failures before I decide
that the system is unhealthy,

391
00:19:32,225 --> 00:19:36,704
that means it's gonna take a minimum
of 1 minute to detect a failure.

392
00:19:36,704 --> 00:19:40,938
A server could fail and it would take
a minute before I recognized it.

393
00:19:40,938 --> 00:19:43,630
Well, you'd recognize it right away, but
it'd take a minute before I acted on it.

394
00:19:45,000 --> 00:19:47,290
That minute might be too long.

395
00:19:47,290 --> 00:19:50,225
If that's too long for you,
you can reduce these numbers.

00:19:50,225 --> 00:19:53,970
You can reduce it to say,
check every ten seconds.

397
00:19:53,970 --> 00:19:57,130
Now it's gonna reduce that window
to something very, very small.

398
00:19:57,130 --> 00:19:59,356
It's up to you to customize

00:19:59,356 --> 00:20:02,610
These are default values that

00:20:04,540 --> 00:20:08,840
The other thing is once the node becomes

00:20:08,840 --> 00:20:13,000
Well, at 30 seconds each,
that's 300 seconds that's 5 minutes.

00:20:13,000 --> 00:20:16,981
So when a system becomes healthy, it won't
go back in the pool for five minutes and

00:20:16,981 --> 00:20:20,693
the reason it does that is want to make
sure the server's actually healthy.

404
00:20:20,693 --> 00:20:23,107
That it comes up, that it's running,
that things are working fine and

405
00:20:23,107 --> 00:20:25,220
everything's the way
that we expect it to be.

406
00:20:25,220 --> 00:20:29,300
But a server might come up and
then go right back down again and so

407
00:20:29,300 --> 00:20:31,180
that's why it's set to five minutes.

408
00:20:31,180 --> 00:20:32,240
You might want to shorten that or

409
00:20:32,240 --> 00:20:35,070
you might even want to lengthen

Well, if all of your servers

And they do it it's all handled for

If you turn that off, you won't be able

That actually reduces the cost

00:23:32,020 --> 00:23:33,220
They don't see a down time, but

00:23:36,890 --> 00:23:40,110

00:23:40,110 --> 00:23:44,096

00:23:48,373 --> 00:23:51,411
Draining is where you tell

If customers on your site browse for

00:24:11,700 --> 00:24:13,040
But it just gives it
a little bit of time for

00:24:13,040 --> 00:24:15,220

up what they're doing.

00:24:15,220 --> 00:24:17,840
And then no new traffic is going to it.

482
00:24:17,840 --> 00:24:20,240
Everybody is being sent
to the other servers so

00:24:20,240 --> 00:24:21,780

00:24:21,780 --> 00:24:24,340
But it minimizes the impact

00:24:24,340 --> 00:24:27,500
And once it's drained, you can take

00:24:29,000 --> 00:24:31,810
Nobody's actually using it and

00:36:22,260 --> 00:36:24,388
When you're talking about a few
hundred bucks it's a no brainer.

725
00:36:24,388 --> 00:36:29,580
All right so, that in effect,
is configuring load balancing, right?

726
00:36:29,580 --> 00:36:33,560
So in this segment we got a chance to
see how to create the load balancer,

727
00:36:33,560 --> 00:36:36,080
how to add instances to it, how to

728
00:36:36,080 --> 00:36:39,650
tune it in that configuration wizard to
modify things, like our health checks.

729
00:36:39,650 --> 00:36:42,560
We saw how to view the health
of our instances, and

730
00:36:42,560 --> 00:36:44,670
what happens when one goes out,
and back in.

731
00:36:44,670 --> 00:36:47,660
So we got a pretty good walk
thru of the load balancers.

732
00:36:47,660 --> 00:36:48,720
But there's a lot more.

733
00:36:48,720 --> 00:36:51,520
There's some advanced stuff that you
can do with the load balancing and

734
00:36:51,520 --> 00:36:54,180
we're gonna take a look at
that in some other segments.

735
00:36:54,180 --> 00:36:57,360
So I hope you guys enjoyed this segment,
but make sure you stay tuned.

736
00:36:57,360 --> 00:36:59,820
We've got other load
balancing episodes coming up.

episodes.title: Security Groups With ELB
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:07.614
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:07.614 --> 00:00:11.172
In this segment, we're gonna take a look
at security group configurations when

3
00:00:11.172 --> 00:00:13.220
using the Elastic Load Balancer.

4
00:00:13.220 --> 00:00:17.670
Now, you might ask yourself, if I have
a security group that I'm using for

5
00:00:17.670 --> 00:00:22.810
my clustered nodes, can't I just use that
same security group for the load balancer?

6
00:00:22.810 --> 00:00:23.400
And you can, sure.

7
00:00:23.400 --> 00:00:25.400
Right, there's plenty
of people that do that.

8
00:00:25.400 --> 00:00:29.165
If you've got various rules put in that
security group that allow access to your

9
00:00:29.165 --> 00:00:30.160
nodes, right.

10
00:00:30.160 --> 00:00:33.380
That's typically gonna match
what the load balancer does.

11
00:00:33.380 --> 00:00:36.375
But, if you really want to improve
security in your environment,

12
00:00:36.375 --> 00:00:39.520
there's some reasons why we
might want to change that.

13
00:00:39.520 --> 00:00:43.140
Typically, when I can figure it, a load
balancer, I'll create a separate security

14
00:00:43.140 --> 00:00:45.680
group for the load balancer from
the nodes that are behind it.

15
00:00:45.680 --> 00:00:47.920
And there's a few reasons for that, right.

16
00:00:47.920 --> 00:00:49.050
Let me show you what I've got right now.

17
00:00:49.050 --> 00:00:53.498
So I've got a load balancer, here's web
LB and it's got two nodes behind it,

18
00:00:53.498 --> 00:00:56.220
web01 and web02, so
there is two web servers.

19
00:00:56.220 --> 00:00:58.880
And when a user browses
to the load balancer,

20
00:00:58.880 --> 00:01:01.340
they're being load balanced
across those two nodes.

21
00:01:01.340 --> 00:01:03.670
All right, so
that's how our a balancing is working, so

22
00:01:03.670 --> 00:01:06.830
that's the entry point
is that load balancer.

23
00:01:06.830 --> 00:01:09.570
But those two nodes they have static IPs.

24
00:01:09.570 --> 00:01:13.000
Even if they didn't have static IPs,
they would at least have IP addresses.

25
00:01:13.000 --> 00:01:17.240
And since I'm using the same security
group for the load balancer as I am for

26
00:01:17.240 --> 00:01:19.560
those nodes, that means the end users.

27
00:01:19.560 --> 00:01:20.820
People out there on the Internet,

28
00:01:20.820 --> 00:01:25.450
have the same access to the load
balancers they would an individual node.

29
00:01:25.450 --> 00:01:30.360
So, if they knew an address behind my load
balancer, they could contact it directly.

30
00:01:30.360 --> 00:01:34.130
I know that doesn't sound like a big deal
because if I go to the load balancer,

31
00:01:34.130 --> 00:01:35.800
right, I can sit here and hit refresh.

32
00:01:35.800 --> 00:01:41.000
And I got web02 that time, and if I hit
refresh I got web01 that time, right?

33
00:01:41.000 --> 00:01:45.000
But I could also just type
in web01.itprotv.net,

34
00:01:45.000 --> 00:01:47.950
and I would always hit that one node.

35
00:01:47.950 --> 00:01:50.880
And web02,
I'm always hitting that one node.

36
00:01:50.880 --> 00:01:52.080
And why does that matter?

37
00:01:52.080 --> 00:01:56.540
Well, If I'm an attacker,
if I'm trying to hack into that network.

38
00:01:56.540 --> 00:02:01.650
It's much easier if I can get
a consistent connection to one server

39
00:02:01.650 --> 00:02:04.050
to pull off prediction attacks and
things like that.

40
00:02:04.050 --> 00:02:06.360
Then if I'm being bounced
between multiple servers,

41
00:02:06.360 --> 00:02:09.760
where I effectively have to start over
every time I get moved to a new server.

42
00:02:09.760 --> 00:02:14.240
So, an attacker is going to
attempt to target a single server.

43
00:02:14.240 --> 00:02:16.500
So, to improve security
on our environment.

44
00:02:16.500 --> 00:02:20.230
What we should do is restrict access so
that end users can

45
00:02:20.230 --> 00:02:24.410
get to the load balancer, but they can't
get to the nodes individually, right?

46
00:02:24.410 --> 00:02:27.330
We're gonna force all of our traffic
to go through the load balancer.

47
00:02:27.330 --> 00:02:30.430
The problem is you can't do
that with one security group.

48
00:02:30.430 --> 00:02:32.025
If I go back to my security group, right?

49
00:02:32.025 --> 00:02:33.850
To my web load balancer,

50
00:02:33.850 --> 00:02:37.775
if I look it's in a security group
that is called, what is it called?

51
00:02:37.775 --> 00:02:39.100
Web-hosts, right?

52
00:02:39.100 --> 00:02:41.240
So I can see the security group,
it's in right there.

53
00:02:41.240 --> 00:02:47.210
And my hosts, if I go up to my instances,
they're in that same security group.

54
00:02:47.210 --> 00:02:50.050
If I scroll over here I'll see web-hosts,
right?

55
00:02:50.050 --> 00:02:51.940
That's that security
group that they're in.

56
00:02:51.940 --> 00:02:55.600
And if I take a look at the security
group, I'll see what I'm approving.

57
00:02:55.600 --> 00:03:00.210
I'm approving inbound traffic for
SSH and HTTP.

58
00:03:01.620 --> 00:03:05.710
HTTP from the entire world,
and SSH just from my IP.

59
00:03:05.710 --> 00:03:09.900
That means that I am approving that to
the load balancer, as well as the nodes.

60
00:03:09.900 --> 00:03:13.330
And it says HTTP part here,
that's the one that's from everywhere.

61
00:03:13.330 --> 00:03:15.290
And that's allowing that
connectivity to the load balancers,

62
00:03:15.290 --> 00:03:17.652
as well of the nodes, and
that's what I want to tweak.

63
00:03:17.652 --> 00:03:20.400
I wanna limit that, so
it's only access to the load balancer.

64
00:03:20.400 --> 00:03:22.990
But when you create rules in here,
if I edit it.

65
00:03:22.990 --> 00:03:26.990
Notice how you can specify a source but
not a destination.

66
00:03:26.990 --> 00:03:29.430
I can't say, if you're destined for
the load balancer, yes.

67
00:03:29.430 --> 00:03:31.980
If you're destined for
the node, no, can't do that.

68
00:03:31.980 --> 00:03:36.270
So, the only way to do that is to
create a separate security group.

69
00:03:36.270 --> 00:03:38.050
Then we can start to customize things.

70
00:03:38.050 --> 00:03:40.820
But there's a few little caveats we
bump into when we start to do this kinda

71
00:03:40.820 --> 00:03:42.430
configuration, all right.

72
00:03:42.430 --> 00:03:47.090
Let's start by saying, what I wanna
configure on this security group, right.

73
00:03:47.090 --> 00:03:48.990
Or let's go the other way around.

74
00:03:48.990 --> 00:03:52.590
I'll go and create the security group for
the load balancer first, and

75
00:03:52.590 --> 00:03:53.410
then we'll get that set up.

76
00:03:53.410 --> 00:03:56.200
So I'm gonna cancel this and
I'm gonna create a new security group.

77
00:03:57.570 --> 00:04:00.770
So I'll create the security group, and
I'm just gonna call this one web-lb.

78
00:04:00.770 --> 00:04:02.610
So I've got web-hosts, those would be for

79
00:04:02.610 --> 00:04:04.450
the the hosts that are behind
the load balancer.

80
00:04:04.450 --> 00:04:07.390
And web-lb,
that'll be to the load balancer itself.

81
00:04:07.390 --> 00:04:10.990
And so I'll call that,
that's my security group for

82
00:04:10.990 --> 00:04:15.610
the ELB on our web farm, all right.

83
00:04:15.610 --> 00:04:17.035
If it's in more than one VPC,

84
00:04:17.035 --> 00:04:19.860
you'll have to specify the VPC
where a load balancer resides.

85
00:04:19.860 --> 00:04:23.320
I've only got one, so
I'll just choose that and then the rules.

86
00:04:23.320 --> 00:04:28.820
I want everyone on the Internet to
be able to access this thing using

87
00:04:28.820 --> 00:04:30.990
HTTP, so I punch that in.

88
00:04:30.990 --> 00:04:31.740
Now on my host,

89
00:04:31.740 --> 00:04:35.620
I also had SSH because I'll SSH
into those service to manage them.

90
00:04:35.620 --> 00:04:39.618
But on the load balancer, I don't have SSH
access to it, so I can leave that off.

91
00:04:39.618 --> 00:04:43.340
That's actually gonna improve security
too, cuz as long as the SSH rule is there,

92
00:04:43.340 --> 00:04:47.510
I'm opening up access to a server that
doesn't actually provide me any benefits.

93
00:04:47.510 --> 00:04:50.785
It only increases the attack
surface of the load balancer.

94
00:04:50.785 --> 00:04:54.425
Even though it's limited to
my IP which is pretty secure,

95
00:04:54.425 --> 00:04:57.675
somebody could spoof that IP and
try and hit the load balancer itself.

96
00:04:57.675 --> 00:04:59.675
All right, so
this is gonna help there too.

97
00:04:59.675 --> 00:05:03.795
We're just listing typically what
our load balancer is listening on,

98
00:05:03.795 --> 00:05:05.375
our listeners that we defined.

99
00:05:05.375 --> 00:05:07.880
Those are usually the only
things that we define here.

100
00:05:07.880 --> 00:05:09.750
All right, so I'm gonna set that up.

101
00:05:09.750 --> 00:05:14.740
That's my load balancing security group,
all right.

102
00:05:14.740 --> 00:05:18.930
Then I need to move my load balancer
into that security group, right,

103
00:05:18.930 --> 00:05:20.970
cuz it's in the wrong
security group right now.

104
00:05:20.970 --> 00:05:22.700
So I'll go over here to my load balancer.

105
00:05:24.190 --> 00:05:25.890
And I'll find it, it's right here.

106
00:05:25.890 --> 00:05:29.610
And down under security,
we can change the security groups.

107
00:05:29.610 --> 00:05:30.940
I'll just hit edit and

108
00:05:30.940 --> 00:05:33.540
I'm gonna move it to that new
security group that I just created.

109
00:05:33.540 --> 00:05:37.520
So I'll choose web-lb and
I'll say that, all right.

110
00:05:37.520 --> 00:05:40.480
It's now moved off to
the other security group.

111
00:05:40.480 --> 00:05:43.900
Now, I can go and
customize the other security group.

112
00:05:43.900 --> 00:05:47.180
Before I do that, I might want to
test it just to see that things work.

113
00:05:47.180 --> 00:05:50.190
They should be good and
we see that everything's fine.

114
00:05:50.190 --> 00:05:52.080
But it's possible that we break something,

115
00:05:52.080 --> 00:05:54.488
when we move the load balancer
off to its own security group.

116
00:05:54.488 --> 00:05:58.840
So I'm gonna jump over to my web browser.

117
00:05:58.840 --> 00:06:02.670
And I'm gonna try and
browse to www.itprotv.net, right?

118
00:06:02.670 --> 00:06:04.940
That's gonna be that load balancer.

119
00:06:04.940 --> 00:06:08.480
And when I hit refresh,
I see that I'm still getting the pages

120
00:06:08.480 --> 00:06:10.610
in the new security group and
everything's running fine.

121
00:06:12.170 --> 00:06:15.770
But now, I need to go and
secure the back end, right?

122
00:06:15.770 --> 00:06:17.340
Because I can still go
to these other nodes.

123
00:06:17.340 --> 00:06:19.920
I go to web01 and refresh it.

124
00:06:19.920 --> 00:06:22.520
And I'm still getting web01, and
I go to web02 and refresh it.

125
00:06:22.520 --> 00:06:24.310
And I'm still getting that one, too.

126
00:06:24.310 --> 00:06:25.970
So, now I need to go and secure them.

127
00:06:25.970 --> 00:06:29.060
And I can do that now because
they're in their own security group.

128
00:06:30.160 --> 00:06:34.550
So I'll jump back over here, and
I'll go to my security groups, and

129
00:06:34.550 --> 00:06:38.000
I'll take the web-host's security.

130
00:06:38.000 --> 00:06:39.390
I'm gonna take that one.

131
00:06:39.390 --> 00:06:42.580
And this is the one that's giving that
HTTP access to the world to my back end.

132
00:06:42.580 --> 00:06:44.880
And I don't want that so I'll hit edit.

133
00:06:44.880 --> 00:06:46.420
And I'm gonna change that.

134
00:06:46.420 --> 00:06:50.060
Now, I've got SSH enabled and
that's just from my IP.

135
00:06:50.060 --> 00:06:51.710
I want that, all right?

136
00:06:51.710 --> 00:06:56.685
And maybe I want to allow my IP to
be able to get to those addresses.

137
00:06:56.685 --> 00:06:59.045
So I might wanna come in here and
say my IP, so

138
00:06:59.045 --> 00:07:02.765
that I can use HTTP to browse
to the end units, right.

139
00:07:02.765 --> 00:07:04.095
Maybe I just wanna be able to test,

140
00:07:04.095 --> 00:07:05.895
do my own manual verification
they're up and running.

141
00:07:05.895 --> 00:07:06.835
So, I might choose to approve that.

142
00:07:07.875 --> 00:07:12.872
But the other thing I need to add, is I
need to allow the load balancer access.

143
00:07:12.872 --> 00:07:17.542
If I don't do that, if I don't add the
load balancer, then it's gonna be blocked.

144
00:07:17.542 --> 00:07:19.522
And we'll see that it
doesn't get that access.

145
00:07:19.522 --> 00:07:22.782
The only problem is when you add a rule,
like If I add another rule here for

146
00:07:22.782 --> 00:07:25.652
HTTP, right, TCP port 80.

147
00:07:25.652 --> 00:07:28.780
And I want to say that this is
traffic from the load balancer.

148
00:07:28.780 --> 00:07:34.220
Well, I have to choose custom IP, and
it wants me to put in an IP address.

149
00:07:34.220 --> 00:07:36.640
What's the IP address of my load balancer?

150
00:07:36.640 --> 00:07:40.700
I don't know, the IP address of
your load balancer, it changes.

151
00:07:40.700 --> 00:07:43.390
It changes based on Amazon's
availability configuration.

152
00:07:43.390 --> 00:07:46.165
So it can move around as needed,
it's very flexible.

153
00:07:46.165 --> 00:07:47.870
That's what makes them so powerful.

154
00:07:47.870 --> 00:07:50.630
The other thing is the load bouncer
actually has two IP addresses or

155
00:07:50.630 --> 00:07:52.100
a minimum of two it could have more.

156
00:07:52.100 --> 00:07:55.420
But it'll usually have two IP addresses,
again for redundancy.

157
00:07:55.420 --> 00:07:59.300
So if I don't know what those IPs are,
how do I fill that in?

158
00:07:59.300 --> 00:08:00.640
Well, the answer is you really can't.

159
00:08:00.640 --> 00:08:01.980
Not by IP at least.

160
00:08:01.980 --> 00:08:04.835
But there's actually a neat
little thing that we can do here,

161
00:08:04.835 --> 00:08:09.370
it's documented in Amazon's
web documentation, AWS.

162
00:08:09.370 --> 00:08:11.690
But it's not shown here in the GUI.

163
00:08:11.690 --> 00:08:13.200
Based on the GUI, you wouldn't know it.

164
00:08:13.200 --> 00:08:16.480
But you can actually
put in a resource name

165
00:08:16.480 --> 00:08:17.970
in this block instead of an IP, right.

166
00:08:17.970 --> 00:08:20.060
And what is a resource name?

167
00:08:20.060 --> 00:08:24.180
Well, every object you
create inside of AWS, and

168
00:08:24.180 --> 00:08:26.550
not just EC2 to but S3 everywhere.

169
00:08:26.550 --> 00:08:27.220
Gets resource a name.

170
00:08:27.220 --> 00:08:30.390
it is a name that identifies
your object specifically and

171
00:08:30.390 --> 00:08:33.620
Amazon uses that in the for the most part,

172
00:08:33.620 --> 00:08:37.240
to make it where you don't have
duplicate names with other customers.

173
00:08:37.240 --> 00:08:39.930
If I have a load balancer
called Web LB and

174
00:08:39.930 --> 00:08:43.040
you create a load balancer called Web LB,
how do we know them apart?

175
00:08:43.040 --> 00:08:48.560
Well, the resource name is a unique name
tied to it, and we don't normally see it.

176
00:08:48.560 --> 00:08:52.480
But it's there, it exists, and
that's how Amazon identifies it.

177
00:08:52.480 --> 00:08:56.670
So we can use that resource name and
punch it right in here, and

178
00:08:56.670 --> 00:08:59.430
that will be our load balancer, right.

179
00:08:59.430 --> 00:09:01.880
The problem is load balancers are special.

180
00:09:01.880 --> 00:09:06.060
When we talk about resource names on one
of our objects, we see those really easy.

181
00:09:06.060 --> 00:09:07.170
Let me show you what I mean.

182
00:09:07.170 --> 00:09:09.050
I'm just gonna cancel that.

183
00:09:09.050 --> 00:09:12.250
I'll put this limit in here,
tying it to my IP and I'll hit save.

184
00:09:12.250 --> 00:09:14.610
Now I'm leaving my load balancer out.

185
00:09:14.610 --> 00:09:18.980
So my load balancer is gonna lose
access to the web servers, alright.

186
00:09:18.980 --> 00:09:21.720
And so I'm gonna have to come back and
fix that.

187
00:09:21.720 --> 00:09:24.790
But if I go to the web site right now and
try and refresh.

188
00:09:24.790 --> 00:09:26.530
I'm hitting the load balancer.

189
00:09:26.530 --> 00:09:30.340
And then it's taking a long
time to generate that page.

190
00:09:30.340 --> 00:09:33.250
If I wait long enough,
I'll get server unreachable right or

191
00:09:33.250 --> 00:09:35.560
then I'm not able to get that
content I get to the load balancer.

192
00:09:35.560 --> 00:09:37.710
But I don't get the back end content.

193
00:09:37.710 --> 00:09:40.660
And if I come here and
look at my load balancer right now, and

194
00:09:40.660 --> 00:09:44.080
I go to my instances,
they're failing their health checks.

195
00:09:44.080 --> 00:09:45.470
One's already gone out of service,

196
00:09:45.470 --> 00:09:47.080
the other will go out of
service here any moment.

197
00:09:47.080 --> 00:09:49.390
You know the health checks happen every so
often, so

198
00:09:49.390 --> 00:09:53.265
they can be detected at different times,
but it's gonna try and figure it out.

199
00:09:53.265 --> 00:09:55.415
And there it goes,
they're both out of service, all right?

200
00:09:55.415 --> 00:09:58.485
So I just broke my network because I
didn't list the load balancer as being

201
00:09:58.485 --> 00:10:00.775
approved to get to those systems, right?

202
00:10:00.775 --> 00:10:04.265
Now the load balancer,
well, forgot my point.

203
00:10:04.265 --> 00:10:06.295
If I go up here to my instances.

204
00:10:06.295 --> 00:10:10.325
When you look at an instance, you've
got an instance ID right here, right?

205
00:10:10.325 --> 00:10:12.760
That's the resource name for this item.

206
00:10:12.760 --> 00:10:14.400
That's how we know our instance.

207
00:10:14.400 --> 00:10:17.760
There might be a thousand other customers
with a server called Web03, but

208
00:10:17.760 --> 00:10:20.030
Amazon knows this one is mine
because of the instance ID.

209
00:10:21.090 --> 00:10:24.370
Everything has an ID like that,
the resource name, but

210
00:10:24.370 --> 00:10:28.460
a load balancer is special,
because you don't own the load balancer.

211
00:10:28.460 --> 00:10:31.360
You get billed for it,
but Amazon manages it.

212
00:10:31.360 --> 00:10:35.350
That load balancer is actually an instance
running in the background, but

213
00:10:35.350 --> 00:10:37.660
it's Amazon's instance, not yours.

214
00:10:37.660 --> 00:10:40.540
So, when you go to the load balancer and
you go to description.

215
00:10:40.540 --> 00:10:45.112
Or even just looking at the columns up
here, you won't see an ID like that,

216
00:10:45.112 --> 00:10:45.720
all right?

217
00:10:45.720 --> 00:10:47.030
The closest you get is the DNS name.

218
00:10:47.030 --> 00:10:49.450
But when you look in here,
you don't see an ID.

219
00:10:49.450 --> 00:10:52.720
So, we actually can't list
the load balancer itself.

220
00:10:52.720 --> 00:10:55.620
But we can list the security group.

221
00:10:55.620 --> 00:10:58.640
We own the security group that
we put the load balancer in.

222
00:10:58.640 --> 00:11:01.890
So when you look at the description of
the load balancer as I scroll down,

223
00:11:01.890 --> 00:11:05.840
what you'll see in here is
the source security group.

224
00:11:05.840 --> 00:11:08.890
And there's the identifier for
my security group.

225
00:11:08.890 --> 00:11:13.360
And it's just your account number/web-LB
is the name I gave it, right.

226
00:11:13.360 --> 00:11:17.820
So that's the identifier for my security
group that the load balancer is in.

227
00:11:17.820 --> 00:11:19.290
And so instead of approving an IP,

228
00:11:19.290 --> 00:11:23.270
since I don't know what the IPs are gonna
be, I can approve the security group.

229
00:11:23.270 --> 00:11:26.460
I can say any node that's in Web-LB,

230
00:11:26.460 --> 00:11:30.400
in that security group, allow it to
access this other security group.

231
00:11:30.400 --> 00:11:34.110
So that's a cool way to provide that
access without knowing the IP addresses.

232
00:11:34.110 --> 00:11:34.770
And that's what I'm gonna do.

233
00:11:34.770 --> 00:11:36.780
I'm gonna go up to my security groups.

234
00:11:36.780 --> 00:11:43.270
and I'm gonna modify my Web host security
group to add in that new entry, right.

235
00:11:43.270 --> 00:11:45.794
So here's my IP specifically, and

236
00:11:45.794 --> 00:11:50.279
I'm gonna add a rule that allows
HTTP traffic on TCP port 80.

237
00:11:50.279 --> 00:11:54.960
I'm gonna say custom IP but
instead of an IP address,

238
00:11:54.960 --> 00:11:58.920
I'll just paste in that identifier,
alright, then I hit save.

239
00:11:59.930 --> 00:12:01.550
And you'll see it changes it.

240
00:12:01.550 --> 00:12:04.390
It takes the identifier, it looks it up.

241
00:12:04.390 --> 00:12:09.320
And then it puts the unique ID only,
it puts that unique ID in there.

242
00:12:09.320 --> 00:12:12.710
So I've got SG-40F,
blah, blah, blah, right?

243
00:12:12.710 --> 00:12:16.170
That's the security identifier for
that security group.

244
00:12:16.170 --> 00:12:20.410
Now, my load balancer will be allowed
to access the Web servers on port 80,

245
00:12:20.410 --> 00:12:23.670
and I will be allowed to access
the Web servers on port 80.

246
00:12:23.670 --> 00:12:29.140
If an end user tries to get to those
nodes directly, they won't be able to.

247
00:12:29.140 --> 00:12:30.740
Now I can, because of my IP.

248
00:12:30.740 --> 00:12:34.240
I'm gonna change that,
I'm gnna take my IP out.

249
00:12:34.240 --> 00:12:35.740
So let me just bump that out.

250
00:12:35.740 --> 00:12:38.640
So now, I can get to it with SSH but
I can't get to it with HTTP.

251
00:12:39.790 --> 00:12:44.030
So I'll save that, all right, there we go.

252
00:12:44.030 --> 00:12:46.640
And now, let's go test it, right?

253
00:12:46.640 --> 00:12:50.500
So, actually I should probably wait until
the load balancer is healthy again.

254
00:12:50.500 --> 00:12:54.720
If I go down here to my load balancer,
I can go to my load balancer.

255
00:12:54.720 --> 00:12:57.810
And then instances, and
I see they're both in service.

256
00:12:57.810 --> 00:12:59.860
They're both healthy again, okay.

257
00:12:59.860 --> 00:13:05.060
So if I'm a customer, and
I go browsing through www.itprotv.net,

258
00:13:05.060 --> 00:13:09.120
and I refresh that,
there's web01, there's web02.

259
00:13:09.120 --> 00:13:12.090
So, I see that I'm connecting
to these two different servers.

260
00:13:12.090 --> 00:13:14.960
As I just sit here and
refresh I'm bouncing between them.

261
00:13:14.960 --> 00:13:17.900
But if I try and
go to the server directly, right.

262
00:13:17.900 --> 00:13:23.340
If I try to go to Web01 directly,
it's taking a long time.

263
00:13:23.340 --> 00:13:26.950
And if I try and got to Web02 directly,
it's taking a long time.

264
00:13:26.950 --> 00:13:30.640
I can no longer directly access the notes.

265
00:13:30.640 --> 00:13:33.280
I have to go through the load balancer,
right.

266
00:13:33.280 --> 00:13:36.560
That is gonna decrease
your attack surface.

267
00:13:36.560 --> 00:13:39.500
People will not be able to
target the servers individually.

268
00:13:39.500 --> 00:13:41.290
They'll have to pass
through the load balancer,

269
00:13:41.290 --> 00:13:43.400
which is gonna be moving
them between servers.

270
00:13:43.400 --> 00:13:47.320
And that's gonna make session
spoofing a lot more difficult.

271
00:13:47.320 --> 00:13:49.750
Basically, it'll make it where they
have to do cookie compromises or

272
00:13:49.750 --> 00:13:50.780
other types of attacks.

273
00:13:50.780 --> 00:13:54.580
There are still other attacks but
this definitely helps out a lot.

274
00:13:54.580 --> 00:13:58.290
So neat little caveats there, a couple
little things we need to be aware of when

275
00:13:58.290 --> 00:14:00.450
we deal with load balancers like these.

276
00:14:00.450 --> 00:14:01.250
Eventually they'll fail.

277
00:14:01.250 --> 00:14:06.100
Apparently, Chrome's timeout is insanely
long but eventually that'll fail.

278
00:14:06.100 --> 00:14:09.920
But, the key thing to remember is
that when you're setting up those

279
00:14:09.920 --> 00:14:15.230
security groups, you don't have to
put an IP address in that field.

280
00:14:15.230 --> 00:14:20.500
It does accept other things like the ARNs,
the resource names.

281
00:14:20.500 --> 00:14:23.790
You can put those in, it'll recognize it,
and that's what it will use.

282
00:14:24.820 --> 00:14:27.740
All right, so that's a quick chance for
us to see that.

283
00:14:27.740 --> 00:14:31.890
So in this segment, we took a look at
advanced security configurations, right.

284
00:14:31.890 --> 00:14:34.510
Security groups in conjunction
with a load balancer,

285
00:14:34.510 --> 00:14:35.860
how we can improve that performance.

286
00:14:35.860 --> 00:14:38.130
So, I hope you guys enjoyed the segment.

287
00:14:38.130 --> 00:14:40.810
Stay tuned, we've got more
Amazon Web Services coming up.

episodes.title: Connection Draining In ELB
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:05,122
[SOUND] In this segment we're gonna take

2
00:00:05,122 --> 00:00:13,358
a look at Connection Draining
within Elastic Load Balancing.

3
00:00:13,358 --> 00:00:14,930
Now, what is Connection Draining?

4
00:00:14,930 --> 00:00:19,910
Well, one of the really cool parts
about using the Elastic Load Balancing

5
00:00:19,910 --> 00:00:24,100
is that you can have multiple hosts all
masked behind a single load balancing.

6
00:00:24,100 --> 00:00:26,360
And as your end users connect to it,

7
00:00:26,360 --> 00:00:29,490
that traffic is distributed
across the nodes behind it.

8
00:00:29,490 --> 00:00:33,190
And because the traffic is being
distributed, you can actually take a node

9
00:00:33,190 --> 00:00:36,830
offline, and the traffic just gets
redistributed across the existing,

10
00:00:36,830 --> 00:00:38,370
the ones that are still online.

11
00:00:38,370 --> 00:00:41,440
So that means that we can
do routine maintenance.

12
00:00:41,440 --> 00:00:46,550
Things like system updates and firmware
updates, copy files things like that

13
00:00:46,550 --> 00:00:49,910
even backups, we can do that
while our server is offline but

14
00:00:49,910 --> 00:00:52,530
our end users are still
able to get access, right?

15
00:00:52,530 --> 00:00:55,270
Definitely a very cool thing a lot of
stuff we used to schedule for after

16
00:00:55,270 --> 00:00:58,360
hours you can now do in the middle of
the day so you're not working on Sunday.

17
00:00:58,360 --> 00:01:01,195
You can just do it right there even during
peak time, as long as you’ve got enough

18
00:01:01,195 --> 00:01:03,850
additional servers to carry
the load in your environment.

19
00:01:04,900 --> 00:01:08,670
The only problem is,
when you take a node out of service,

20
00:01:08,670 --> 00:01:14,290
when you take it out of the load
balancing pool, if anybody was currently

21
00:01:14,290 --> 00:01:18,990
connected to that node, Their session gets
reset, they get moved to another server.

22
00:01:18,990 --> 00:01:20,990
Now a lot of applications
handle that seamlessly.

23
00:01:20,990 --> 00:01:25,360
A lot of web applications use cookies
on the person's end, on your client.

24
00:01:25,360 --> 00:01:27,700
And so when they jump from server
to server it makes no difference.

25
00:01:27,700 --> 00:01:31,150
That's how Amazon's storefront is, they
don't really care which server you connect

26
00:01:31,150 --> 00:01:33,400
to, your cookies identify your session.

27
00:01:33,400 --> 00:01:36,940
But other applications may be
a lot more sensitive about that.

28
00:01:36,940 --> 00:01:39,840
Like you might be load
balancing a MySQL box.

29
00:01:39,840 --> 00:01:41,380
So, you've already authenticated and

30
00:01:41,380 --> 00:01:43,790
logged in and
run some queries against one.

31
00:01:43,790 --> 00:01:47,690
If you all the sudden get moved to
another server, you're not authenticated.

32
00:01:47,690 --> 00:01:49,310
And so you have to reauthenticate.

33
00:01:49,310 --> 00:01:51,070
Your end users will notice that.

34
00:01:51,070 --> 00:01:52,380
It's not an outage.

35
00:01:52,380 --> 00:01:53,170
They still have access.

36
00:01:53,170 --> 00:01:56,610
They'll just notice that they have
to relogin or rebuild their session.

37
00:01:56,610 --> 00:01:59,950
So, if we want to try and
keep that as seamless as possible,

38
00:01:59,950 --> 00:02:02,420
just taking a node out of
service isn't a great idea.

39
00:02:02,420 --> 00:02:04,768
And that's where connection
draining comes in.

40
00:02:04,768 --> 00:02:06,540
With connection draining we say,

41
00:02:06,540 --> 00:02:09,550
when we take a node out of
service don't just yank it out.

42
00:02:09,550 --> 00:02:12,700
Instead, let it sit there for
a little while.

43
00:02:12,700 --> 00:02:17,860
And will not send any new connections,
no new connections to the node.

44
00:02:17,860 --> 00:02:21,590
But any existing connections will
have a certain amount of time to wrap

45
00:02:21,590 --> 00:02:22,770
up what they're doing.

46
00:02:22,770 --> 00:02:26,570
And you can designate that amount of time,
And it'll do that.

47
00:02:26,570 --> 00:02:30,530
Connection draining is turned on by
default on the Elastic Load Balancer, and

48
00:02:30,530 --> 00:02:33,120
the default window is set to five minutes.

49
00:02:33,120 --> 00:02:35,430
So when you remove a node
from a Load Balancer,

50
00:02:35,430 --> 00:02:37,600
by default it will wait five minutes.

51
00:02:37,600 --> 00:02:39,590
No new connections will be sent to it but

52
00:02:39,590 --> 00:02:42,890
existing ones are still allowed
to complete for five minutes.

53
00:02:42,890 --> 00:02:45,840
If they finish in five minutes,
the end user won't even notice

54
00:02:45,840 --> 00:02:48,880
that they get bumped over to another
system cause they're finished.

55
00:02:48,880 --> 00:02:49,950
But if somebody is working and

56
00:02:49,950 --> 00:02:53,460
they take longer than five minutes,
then they'll get interrupted.

57
00:02:53,460 --> 00:02:56,200
But the idea behind
connection draining is to

58
00:02:56,200 --> 00:02:57,970
minimize the amount of
people that we affect.

59
00:02:59,130 --> 00:03:02,350
Now, when you run the setup wizard for
creating a Load Balancer,

60
00:03:02,350 --> 00:03:05,440
you get to pick whether or not you
want to enable connection draining.

61
00:03:05,440 --> 00:03:08,880
But you can always change it after
the fact, so let me show you that.

62
00:03:08,880 --> 00:03:11,670
I'm gonna take one of my Load Balancer,
let me just switch over.

63
00:03:11,670 --> 00:03:14,940
So if we start at the AWS console,
I'm gonna into EC2 and

64
00:03:14,940 --> 00:03:18,480
then in EC2 I'm gonna go
down to my Load Balancers.

65
00:03:20,010 --> 00:03:24,100
Here's my load balancer, and I can't
really remember when I set this one up,

66
00:03:24,100 --> 00:03:26,470
I don't remember if I turned
on connection draining or not.

67
00:03:26,470 --> 00:03:27,400
But it's easy to check.

68
00:03:27,400 --> 00:03:31,250
If we just go down to our Instances tab,
you'll see our instances, and

69
00:03:31,250 --> 00:03:34,130
I almost always just really quick
scroll down to get to the instances,

70
00:03:34,130 --> 00:03:35,330
that's what I care about.

71
00:03:35,330 --> 00:03:39,380
But right at the very top you'll
see Connection Draining, and

72
00:03:39,380 --> 00:03:40,950
whether it's enabled or not.

73
00:03:40,950 --> 00:03:43,900
And then it'll tell you
how long the interval is.

74
00:03:43,900 --> 00:03:47,630
So it looks like mine is turned on and
set to five minutes, or 300 seconds.

75
00:03:47,630 --> 00:03:50,890
That's the default, so I must not have
changed it when I ran the wizard.

76
00:03:50,890 --> 00:03:53,330
But you can edit that to modify it.

77
00:03:53,330 --> 00:03:55,500
If you turn off Connection Draining,

78
00:03:55,500 --> 00:03:59,030
when you remove a node from
the pool it immediately comes out.

79
00:03:59,030 --> 00:04:01,710
And anybody who had a session on
that node, that sessions gone, so

80
00:04:01,710 --> 00:04:03,870
they'll have to build up a session
on one of the other nodes.

81
00:04:03,870 --> 00:04:07,800
Right, again, not an outage, but
they do notice the little interruption.

82
00:04:07,800 --> 00:04:10,960
But if it's on,
we can then specify the time.

83
00:04:10,960 --> 00:04:13,560
Now, the longer the time,

84
00:04:13,560 --> 00:04:16,710
the more likely people will
finish doing what they're doing.

85
00:04:16,710 --> 00:04:18,810
Five minutes may not be long enough for
you.

86
00:04:18,810 --> 00:04:22,350
If this is gonna stop me from
having to come into work on Sunday,

87
00:04:22,350 --> 00:04:24,130
then I might set this to 30 minutes.

88
00:04:24,130 --> 00:04:26,690
You know, I might go really long
to guarantee that everybody

89
00:04:26,690 --> 00:04:27,745
finishes their stuff.

90
00:04:27,745 --> 00:04:29,530
Cause I can drain it in the morning and

91
00:04:29,530 --> 00:04:32,450
then come in at lunch and
do my changes and whatever.

92
00:04:32,450 --> 00:04:35,060
So you can kind of pick
how much time you want it.

93
00:04:35,060 --> 00:04:36,840
But five minutes is the default.

94
00:04:36,840 --> 00:04:39,730
I'm gonna lower mine, just because
I don't want to wait five minutes.

95
00:04:39,730 --> 00:04:41,510
I'm gonna lower it to 30 seconds.

96
00:04:41,510 --> 00:04:46,050
So when I take a node out,
it's actually gonna wait 30 seconds, and

97
00:04:46,050 --> 00:04:48,970
then it'll remove it from the pool,
all right?

98
00:04:48,970 --> 00:04:51,050
So I'll go ahead and just save that.

99
00:04:51,050 --> 00:04:52,480
And now it's in place.

100
00:04:52,480 --> 00:04:54,760
Connection draining is on.

101
00:04:54,760 --> 00:04:57,730
Once it's on,
if I wanna do maintenance on a node.

102
00:04:57,730 --> 00:04:59,330
So let's say Web02 here.

103
00:04:59,330 --> 00:05:02,190
I wanna do maintenance on web02.

104
00:05:02,190 --> 00:05:05,190
So I'm gonna go and tweak it and
change whatever I need.

105
00:05:05,190 --> 00:05:07,620
I need to do some updates and
reboot the server.

106
00:05:07,620 --> 00:05:10,790
All right, well, if I'm gonna reboot it,
that's gonna interrupt my users, so

107
00:05:10,790 --> 00:05:12,070
I don't want that to happen.

108
00:05:12,070 --> 00:05:17,260
So I can take node two, and
I can hit remove from Load Balancer.

109
00:05:17,260 --> 00:05:20,860
When I hit remove from Load Balancer,
it's gonna take node two out of the pool.

110
00:05:20,860 --> 00:05:24,800
Now, if draining is turned off,
that'll happen instantly.

111
00:05:24,800 --> 00:05:28,350
But since draining is on,
it's gonna wait 30 seconds.

112
00:05:28,350 --> 00:05:31,820
So when I remove it, so
I'll just say yes to remove it.

113
00:05:31,820 --> 00:05:35,410
Existing connections are still
allowed to stay connected.

114
00:05:35,410 --> 00:05:37,750
Nobody new is going to web02.

115
00:05:37,750 --> 00:05:40,360
But existing users on web02
are still functioning.

116
00:05:40,360 --> 00:05:42,380
And they'll still function for 30 seconds.

117
00:05:42,380 --> 00:05:46,140
Now they got 30 seconds to wrap
up whatever they were doing and

118
00:05:46,140 --> 00:05:47,160
if they do, great.

119
00:05:47,160 --> 00:05:49,170
Their service is completely uninterrupted.

120
00:05:49,170 --> 00:05:49,860
But if they don't,

121
00:05:49,860 --> 00:05:52,810
at the end of that 30 second window,
they'll get bumped over to web01.

122
00:05:52,810 --> 00:05:55,890
So they'll still have access on web01,

123
00:05:55,890 --> 00:05:59,710
but if our developers haven't planned for
that,

124
00:05:59,710 --> 00:06:03,550
then they may have a little interruption,
may have to relogin, or whatever.

125
00:06:03,550 --> 00:06:05,380
All right, so we're good there.

126
00:06:05,380 --> 00:06:07,900
I've drained it, and I'm kind of
stalling here for the 30 seconds.

127
00:06:07,900 --> 00:06:09,910
I probably should have picked
something even shorter.

128
00:06:09,910 --> 00:06:14,310
But once it's out, now I can do
whatever maintenance I want on Web02.

129
00:06:14,310 --> 00:06:16,930
Which I think I'm [INAUDIBLE]
into it on the background.

130
00:06:18,360 --> 00:06:20,080
Here, let's see.

131
00:06:20,080 --> 00:06:26,100
Yeah, I'm in Web02 here, so
I might do a series of updates

132
00:06:26,100 --> 00:06:28,650
and so I'll go and punch that in and so.

133
00:06:28,650 --> 00:06:31,590
No updates, but
I go in to do my updates for the system.

134
00:06:31,590 --> 00:06:33,080
Maybe I reboot it.

135
00:06:33,080 --> 00:06:34,645
So I go ahead and reboot that node.

136
00:06:34,645 --> 00:06:37,900
[LAUGH] I'm not logged in as root.

137
00:06:37,900 --> 00:06:38,610
So there we go.

138
00:06:38,610 --> 00:06:40,150
So now I'm going and rebooting it.

139
00:06:40,150 --> 00:06:42,630
That node's gonna reboot but
no users are on it.

140
00:06:42,630 --> 00:06:45,360
Well, assuming that I waited
the 30 seconds, right?

141
00:06:45,360 --> 00:06:48,220
But no users are on it so
I reboot, do my maintenance.

142
00:06:48,220 --> 00:06:49,550
Everything is happy.

143
00:06:49,550 --> 00:06:52,510
And then,
once I'm done with my maintenance.

144
00:06:52,510 --> 00:06:54,550
I just go and add it back into the pool.

145
00:06:54,550 --> 00:06:57,960
So I go back to my Load Balancer,
I go to Instances,

146
00:06:57,960 --> 00:07:02,160
and Edit Instances, and
I just add that node right back in.

147
00:07:02,160 --> 00:07:08,660
So I'm gonna add web02, and I'll hit save,
and now web02 is gonna be right back in.

148
00:07:08,660 --> 00:07:11,330
Now, it's rebooting right now, so
it's gonna fail it's health check.

149
00:07:11,330 --> 00:07:12,500
But I'm not worried about that.

150
00:07:12,500 --> 00:07:15,790
I know that when it comes back online
it'll be ready, so the system's gonna wait

151
00:07:15,790 --> 00:07:18,960
until it passes it's health
checks to bring it back online.

152
00:07:18,960 --> 00:07:21,710
If it was already online,
it would actually come up very,

153
00:07:21,710 --> 00:07:23,440
very quickly as in service.

154
00:07:23,440 --> 00:07:25,800
But since it's It's offline right now,
it's failing health checks.

155
00:07:25,800 --> 00:07:28,826
It will have to do the rest of
the health checks to see it.

156
00:07:28,826 --> 00:07:31,939
If you don't remember what your health
checks are set to,that's another tab up

157
00:07:31,939 --> 00:07:32,820
here, Health Check.

158
00:07:32,820 --> 00:07:37,040
So, notice on mine
the Healthy Threshold is set to two.

159
00:07:37,040 --> 00:07:38,360
The default is ten.

160
00:07:38,360 --> 00:07:39,490
I've lowered mine.

161
00:07:39,490 --> 00:07:40,720
So let's assume it's the default.

162
00:07:40,720 --> 00:07:41,890
The default is ten.

163
00:07:41,890 --> 00:07:46,410
That means we have to pass ten Health
Checks before the server comes online, and

164
00:07:46,410 --> 00:07:48,990
the default interval for
that is 30 seconds.

165
00:07:48,990 --> 00:07:54,380
So 300 seconds, or five minutes has to go
by before I'll bring that node online.

166
00:07:54,380 --> 00:07:55,940
That might be long time for you.

167
00:07:55,940 --> 00:07:57,330
For me, I'm not worried about it, right.

168
00:07:57,330 --> 00:07:58,980
This was an extra server,
I did maintenance.

169
00:07:58,980 --> 00:08:01,240
It can come back online in five minutes,
I'm fine with that.

170
00:08:01,240 --> 00:08:03,530
But if you're in a hurry,
you might lower it.

171
00:08:03,530 --> 00:08:05,300
As you see, I've lowered mine.

172
00:08:05,300 --> 00:08:09,360
My interval is ten seconds and
I've got a threshold of two,

173
00:08:09,360 --> 00:08:13,310
that means it has to pass two checks,
ten seconds apart, so

174
00:08:13,310 --> 00:08:17,270
it will take 20 seconds to recognize
that and bring this node back online.

175
00:08:17,270 --> 00:08:22,620
So it will come up online a lot faster and
then it will be up and happy.

176
00:08:22,620 --> 00:08:24,560
As happy as a server gets.

177
00:08:24,560 --> 00:08:26,910
And I can see web02 is already in service.

178
00:08:26,910 --> 00:08:31,980
And now new connections will start
getting balanced over to web02.

179
00:08:31,980 --> 00:08:36,150
So really easy to do that maintenance
without impacting our customers.

180
00:08:36,150 --> 00:08:40,340
And instead of having to wake up early or
stay up and do maintenance at 3 am or

181
00:08:40,340 --> 00:08:42,980
non peak time, you can do it
right in the middle of the day

182
00:08:42,980 --> 00:08:47,500
as long as you have enough other servers
to maintain redundancy, all right?

183
00:08:47,500 --> 00:08:50,030
And if you're not sure,
you can always scroll down a bit here, and

184
00:08:50,030 --> 00:08:53,540
it gives you a little bit of information
as to whether you are redundant.

185
00:08:53,540 --> 00:08:57,620
And so we'll see here in us-east-1a,
I've got two nodes.

186
00:08:57,620 --> 00:08:59,460
I'm healthy, I'm redundant,

187
00:08:59,460 --> 00:09:02,870
versus my other nodes where I don't have
enough healthy instances to be redundant.

188
00:09:02,870 --> 00:09:04,970
But you can just kinda take
a quick peek there, but

189
00:09:04,970 --> 00:09:07,040
usually you know right
here from your instances.

190
00:09:08,300 --> 00:09:09,270
All right.
So in this segment,

191
00:09:09,270 --> 00:09:12,600
we got a chance to see how to
drain a node to do maintenance,

192
00:09:12,600 --> 00:09:13,510
how to bring it back online.

193
00:09:13,510 --> 00:09:17,610
It's pretty easy, cool feature
that wasn't always there in AWS.

194
00:09:17,610 --> 00:09:20,680
They added this one just, I think,
a little over a year or two ago.

195
00:09:20,680 --> 00:09:22,430
So it's one of the newer options.

196
00:09:22,430 --> 00:09:25,020
Definitely useful though,
so take advantage of it.

197
00:09:25,020 --> 00:09:26,780
All right,
I hope you guys enjoyed the segment.

198
00:09:26,780 --> 00:09:27,420
Stay tuned.

199
00:09:27,420 --> 00:09:29,680
We've got more Amazon
web services coming up.

episodes.title: Cross-Zone Load Balancing
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:07,708
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:07,708 --> 00:00:11,770
In this segment, we're going to take
a look at cross-zone load balancing.

3
00:00:11,770 --> 00:00:13,020
Now, what is that?

4
00:00:13,020 --> 00:00:15,530
Well, when we configure
a load balancer inside a EC2,

5
00:00:15,530 --> 00:00:19,570
one of the questions it asks us is if we
want to enable cross-zone load balancing.

6
00:00:19,570 --> 00:00:23,420
And if you check that off, what that
means is that you can have nodes,

7
00:00:23,420 --> 00:00:25,850
or instances,
that are behind that cluster,

8
00:00:25,850 --> 00:00:29,570
that are actually in more
than one Availability Zone.

9
00:00:29,570 --> 00:00:33,478
Remember that with EC2, Amazon has
many different data centers, and so

10
00:00:33,478 --> 00:00:35,495
if you choose to bring up an instance,

11
00:00:35,495 --> 00:00:38,599
one of the questions it asks you
is where you want to put it?

12
00:00:38,599 --> 00:00:41,980
And that's gonna impact availability.

13
00:00:41,980 --> 00:00:44,300
Let me show you what I mean
here with my instances, so

14
00:00:44,300 --> 00:00:48,950
I'm gonna go into my AWS console,
and I'm gonna go to EC2, and

15
00:00:48,950 --> 00:00:51,530
inside of EC2 I'm gonna
go to my instances.

16
00:00:52,630 --> 00:00:56,605
I've got three web servers whipped up,
and so you can see web01,

17
00:00:56,605 --> 00:00:58,570
web02, web03 right there.

18
00:00:58,570 --> 00:01:02,770
Web01 and web02,
I put both of them in us-east-1a,

19
00:01:02,770 --> 00:01:07,642
that's the us-east,
that's the North Virginia data center, and

20
00:01:07,642 --> 00:01:11,580
then 1a,
that's the first Availability Zone.

21
00:01:11,580 --> 00:01:15,180
There's actually five zones there, but for

22
00:01:15,180 --> 00:01:17,085
availability they only let
you pick between three.

23
00:01:17,085 --> 00:01:20,030
So, not every zone is equipped for this.

24
00:01:20,030 --> 00:01:23,390
So, there's five zones in North Virginia,
but there's three that we can pick,

25
00:01:23,390 --> 00:01:27,680
if I remember right is a, c, and
d, we'll see it in a minute.

26
00:01:27,680 --> 00:01:31,820
I'm pretty sure b is not one of them,
but you'll see where web01 and

27
00:01:31,820 --> 00:01:33,650
web02 are both in a.

28
00:01:34,650 --> 00:01:37,825
Well, that means they're
in the same data center,

29
00:01:37,825 --> 00:01:41,585
they're using the same redundant Internet
connection, and redundant power and

30
00:01:41,585 --> 00:01:46,555
all that, it's all heavily redundant, but
occasionally, data centers can go down.

31
00:01:46,555 --> 00:01:48,725
And Amazon has had a few
outages over the years,

32
00:01:48,725 --> 00:01:52,985
and it's usually caused by something
like a poor BGP configuration, or

33
00:01:52,985 --> 00:01:54,885
something like that, that affects routing.

34
00:01:54,885 --> 00:01:57,615
So, traffic isn't getting
routed into that data center.

35
00:01:57,615 --> 00:01:59,655
Well, if the whole data
center goes offline,

36
00:01:59,655 --> 00:02:02,310
I'm gonna lose both of those servers.

37
00:02:02,310 --> 00:02:07,990
So, if I want redundancy, it's a good
idea to not just have multiple servers,

38
00:02:07,990 --> 00:02:11,740
but to also have servers in
different Availability Zones.

39
00:02:11,740 --> 00:02:17,260
So, notice how I've got web03,
and web03 is in us-east-1c.

40
00:02:17,260 --> 00:02:22,220
So, it's actually in the third
Availability Zone in North Virginia.

41
00:02:22,220 --> 00:02:24,730
I could have chosen to put
it in one of the us-west,

42
00:02:24,730 --> 00:02:26,430
Northern California or Oregon.

43
00:02:26,430 --> 00:02:29,100
You can put them various places,
I chose to put them here.

44
00:02:29,100 --> 00:02:32,510
Now, you might say to yourself, well,
Don, they're both in North Virginia,

45
00:02:32,510 --> 00:02:33,630
why would you do that?

46
00:02:33,630 --> 00:02:38,310
Well, these are actually two
completely independent data centers.

47
00:02:38,310 --> 00:02:39,870
They use separate Internet connections,

48
00:02:39,870 --> 00:02:44,880
separate subnets, separate equipment,
separate power, completely separate power.

49
00:02:44,880 --> 00:02:49,300
So, if one data center fails
the other one's unaffected.

50
00:02:49,300 --> 00:02:51,920
So, that actually gives me
enough redundancy to meet

51
00:02:51,920 --> 00:02:55,160
pretty much every SLA that I've
ever had to deal with in my career.

52
00:02:55,160 --> 00:02:59,690
So, that's usually good enough, but you're
right, a natural disaster could hit.

53
00:02:59,690 --> 00:03:03,740
A hurricane, earthquake, tornado,
something really big that is

54
00:03:03,740 --> 00:03:07,180
super catastrophic, and
levels both of those data centers.

55
00:03:07,180 --> 00:03:11,340
It'd be pretty challenging, but
it could happen, and if that did happen.

56
00:03:11,340 --> 00:03:14,620
Well, it would be nice if I
had some over in Oregon, or

57
00:03:14,620 --> 00:03:16,510
northern California, or wherever.

58
00:03:16,510 --> 00:03:20,820
So you can choose to do that, for
my example, I've just got that right here.

59
00:03:20,820 --> 00:03:22,520
Now, when I do load balancing,

60
00:03:22,520 --> 00:03:26,552
one of the main reasons we do load
balancing is for performance.

61
00:03:26,552 --> 00:03:30,090
We wanna distribute all our end users
across more than one server, so

62
00:03:30,090 --> 00:03:32,130
that we can scale out.

63
00:03:32,130 --> 00:03:36,320
Scaling up, when we increase processor,
or memory, there's limits.

64
00:03:36,320 --> 00:03:38,360
There's only so
much memory you can have in a server, so

65
00:03:38,360 --> 00:03:41,670
much CPU power you can have in a server,
but when we scale out,

66
00:03:41,670 --> 00:03:45,560
you can add as many servers as you need,
so you really get the ability to grow.

67
00:03:45,560 --> 00:03:49,090
And that's how most people use load
balancers, if you're just using it for

68
00:03:49,090 --> 00:03:52,460
performance, then you don't
really care about this piece.

69
00:03:52,460 --> 00:03:55,180
And so you may choose to put
them all in one zone, and

70
00:03:55,180 --> 00:03:58,030
then cross-zone availability
doesn't mean anything to you.

71
00:03:58,030 --> 00:04:01,575
But if you're trying to get the best
redundancy, so your systems

72
00:04:01,575 --> 00:04:05,901
are online during failures, cross-zone
gives you a great level of planning.

73
00:04:05,901 --> 00:04:09,415
Now, when you created your load balancer,
you might not remember, but

74
00:04:09,415 --> 00:04:13,044
it actually asked if you wanted to
turn on cross-site load balancing, and

75
00:04:13,044 --> 00:04:14,560
the default is it's checked.

76
00:04:14,560 --> 00:04:18,160
So, if you ignored it, it's already
turned on, and it's pretty easy to spot.

77
00:04:18,160 --> 00:04:21,299
When you look at your load balancer,
I'll go down here to my load balancer.

78
00:04:22,930 --> 00:04:28,840
Here's my load balancer, and in the status
columns here I can see Availability Zones,

79
00:04:28,840 --> 00:04:30,720
let me resize some of this,
so we can see it better.

80
00:04:32,450 --> 00:04:36,760
And, in the Availability Zones, notice how
it's got us-east 1c, 1a, and 1d, yeah,

81
00:04:36,760 --> 00:04:40,530
b and e are not in the list.

82
00:04:40,530 --> 00:04:43,930
So, I've got three Availabilities Zones,
that's because this

83
00:04:43,930 --> 00:04:47,090
load balancer is residing in
North Virginia that's where I created it.

84
00:04:47,090 --> 00:04:49,351
And I chose cross-zone availability,

85
00:04:49,351 --> 00:04:53,270
so it's showing each of those
different zones right there.

86
00:04:53,270 --> 00:04:56,670
I can put nodes in any of those, and
the load balancer will accept that.

87
00:04:58,100 --> 00:05:01,650
I didn't do that during the setup,
I just picked web01 and web02, so

88
00:05:01,650 --> 00:05:08,150
if I go down here to my instances,
I've only got instances in us-east 1a.

89
00:05:08,150 --> 00:05:13,070
If I scroll down in my instances here,
I'll see my Availability Zones,

90
00:05:13,070 --> 00:05:17,118
and I can see, let me just resize that,
so we can see it all.

91
00:05:17,118 --> 00:05:20,120
I can see us-east 1c, 1a, 1d.

92
00:05:20,120 --> 00:05:24,540
There's the three zones, and
I can see that, yeah I'm healthy,

93
00:05:24,540 --> 00:05:30,560
I've got two instances in 1a, but
I'm not redundant for 1c, or 1d.

94
00:05:30,560 --> 00:05:35,069
So, if 1a goes offline, 1c and
1d can't help me, I'm not fully redundant.

95
00:05:36,230 --> 00:05:37,500
So, I need to go and

96
00:05:37,500 --> 00:05:40,380
change this, and this is something
that you can do after the fact.

97
00:05:40,380 --> 00:05:43,425
If you want to enable it after the fact,
you just come here, and edit the zones,

98
00:05:43,425 --> 00:05:45,605
and you can add more zones, or
if you wanna turn them off,

99
00:05:45,605 --> 00:05:46,808
you can just remove the zones.

100
00:05:46,808 --> 00:05:50,038
I could actually go, and
remove 1c and 1d from the list, and

101
00:05:50,038 --> 00:05:54,141
