a lot of times you'll do that, maybe I
wanna make mine redundant, actually,

102
00:05:54,141 --> 00:05:56,150
I've forgotten, where is web03?

103
00:05:56,150 --> 00:05:59,400
Let's go back to my instances,
and see where web03 is.

104
00:05:59,400 --> 00:06:03,020
Web03 is in 1c,
I don't have any nodes in 1d,

105
00:06:03,020 --> 00:06:06,180
so there's really no point in
having that on my load balancer.

106
00:06:06,180 --> 00:06:09,140
And it's gonna continue to generate
that little warning message there,

107
00:06:09,140 --> 00:06:11,760
if I leave it, so
I'll go ahead and remove that one.

108
00:06:11,760 --> 00:06:16,060
So, I'll go back to my load balancer, and
here I am in my web/lb and wanted to call

109
00:06:16,060 --> 00:06:21,800
in my instances, and I'll browse down and
Edit my Availability Zones.

110
00:06:21,800 --> 00:06:25,740
And I'm just gonna remove 1d from
the list, no sense keeping it,

111
00:06:25,740 --> 00:06:27,920
I don't have anybody there,
so I'll just remove it.

112
00:06:27,920 --> 00:06:30,720
I can always add it back later,
see how I've got the plus sign?

113
00:06:30,720 --> 00:06:31,760
So, you can add these, and

114
00:06:31,760 --> 00:06:34,677
that's effectively what turns
on the cross-zone availability.

115
00:06:35,950 --> 00:06:40,545
So, I'll Save that, and now I've got 1a
and 1c, I don't see any errors anymore for

116
00:06:40,545 --> 00:06:43,550
1d, it's just gone, but
I'm still not healthy in 1c.

117
00:06:44,570 --> 00:06:48,882
Now, I can just add in a node from 1c,
and so I'll do that.

118
00:06:48,882 --> 00:06:51,580
Let me go back up to my instances, and

119
00:06:51,580 --> 00:06:54,080
I'll Edit that, and
I'm gonna to pick my web03.

120
00:06:54,080 --> 00:06:59,930
So, now I've got it checked,
it's in 1c right there, and I'll hit Save.

121
00:07:01,250 --> 00:07:05,300
And now I've got nodes in
multiple Availability Zones.

122
00:07:05,300 --> 00:07:07,100
And it's gonna take a moment
to detect that right.

123
00:07:07,100 --> 00:07:10,290
Its gotta pass its health check, so
it's showing as out of service right now.

124
00:07:10,290 --> 00:07:14,020
I shorten my health checks
to be about 20 seconds.

125
00:07:14,020 --> 00:07:18,210
The default is five minutes, so it could
take a little while for it to detect, and

126
00:07:18,210 --> 00:07:19,450
go in service.

127
00:07:19,450 --> 00:07:23,630
For me, I'm stalling right now,
[LAUGH] but if we hit 20 seconds, it'll go

128
00:07:23,630 --> 00:07:26,910
in service, and I can just sit here,
and impatiently hit the Refresh button.

129
00:07:26,910 --> 00:07:29,130
There it is, so
now they're all in service.

130
00:07:29,130 --> 00:07:30,070
And when I scroll down, and

131
00:07:30,070 --> 00:07:34,140
look at my zones, see how that
zone 1c shows it's healthy now.

132
00:07:34,140 --> 00:07:39,220
I've only got one node in there,
so if 1a were to fail,

133
00:07:39,220 --> 00:07:43,820
that one node and 1c would have to
carry the whole load of my company, and

134
00:07:43,820 --> 00:07:45,730
that's not really ideal, is it?

135
00:07:45,730 --> 00:07:48,760
So, we usually wanna keep
the numbers pretty much equal,

136
00:07:48,760 --> 00:07:51,590
that you have an equal number of
servers in the different zones.

137
00:07:51,590 --> 00:07:54,380
That way if one zone fails, the other
one's gotta pick up the slack, but

138
00:07:54,380 --> 00:07:55,180
it's equal.

139
00:07:55,180 --> 00:07:58,950
It's not already behind the gun,
you don't want it to be at a detriment.

140
00:07:58,950 --> 00:08:04,080
If I go from three servers down to
one server, that's a pretty big loss.

141
00:08:04,080 --> 00:08:09,223
So, if I've just got three servers and
that's it, I might choose to put 1 in 1a,

142
00:08:09,223 --> 00:08:12,130
1 in 1c, and 1 in 1d.

143
00:08:12,130 --> 00:08:15,990
And that way I've got three zones of
availability with my three servers, but

144
00:08:15,990 --> 00:08:18,450
if I wanna go more,
you can balance it out.

145
00:08:18,450 --> 00:08:20,120
That's usually what I do.

146
00:08:20,120 --> 00:08:25,320
One word of caution, when all of
your servers are in the same zone,

147
00:08:25,320 --> 00:08:28,510
any transfer between those servers,
you don't pay for the bandwidth,

148
00:08:28,510 --> 00:08:33,870
it's in the zone, but when you go between
zones you do pay for the bandwidth.

149
00:08:33,870 --> 00:08:35,610
Well in some scenarios you pay for
the bandwidth.

150
00:08:35,610 --> 00:08:38,370
Sometimes like here, when it's all in
North Virgina I don't believe they bill

151
00:08:38,370 --> 00:08:41,680
for that, but when you're going from
like North Virginia to Oregon, or

152
00:08:41,680 --> 00:08:44,080
something like that,
they do bill for that.

153
00:08:44,080 --> 00:08:47,430
So, cross the zone data
transfers do get charged, so

154
00:08:47,430 --> 00:08:49,370
be aware of that cuz there's
separate data centers.

155
00:08:49,370 --> 00:08:53,260
They've gotta manage that bandwidth,
so that may increase your cost a bit.

156
00:08:53,260 --> 00:08:55,740
But the tradeoff is you
get great availability,

157
00:08:55,740 --> 00:08:57,350
it's usually worth that extra cost.

158
00:08:57,350 --> 00:09:01,050
It's not that significant, but
I can see I'm happy now, and

159
00:09:01,050 --> 00:09:02,770
I'm getting load balance
between the zones.

160
00:09:02,770 --> 00:09:06,700
My end users don't know that,
if they go here to the servers,

161
00:09:06,700 --> 00:09:08,660
well let me just check each one
to make sure they're healthy.

162
00:09:08,660 --> 00:09:10,140
Oh, actually wait we blocked that.

163
00:09:10,140 --> 00:09:13,020
So, let me just go to my load balancer
here, and I'll refresh, I just hit web01.

164
00:09:14,030 --> 00:09:14,620
Now, I hit web02.

165
00:09:14,620 --> 00:09:16,903
I'll just keep refreshing.

166
00:09:16,903 --> 00:09:17,870
Now, I hit web03.

167
00:09:19,200 --> 00:09:22,270
Not only am I hitting different servers,
I'm hitting

168
00:09:22,270 --> 00:09:26,790
completely different data centers, and
as an end user I don't even notice.

169
00:09:26,790 --> 00:09:31,708
To me it's just www.itprotv.net,
and that's it,

170
00:09:31,708 --> 00:09:34,980
but to the servers,
completely different data centers.

171
00:09:34,980 --> 00:09:36,490
And if one goes offline,

172
00:09:36,490 --> 00:09:40,250
the other one just picks up the slack,
really high availability here.

173
00:09:40,250 --> 00:09:43,110
This is how you start to
hit your really high SLAs.

174
00:09:43,110 --> 00:09:49,100
If you've ever wondered how somebody hits
99.999% of availability, five nines, five

175
00:09:49,100 --> 00:09:53,870
nines means that you only get a couple of
minutes per year that you can be down.

176
00:09:53,870 --> 00:09:55,230
How do you achieve that?

177
00:09:55,230 --> 00:10:00,030
This is how you do it, a load balancer
where you can take nodes in and out.

178
00:10:00,030 --> 00:10:03,450
Nodes in multiple data centers,
that's how we get that availability.

179
00:10:04,450 --> 00:10:07,363
So, once we get that configured,
we're now in really good shape.

180
00:10:07,363 --> 00:10:13,695
So, cross-zone [LAUGH] load balancing,
it's brain freeze there.

181
00:10:13,695 --> 00:10:16,474
Cross-zone load balancing
really important,

182
00:10:16,474 --> 00:10:19,737
really easy, so
no reason you shouldn't be doing that.

183
00:10:19,737 --> 00:10:22,016
So, in this segment we got
a chance to look at that,

184
00:10:22,016 --> 00:10:25,541
what cross-zone load balancing is,
we saw how to set it up, and how it works.

185
00:10:25,541 --> 00:10:28,820
Pretty easy, so hopefully,
you guys benefit from that,

186
00:10:28,820 --> 00:10:31,100
and put it in use in your environment.

187
00:10:31,100 --> 00:10:32,490
I hope you guys enjoyed the segment.

188
00:10:32,490 --> 00:10:35,320
Stay tuned,
got more Amazon Web Services coming up.

episodes.title: Change Instance Zones
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,008 --> 00:00:08,062
[SOUND]

2
00:00:08,062 --> 00:00:10,633
In this segment, we're gonna take a look

3
00:00:10,633 --> 00:00:15,180
at how to move an instance in
EC2 between availability zones.

4
00:00:15,180 --> 00:00:19,220
When you create an instance, when you
spin up a new virtual server in EC2,

5
00:00:19,220 --> 00:00:22,460
one of the questions it asks you
is where you want to put it.

6
00:00:22,460 --> 00:00:25,200
And you've got a choice between
the various data centers, right.

7
00:00:25,200 --> 00:00:28,200
So you can pick a region like
the North American region or

8
00:00:28,200 --> 00:00:30,780
the US West or whatever.

9
00:00:30,780 --> 00:00:33,020
The North Virginia region is the default.

10
00:00:33,020 --> 00:00:35,360
And you can then choose a data center or

11
00:00:35,360 --> 00:00:38,200
an availability zone
inside of that region.

12
00:00:38,200 --> 00:00:41,290
And so using the North Virginia
region as an example,

13
00:00:41,290 --> 00:00:43,610
there's actually five different
data centers in there.

14
00:00:43,610 --> 00:00:47,220
And you can pick and choose between
those data centers to deploy it.

15
00:00:47,220 --> 00:00:51,440
Well, some data centers have
features that others don't.

16
00:00:51,440 --> 00:00:54,180
So occasionally you might have deployed

17
00:00:54,180 --> 00:00:57,450
a server in one zone that
was fine at the time.

18
00:00:57,450 --> 00:01:01,450
But now you want to deploy some new
feature, and it's not supported.

19
00:01:01,450 --> 00:01:03,360
A great example of that is load balancing.

20
00:01:03,360 --> 00:01:07,150
With the elastic load balancer,
you can do cross-zone load balancing, but

21
00:01:07,150 --> 00:01:11,200
in the North Virginia region,
right there in that North America region,

22
00:01:11,200 --> 00:01:15,110
East, it only supports it
in three of the five zones.

23
00:01:15,110 --> 00:01:19,460
So, if your instances are in zone a,
c, or d, you're fine.

24
00:01:19,460 --> 00:01:22,180
But, if they're in b or
e you can't do it, right.

25
00:01:22,180 --> 00:01:27,200
So if you made that mistake, you might
need to move an instance from b over

26
00:01:27,200 --> 00:01:30,370
to one of the other ones that does support
the load balancing piece, all right.

27
00:01:30,370 --> 00:01:32,540
Well, unfortunately,
there's not an easy way to move it.

28
00:01:32,540 --> 00:01:36,090
You can't just right-click on an instance
and say move it to another zone.

29
00:01:36,090 --> 00:01:40,050
So there's a little bit of a process
we have to go through to get it moved.

30
00:01:40,050 --> 00:01:42,870
It's not so painful, though, so
I wanna show you guys how to do that,

31
00:01:42,870 --> 00:01:45,460
how we can quickly and
easily move it between zones.

32
00:01:45,460 --> 00:01:47,450
One little caveat before I get started.

33
00:01:47,450 --> 00:01:50,550
I'm gonna show you guys how to do this
right here using the GUI, and you'll see

34
00:01:50,550 --> 00:01:55,530
it's not that bad, but my way does involve
a little bit of downtime, all right.

35
00:01:55,530 --> 00:01:58,400
So I am gonna be taking the server
offline while I do this, and

36
00:01:58,400 --> 00:02:01,880
it'll take five to ten
minutes to do the move.

37
00:02:01,880 --> 00:02:04,920
If you’re in a mission critical
environment and you can’t afford that kind

38
00:02:04,920 --> 00:02:07,690
of downtime, this isn’t going
to be the solution for you.

39
00:02:07,690 --> 00:02:10,200
Instead, you might want to look
into third-party software,

40
00:02:10,200 --> 00:02:15,112
services like Ylastic,
it’s spelled with a y, Y L A S T I C,

41
00:02:15,112 --> 00:02:19,405
Ylastic or Scalr, S C A L R,
they leave E out.

42
00:02:19,405 --> 00:02:23,260
Scalr is another one where they provide
special services for moving these between

43
00:02:23,260 --> 00:02:29,070
zones that can minimize or
eliminate that downtime, right.

44
00:02:29,070 --> 00:02:32,151
There's a little way we can kind of trick
it by moving around elastic IPs, too, so

45
00:02:32,151 --> 00:02:34,178
we'll see there's a few
different ways we can do it.

46
00:02:34,178 --> 00:02:36,724
But my way, we can do it with GUI.

47
00:02:36,724 --> 00:02:37,747
We don't need third-party software.

48
00:02:37,747 --> 00:02:39,560
It just involves a little bit of downtime.

49
00:02:39,560 --> 00:02:40,260
All right.

50
00:02:40,260 --> 00:02:41,710
So I'm gonna show you my environment here.

51
00:02:41,710 --> 00:02:46,720
If I go into EC2 and I go to my instances,
I have a load balancer set up for

52
00:02:46,720 --> 00:02:47,910
my web farm.

53
00:02:47,910 --> 00:02:54,250
And right now, I've got two of my nodes in
zone 1A and one of my nodes in zone 1C.

54
00:02:54,250 --> 00:02:54,900
All right.

55
00:02:54,900 --> 00:02:57,620
Well, my problem is it's
not evenly balanced.

56
00:02:57,620 --> 00:03:01,550
So if zone 1A goes offline,
I lose 66% of my servers,

57
00:03:01,550 --> 00:03:05,910
and this one server then has to carry
that whole load, and that's not ideal.

58
00:03:05,910 --> 00:03:08,820
So we typically want to do even balancing,
but

59
00:03:08,820 --> 00:03:10,710
I've got an odd number of servers here.

60
00:03:10,710 --> 00:03:13,680
So it'd be nice if I could bring
a third zone into the mix.

61
00:03:13,680 --> 00:03:16,230
If I want to bring a third zone,
I've got to move one of these guys.

62
00:03:16,230 --> 00:03:19,080
One of these guys that's 1A I
need to move to another zone, and

63
00:03:19,080 --> 00:03:21,440
1D would be a great candidate for me.

64
00:03:21,440 --> 00:03:25,040
So I'm going to move web02 from 1A to 1D.

65
00:03:25,040 --> 00:03:30,100
But you'll see if you right-click,
there's no change zone link or edit zone.

66
00:03:30,100 --> 00:03:33,530
It's not something that you can
change cuz the server is in place.

67
00:03:33,530 --> 00:03:38,010
So what we have to do is
we have to create an AMI.

68
00:03:38,010 --> 00:03:40,080
An AMI is an Amazon Machine Image.

69
00:03:40,080 --> 00:03:41,290
When I built these servers,

70
00:03:41,290 --> 00:03:46,100
I picked from one of the default AMIs
that Amazon had, the Amazon Linux, but

71
00:03:46,100 --> 00:03:50,270
since then, I've made a bunch of
configuration changes to the server.

72
00:03:50,270 --> 00:03:54,240
So what we can do is we can create
a new AMI based on this server.

73
00:03:54,240 --> 00:03:57,070
It'll basically be a clone of the server.

74
00:03:57,070 --> 00:04:01,940
I can clone it and
then deploy the clone in another zone.

75
00:04:01,940 --> 00:04:06,350
And when I do that, I've effectively moved
it to a new zone, and I can just go and

76
00:04:06,350 --> 00:04:07,950
delete the old one, all right?

77
00:04:07,950 --> 00:04:09,280
So that's exactly what I'm gonna do.

78
00:04:09,280 --> 00:04:13,280
Now before I get started, it's really easy
to get mixed up and confused on this one.

79
00:04:13,280 --> 00:04:19,950
I'm gonna take web02, and I'm gonna
edit its name to change it to -old.

80
00:04:19,950 --> 00:04:22,480
I'm calling it -old so that I can
remember that that's the original.

81
00:04:22,480 --> 00:04:23,370
You can call it whatever you want.

82
00:04:23,370 --> 00:04:26,420
This is just something that I like to do
so I can remember what the heck it was and

83
00:04:26,420 --> 00:04:28,070
not get it mixed up.

84
00:04:28,070 --> 00:04:28,840
All right.

85
00:04:28,840 --> 00:04:31,420
From there, I need to take an image.

86
00:04:31,420 --> 00:04:34,520
Now, when you take an image of it,
you just go up here to Actions, and

87
00:04:34,520 --> 00:04:37,010
you'll see in here Create Image.

88
00:04:37,010 --> 00:04:40,650
An image is made as a snapshot
of the hard drives.

89
00:04:40,650 --> 00:04:45,730
That means it doesn't capture what's in
RAM, and our big issue there is if there's

90
00:04:45,730 --> 00:04:49,687
writes that are in process, if somebody
is writing to the hard drive when I take

91
00:04:49,687 --> 00:04:54,230
an image, if the system is online, that
partial write is now a part of that image,

92
00:04:54,230 --> 00:04:58,370
which means I basically have corrupt data
on my drive right from the beginning.

93
00:04:58,370 --> 00:05:00,690
So this is the downtime
I was talking about.

94
00:05:00,690 --> 00:05:03,580
The server's got to get shut
down while we take the image.

95
00:05:03,580 --> 00:05:07,330
All right, and you'll see that
option in here, this no reboot.

96
00:05:07,330 --> 00:05:09,160
See how it says if we turn this on,

97
00:05:09,160 --> 00:05:12,150
Amazon won't shut the instance
down when it makes the image.

98
00:05:12,150 --> 00:05:16,180
But if you want a consistent image,
you really do need to shut it down.

99
00:05:16,180 --> 00:05:18,220
So I'm definitely not gonna choose that.

100
00:05:18,220 --> 00:05:21,200
And I'm gonna create an image name,
I'll just call it the web02 image.

101
00:05:21,200 --> 00:05:23,370
And I could give it a description,

102
00:05:23,370 --> 00:05:26,660
but I'm not gonna keep this around very
long, so I'm not gonna bother with that.

103
00:05:26,660 --> 00:05:30,460
And then it's cloning all
the settings of the existing machine,

104
00:05:30,460 --> 00:05:31,640
the amount of storage and so on.

105
00:05:31,640 --> 00:05:35,110
If I wanna change it, I could here,
but I'm not interested in changing it.

106
00:05:35,110 --> 00:05:36,980
I just wanna move it over to a new place.

107
00:05:36,980 --> 00:05:41,110
So I'm gonna leave all that alone and
hit Create Image.

108
00:05:41,110 --> 00:05:46,350
Now, it's gonna shut that instance down,
take an image of it,

109
00:05:46,350 --> 00:05:48,360
and then bring the instance back up.

110
00:05:48,360 --> 00:05:52,080
And so if I sit here and refresh my
screen, I should see it go offline.

111
00:05:52,080 --> 00:05:55,610
And I may not see it go offline,
if it takes a snapshot and

112
00:05:55,610 --> 00:05:57,516
builds it off of the snapshot.

113
00:05:57,516 --> 00:06:01,750
Sometimes if you're EBS-backed, it can
use snapshots to do the process, and

114
00:06:01,750 --> 00:06:03,430
you may not see the server go offline.

115
00:06:03,430 --> 00:06:04,750
But it almost always does.

116
00:06:04,750 --> 00:06:07,780
If I'm patient enough,
I'll wait and it will show up.

117
00:06:07,780 --> 00:06:10,520
But if you go down under Snapshots,
you'll actually see it kind of in action.

118
00:06:10,520 --> 00:06:11,375
There's the snapshot.

119
00:06:11,375 --> 00:06:15,745
And so it's actually grabbing a snapshot
of this AMI which is web02, and

120
00:06:15,745 --> 00:06:17,600
it's kind of in process.

121
00:06:17,600 --> 00:06:18,525
See how that one's pending?

122
00:06:18,525 --> 00:06:23,490
And if I go under AMIs,
here I can see where

123
00:06:23,490 --> 00:06:26,878
it's actually building that web02
image right now, all right.

124
00:06:26,878 --> 00:06:28,450
Now it says pending.

125
00:06:28,450 --> 00:06:30,370
It's gotta take that server down.

126
00:06:30,370 --> 00:06:33,980
It's gotta take that snapshot and
then bring the server back up and

127
00:06:33,980 --> 00:06:36,210
then build the image from the snapshot.

128
00:06:36,210 --> 00:06:38,410
And so I just have to wait for
that to happen.

129
00:06:38,410 --> 00:06:43,050
But once it's done,
this AMI will now be a clone of web02.

130
00:06:43,050 --> 00:06:44,880
All the settings,

131
00:06:44,880 --> 00:06:49,480
all the configurations, everything that
was in web02, I've now got a clone.

132
00:06:49,480 --> 00:06:53,360
The nice thing is the original web02
will come back online after this, and

133
00:06:53,360 --> 00:06:56,540
so we may not see much of
an outage at all, right?

134
00:06:56,540 --> 00:06:58,300
That's the downtime that
I was talking about,

135
00:06:58,300 --> 00:07:00,120
the amount of time it takes for
that to happen.

136
00:07:00,120 --> 00:07:02,370
Actually, it looks like
this AMI is already done.

137
00:07:02,370 --> 00:07:06,750
My server was only 8 GB of storage, so
it wasn't much, so it's already done and

138
00:07:06,750 --> 00:07:07,270
available.

139
00:07:07,270 --> 00:07:08,650
I can see the AMI there.

140
00:07:08,650 --> 00:07:13,120
That means my other instance should
be back online and functional, and so

141
00:07:13,120 --> 00:07:15,850
I can jump over to my instances and
just double-check.

142
00:07:15,850 --> 00:07:18,000
Yeah.
Web02 is up.

143
00:07:18,000 --> 00:07:20,625
And did my name change not stay?

144
00:07:20,625 --> 00:07:24,650
[LAUGH] See,
it makes it easy to get them mixed up.

145
00:07:24,650 --> 00:07:28,960
I've got my web02 back online and healthy,
but my name change didn't stick for

146
00:07:28,960 --> 00:07:29,490
some reason.

147
00:07:29,490 --> 00:07:33,790
So I'm gonna re-edit that again just
to make sure I don't make a mistake.

148
00:07:35,930 --> 00:07:36,430
There we go.

149
00:07:37,980 --> 00:07:39,590
Refresh to make sure that changed state.

150
00:07:40,850 --> 00:07:43,485
My name change does not want to stay.

151
00:07:45,550 --> 00:07:46,870
Maybe it doesn't like that hyphen.

152
00:07:48,070 --> 00:07:50,200
Although I use hyphens all the time,
so I don't think that's it.

153
00:07:50,200 --> 00:07:51,610
But, all right, so
we'll put that in there.

154
00:07:51,610 --> 00:07:53,540
So now I've got my image.

155
00:07:53,540 --> 00:07:55,520
The important part is it's a clone.

156
00:07:55,520 --> 00:07:58,400
And I can go down to my AMIs,

157
00:07:58,400 --> 00:08:03,250
I can pick that image that we just took,
and I can hit Launch.

158
00:08:03,250 --> 00:08:06,450
That's going to launch a new
instance built off of this image.

159
00:08:06,450 --> 00:08:10,030
In other words, we're going to
launch a clone of the other AMI.

160
00:08:10,030 --> 00:08:13,370
So, I'll hit Launch, and it's gonna
ask if I want to change the hardware.

161
00:08:13,370 --> 00:08:16,630
I'm going to leave it at
the hardware that it was already at.

162
00:08:16,630 --> 00:08:19,110
If you change the hardware,
that's fine, right.

163
00:08:19,110 --> 00:08:21,440
It will be resilient to that.

164
00:08:21,440 --> 00:08:22,940
It's a good time to upgrade if you want,

165
00:08:22,940 --> 00:08:24,500
but in my case,
I don't want to upgrade the hardware.

166
00:08:24,500 --> 00:08:27,120
I just want to launch it, right?

167
00:08:27,120 --> 00:08:30,310
Now, I could hit Review and Launch,
and it'll give me my summary and

168
00:08:30,310 --> 00:08:33,840
I might need to change some things, but
on mine I do need to change one thing.

169
00:08:33,840 --> 00:08:36,516
I need to change the zone that
this is gonna be launching in, and

170
00:08:36,516 --> 00:08:38,486
if you look at your
different options up here,

171
00:08:38,486 --> 00:08:41,489
you'll see as you go through that
you get to pick where it's gonna be.

172
00:08:41,489 --> 00:08:44,634
So I'm gonna use the little
Next button over here.

173
00:08:44,634 --> 00:08:47,450
Let me resize this window so
my head's not covering it.

174
00:08:47,450 --> 00:08:51,370
So I'm gonna use this Next Configure
button, and we'll run through because

175
00:08:51,370 --> 00:08:54,730
here's where I can pick the instances and
the subnets and so on.

176
00:08:54,730 --> 00:08:57,410
And it's this subnet value
that picks our zone.

177
00:08:57,410 --> 00:08:58,370
All right.
It's kind

178
00:08:58,370 --> 00:09:01,220
of confusing because you think there'll
be a zone drop-down, but there isn't.

179
00:09:01,220 --> 00:09:03,092
It's the subnet, the network.

180
00:09:03,092 --> 00:09:06,083
And when you see that subnet and
drop it down,

181
00:09:06,083 --> 00:09:09,325
see how I've got subnets in 1A,
1C, and 1D?

182
00:09:09,325 --> 00:09:11,517
I can pick between them.

183
00:09:11,517 --> 00:09:14,050
And I wanna move this one to 1D.

184
00:09:14,050 --> 00:09:18,270
That's what's gonna move this
instance to the other zone, to D.

185
00:09:18,270 --> 00:09:20,300
So I'm gonna choose that.

186
00:09:20,300 --> 00:09:23,200
If you're missing a subnet,
you can always hit Create New Subnet and

187
00:09:23,200 --> 00:09:26,020
make one, but for
what I need it was already right there.

188
00:09:26,020 --> 00:09:27,070
I'll choose it.

189
00:09:27,070 --> 00:09:29,000
I'm not really gonna change anything else,
right?

190
00:09:29,000 --> 00:09:30,300
I don't want to modify the server.

191
00:09:30,300 --> 00:09:31,030
I just want to move it.

192
00:09:31,030 --> 00:09:33,770
So that's the value that we want,
is the subnet.

193
00:09:33,770 --> 00:09:36,300
So I'll go ahead and
hit review and launch.

194
00:09:36,300 --> 00:09:38,040
It's asking me if I want
to convert it to SSD.

195
00:09:38,040 --> 00:09:40,265
I'm still using Magnetic on this one.

196
00:09:40,265 --> 00:09:42,970
SSD, for a lot of people,
is about the same price, so

197
00:09:42,970 --> 00:09:46,450
that's why Amazon is pushing it here,
but for me, I'll stick with Magnetic.

198
00:09:48,470 --> 00:09:52,240
And it's warning me about my security
group because it's using that default

199
00:09:52,240 --> 00:09:53,430
security group.

200
00:09:53,430 --> 00:09:56,410
I can change that, though,
to use one of my existing security groups,

201
00:09:56,410 --> 00:09:57,800
and that's what I'll do.

202
00:09:57,800 --> 00:09:59,200
I'm gonna edit that and

203
00:09:59,200 --> 00:10:03,560
switch to a different security group like
my web-host1 cuz that is a web host.

204
00:10:04,590 --> 00:10:05,470
All right.

205
00:10:05,470 --> 00:10:08,420
So now,
wow it's really pushing that SSD isn't it?

206
00:10:08,420 --> 00:10:11,768
So now that should be all I need,
and I can go ahead and hit Launch.

207
00:10:11,768 --> 00:10:14,970
Now it's gonna spin up,
well after I pick my shared keys,

208
00:10:14,970 --> 00:10:16,868
so I'll pick my share key there.

209
00:10:16,868 --> 00:10:21,890
Now it's gonna spin up a new instance
that's effectively a clone of web02.

210
00:10:21,890 --> 00:10:26,260
So I have web02, I've now cloned it,
but this clone will have a different IP

211
00:10:26,260 --> 00:10:29,840
address, right, a different IP address so
they're not gonna bump into each other.

212
00:10:29,840 --> 00:10:31,700
I don't have to sweat that, right.

213
00:10:31,700 --> 00:10:34,250
But what we do is we let it come up, and

214
00:10:34,250 --> 00:10:38,320
once it's up, if you have an elastic IP,
you can do this seamlessly.

215
00:10:38,320 --> 00:10:42,230
If you have an elastic IP,
you can just move the public IP

216
00:10:42,230 --> 00:10:46,690
from the old node to the new node and
you're done, right?

217
00:10:46,690 --> 00:10:47,980
Very straightforward.

218
00:10:47,980 --> 00:10:52,010
If you're using the Amazon dynamic IPs,
then you'll probably need to go and

219
00:10:52,010 --> 00:10:55,200
update whatever CNAME you've got
that points to that server in DNS,

220
00:10:55,200 --> 00:10:57,080
so it's a little bit trickier.

221
00:10:57,080 --> 00:10:59,320
But if you've got elastic IDs,
that's why they call them elastic,

222
00:10:59,320 --> 00:11:02,720
we can move them between zones,
and it'll tackle that for us.

223
00:11:03,790 --> 00:11:05,380
All right, so
it's launching that right now.

224
00:11:05,380 --> 00:11:12,140
I'm gonna go back to my instances,
and I've got my old web02 there.

225
00:11:12,140 --> 00:11:13,650
Finally, my name change kicked in.

226
00:11:13,650 --> 00:11:16,100
So there's my old web02 right there,

227
00:11:16,100 --> 00:11:19,150
and I'm gonna go ahead and
edit this one to call it web02.

228
00:11:19,150 --> 00:11:24,817
This is my new web02, and
my new web02 is right there in us-east 1d.

229
00:11:24,817 --> 00:11:27,600
I've moved it to the other zone.

230
00:11:27,600 --> 00:11:31,030
But I'm not done yet because this new
server, sure it's an exact clone,

231
00:11:31,030 --> 00:11:33,390
it's got the exact software,
the exact same configuration,

232
00:11:33,390 --> 00:11:38,180
it's exactly like the old one, except
it's gonna have a different IP address.

233
00:11:38,180 --> 00:11:40,870
Amazon doesn't want you to have
duplicate IPs, so they change it.

234
00:11:40,870 --> 00:11:44,360
So my next step is gonna
be to move that elastic IP.

235
00:11:44,360 --> 00:11:47,445
So I'll go down here to my elastic IPs,
and

236
00:11:47,445 --> 00:11:52,847
I'll find the one attached to web02 old,
and I'm gonna take that one and

237
00:11:52,847 --> 00:11:57,479
I'm gonna disassociate it with web02 or
with old web02, so

238
00:11:57,479 --> 00:12:02,456
it's gonna disassociate, and
then I'm gonna re-associate it and

239
00:12:02,456 --> 00:12:05,890
attach it to the new web02 and, oh shoot.

240
00:12:05,890 --> 00:12:08,200
The new web02's not showing up yet, and

241
00:12:08,200 --> 00:12:11,380
the main reason it's not showing
up is it's still spinning up.

242
00:12:11,380 --> 00:12:12,590
It hasn't finished.

243
00:12:12,590 --> 00:12:14,300
So if I go back, so I jumped the gun.

244
00:12:14,300 --> 00:12:17,730
I shouldn't have removed that until I
knew that instance was up and healthy.

245
00:12:17,730 --> 00:12:22,040
If we go back up here to our Instances,
this is my new web02 right here.

246
00:12:22,040 --> 00:12:25,420
See how it still says initializing
on the Status Checks?

247
00:12:25,420 --> 00:12:26,980
I've got to wait until it's healthy, and

248
00:12:26,980 --> 00:12:29,880
then I'll be able to move
the IPs over to it, all right.

249
00:12:29,880 --> 00:12:34,140
Now if I'm worried about down time I
need to wait until it goes healthy and

250
00:12:34,140 --> 00:12:35,670
then move the IP.

251
00:12:35,670 --> 00:12:38,740
In my case, I'm not really worried about
it because users aren't hitting this.

252
00:12:38,740 --> 00:12:42,750
I'm using load balancing, and web02 has
been pulled out of the load balance pool.

253
00:12:42,750 --> 00:12:45,350
So I'm not really worried about
the downtime on this one, so I can go and

254
00:12:45,350 --> 00:12:47,690
start to do some of my other
work while I'm waiting.

255
00:12:47,690 --> 00:12:50,780
This one is initializing, but
I can go and clean up my mess.

256
00:12:50,780 --> 00:12:51,894
I've got that AMI.

257
00:12:51,894 --> 00:12:54,925
I don't need the AMI anymore,
so I can remove it.

258
00:12:54,925 --> 00:12:58,805
I can just go and right-click on it and
choose Deregister, and

259
00:12:58,805 --> 00:13:00,175
that'll get rid of that AMI.

260
00:13:00,175 --> 00:13:01,535
I don't wanna keep it around.

261
00:13:01,535 --> 00:13:03,335
I'm not gonna make more web02s.

262
00:13:03,335 --> 00:13:04,805
I just needed to get rid of this one.

263
00:13:06,095 --> 00:13:08,603
Now, if it does what mine just did,
see how it's still there?

264
00:13:08,603 --> 00:13:10,820
If I hit Refresh, it's still there.

265
00:13:10,820 --> 00:13:13,510
That means that there’s something
dependent on it, something attached.

266
00:13:13,510 --> 00:13:14,890
I forgot about my snapshot.

267
00:13:14,890 --> 00:13:19,150
If I go down to my Snapshots, there’s the
snapshot it made during that process, and

268
00:13:19,150 --> 00:13:21,621
I need to get rid of that snapshot,
so I’ll delete it.

269
00:13:21,621 --> 00:13:23,340
All right.

270
00:13:23,340 --> 00:13:29,120
Now the snapshot’s gone, I can go back
to my AMIs, and it’s still there.

271
00:13:29,120 --> 00:13:30,410
Sometimes it’ll go away on its own.

272
00:13:30,410 --> 00:13:31,880
Sometimes you have to deregister it again.

273
00:13:31,880 --> 00:13:36,000
So I’ll do another deregister,
and oh, I got an error, good.

274
00:13:36,000 --> 00:13:38,845
So I'm getting an error here just
letting me know that it had a problem

275
00:13:38,845 --> 00:13:42,170
deregistering, and that usually means
that it's already deregistered.

276
00:13:42,170 --> 00:13:45,100
So if I just wait,
it'll disappear on its own eventually.

277
00:13:46,290 --> 00:13:49,830
All right, so now,
once my instance is healthy,

278
00:13:49,830 --> 00:13:53,582
which is apparently taking a while,
we'll be able to move that IP over.

279
00:13:53,582 --> 00:13:54,410
All right.

280
00:13:54,410 --> 00:13:57,670
So web02 old won't be necessary anymore.

281
00:13:57,670 --> 00:14:01,840
And I've already unassociated the address,
so I can take web02 and just delete it.

282
00:14:01,840 --> 00:14:03,580
I don't need it anymore.

283
00:14:03,580 --> 00:14:05,000
So I'll terminate that instance.

284
00:14:06,140 --> 00:14:07,030
All right.

285
00:14:07,030 --> 00:14:08,140
And I'm gonna go ahead and
say Yes to that.

286
00:14:08,140 --> 00:14:09,980
So that's gonna terminate the old web02.

287
00:14:09,980 --> 00:14:14,850
And the last thing I need to do is attach
web02, the new web02's IP address.

288
00:14:14,850 --> 00:14:19,920
And if I'm doing a load balancing pool, I
can just add that back to the pool, or if

289
00:14:19,920 --> 00:14:24,250
I'm doing something else, you know I can
just go in and start to use that system.

290
00:14:24,250 --> 00:14:26,270
So we'll see if it'll let me assign this.

291
00:14:26,270 --> 00:14:29,370
I don't wanna sit here and
just wait for this last IP assignment.

292
00:14:29,370 --> 00:14:31,750
You guys at this point have
probably seen elastic IPs enough.

293
00:14:33,180 --> 00:14:37,520
But we'll try and associate that just so
we can be complete.

294
00:14:37,520 --> 00:14:38,310
And there's web02.

295
00:14:38,310 --> 00:14:41,790
So I'm gonna go ahead and assign that.

296
00:14:41,790 --> 00:14:42,996
And I'll associate it.

297
00:14:45,515 --> 00:14:46,480
All right.

298
00:14:46,480 --> 00:14:47,758
So now it's associated with web02.

299
00:14:47,758 --> 00:14:51,240
I can double-check just to make
sure I didn't make a mistake and

300
00:14:51,240 --> 00:14:55,535
go back into Instances and
just make sure that the new

301
00:14:55,535 --> 00:15:00,300
web02 actually has that IP, and I could
see that it's a clickable link there, so

302
00:15:00,300 --> 00:15:02,020
yeah, I do know that
I've got the right IP.

303
00:15:02,020 --> 00:15:07,160
So now, web02 is up and
operating in this new zone, and off I go.

304
00:15:07,160 --> 00:15:10,360
So a little bit of downtime, but
it didn't take very long, right?

305
00:15:10,360 --> 00:15:14,250
Maybe ten minutes to do that move,
and now we're in a new zone.

306
00:15:14,250 --> 00:15:15,560
Like I mentioned in
the beginning of the segment,

307
00:15:15,560 --> 00:15:18,920
you could use third-party software, and
it kind of automates this process and

308
00:15:18,920 --> 00:15:21,730
ensures that it all kind of steps
through without your interaction.

309
00:15:21,730 --> 00:15:24,070
That's the benefit of
software packages like that.

310
00:15:24,070 --> 00:15:26,100
But you don't need third-party
software to do it.

311
00:15:26,100 --> 00:15:26,900
You can do it yourself here.

312
00:15:26,900 --> 00:15:28,750
You can even do it through the API, so

313
00:15:28,750 --> 00:15:32,070
if you want to schedule this to be
automated, you can do it that way, too.

314
00:15:32,070 --> 00:15:34,860
But now that it's done, I can go and
start to do really cool stuff.

315
00:15:34,860 --> 00:15:38,820
Right like throw in this extra zone
into my load balancer and all that and

316
00:15:38,820 --> 00:15:40,380
start to improve that performance.

317
00:15:40,380 --> 00:15:43,936
So those are the things we can
do when we move our images or

318
00:15:43,936 --> 00:15:46,002
instances in-between zones.

319
00:15:46,002 --> 00:15:49,360
All right, so in this segment
we got a change to see that,

320
00:15:49,360 --> 00:15:53,910
how to take an instance and image it,
redeploy it to a new zone, and

321
00:15:53,910 --> 00:15:56,860
wipe out the original image, and
do it with as little downtime as possible,

322
00:15:56,860 --> 00:16:00,240
as we go and correct, I shouldn't say
correct, it may not have been a bad

323
00:16:00,240 --> 00:16:03,110
decision before it may have been
a perfectly fine decision before, but

324
00:16:03,110 --> 00:16:05,440
just something we need to change now,
all right.

325
00:16:05,440 --> 00:16:07,880
So not too terrible of a process.

326
00:16:07,880 --> 00:16:09,600
All right,
I hope you guys enjoyed this segment.

327
00:16:09,600 --> 00:16:12,360
Stay tuned, we've got more
Amazon web services coming up.

episodes.title: DNS With Route 53
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,063 --> 00:00:04,962
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:07,666 --> 00:00:11,440
In this segment, we're gonna take
a look at the Route 53 service.

3
00:00:11,440 --> 00:00:14,020
It's a part of Amazon Web Services.

4
00:00:14,020 --> 00:00:17,670
Route 53 is AWS's hosted DNS service.

5
00:00:17,670 --> 00:00:21,120
So, if you have DNS zones,
you've got to host them somewhere.

6
00:00:21,120 --> 00:00:23,290
Might as well host them with Amazon,
right?

7
00:00:23,290 --> 00:00:27,160
Well, I know that sounds kind of silly,
like, if we've already got DNS servers out

8
00:00:27,160 --> 00:00:29,890
there with some registrar,
why not leave them there?

9
00:00:29,890 --> 00:00:31,940
And for most people,
that's perfectly fine.

10
00:00:31,940 --> 00:00:36,500
Whatever registrar you're using is more
than likely got redundant DNS servers,

11
00:00:36,500 --> 00:00:38,010
have them geolocated, and

12
00:00:38,010 --> 00:00:42,000
all of that, to provide the best
lookup capabilities possible.

13
00:00:42,000 --> 00:00:46,090
But what you'll find is that a lot
of DNS providers that are out there,

14
00:00:46,090 --> 00:00:50,260
a lot of registrars have limits
to what you can configure.

15
00:00:50,260 --> 00:00:53,700
A great example would be
like the ITProTV.net domain.

16
00:00:53,700 --> 00:00:55,255
I've been using this whole series.

17
00:00:55,255 --> 00:01:01,370
ITProTV.net, I registered that with
a company called Hover, hover.com.

18
00:01:01,370 --> 00:01:02,620
And they're a great company.

19
00:01:02,620 --> 00:01:06,840
I really like to do business with them,
but they don't let you do subdomains.

20
00:01:06,840 --> 00:01:09,470
And, they don't let you
adjust your time to live.

21
00:01:09,470 --> 00:01:12,310
Those are limits to
what you can configure.

22
00:01:12,310 --> 00:01:13,770
Subdomains are a big part.

23
00:01:13,770 --> 00:01:17,610
A lot of the big providers like
GoDaddy won't let you do subdomains.

24
00:01:17,610 --> 00:01:20,480
If you wanna do subdomains,
you've gotta set up your own DNS servers.

25
00:01:20,480 --> 00:01:25,300
If you're setting up your own DNS servers,
now you gotta worry about redundancy.

26
00:01:25,300 --> 00:01:27,140
What if your DNS server fails?

27
00:01:27,140 --> 00:01:31,060
All of a sudden,
access to all of your services is gone.

28
00:01:31,060 --> 00:01:33,330
People can't look up the IP to get there.

29
00:01:33,330 --> 00:01:34,280
The servers might be up and

30
00:01:34,280 --> 00:01:38,340
happy, but people can't get to them
because the name is not resolving.

31
00:01:38,340 --> 00:01:39,980
Route 53 solves that.

32
00:01:39,980 --> 00:01:46,310
You can take your DNS domain and
host it right in Amazon's DNS servers.

33
00:01:46,310 --> 00:01:48,790
If Amazon goes down, well,
your servers are down there too.

34
00:01:48,790 --> 00:01:51,290
So, it doesn't necessarily
matter at that point.

35
00:01:51,290 --> 00:01:55,740
But they've got a highly redundant
multiple GO located system

36
00:01:55,740 --> 00:01:59,320
with DNS servers all over the planet
to be able to make your systems

37
00:01:59,320 --> 00:02:00,590
as redundant as possible.

38
00:02:00,590 --> 00:02:04,910
And we'll see there's actually some neat
integrations that we get too by having

39
00:02:04,910 --> 00:02:07,910
the domain hosted on Amazon services.

40
00:02:07,910 --> 00:02:11,110
There's a few little bells and
whistles that we get out of it.

41
00:02:11,110 --> 00:02:11,880
Let's take a look.

42
00:02:13,010 --> 00:02:16,220
I'm just jumping over here to my
Amazon web services console, and

43
00:02:16,220 --> 00:02:20,310
in the console right here under Compute
and Networking, we'll see Route 53.

44
00:02:20,310 --> 00:02:22,880
It's one of the few ones
we haven't used yet.

45
00:02:22,880 --> 00:02:26,940
When you go into Route 53, this is
the scalable domain name system is their

46
00:02:26,940 --> 00:02:30,870
highly redundant and
very efficient domain naming system.

47
00:02:30,870 --> 00:02:32,700
Now, if you already have a zone,

48
00:02:32,700 --> 00:02:34,820
when you'll log in here you'll
see something different.

49
00:02:34,820 --> 00:02:38,180
But when you're just getting started,
you get the welcome screen.

50
00:02:38,180 --> 00:02:42,540
And what most of us will wanna do is hit
this DNS management to get started now.

51
00:02:42,540 --> 00:02:43,600
All right.

52
00:02:43,600 --> 00:02:47,020
That's where we jump in and
we start to create our DNS zones.

53
00:02:47,020 --> 00:02:50,740
But if you don't have a domain yet,
maybe you wanna buy a domain.

54
00:02:50,740 --> 00:02:52,420
You can actually buy
the domain from Amazon.

55
00:02:52,420 --> 00:02:54,490
You just have to scroll down a bit and
it's down here.

56
00:02:54,490 --> 00:02:57,750
You can do domain registration and
you can purchase a domain.

57
00:02:57,750 --> 00:03:00,860
They actually resell for
a couple of other registrars, and

58
00:03:00,860 --> 00:03:02,190
you can buy it right there.

59
00:03:02,190 --> 00:03:04,540
Well, I've already got a domain,
itprotv.net.

60
00:03:04,540 --> 00:03:06,730
I wanna host that right here.

61
00:03:06,730 --> 00:03:11,250
So up top, I'm just gonna go here to
getting started for DNS management.

62
00:03:11,250 --> 00:03:14,950
And that's gonna take us into
the actual administration tool.

63
00:03:14,950 --> 00:03:16,100
If you already had a zone,

64
00:03:16,100 --> 00:03:19,090
this is what you would have gotten
when you first clicked on Route 53.

65
00:03:19,090 --> 00:03:22,550
And what I'm looking at
here are my hosted zones.

66
00:03:22,550 --> 00:03:24,370
What zones am I hosting?

67
00:03:24,370 --> 00:03:29,400
When you have a domain name
like itprotv.net or google.com,

68
00:03:29,400 --> 00:03:34,540
those are domain names and
they're hosted on what's called a Zone.

69
00:03:34,540 --> 00:03:35,810
Zones are redundant.

70
00:03:35,810 --> 00:03:40,250
They can be replicated across multiple
DNS servers by doing zone transfers.

71
00:03:40,250 --> 00:03:41,750
That's how we get redundancy.

72
00:03:41,750 --> 00:03:44,310
So the DNS terminology's
a little bit weird.

73
00:03:44,310 --> 00:03:47,270
A zone usually corresponds
to a domain name.

74
00:03:47,270 --> 00:03:50,520
But a zone coul correspond
to a subdomain name.

75
00:03:50,520 --> 00:03:55,550
I might have a development..ITProTV.net,
right?

76
00:03:55,550 --> 00:03:57,510
It's not the parent domain,
it's a child of it.

77
00:03:57,510 --> 00:03:59,920
It's a sub.
And then, this other host underneath that.

78
00:03:59,920 --> 00:04:03,070
So I might have a zone just for
that subdomain.

79
00:04:03,070 --> 00:04:04,920
I can come in here and create it.

80
00:04:04,920 --> 00:04:05,650
All right.

81
00:04:05,650 --> 00:04:10,270
So I'll go ahead and choose to create that
hosted zone, and we're gonna even specify.

82
00:04:10,270 --> 00:04:13,550
Now I don't know why it does this to me,
but every time I hit that created zone,

83
00:04:13,550 --> 00:04:15,370
it changes the screen and
then it just sits there.

84
00:04:15,370 --> 00:04:17,690
I always have to click on it twice.

85
00:04:17,690 --> 00:04:21,580
That may just be me, but
if it happens to you, just expect it, and

86
00:04:21,580 --> 00:04:23,020
click on it a second time.

87
00:04:23,020 --> 00:04:26,040
And you'll get this box over here
where you can create the zone.

88
00:04:26,040 --> 00:04:28,540
I'm gonna put in the name and
we'll do itprotv.net.

89
00:04:28,540 --> 00:04:29,690
All right.

90
00:04:29,690 --> 00:04:31,110
So, I'll just punch that in there.

91
00:04:31,110 --> 00:04:34,100
You can give a comment if you
want to remember what it is, or

92
00:04:34,100 --> 00:04:37,240
what we're doing, and then you can hit
the Create button down at the bottom.

93
00:04:38,660 --> 00:04:40,390
All right.
Once it's created, we're done,

94
00:04:40,390 --> 00:04:41,810
we walk away, right.

95
00:04:41,810 --> 00:04:43,210
Well, not quite.

96
00:04:43,210 --> 00:04:45,350
The zone that it creates is empty.

97
00:04:46,380 --> 00:04:51,060
Inside of DNS, there's really only
two records you have to have.

98
00:04:51,060 --> 00:04:55,130
There's what's called a Start
of Authority and a Name Server.

99
00:04:55,130 --> 00:04:58,780
The start of authority is who's
in charge of that domain,

100
00:04:58,780 --> 00:05:01,640
who is it that's responsible for
it, and well, it's us.

101
00:05:01,640 --> 00:05:03,120
Well, it's Amazon now.

102
00:05:03,120 --> 00:05:05,110
They're the ones responsible for

just regular HTTP and

329
00:17:08,490 --> 00:17:11,790
now I could even request
a particular web page.

330
00:17:11,790 --> 00:17:13,060
That's pretty slick.

331
00:17:13,060 --> 00:17:15,460
It'll try and connect to that server and
pull its webpage.

332
00:17:15,460 --> 00:17:19,190
And if it doesn't get the page,
then it'll assume the health check failed,

333
00:17:19,190 --> 00:17:20,680
and it'll send me an alert.

334
00:17:20,680 --> 00:17:23,560
It'll let me know, it's monitoring
that and keeping an eye on it.

335
00:17:23,560 --> 00:17:25,710
So, pretty neat functionality.

336
00:17:25,710 --> 00:17:28,850
Notice that by default,
it only monitors every 30 seconds.

337
00:17:28,850 --> 00:17:30,820
You can change it to ten seconds and
that's it.

338
00:17:30,820 --> 00:17:32,550
You don't get anything more advanced.

339
00:17:32,550 --> 00:17:34,140
If you wan to go more advanced than that,

340
00:17:34,140 --> 00:17:37,400
you can set up Cloud Watch to
do a lot of advanced monitoring.

341
00:17:37,400 --> 00:17:40,831
But, these right here, 10 seconds and 30
seconds are usually more than enough for

342
00:17:40,831 --> 00:17:41,403
most people.

343
00:17:44,923 --> 00:17:48,610
All right, some of the other things,
well, we've got our domain review.

344
00:17:48,610 --> 00:17:51,490
We can come in here and see domains
that we've purchased from Amazon.

345
00:17:51,490 --> 00:17:55,490
So, if I register a domain, that's where
I can see it if I bought it from them.

346
00:17:55,490 --> 00:17:57,690
If I have my own, though, somewhere else.

347
00:17:57,690 --> 00:18:00,960
So, I mentioned my domain is hosted
with hover.com right now, right?

348
00:18:00,960 --> 00:18:03,370
If I wanna move it here,
this is where I'd do it.

349
00:18:03,370 --> 00:18:07,300
I'd go to Transfer Domain and
I can start the transfer process.

350
00:18:07,300 --> 00:18:10,720
Be aware that domain
transfers are not fast.

351
00:18:10,720 --> 00:18:14,750
Domain transfers can take four
to seven days to take effect.

352
00:18:14,750 --> 00:18:17,960
So, how do you prevent downtime
in the middle of that?

353
00:18:17,960 --> 00:18:21,010
Well, the steps you should follow
if you’re gonna transfer a domain,

354
00:18:21,010 --> 00:18:24,490
step one, recreate your records.

355
00:18:24,490 --> 00:18:28,790
You need to get the zone
here in Route 53 identical

356
00:18:28,790 --> 00:18:30,960
to your zone on the other provider.

357
00:18:30,960 --> 00:18:36,400
So if you can, you can go to Hosted Zones
and pull up that zone that you made.

358
00:18:36,400 --> 00:18:39,770
And once you go into its record sets,
if you've got it,

359
00:18:39,770 --> 00:18:41,850
you can import that zone file.

360
00:18:41,850 --> 00:18:45,450
Import it, bring it in, get that in place.

361
00:18:45,450 --> 00:18:47,970
If you don't,
then manually create the records.

362
00:18:47,970 --> 00:18:50,430
Make it identical to
your current provider.

363
00:18:50,430 --> 00:18:52,270
The rest of the world's
not gonna see this yet,

364
00:18:52,270 --> 00:18:53,700
they're still seeing
your current provider.

365
00:18:54,870 --> 00:18:57,110
Then, initiate the transfer.

366
00:18:57,110 --> 00:18:59,460
To initiate the transfer, you'll probably
have to call your current provider.

367
00:18:59,460 --> 00:19:02,830
They usually lock the domains
to stop inadvertent transfers.

368
00:19:02,830 --> 00:19:05,400
And so you just have to tell
them to unlock the domain.

369
00:19:05,400 --> 00:19:08,160
And when that's done, you can come here.

370
00:19:08,160 --> 00:19:11,650
Go under Domains, and
go to Transfer the Domain.

371
00:19:11,650 --> 00:19:13,960
And you'll specify what the domain
is you're gonna transfer.

372
00:19:13,960 --> 00:19:18,490
And they charge for that, they charge $12
for a .com and some various other pricing.

373
00:19:18,490 --> 00:19:20,140
But basically you specify that.

374
00:19:20,140 --> 00:19:22,190
They're gonna check to see
whether it's unlocked.

375
00:19:22,190 --> 00:19:23,670
So if I take ITProTV.

376
00:19:27,710 --> 00:19:30,874
Oh, the extension's over
here ao I need .net.

377
00:19:30,874 --> 00:19:34,560
So itprotv.net, if I check that
it's gonna look it up right now.

378
00:19:34,560 --> 00:19:36,220
It's gonna find it on hover, and

379
00:19:36,220 --> 00:19:39,340
it's gonna see that it cannot be
transferred because it's locked.

380
00:19:39,340 --> 00:19:42,110
So, I'm need to go to hover and
unlock it and then come back and

381
00:19:42,110 --> 00:19:43,370
do this check again.

382
00:19:43,370 --> 00:19:45,780
And once I do the check,
it'll show it as unlocked and

383
00:19:45,780 --> 00:19:48,030
then I can initiate the transfer.

384
00:19:48,030 --> 00:19:52,100
It'll send an email to whoever the
administrative contact is that's listed

385
00:19:52,100 --> 00:19:53,740
for that DNS zone.

386
00:19:53,740 --> 00:19:55,860
That person will have to
click on that to activate it,

387
00:19:55,860 --> 00:19:59,360
and that'll approve the transfer and
it'll move through.

388
00:19:59,360 --> 00:20:04,770
And sometime in the next four to seven
days, That zone will now be hosted here.

389
00:20:04,770 --> 00:20:07,950
But it doesn't really matter when it
happens, because your zones are identical.

390
00:20:07,950 --> 00:20:09,920
The zone that you have in
production right now and

391
00:20:09,920 --> 00:20:11,230
the zone you created here are identical.

392
00:20:11,230 --> 00:20:13,570
You've matched up the records, all right?

393
00:20:13,570 --> 00:20:16,730
So whenever that flip over happens,
people are still getting the same values.

394
00:20:16,730 --> 00:20:18,810
And from there, you can go and

395
00:20:18,810 --> 00:20:23,220
start to customize the zone to take
advantage of the things that Amazon has.

396
00:20:23,220 --> 00:20:26,290
Don't put all the fancy bells and
whistles in place on day 1, right?

397
00:20:26,290 --> 00:20:29,860
Start off with just a mirror of
your current environment, and

398
00:20:29,860 --> 00:20:32,940
then enhance it after
the transfer is done.

399
00:20:32,940 --> 00:20:35,732
You don't want to run into
a situation where DNS is failing,

400
00:20:35,732 --> 00:20:38,086
and you don't know if
the transfer is the problem or

401
00:20:38,086 --> 00:20:41,393
your new settings are the problem,
so take it easy, take it in stages.

402
00:20:41,393 --> 00:20:44,104
DNS issues,
if you mess up your DNS domain name,

403
00:20:44,104 --> 00:20:47,840
that can create outages that
can take up to two days to fix.

404
00:20:47,840 --> 00:20:51,530
A lot of DNS servers out there
can cache DNS entries, and

405
00:20:51,530 --> 00:20:53,850
48 hours is usually the maximum.

406
00:20:53,850 --> 00:20:56,450
So, there could be bad entries cached for

407
00:20:56,450 --> 00:20:59,300
your zone up to 48 hours
if you make a mistake.

408
00:20:59,300 --> 00:21:00,660
So take it easy.

409
00:21:00,660 --> 00:21:02,590
Go through and double-check your work.

410
00:21:02,590 --> 00:21:05,870
And then get it all set,
moving in little stages, right?

411
00:21:05,870 --> 00:21:10,760
Duplicate the zone, do the transfer, and
then implement the advanced features.

412
00:21:12,220 --> 00:21:12,860
All right.

413
00:21:12,860 --> 00:21:14,559
So, that's the basic process right there,

414
00:21:14,559 --> 00:21:16,268
those are the things
that we have available.

415
00:21:16,268 --> 00:21:19,269
When it's all set up, you have a little
dashboard where you can monitor

416
00:21:19,269 --> 00:21:22,820
your current health checks, the amount of
domains that are actually hosted here and

417
00:21:22,820 --> 00:21:24,340
the hosted zones that you've got.

418
00:21:24,340 --> 00:21:27,170
And you can see their health and
other alerts.

419
00:21:27,170 --> 00:21:30,710
It's one of the simpler services,
but very powerful and very useful.

420
00:21:31,792 --> 00:21:36,440
All right, in this segment, we got
a chance to take a look at Route 53,

421
00:21:36,440 --> 00:21:43,040
the redundant and extremely customizable
DNS service from Amazon Web Services.

422
00:21:43,040 --> 00:21:45,010
I hope you guys enjoyed the segment.

423
00:21:45,010 --> 00:21:46,410
If you did, stay tuned.

424
00:21:46,410 --> 00:21:49,640
We've got more Amazon Web Services
content coming up.

episodes.title: Databases With RDS
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:08,113
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:08,113 --> 00:00:09,107
In this segment,

3
00:00:09,107 --> 00:00:13,940
we're gonna to take a look at the RDS
service as a part of Amazon web Services.

4
00:00:13,940 --> 00:00:18,510
RDS is the managed relational database
service from Amazon, and what it does is

5
00:00:18,510 --> 00:00:23,750
it gives us the opportunity to store our
databases in a fully managed environment.

6
00:00:23,750 --> 00:00:25,820
Now what do I mean by that?

7
00:00:25,820 --> 00:00:29,210
Well more and more we're seeing
applications go web based and

8
00:00:29,210 --> 00:00:34,010
web based applications almost always
depend on a database of some sort.

9
00:00:34,010 --> 00:00:38,100
It might be Microsoft SQL it might
be Oracle, it might be my SQL,

10
00:00:38,100 --> 00:00:39,200
we don't know right?

11
00:00:39,200 --> 00:00:42,090
There's various databases
that could be in use.

12
00:00:42,090 --> 00:00:46,660
And as you deploy these web apps you
may not be an expert on that database.

13
00:00:46,660 --> 00:00:51,550
You might know enough to get it set up and
fired up, but the routine day to day

14
00:00:51,550 --> 00:00:56,475
maintenance of it, the things you need
to do to keep that server healthy, may

15
00:00:56,475 --> 00:01:00,415
not be things that you know, or may not
be things that you just have time to do.

16
00:01:00,415 --> 00:01:03,875
A lot of us don't have time to mess around
with maintaining our databases because we

17
00:01:03,875 --> 00:01:06,835
wanna focus on the things that
make our company important,

18
00:01:06,835 --> 00:01:10,981
our web UI, our actual user experience,
and that sort of information.

19
00:01:10,981 --> 00:01:16,980
So, with RDS,what you do is you give
all that mundane labor over to Amazon.

20
00:01:16,980 --> 00:01:21,060
And you say, hey, I need a database,
can you manage the server for me?

21
00:01:21,060 --> 00:01:24,590
Can you do the updates for the server and
updates for my database software?

22
00:01:24,590 --> 00:01:27,120
Can you manage the backups so
that it's backed up and

23
00:01:27,120 --> 00:01:29,030
I can easily recover if I need to?

24
00:01:29,030 --> 00:01:30,570
And oh yeah, I want redundancy.

25
00:01:30,570 --> 00:01:32,180
I wanna have this in more than one zone.

26
00:01:32,180 --> 00:01:35,460
Can you take care of setting that up
cuz I hate dealing with replication.

27
00:01:35,460 --> 00:01:37,490
That's what RDS does.

28
00:01:37,490 --> 00:01:41,570
RDS lets you quickly spin
up a database server and

29
00:01:41,570 --> 00:01:45,600
you configure the database,
Amazon takes care of the rest.

30
00:01:45,600 --> 00:01:50,530
They build the server, they manage
the database engine itself, the software.

31
00:01:50,530 --> 00:01:55,290
They do the tuning and optimization, they
back that up, they keep it stable, and

32
00:01:55,290 --> 00:01:58,580
they keep it redundant, and
you don't have to worry about it.

33
00:01:58,580 --> 00:02:01,980
You get to focus on the areas of your
software that are important, all right?

34
00:02:01,980 --> 00:02:03,410
Now it does come at a cost.

35
00:02:03,410 --> 00:02:04,320
When you sign up for RDS,

36
00:02:04,320 --> 00:02:08,610
what you're really doing is on the back
end you're spinning up EC2 instances,

37
00:02:08,610 --> 00:02:13,610
fully managed EC2 instances, so
you don't see that, but it's still there.

38
00:02:13,610 --> 00:02:15,590
So you're paying for that EC2 instance.

39
00:02:15,590 --> 00:02:18,750
You could've just as well brought
up your own EC2 instance and

40
00:02:18,750 --> 00:02:19,960
ran your own database software.

41
00:02:19,960 --> 00:02:23,220
You can do that, but
then you've got to manage it.

42
00:02:23,220 --> 00:02:27,050
Here you pay for the instance and
then you pay a little extra for

43
00:02:27,050 --> 00:02:28,360
the management piece.

44
00:02:28,360 --> 00:02:31,360
Now it's not much and
in my opinion it's absolutely worth it,

45
00:02:31,360 --> 00:02:34,210
because if your database fails or
if your database goes offline,

46
00:02:34,210 --> 00:02:38,340
your whole product goes offline,
and that is a big deal, right?

47
00:02:38,340 --> 00:02:42,230
So the more stable we can make our
databases, the better, and RDS helps, and

48
00:02:42,230 --> 00:02:44,160
if you're doing multi-zone or

49
00:02:44,160 --> 00:02:48,950
even multi-region redundancy with your
database, that is very challenging

50
00:02:48,950 --> 00:02:53,070
to set up, and having them take care
of that piece for you, it's worth it.

51
00:02:53,070 --> 00:02:55,930
All right, so
let's take a look at that process.

52
00:02:55,930 --> 00:03:00,440
All right, I'm logged into my Amazon
Web Services console right here, and

53
00:03:00,440 --> 00:03:02,320
I'm just gonna scroll down under Database.

54
00:03:02,320 --> 00:03:05,110
Now you'll see there's a few different
database products they have,

55
00:03:05,110 --> 00:03:06,600
like DynamoDB.

56
00:03:06,600 --> 00:03:10,170
If you need a no-SQL database
that's the way to go.

57
00:03:10,170 --> 00:03:14,060
DynamoDB, that's their big one, but
RDS is what we're talking about,

58
00:03:14,060 --> 00:03:16,310
relational databases.

59
00:03:16,310 --> 00:03:19,400
And when we go in there,
we can see our little welcome screen,

60
00:03:19,400 --> 00:03:22,600
which I'll just ignore, and
I'll just go over here to instances.

61
00:03:22,600 --> 00:03:24,690
I mentioned that when
we launch a database,

62
00:03:24,690 --> 00:03:27,575
it's really launching an EC2 instance on
the background that just happens to be

63
00:03:27,575 --> 00:03:29,730
pre-configured with all
our database software.

64
00:03:29,730 --> 00:03:33,810
So that's what we see here,
we're launching a database instance.

65
00:03:33,810 --> 00:03:37,350
Now, when we do it we're gonna see
the database and we can just connect and

66
00:03:37,350 --> 00:03:41,210
work with it directly and completely
ignore the underlying operating system.

67
00:03:41,210 --> 00:03:44,670
Or, if you really want to you
can give into the instance and

68
00:03:44,670 --> 00:03:46,680
you can start to customize things.

69
00:03:46,680 --> 00:03:51,560
But, Amazon's support for you starts to
dwindle with each change that you make,

70
00:03:51,560 --> 00:03:53,600
so typically you want to rely on them.

71
00:03:53,600 --> 00:03:56,730
And their support team is really good
about it, you can reach out to them and

72
00:03:56,730 --> 00:03:58,520
they help you with all sorts of things.

73
00:03:58,520 --> 00:03:59,350
All right.

74
00:03:59,350 --> 00:04:05,060
Just like EC2 you have undemanding
instances and reserved instances.

75
00:04:05,060 --> 00:04:09,170
Reserved instances, if you know you're
going to need this database 24/7,

76
00:04:09,170 --> 00:04:13,285
365 days a year, you can save
a lot of money by going reserved.

77
00:04:13,285 --> 00:04:16,645
But if you do on demand the cost
is a little bit higher and

78
00:04:16,645 --> 00:04:20,245
you just, run it when you need it and
take it offline when you don't need it.

79
00:04:20,245 --> 00:04:24,145
But due to the nature of databases, that's
not normally something we deal with right?

80
00:04:24,145 --> 00:04:26,255
We normally need it all the time.

81
00:04:26,255 --> 00:04:29,930
So, just reserved instances
are a great way to go about that.

82
00:04:29,930 --> 00:04:32,800
You'll also other things along
the left side here like Snapshots.

83
00:04:32,800 --> 00:04:35,350
We can take quick backups of our database.

84
00:04:35,350 --> 00:04:38,630
You want a snapshot of that server,
so we can do easy restores.

85
00:04:38,630 --> 00:04:40,360
We've got Security Groups.

86
00:04:40,360 --> 00:04:45,720
We have to use software firewall settings
to control who has access to our database.

87
00:04:45,720 --> 00:04:47,710
You've got Parameter Groups.

88
00:04:47,710 --> 00:04:50,130
If you've ever configured
things like MySQL,

89
00:04:50,130 --> 00:04:54,520
MySQL has these configuration files
that are all text-based and they're big.

90
00:04:54,520 --> 00:04:57,340
And when you configure those settings
you normally want those settings to be

91
00:04:57,340 --> 00:05:00,230
the same across multiple databases or
multiple servers.

92
00:05:00,230 --> 00:05:03,830
So you can create a parameter group and
apply it to several servers or

93
00:05:03,830 --> 00:05:06,350
several databases and
they'll all be configured the same way.

94
00:05:06,350 --> 00:05:07,850
It makes things nice and consistent.

95
00:05:08,860 --> 00:05:10,000
Option groups are similar.

96
00:05:10,000 --> 00:05:12,010
It's additional options that are set.

97
00:05:12,010 --> 00:05:16,270
The parameter groups will apply to
the server itself as well as the database.

98
00:05:16,270 --> 00:05:19,360
The options groups are really just
applying to just the database.

99
00:05:19,360 --> 00:05:23,650
We have subnet groups for dividing
our database up into network subnets.

100
00:05:23,650 --> 00:05:26,290
You'll probably have some
databases that are designed for

101
00:05:26,290 --> 00:05:29,100
internal use only,
not exposed to the internet, right?

102
00:05:29,100 --> 00:05:33,840
So just for your private servers in one
VPC, you might have other databases

103
00:05:33,840 --> 00:05:38,480
that are in a VPC that has access just
to your public web servers, right?

104
00:05:38,480 --> 00:05:40,980
You don't want the public to connect
to your database servers ever, but

105
00:05:40,980 --> 00:05:44,280
they will connect to a web server and
it provides access to the database.

106
00:05:44,280 --> 00:05:47,265
So you can define those subnet groups
right here to create the separation.

107
00:05:47,265 --> 00:05:51,590
You've also got events, and that's where
you can review any current events and

108
00:05:51,590 --> 00:05:53,340
activity with your databases.

109
00:05:53,340 --> 00:05:55,410
And lastly events subscriptions, and

110
00:05:55,410 --> 00:05:59,960
that's where you can designate to transmit
the events to use so you're kept aware.

111
00:05:59,960 --> 00:06:01,890
You'll see there are different
ways to do that.

112
00:06:01,890 --> 00:06:03,190
When you create an event subscription,

113
00:06:03,190 --> 00:06:07,640
you'll see some of the different
places that we can pull data from.

114
00:06:07,640 --> 00:06:10,610
So we're pulling from database instances,
or parameter groups, or so

115
00:06:10,610 --> 00:06:15,040
on, to gather that data, and
we're sending them to people, right?

116
00:06:15,040 --> 00:06:19,650
ARMs, the resource names, which
are normally gonna be IAM identities,

117
00:06:19,650 --> 00:06:21,619
right to your users, and
you'll send them the notifications.

118
00:06:23,980 --> 00:06:26,460
All right, but let's take a look
at creating the instance itself,

119
00:06:26,460 --> 00:06:27,740
that's the big part.

120
00:06:27,740 --> 00:06:30,840
When you go to Launch DB Instance,

121
00:06:30,840 --> 00:06:33,710
it's gonna ask you what
type of database you want.

122
00:06:33,710 --> 00:06:37,270
When this service first launched
they only had MySQL, and so

123
00:06:37,270 --> 00:06:41,970
many people associate Amazon RDS with
MySQL, but it's much bigger than that.

124
00:06:41,970 --> 00:06:46,880
You can spawn PostgreSQL, Oracle,
SQL server, Microsoft SQL server,

125
00:06:46,880 --> 00:06:49,890
whichever one you want, and
you just come in here and choose it.

126
00:06:49,890 --> 00:06:54,210
Now the pricing is a little bit
different because MySQL, by and large,

127
00:06:54,210 --> 00:06:55,320
is a free product.

128
00:06:55,320 --> 00:06:57,520
It's the MySQL community edition.

129
00:06:57,520 --> 00:06:59,240
But when you go to oracle and

130
00:06:59,240 --> 00:07:03,960
SQL server, those are licensed products
that can actually be pretty expensive.
